Section Title: TABLE OF CONTENTS
Subsection Title: NOTICE TO CERTAIN INVESTORS United States
Subsubsection Text: None of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, any state securities commission or any other regulatory authority has reviewed or approved or disapproved of the Notes or the Note Guarantees, and none of the foregoing authorities have passed upon or endorsed the merits of the Offering or the accuracy or adequacy of this offering memorandum. Any representation to the contrary is a criminal offense under the laws of the United States and could be a criminal offense in certain other jurisdictions. Each purchaser of the Notes will be deemed to have made the representations, warranties and acknowledgements that are described in this offering memorandum under “Transfer Restrictions.” The Notes have not been and will not be registered under the Securities Act or the securities laws of any state of the United States and are subject to certain restrictions on transfer. Prospective purchasers are hereby notified that the seller of any note may be relying on the exemption from the provisions of Section 5 of the Securities Act provided by Rule 144A. For a description of certain further restrictions on resale or transfer of the Notes, see “Transfer Restrictions.”

Section Title: TABLE OF CONTENTS
Subsubsection Text: This offering memorandum constitutes an “exempt offering document” as defined in and for the purposes of applicable Canadian securities laws. No prospectus has been filed with any securities commission or similar regulatory authority in Canada in connection with the offer and sale of the Notes. No securities commission or similar regulatory authority in Canada has reviewed or in any way passed upon this document or on the merits of the Notes and any representation to the contrary is an offence. The Notes may be sold only to Canadian purchasers purchasing, or deemed to be purchasing, as principal that are “accredited investors”, as such term is defined in Section 1.1 of National Instrument 45-106 Prospectus Exemptions or, in Ontario, as such term is defined in Section 73.3(1) of the Securities Act (Ontario), and are “permitted clients”, as such term is defined in section 1.1 of National Instrument 31-103 Registration Requirements, Exemptions and Ongoing Registrant Obligations. Each Canadian purchaser who purchases the Notes will be deemed to have represented to the Issuers, the Initial Purchasers and to each dealer from whom a purchase confirmation is received, as applicable, that the purchaser (i) is purchasing as principal, or is deemed to be purchasing as principal in accordance with applicable Canadian securities laws, for investment only and not with a view to resale or redistribution; (ii) is an “accredited investor”; and (iii) is a “permitted client”. Any resale of Notes acquired by a Canadian purchaser in the Offering must be made in accordance with applicable Canadian securities laws, which may vary depending on the relevant jurisdiction, and which may require resales to be made in accordance with Canadian prospectus requirements, a statutory exemption from the prospectus requirements, in a transaction exempt from the prospectus requirements or otherwise under a discretionary exemption from the prospectus requirements granted by the applicable local Canadian securities regulatory authority. These resale restrictions may under certain circumstances apply to resales of the Notes outside of Canada. Securities legislation in certain provinces or territories of Canada may provide a purchaser with remedies for rescission or damages if this offering memorandum (including any amendment thereto) contains a misrepresentation, provided that the remedies for rescission or damages are exercised by the purchaser within the time limit prescribed by the securities legislation of the purchaser’s province or territory. The purchaser should refer to any applicable provisions of the securities legislation of the purchaser’s province or territory for particulars of these rights, or consult with a legal advisor. Canadian purchasers are advised that this document has been prepared in reliance on Section 3A.3 of National Instrument 33-105 Underwriting Conflicts (“NI 33-105”). Pursuant to section 3A.3 of NI 33-105, this document is exempt from the requirement that the Issuer and the Initial Purchasers in the Offering provide Canadian purchasers with certain conflicts of interest disclosure pertaining to “connected issuer” and/or “related issuer” relationships as would otherwise be required pursuant to subsection 2.1(1) of NI 33-105. Upon receipt of this offering memorandum, each Canadian purchaser hereby confirms that it has expressly requested that all documents evidencing or relating in any way to the sale of the Notes described herein (including for greater certainty any purchase confirmation or any notice) be drawn up in the English language only. Par la réception de ce document, chaque investisseur Canadien confirme par les présentes qu’il a _expressément exigé que tous les documents faisant foi ou se rapportant de quelque manière que ce soit à la vente des valeurs mobilières décrites aux présentes (incluant, pour plus de certitude, toute confirmation d’achat ou tout avis) soient rédigés en anglais seulement._ v -----

Section Title: TABLE OF CONTENTS
Subsection Title: European Economic Area and the UK
Subsubsection Title: Prohibition of Sales to EEA or UK Retail Investors
Subsubsection Text: The Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should not be offered, sold or otherwise made available to any retail investor in the EEA or the United Kingdom. For these purposes, a retail investor means a person who is one (or more) of: (i) a retail client as defined in point (11) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II; or (ii) a customer within the meaning of Directive (EU) 2016/97 (as amended or superseded, the “Insurance Distribution Directive”), where that customer would not qualify as a professional client as defined in point (10) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II. Consequently no key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 (as amended, the “PRIIPs Regulation”) for offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to retail investors in the EEA or the United Kingdom has been prepared and therefore offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to any retail investor in the EEA or the United Kingdom may be unlawful under the PRIIPs Regulation. This offering memorandum has been prepared on the basis that any offer of Notes in any Member State of the EEA or the United Kingdom that is subject to Regulation (EU) 2017/1129 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 14 June 2017 (as amended, the “Prospectus Regulation”) will be made pursuant to an exemption under the Prospectus Regulation from the requirement to publish a prospectus for offers of the Notes. Notwithstanding the United Kingdom’s departure from the European Union, any references in this offering memorandum to European Union law should be treated as references to such law as applies in England and Wales from time to time including as retained, amended, extended, re-enacted or otherwise given effect on or after 11:00 pm on January 31, 2020.

Section Title: TABLE OF CONTENTS
Subsection Title: European Economic Area and the UK
Subsubsection Text: Solely for the purposes of the manufacturer’s product approval process, the target market assessment in respect of the Notes has led to the conclusion that: (i) the target market for the Notes is eligible counterparties and professional clients only, each as defined in MiFID II; and (ii) all channels for distribution of the Notes to eligible counterparties and professional clients are appropriate. Any person subsequently offering, selling or recommending the Notes (a “distributor”) should take into consideration the manufacturers’ target market assessment; however, a distributor subject to MiFID II is responsible for undertaking its own target market assessment in respect of the Notes (by either adopting or refining the manufacturers’ target market assessment) and determining appropriate distribution channels.

Section Title: TABLE OF CONTENTS
Subsubsection Text: The Offering is not a public offering in the Federal Republic of Germany. The Notes may not be offered and sold in the Federal Republic of Germany except in accordance with the provisions of the Securities Prospectus Act of the Federal Republic of Germany (Wertpapierprospektgesetz) (as amended, the “German Securities Prospectus Act”), the Prospectus Regulation and any other laws applicable in Germany. This offering memorandum has not been and will not be submitted to, nor has it been nor will it be approved by, the German Federal Financial Supervisory Authority (Bundesanstalt für Finanzdienstleistungsaufsicht) (“BaFin”). BaFin has not obtained and will not obtain a notification from another competent authority of a member state of the European Union (each a Member State), with which a securities prospectus may have been filed, pursuant to Article 25 of the Prospectus Regulation. The Notes must not be distributed within Germany by way of a public offer, public advertisement or in any similar manner, and this offering memorandum and any other document relating to the Notes, as well as information contained therein, may not be supplied to the public in Germany or used in connection with any offer for subscription of Notes to the public in Germany. Consequently, in Germany the Notes will only be available to, and this offering memorandum and any other offering material in relation to the Notes is directed only at, persons who are qualified investors (qualifizierte Anleger) within the meaning of Section 2 No. 3 of the German Securities Prospectus Act in connection with Article 2 lit. e of the Prospectus Regulation. Any resale of the Notes in Germany may only be made in accordance with the German Securities Prospectus Act, the Prospectus Regulation and other applicable laws.

Section Title: TABLE OF CONTENTS
Subsubsection Text: This offering memorandum is for distribution only to persons who (i) have professional experience in matters relating to investments falling within Article 19(5) of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (Financial Promotion) Order 2005 (as amended, the “Financial Promotion Order”), (ii) are persons falling within Article 49(2)(a) to (d) (“high net worth companies, unincorporated associations etc.”) of the Financial Promotion vi ----- Order, (iii) are outside the United Kingdom or (iv) are persons to whom an invitation or inducement to engage in investment activity (within the meaning of section 21 of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000) in connection with the issue or sale of any Notes may otherwise lawfully be communicated or caused to be communicated (all such persons together being referred to as “Relevant Persons”). This offering memorandum is directed only at Relevant Persons and must not be acted on or relied on by persons who are not Relevant Persons. Any investment or investment activity to which this offering memorandum relates is permitted only by Relevant Persons and will be engaged in only with Relevant Persons. vii -----

None of the Issuers, the Guarantors or any of Goldman Sachs International, Barclays Bank PLC, Credit Suisse Securities (Europe) Limited, Credit Suisse Securities (USA) LLC, UBS AG, London Branch, UBS Securities LLC, Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch, RBC Europe Limited and RBC Capital Markets LLC (the “Initial Purchasers”) has authorized anyone to provide you with information that is different from the information contained herein. You should not assume that the information contained in this offering memorandum is accurate as of any date other than the date on the front cover of this offering memorandum. The Target’s business or financial condition, along with the other information contained in this offering memorandum, may change after this date. i ----- **IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THIS OFFERING MEMORANDUM THE NOTES HAVE NOT BEEN REGISTERED UNDER THE SECURITIES ACT AND MAY NOT BE OFFERED OR SOLD IN THE UNITED STATES OR TO U.S. PERSONS UNLESS THE NOTES ARE REGISTERED UNDER THE SECURITIES ACT, OR AN EXEMPTION FROM THE REGISTRATION REQUIREMENTS OF THE SECURITIES ACT IS AVAILABLE. None of the Issuers, the Guarantors, the Sponsors (as defined herein), or any of the Initial Purchasers have authorized anyone to provide prospective investors with different information, and you should not rely on any such information. You should assume that the information contained in this offering memorandum is accurate only as of the date on the front of this offering memorandum or otherwise as of the date specifically referred to in connection with the particular information. This offering memorandum does not constitute an offer to sell or an invitation to subscribe for or purchase any of the Notes in any jurisdiction in which such offer or invitation is not authorized or to any person to whom it is unlawful to make such an offer or invitation. No action has been, or will be, taken to permit a public offering in any jurisdiction where action would be required for that purpose. Accordingly, the Notes may not be offered or sold, directly or indirectly, and this offering memorandum may not be distributed, in any jurisdiction except in accordance with the legal requirements applicable in such jurisdiction. You must comply with all laws that apply to you in any place in which you buy, offer or sell any Notes or possess this offering memorandum. You must also obtain any consents or approvals that you need in order to purchase any Notes. Neither the Issuers, the Guarantors, the Group (as defined herein), the Sponsors nor any of the Initial Purchasers are responsible for your compliance with these legal requirements. The Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale, which are described under the caption “Transfer Restrictions.” By possessing this offering memorandum or purchasing any Notes, you will be deemed to have represented and agreed to all of the provisions contained in that section of this offering memorandum. You should be aware that you may be required to bear the financial risks of this investment for an indefinite period of time. None of the Issuers, the Guarantors or the Initial Purchasers are making an offer to sell the Notes in any jurisdiction where the offer and sale of the Notes is prohibited. Neither the Issuers nor any Guarantor makes any representation to you that the Notes are a legal investment for you. No action has been, or will be, taken to permit a public offering in any jurisdiction where action would be required for that purpose. None of the Issuers, the Guarantors, the Group, the Sponsors or the Initial Purchasers or any of their respective representatives are providing you with any legal, business, tax or other advice in this offering memorandum. You should consult with your own advisors as needed to assist you in making your investment decision and to advise you whether you are legally permitted to purchase the Notes. You should base your decision to invest in the Notes solely on information contained in this offering memorandum. This offering memorandum contains summaries believed to be accurate with respect to certain documents, but reference is made to the actual documents for complete information. All such summaries are qualified in their entirety by such reference. Copies of certain of the documents referred to herein will be made available to prospective investors upon request to us or set forth under the caption “Where You Can Find Other _Information.”_ By purchasing the Notes, you will be deemed to have acknowledged that you have reviewed this offering memorandum and have had an opportunity to request, and have received all additional information that you need from us. No person is authorized in connection with any offering made pursuant to this offering memorandum to give any information or to make any representation not contained in this offering memorandum or any pricing term sheet or supplement and, if given or made, any other information or representation must not be relied upon as having been authorized by the Issuers, the Group, the Sponsors or the Initial Purchasers. Neither the Trustee, the Security Agent, any Paying Agent, any Registrar, any Transfer Agent nor any other agent acting with respect to the Notes is responsible for the contents of this offering memorandum or expresses any opinion as to the merits of the Notes under this offering memorandum. ii ----- The information contained in this offering memorandum is accurate as of the date hereof. The Issuers’ and the Guarantors’ business, financial condition or other information contained in this offering memorandum may change after the date hereof. Neither the delivery of this offering memorandum at any time after the date of publication nor any subsequent commitment to purchase the Notes shall, under any circumstances, create an implication that there has been no change in the information set out in this offering memorandum or in our business since the date of this offering memorandum. None of the Initial Purchasers, the Trustee, the Security Agent, the Paying Agents, the Registrars, the Transfer Agents, the Group, the Sponsors or any other agent acting with respect to the Notes accept responsibility for and make no representation or warranty, express or implied, as to the accuracy or completeness of the information set out in this offering memorandum and nothing contained in this offering memorandum is, or should be relied upon as, a promise or representation by the Initial Purchasers, the Trustee, the Security Agent, or any other agent acting with respect to the Notes as to the past or the future. By receiving this offering memorandum, you acknowledge that you have not relied on the Initial Purchasers, the Trustee, the Security Agent, any Paying Agent, any Registrar, any Transfer Agent, the Group, the Sponsors or their respective directors, affiliates, advisers and agents in connection with your investigation of the accuracy of this information or your decision whether to invest in the Notes. The Initial Purchasers disclaim all and any liability whether arising in tort, contract or otherwise which they may otherwise have in relation to this offering memorandum or any information contained herein. The Initial Purchasers do not undertake to review the financial condition or affairs of the Issuers or any Guarantor during the life of the Notes or to advise any investor or potential investor in the Notes of any information coming to the attention of any Initial Purchaser. Nothing contained in this Offering Memorandum is, or shall be relied upon as, a promise or representation by any of the Initial Purchasers as to the past or future. We reserve the right to withdraw the Offering at any time. We and the Initial Purchasers each reserve the right to reject any offer to purchase the Notes in whole or in part and to allot to any prospective purchaser less than the amount of the Notes sought by it. The Initial Purchasers and certain of their respective related entities may acquire, for their own accounts, a portion of the Notes. This offering memorandum is a confidential document that we are providing only to prospective purchasers of the Notes and has only been prepared in connection with the Offering. You must not make copies of any part of this offering memorandum or give a copy of it to any other person, or disclose any information in this offering memorandum to any other person. By accepting delivery of this offering memorandum, you agree to the foregoing and agree not to use any information herein for any purpose other than considering an investment in the Notes. This offering memorandum may be used only for the purpose for which it was published. The Notes will be available in book-entry form only. The Issuers expect that the Notes offered and sold in the United States to qualified institutional buyers in reliance upon Rule 144A will initially be represented by beneficial interests in one or more permanent global notes in registered form without interest coupons attached (the “Rule 144A Global Notes”). The Issuers expect that the Notes offered and sold outside the United States to non-U.S. persons pursuant to Regulation S will initially be represented by beneficial interests in one or more temporary global notes in registered form without interest coupons attached (the “Temporary Regulation S Global Notes”). Interests in the Temporary Regulation S Global Notes will be exchangeable for interests in one or more corresponding permanent Regulation S global notes in registered form without interest coupons attached and with denominations equal to the aggregate principal amount of the corresponding Temporary Regulation S Global Notes (the “Permanent Regulation S Global Notes” and, together with the Temporary Regulation S Global Notes, the “Regulation S Global Notes”) not earlier than the later of (i) the “distribution compliance period” as defined in Regulation S (which shall be the period through and including the 40th day after the closing of the Offering) and (ii) the first day on which certification on non-U.S. ownership is provided to the Trustee as described under “Book-Entry, Delivery and Form—Transfers.” The information set out in relation to sections of this Offering Memorandum describing clearing and settlement arrangements, including the section entitled “Book Entry, Delivery and Form,” is subject to any change in or reinterpretation of the rules, regulations and procedures of DTC, Euroclear or Clearstream currently in effect. We will not, nor will any of our agents, have responsibility for the performance of the respective obligations of DTC, Euroclear and Clearstream or their respective participants under the rules and procedures governing their operations, nor will we or our agents have any responsibility or liability for any aspect of the records relating to, or payments made on account of, book entry interests held through the facilities of any clearing system or for maintaining, supervising or reviewing any records relating to these book entry interests. Investors wishing to use iii ----- these clearing systems are advised to confirm the continued applicability of their rules, regulations and procedures. There is currently no market for the Notes. Application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange. There can be no assurance that the Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that permission to deal in the Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained, and settlement of the Notes is not conditioned on obtaining this listing. Any investor or potential investor in the EEA should not base any investment decision relating to the Notes on the information contained in this Offering Memorandum after publication of the listing particulars and should refer instead to those listing particulars. **STABILIZATION IN CONNECTION WITH THE OFFERING, CREDIT SUISSE SECURITIES (EUROPE) (THE “SSN EUR FIXED NOTES STABILIZING MANAGER”), CREDIT SUISSE SECURITIES (EUROPE) (THE “SSN EUR FRN NOTES STABILIZING MANAGER”), GOLDMAN SACHS INTERNATIONAL (THE “SSN USD NOTES STABILIZING MANAGER”), GOLDMAN SACHS INTERNATIONAL (THE “SUN USD NOTES STABILIZING MANAGER”) AND BARCLAYS BANK PLC (THE “SUN EUR NOTES STABILIZING MANAGER” AND, TOGETHER WITH THE SSN EUR FIXED NOTES STABILIZING MANAGER, THE SSN EUR FRN NOTES STABILIZING MANAGER, THE SSN USD NOTES STABILIZING** **MANAGER** **AND** **THE** **SUN** **USD** **NOTES** **STABILIZING** **MANAGER,** **THE “STABILIZING MANAGERS”) (OR PERSONS ACTING ON THEIR RESPECTIVE BEHALF) MAY OVER-ALLOT OR EFFECT TRANSACTIONS WITH A VIEW TO SUPPORTING THE MARKET PRICE OF THE NOTES AT A LEVEL OTHER THAN THAT WHICH MIGHT OTHERWISE PREVAIL. HOWEVER, THERE IS NO ASSURANCE THAT THE STABILIZING MANAGERS (OR PERSONS ACTING ON THEIR RESPECTIVE BEHALF) WILL UNDERTAKE ANY STABILIZING ACTION. ANY STABILIZING ACTION MAY BEGIN ON OR AFTER THE DATE ON WHICH ADEQUATE PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF THE FINAL TERMS OF THIS OFFERING IS MADE. SUCH STABILIZING ACTION, IF COMMENCED, MAY BE DISCONTINUED AT ANY TIME, BUT MUST BE BROUGHT TO AN END NO LATER THAN THE EARLIER OF 30 CALENDAR DAYS AFTER THE ISSUE DATE AND 60 CALENDAR DAYS AFTER THE DATE OF THE ALLOTMENT OF THE NOTES. ANY STABILIZATION OR OVER-ALLOTMENT MUST BE CONDUCTED BY ANY STABILIZING MANAGER (OR PERSONS ACTING ON ANY STABILIZING MANAGER’S BEHALF) IN ACCORDANCE WITH ALL APPLICABLE LAWS AND RULES. FOR A DESCRIPTION OF THESE ACTIVITIES, SEE “PLAN OF DISTRIBUTION.”** iv -----

Section Title: FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: This offering memorandum contains forward-looking statements, including statements about market consolidation and our strategy, investment program, future operations, prospects, growth, goals, targets, industry forecasts, expected acquisitions, transactions and investments, and target levels of liquidity, leverage and indebtedness. Forward-looking statements provide our current expectations, intentions or forecasts of future events. Forward-looking statements include statements about expectations, beliefs, plans, objectives, intentions, assumptions and other statements that are not statements of historical fact. Words or phrases such as “aim,” “anticipate,” “assume,” “believe,” “continue,” “could,” “estimate,” “expect,” “forecast,” “guidance,” “intend,” “may,” “ongoing,” “plan,” “potential,” “predict,” “project,” “seek,” “should,” “target,” “will,” “would” or similar words or phrases, or the negatives of those words or phrases, may identify forward-looking statements, but the absence of these words does not necessarily mean that a statement is not forward-looking. Forward-looking statements are subject to known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other factors and are based on potentially inaccurate assumptions that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expected or implied by the forward-looking statements. Our actual results could differ materially from those expected in our forward-looking statements for many reasons, including the factors described in “Risk Factors.” In addition, even if our actual results are consistent with the forward-looking statements contained in this offering memorandum, those results or developments may not be indicative of results or developments in subsequent periods. For example, factors that could cause our actual results to vary from projected future results include, but are not limited to: - operating within a highly competitive industry, including the resulting pricing pressure on our business; - our ability to respond to evolving market trends with innovative products and services on competitive terms; - the outbreak of COVID-19 and its global economic impact; - our ability to adjust our personnel and production capacity in line with demand for our products and services; - the incurrence of significant costs, including from warranty and product liability claims, due to products that do not meet customer specifications or that contain defects or errors; - our ability to comply with a range of different legal and regulatory requirements worldwide, and the significant costs and liabilities which could result from non-compliance; - global and regional economic conditions; - the imposition of protectionist measures, including tariffs and other barriers to trade; - our dependence on third-party suppliers, contractors and distributors; - our ability to achieve the targeted benefits from restructuring and operational improvement measures; - project management and execution risks in connection with our New Installation business; - the price and availability of high-quality raw materials, parts and components; - unforeseen business interruptions at production facilities or other operational problems; - risks relating to public sector contracts and non-compliance with regulations on public procurement; - our failure to successfully identify, enter into or integrate acquisitions and/or successfully execute disposals; - our exposure to foreign exchange translation and transaction risks; - risks related to our international operations; - legal disputes and government proceedings in which we are currently, or in the future may be, involved; - antitrust regulation and related enforcement actions and damage claims; - the imposition of tax adjustments for greater taxation of profits by tax authorities; - transfer price risks in connection with our operating activities; - our dependence on good relationships with our employees and their trade unions as well as employee representative bodies and stakeholders; - our ability to attract, hire, train and retain experienced management and personnel; viii ----- - impairment of the value of goodwill, brand names or other intangible assets; - our substantial pension and other similar employee benefits-related obligations, including the development of these obligations and related funding requirements; - the sufficiency of our insurance coverage and increases to our insurance premiums; - our reliance on complex information technology systems and networks that are subject to the risk of disruption and security breaches; - our ability to comply with various laws and regulations relating to the protection of the environment, health and safety worldwide, and the significant costs and liabilities which could result from non-compliance; - our ability to comply with sanctions, anti-corruption and money-laundering laws and regulations; - the adequacy of our internal controls, procedures, compliance systems and risk management systems to prevent and discover previous or future breaches of laws and regulations and generally to manage risks; - our ability to adequately protect our intellectual property and know-how or any infringement of third-party intellectual property; - regulatory and legal risks relating to data protection; - the complexity of applicable tax laws, and changes in tax laws or challenges to our tax position; - tax risks that could arise in particular as a result of tax audits or past measures; - risks related to the Transactions, our capital structure and the Notes; and - other factors discussed under “Risk Factors.” These risks are not exhaustive. Other sections of this offering memorandum describe additional factors that could adversely affect our financial position, results of operations and liquidity and developments in the markets and industries in which we operate. New risks can emerge from time to time, and it is not possible for us to predict all such risks, nor can we assess the impact of all such risks on our business or the extent to which any risks, or combination of risks and other factors, may cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in any forward-looking statements. Given these risks and uncertainties, you should not rely on forward-looking statements as a prediction of actual results. We urge you to read this entire offering memorandum, including the sections entitled, “Risk Factors”, “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations”, “Industry” and “Business” for a more complete discussion of the factors that could affect our future performance and the industry in which we operate. Any forward-looking statements are only made as at the date of this offering memorandum, and we do not intend, and do not assume any obligation, to update forward-looking statements set out in this offering memorandum. You should interpret all subsequent written or oral forward-looking statements attributable to us or to persons acting on our behalf as being qualified by the cautionary statements in this offering memorandum. As a result, you should not place undue reliance on these forward-looking statements.

Section Title: INDUSTRY AND MARKET DATA
Subsubsection Text: We operate in the elevator and escalator and access solutions industries. In certain cases, it is difficult in this sector to obtain precise market, economic and industry information. Certain information used in this offering memorandum has been obtained from FactSet’s financial data and analytics; IHS Markit’s “Global Construction Outlook: Executive Overview” dated March 2020; The Freedonia Group’s “Global Elevator Equipment and Services by Product, Market and Region” dated July 2017; Oxford Economics’s “Country Economic Forecasts” dated September 2019; The Economist Intelligence Unit’s “Country Data” dated May 2019 ([©] reproduced with permission of the Economist Intelligence Unit), and third party and the Target’s analysis and estimates (together, the “Market Position Analysis”) and services commissioned from the Boston Consulting Group (“Market Size/ Growth Analysis”). Some of the information herein has also been extrapolated from market data, reports, surveys and studies using our experience and internal estimates. Elsewhere in this offering memorandum, statements regarding the industry in which we operate, our position in this industry and the size of certain markets are based solely on our experience, internal studies, estimates and surveys, and our own investigation of market conditions. ix ----- None of the Issuers, the Guarantors or the Initial Purchasers accepts responsibility for the factual correctness of any such statistics or information obtained from third parties. While the Issuers believe this information to be reliable, it has not been independently verified, and we do not make any representation or warranty as to the accuracy or completeness of such information set forth in this offering memorandum. Any forward-looking statements contained in such industry and market data were made prior to the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic and have not been updated to account for the impact of such outbreak. There can be no assurance that such forward-looking statements would not have been materially different if the COVID-19 pandemic had been taken into account. See ‘‘Forward-looking Statements’’. Market data and statistics are inherently predictive and subject to uncertainty and not necessarily reflective of actual market conditions. Such statistics are based on market research, which itself is based on sampling and subjective judgments by both the researchers and the respondents, including judgments about what types of products and transactions should be included in the relevant market. Additionally, industry publications and reports from management consultants generally state that the information contained therein has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but that the accuracy and completeness of such information is not guaranteed and in some instances state that they do not assume liability for such information. We cannot therefore assure you of the accuracy and completeness of such information as we have not independently verified such information.

Section Title: TRADEMARKS AND TRADE NAMES
Subsubsection Text: The Group owns or has rights to certain trademarks, trade names or service marks that it uses in connection with the operation of its business. The Group asserts, to the fullest extent under applicable law, its rights to its trademarks, trade names and service marks. Each trademark, trade name or service mark of any other company appearing in this offering memorandum belongs to its holder. Solely for convenience, the trademarks, trade names and copyrights referred to in this offering memorandum are listed without the TM, [®] and [©] symbols. x -----

Section Title: CERTAIN DEFINITIONS
Subsection Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL INFORMATION The Issuers
Subsubsection Text: The SUN Issuer and the EUR SSN Issuer were each incorporated on February 11, 2020, and the USD SSN Issuer was incorporated on April 14, 2020, in each case to facilitate the Transactions. As of the date of this offering memorandum, the Issuers have no material assets or liabilities, do not have any revenue-generating activities of their own and have not engaged in activities other than those related to their incorporation and in preparation of the Transactions. As a result, no historical financial information of the Issuers is included in this offering memorandum.

Section Title: CERTAIN DEFINITIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Elevator Technology Business did not exist as a separate group prior to December 31, 2019. It formed part of a larger group of companies controlled by thyssenkrupp AG and was reported as a segment within the consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG. In order to facilitate the Acquisition, all companies and operating activities that are part of the Elevator Technology Business were transferred, directly or indirectly, to the Target in a corporate reorganization that was completed on December 31, 2019 (the “Reorganization”). All historical financial information presented in this offering memorandum is that of the Elevator Technology Business. When referring to the “Elevator Technology Business,” “we,” “us,” “our” or the “Group” in respect of such financial information, we mean (i) prior to the completion of the Reorganization on December 31, 2019, the “Elevator Technology Business” as defined in our Audited Combined Financial Statements (as defined below) and (ii) after the Reorganization, the “thyssenkrupp Elevator Technology Group” as defined in our Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements (as defined below) or the business carried out by the “thyssenkrupp Elevator Technology Group,” as the context requires. The financial information as of and for the six months ended March 31, 2019 and 2020 gives effect to the Reorganization as if it had occurred at the beginning of the periods presented. There are important differences between the Elevator Technology Business as presented in the Audited Combined Financials as of and for the financial years ended September 30, 2017, 2018 and 2019 and the business carried out by the Target and its subsidiaries as presented in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements as of and for the six months ended March 31, 2019 and 2020. See “—Basis of Preparation” and our Financial Statements included elsewhere herein.

Section Title: CERTAIN DEFINITIONS
Subsubsection Text: As the Elevator Technology Business did not exist as a separate group and since all companies and operating activities within the Elevator Technology Business were under the common control of thyssenkrupp AG, in each case, prior to the Reorganization, the financial information presented as of and for the financial years ended September 30, 2017, 2018 and 2019 has been prepared on a combined basis. Effective with the Reorganization, the Elevator Technology Business came into existence as a separate group and therefore, the financial information presented for the Target and its consolidated subsidiaries as of and for the six months ended March 31, 2019 and 2020 was prepared on a consolidated basis. As a result, this offering memorandum presents the following financial information of the Group (the “Financial Statements”): - The unaudited interim consolidated financial statements of the Target and its consolidated subsidiaries as of and for the six months ended March 31, 2020, including comparative information for the six months ended March 31, 2019 (the “Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements”), which were prepared in accordance with International Accounting Standard 34, Interim Financial Reporting; and - The audited combined financial statements of the Elevator Technology Business as of and for the financial years ended September 30, 2017, 2018 and 2019 (the “Audited Combined Financial Statements”), which were prepared in accordance with the International Financial Reporting Standards, as adopted by the EU (“IFRS”), have been audited in accordance with International Standards on Auditing (“ISA”) by PricewaterhouseCoopers GmbH Wirtschaftsprüfungsgesellschaft, Friedrich-List-Straße 20, 45128 Essen, Federal Republic of Germany (“PwC”), independent auditors, who issued an independent auditor’s report thereon. The independent auditor’s report on the Audited Combined Financial Statements is qualified due to issues regarding local book keeping and financial reporting processes, which led to qualified, adverse or disclaimer of opinions on the financial information of certain entities of the Elevator Technology Business’s Operating Unit Spanish Latin America (as defined in the Financial Statements). Due to these issues, PwC was unable to obtain sufficient information and evidence required to assess the existence, completeness, valuation and cut-off of the xvii ----- assets and liabilities as well as the income and expense of these subsidiaries and, as a result, was unable to determine whether any adjustments might have been necessary in respect of the combined financial position as of September 30, 2018 and 2017 and the combined statements of profit and loss, comprehensive income and changes in equity or net cash flows as reported in the combined statement of cash flows for the financial years ended September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017 (see Note 1 of the Audited Combined Financial Statements). The auditor’s qualification does not pertain to the combined statement of financial position as of September 30, 2019 included in the Audited Combined Financial Statements. The independent auditor’s report also contains an emphasis of matter paragraph that the Elevator Technology Business has not operated as a separate stand-alone group of entities and that the Audited Combined Financial Statements are, therefore, not necessarily indicative of the results that would have occurred if the Elevator Technology Business had operated as a separate standalone group of entities during the years presented or for any future period. In the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements, the issues relating to the Elevator Technology Business’s Operating Unit Spanish Latin America described above still remained for the six-month period ended March 31, 2019 (see Note 1 of the other explanatory notes of the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements). For the purposes of this offering memorandum, we refer to the financial year ended September 30, 2017 as the “2016/2017 Financial Year,” the financial year ended September 30, 2018, as the “2017/2018 Financial Year” and the financial year ended September 30, 2019, as the “2018/2019 Financial Year.” After the completion of the Transaction, we expect to report our financial results and condition at the level of thyssenkrupp Elevator until September 30, 2021, and Vertical Topco III thereafter. The Financial Statements in this offering memorandum have not been adjusted to reflect the impact of any changes that might occur as a result of purchase price allocation effects to be applied as a result of the Transactions. However, Vertical Topco III will account for the Acquisition using the acquisition method in accordance with IFRS 3 “Business _Combinations” and will apply purchase price allocation effects in connection with the Transactions to their_ financial statements for accounting periods subsequent to the Acquisition Closing Date. The application of purchase accounting could result in different carrying values for existing assets and assets we may add to our balance sheet, which may include intangible assets, such as goodwill, leasehold rights and software, and different amortization and depreciation expenses. Due to these and other potential adjustments, our future financial statements could be materially different once the adjustments are made and may not be comparable to the Financial Statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. Financial data in this offering memorandum as of and for the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years, and for the six months ended March 31, 2019 and 2020, (i) if presented as “audited,” is taken from the Audited Combined Financial Statements and (ii) if presented as “unaudited,” is taken or derived from the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements, thyssenkrupp Elevator’s accounting records or its internal management reporting systems or derived from the Audited Combined Financial Statements. In making an investment decision, investors must rely upon their own examination of our business, the terms of the Offering and the financial information presented in this offering memorandum.

Section Title: CERTAIN DEFINITIONS
Subsubsection Text: As IFRS does not provide guidelines for the preparation of combined financial statements, the preparation of the Audited Combined Financial Statements was subject to IAS 8 “Accounting Policies, Changes in Accounting _Estimates and Errors,” particularly IAS 8.12, which required management of thyssenkrupp Elevator AG to_ consider recent pronouncements of other standard-setting bodies, other financial reporting requirements and xviii ----- recognized industry practices in connection with the preparation of the Audited Combined Financial Statements. Accordingly, in preparing the Audited Combined Financial Statements, thyssenkrupp Elevator applied the predecessor accounting approach in accordance with recognized industry practices and rules on business combinations under common control. In general, thyssenkrupp Elevator used the same accounting policies and measurement principles in preparing the Audited Combined Financial Statements as were used in preparing the IFRS consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG (the “extraction method”). This approach has been adjusted with respect to transactions with thyssenkrupp Group companies and to ensure compliance with IFRS. Transactions between the Elevator Technology Business and the remaining thyssenkrupp Group were recognized in accordance with IFRS and classified as related party transactions as defined in IAS 24 “Related Party _Disclosures.”_ New IFRS accounting standards were applied in the Audited Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business in fiscal years from October 1, 2016 to September 30, 2019, as follows: - IFRS 9 (Financial instruments) was adopted in the 2018/2019 Financial Year by opting to apply the standard prospectively (i.e., from the beginning of the 2018/2019 Financial Year) and accordingly, no adjusted comparative information was disclosed. - IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) was adopted in 2018/2019 Financial Year by applying the full retrospective approach to initial application. Due to the financial statements of that fiscal year for thyssenkrupp AG only presenting one comparative period, the cumulative transition effects were included directly in retained earnings at the start of the comparative period on October 1, 2017. In contrast, for the Audited Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business, due to the additional comparative period from October 1, 2016 to September 30, 2017 presented, according to the full retrospective approach, IFRS 15 has been applied from the beginning of the 2016/2017 Financial Year for the Audited Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business (i.e. the cumulative transition effects were included directly in invested equity attributable to the thyssenkrupp AG at the start of the comparative period on October 1, 2016). - IFRS 16 (Leases) was adopted in the 2019/2020 Financial Year by thyssenkrupp AG by opting to apply the simplified approach of using the modified retrospective method (i.e., the cumulative transition effects are included directly in equity on October 1, 2019 and the standard is applied from the beginning of the 2019/2020 Financial Year) and no adjusted comparative information was accordingly disclosed. Additional information on the scope and basis of preparation of the Audited Combined Financial Statements and the application of significant accounting policies is presented in Note 1 “Basis of preparation” and Note 2 “Summary of significant accounting policies” to the Audited Combined Financial Statements. As a result, the Audited Combined Financial Statements included in this offering memorandum may not reflect what the results of operations, financial position and cash flows would have been had the Group operated as a separate, stand-alone business without the shared resources of thyssenkrupp AG for the periods presented, and may not be indicative of our future results of operations, financial position and cash flows. The fact that the companies and operating activities comprising the Elevator Technology Business did not historically exist as a separate group limits the validity of the combined financial information.

Section Title: CERTAIN DEFINITIONS
Subsubsection Title: The Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: The Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements as of and for the six months ended March 31, 2020, were prepared in accordance with IAS 34 and the requirements for first-time consolidated financial statements in accordance with IFRS 1 (First-time adoption of International Financial Reporting Standards). In preparing the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements, thyssenkrupp Elevator applied the predecessor accounting approach in accordance with recognized industry practices and rules on business combinations under common control in line with IDW RS HFA 50 Module IFRS 3 M2 published by the Institute of Public Auditors in Germany (Institut der Wirtschaftsprüfer in Deutschland e.V., IDW). In general, thyssenkrupp Elevator applied the same accounting policies and measurement principles in preparing the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements as were used in preparing the IFRS consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG (i.e., the “extraction method”). This approach has been adjusted with respect to transactions with thyssenkrupp Group companies and to ensure compliance with IFRS. Transactions between thyssenkrupp Elevator and the thyssenkrupp Group were recognized in accordance with IFRS and classified as related party transactions as defined in IAS 24 “Related Party Disclosures.” xix -----

Section Title: CERTAIN DEFINITIONS
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of the Audited Combined Financial Statements in conformity with IFRS, and the preparation of the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements in conformity with IAS 34, require the use of certain critical accounting estimates. These standards also require management to exercise its judgment in the process of applying accounting policies. The areas involving a higher degree of judgment or complexity, or areas where assumptions and estimates are significant, are disclosed in the financial statements. IFRS differs in various respects from generally accepted accounting principles in the United States (“U.S. GAAP”). The Group has not prepared a reconciliation of its financial information to U.S. GAAP or a summary of significant differences in the accounting and valuation methods of IFRS and U.S. GAAP and does not intend to do so in the future. Potential investors should therefore consult their own professional advisors for an understanding of the differences between IFRS and U.S. GAAP.

Section Title: CERTAIN DEFINITIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Financial Statements are prepared and presented in accordance with IFRS. On January 13, 2016, the IASB published IFRS 16 (Leases), and the European Union adopted IFRS 16 on November 9, 2017. IFRS 16 replaced IAS 17 and the related IFRIC and SIC interpretations, and resulted in almost all leases being recognized on the balance sheet, as the distinction between operating and finance leases was eliminated. Under the new standard, the lessee recognizes an asset (the right-to-use the leased asset) and a financial liability to pay lease payments. The only exceptions are short-term and low-value leases should a company elect to apply an available practical expedient in order to reduce the transition effort. IFRS 16 became effective for fiscal years commencing on or after January 1, 2019. The Group adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) on October 1, 2019, by opting to apply the simplified approach of using the modified retrospective method, which means that the cumulative transition effects are included directly in equity on October 1, 2019, and the standard is applied from the beginning of the 2019/2020 Financial Year. Accordingly, no adjusted comparative information was disclosed. Unless otherwise indicated, operating and financial information for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, represents the mathematical calculation of adding the financial information for the six months ended March 31, 2020 (as derived from the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements) to the difference between the financial information for the year ended September 30, 2019 (as derived from the Audited Combined Financial Statements), and the six months ended March 31, 2019 (as derived from the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements), without accounting for differences in the application of accounting measures. The financial information of the Group as of and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 includes the six month period ended March 31, 2020, in which IFRS 16 was adopted for the first-time and also includes the calculated six month period from April 1, 2019 to September 30, 2019, for which leases were accounted for in accordance with IAS 17 and the related IFRIC and SIC interpretations, as described above. The first-time adoption of IFRS 16 had significant impact on certain balance sheet and income statement items, as described above and also in Note 1 in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements. For that reason, the financial information as of and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, is limited in its meaningfulness. The transition to IFRS 16 on October 1, 2019, gave rise to changes to our assets and liabilities. As a result, figures as of and for the six months ended March 31, 2020, may not be comparable to the results presented for prior periods. As of March 31, 2020, our right-of-use assets amounted to €397 million and lease liabilities amounted to €330 million. The depreciation of right-of-use assets for the six months ended March 31, 2020, amounted to €49 million and the interest expense from lease liabilities amounted to €8 million. For an analysis of the impact of the first-time application of IFRS 16 (Leases) from October 1, 2019, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Position and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting _Comparability of Our Financial Statements—Changes to Accounting Standards—IFRS 16” and the Notes to the_ Audited Combined Financial Statements.

Section Title: CERTAIN DEFINITIONS
Subsubsection Text: This offering memorandum also includes certain unaudited pro forma financial information of the SUN Issuer and the EUR SSN Issuer as of and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, including pro forma net senior secured indebtedness, pro forma net indebtedness and pro forma interest expense, which has been prepared to illustrate the effect of the Transactions as if the Transactions had occurred (i) on March 31, 2020, for the purposes of calculating pro forma net senior secured indebtedness and pro forma net indebtedness and (ii) on April 1, 2019, for the purposes of calculating pro forma interest expense. The pro forma financial information as of and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, has been prepared for illustrative purposes only and does not represent what our indebtedness or interest expense would have been had the Transactions occurred on March 31, 2020, or April 1, 2019, respectively; nor does it purport to project our financial results, indebtedness or interest expense at any future date. The pro forma financial information as of and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, has not been prepared in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting standards or in accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X of the Securities Act, the Prospectus Regulation, or any other regulations of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, or any other regulator. Neither the assumptions underlying the pro forma adjustments nor the resulting pro forma financial information as of and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, have been audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted auditing standards. The unaudited pro forma adjustments and the unaudited pro forma financial data set forth in this offering memorandum are based on available information and certain assumptions and estimates that we believe are xx ----- reasonable and may differ materially from the actual adjusted amounts. These pro forma measures are not financial measures defined in accordance with IFRS and, as such, may not be comparable to similarly titled measures used by other companies.

Section Title: CERTAIN DEFINITIONS
Subsection Title: Financial Information for the Twelve Months Ended March 31, 2020
Subsubsection Text: The financial information of the Group for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, is unaudited and has been calculated by taking the financial information for the six months ended March 31, 2020 (as derived from the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements) and adding it to the difference between the results of operations for the year ended September 30, 2019 (as derived from the Audited Combined Financial Statements) and the interim financial information for the six months ended March 31, 2019 (as derived from the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements). The financial information for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 constitutes a Non-GAAP Measure (as defined below), has not been audited or reviewed by our auditors, is not required by or presented in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles and has been prepared for illustrative purpose only. This information is not necessarily representative of our results of operations for such period or any future period or any financial position at any past or future date. There are certain key differences between the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements and the Audited Combined Financial Statements, which limit the comparability and meaningfulness of the financial information of the Group for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020. These include the following: - The six month period ended March 31, 2020, accounts for leases under IFRS 16, which was adopted for the first beginning on October 1, 2019. The calculated six month period from April 1, 2019 to September 30, 2019, on the other hand, accounts for leases in accordance with IAS 17 and the related IFRIC and SIC interpretations, as described under “—IFRS 16 (Leases)”. The first-time adoption of IFRS 16 had significant impact on certain balance sheet and income statement items, as described under “—IFRS 16 (Leases)” and also in Note 1 in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements; - The six month period ended March 31, 2020 includes (i) costs for corporate services provided to the Target by thyssenkrupp AG through a combination of direct service agreements and transitional service agreements from the period from January 1, 2020 to March 31, 2020, which were entered into with effect from January 1, 2020 as part of the carve-out of the Elevator Technology Business from the thyssenkrupp Group and (ii) central cost allocations from thyssenkrupp AG from the period from October 1, 2019 to December 31, 2019, which were allocated in accordance with carve-out accounting principles and represent a proportionate amount of corporate costs and non-operational effects that were historically recorded at the parent company level without being recharged to the Elevator Technology Business. The calculated six month period from April 1, 2019 to September 30, 2019 also includes central cost allocations from thyssenkrupp AG, which were allocated in accordance with carve-out accounting principles and represent a proportionate amount of corporate costs and non-operational effects that were historically recorded at the parent company level without being recharged to the Elevator Technology Business. For more information, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key _Factors Affecting our Results of Operations—Corporate Cost Allocations”;_ - The six month period ended March 31, 2020 accounts for the use of the “thyssenkrupp” brand as an intangible asset with indefinite useful life in accordance with IAS 38 (Intangible Assets), on the payment of a one-time fee under a license agreement dated September 25, 2019 entered into between thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and thyssenkrupp AG. In connection with the Acquisition, the License Agreement was amended in March 2020, resulting in the intangible asset for the right of use of the “thyssenkrupp” brand to be classified as held for sale in accordance with IFRS 5 in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements. See “Certain _Relationships_ _and_ _Related_ _Party_ _Transactions—Relationships_ _with_ _the _thyssenkrupp Group in the Past—License Agreement”. The calculated six month period from April 1, 2019_ to September 30, 2019, on the other hand, accounted for the use of the “thyssenkrupp” brand under an operating licensing model, as an expense recognized under “other expenses” in its profit or loss statement.

Section Title: CERTAIN DEFINITIONS
Subsubsection Text: In this offering memorandum, we present certain financial measures that are not recognized by IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles and that may not be permitted to appear on the face of the Financial Statements or footnotes thereto. The primary non-GAAP financial measures used in this offering memorandum include Adjusted EBIT, Adjusted EBIT margin, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA margin, business cash xxi ----- flow (post-restructuring), business cash flow (pre-restructuring), capital expenditures, cash conversion, EBIT, EBIT margin, EBITDA, EBITDA margin, free cash flow, Lease Adjusted EBITDA, operating net working capital, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and other figures for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 (our “Non-GAAP Measures”). Each of the EBITDA-based and net income-based measures presented in this offering memorandum is defined and calculated differently from the definition of “Consolidated Net Income” and “Consolidated EBITDA” presented in the Indentures. Our primary Non-GAAP Measures are defined as follows: - “Adjusted EBIT” is defined as EBIT as adjusted for certain special items, including restructuring expenses, impairment charges/reversals and other non-operating expenses and income; - “Adjusted EBIT margin” is defined as Adjusted EBIT divided by sales; - “Adjusted EBITDA” is defined as Adjusted EBIT as adjusted further by adding back depreciation and amortization expense; - “Adjusted EBITDA margin” is defined as Adjusted EBITDA divided by sales; - “business cash flow (post-restructuring)” is defined as business cash flow (pre-restructuring) after restructuring payments; - “business cash flow (pre-restructuring)” is defined as free cash flow before restructuring payments, major M&A transaction payments, payments for the “thyssenkrupp” brand, income taxes paid, payments made to the remaining thyssenkrupp Group under tax group arrangements and net of interest received/paid; - “capital expenditures” is defined as the sum of purchase of investments accounted for using the equity method and non-current financial assets, expenditures for acquisitions of consolidated companies net of cash acquired, capital expenditures for property, plant and equipment (inclusive of advance payments), expenditures for acquisitions of shares in the Group from thyssenkrupp Group, cash advances and loans classified as investing activities and capital expenditures for intangible assets (inclusive of advance payments); - “cash conversion” is defined as business cash flow (pre-restructuring) divided by Adjusted EBIT; - “EBIT” is defined as income/(loss) before tax, finance income, finance expense and “thyssenkrupp” brand charges but including certain finance expenses and finance income assigned to EBIT based on the economic classification; - “EBIT margin” is defined as EBIT divided by sales; - “EBITDA” is defined as EBIT before depreciation and amortization expense; - “EBITDA margin” is defined as EBITDA divided by sales; - “free cash flow” is defined as operating cash flows less cash flows from investing activities; - “Lease Adjusted EBITDA” is defined as Adjusted EBITDA as adjusted further for the estimated effect of our adoption of IFRS 16 as if it had been adopted at the beginning of each period presented. While calculating the Lease Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, in a first step we excluded the rental expenses resulting from operating leases in accordance with IAS17 for the six month period between April 1, 2019 to September 30, 2019. In a second step we doubled the values for lease expense that were recorded in connection with short-term leases, leases for low value assets and expenses for variable payments for the six month period from October 1, 2019 to March 31, 2020, which were recognized in accordance with IFRS16; - “operating net working capital” is defined as total assets less total non-current assets less current financial and non-financial assets less current income taxes less cash and cash equivalents plus advance payments to suppliers of inventories and to other current non-financial assets less trade accounts payable and contract liabilities; and - “Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA” is defined as Lease Adjusted EBITDA adjusted further for certain cost savings adjustments. These measures are presented in this offering memorandum because they are measures our management used to assess operating performance, and we believe that they and similar measures are widely used in our industry as a means of evaluating a company’s operating performance and financing structure, and because we believe they present helpful comparisons of financial performance between periods by excluding the distorting effect of certain non-recurring items. xxii ----- Our Non-GAAP Measures and ratios are not measurements of our performance or liquidity under IFRS, U.S. GAAP, German GAAP or any other generally accepted accounting principles and should not be considered as alternatives to performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS, U.S. GAAP, German GAAP or any other generally accepted accounting principles. Our Non-GAAP Measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies and have limitations as analytical tools and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our operating results as reported under IFRS. Some of the limitations of Non-GAAP Measures are that: - they do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital investments or contractual commitments; - they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs; - they do not reflect the significant interest expense or cash requirements necessary to service interest or principal payments on our debt; - they do not reflect any cash income taxes that we may be required to pay; - they are not adjusted for all non-cash income or expense items that are reflected in our consolidated income statement; - they do not reflect the impact of earnings or charges resulting from certain matters we consider not to be indicative of our ongoing operations; - assets are depreciated or amortized over differing estimated useful lives and often have to be replaced in the future, and these measures do not reflect any cash requirements for such replacements; and - other companies in our industry and analysts may calculate these measures differently than we do, limiting their usefulness as comparative measures. Because of these limitations, our Non-GAAP Measures should not be considered as measures of discretionary cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will be available to us to meet our obligations. You should compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on the Financial Statements and using these Non-GAAP Measures only to supplement evaluation of our performance.

Section Title: CERTAIN DEFINITIONS
Subsubsection Text: Certain numerical figures set out in this offering memorandum, including financial data presented in million or thousand and percentage terms, have been subject to rounding adjustments and, as a result, the totals of the data in this offering memorandum may vary slightly from the actual arithmetic totals of such information. In addition, as a result of such rounding, the totals of certain financial information presented in tabular form may differ from the information that would have appeared in such totals using the unrounded financial information. Percentages and amounts reflecting changes over time periods relating to financial and other data set forth in “Management’s _Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” are calculated using the numerical_ data in the Audited Combined Financial Statements contained in this offering memorandum, as applicable, and not using the numerical data in the narrative description thereof. In respect of financial data set forth in the main body of this offering memorandum, a dash (“—”) signifies that the relevant figure is not available, while a zero (“0”) signifies that the relevant figure is available but has been rounded to zero. By contrast, no such differentiation has been made in respect of the financial data set forth in the financial information section of this offering memorandum beginning on page F-1. In the financial information section, zero (“0”) is used to signify both unavailable figures and figures which are either exactly zero or have been rounded to zero. xxiii -----

Section Title: EXCHANGE RATE INFORMATION
EXCHANGE RATE INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: We publish our Financial Statements in euro. The following table sets forth, for the periods set forth below, the high, low, average and period end Bloomberg Composite Rate (London) expressed as U.S. dollars per €1.00. The Bloomberg Composite Rate is a “best market” calculation, in which, at any point in time, the bid rate is equal to the highest bid rate of all contributing bank indications and the ask rate is set to the lowest ask rate offered by these banks. The Bloomberg Composite Rate is a mid-value rate between the applied highest bid rate and the lowest ask rate. The below rates may differ from the actual rates used in the preparation of the Financial Statements (see, for instance, Note 2 of the Audited Combined Financial Statements) and other financial information appearing in this offering memorandum. We make no representation that the euro or U.S. dollar amounts referred to in this offering memorandum have been, could have been or could, in the future, be converted into U.S. dollars or euro, as the case may be, at any particular rate, if at all. The average rate for a year means the average of the Bloomberg Composite Rates on the last business day of each month during a year. The average rate for a month, or for any shorter period, means the average of the daily Bloomberg Composite Rates during that month, or shorter period, as the case may be. The Bloomberg Composite Rate of the euro on June 19, 2020 was $1.1193 per €1.00.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: We are one of the world’s leading providers of elevator and escalator technology, with top market positions in the Americas, Europe and Africa and a strong platform to capture growth opportunities in the Asia Pacific region. We design, manufacture, install, service and modernize state-of-the-art passenger and freight elevators, escalators, moving walkways, passenger boarding bridges and chair and platform lifts, covering the entire product life cycle from new installation to service and modernization. Building on our German engineering heritage, we are an innovation leader in the digital age, leveraging Internet of Things technologies to collect data and make recommendations for repairs in real time to better serve rapidly urbanizing societies with a focus on product safety and efficiency. Operating from approximately 1,000 locations worldwide and serving customers in more than 100 countries, our business is characterized by a global sales and service network to ensure optimum proximity to clients. High-profile infrastructure projects such as One World Trade Center in New York, the tallest building in the Americas, the Beijing International Airport T3 Terminal and the Federation Tower in Russia have all featured our elevator and escalator products, illustrating our strengths and global reach. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, our sales and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA were €8,048 million and €1,323 million, respectively. Our operations comprise three business lines: - _New Installation:_ Our New Installation business covers the design, manufacture and installation of elevators, escalators and moving walks for all major markets and industries, including for both commercial and residential projects, and includes low-rise, mid-rise and high-rise solutions offered at different customization levels. Our New Installation business contributed 45% of sales in the twelve months ended March 31, 2020. - _Service:_ Our Service business offers a broad range of maintenance services both for our own and thirdparty equipment, with a view to ensuring the continued safety, performance and efficiency of elevators, escalators and moving walkways throughout their usable lives. Depending on the scope agreed in our service contracts, our services range from basic oil and grease maintenance to bespoke full-service packages that include the sale and installation of replacement parts. As of March 31, 2020, we had approximately 1.4 million units under maintenance. Our Service business contributed 43% of sales in the twelve months ended March 31, 2020. - _Modernization:_ Our Modernization business offers comprehensive solutions ranging from partial modernization to complete replacement of existing elevator and escalator systems and other solutions, both for our own and for third-party systems. Our Modernization business contributed 12% of sales in the twelve months ended March 31, 2020. Our life-cycle business model is built on our New Installation business, which serves as the entry to our Service business. On average, we convert 70% to 80% of new elevator and escalator installations into ongoing Service contracts. This provides a source of stable and recurring sales as we also succeeded in retaining more than 90% of our Service customers in each of our last three financial years. In addition, we win Service and Modernization contracts from third parties where another manufacturer undertook the New Installation. The Service and Modernization businesses, which together accounted for 54% of sales and around 70% of gross profit in the 2018/2019 Financial Year, are a source of stable, recurring sales and high profit margins for the Group, which provides visibility on future earnings. Driven by our high conversion rate and high retention rates, we have been able to maintain longstanding customer relationships. Given our global reach and high level of diversification, our top ten customers in aggregate typically account for less than 3% of our annual revenue. 1 ----- The following graphic illustrates the elevator life-cycle: **>90%** Retention rate 3[rd] party wins 10-20 years elevator lifetime prior to significant Modernization 3[rd] party wins New Manufacturing Selling Installation InstallationInstallation & Supply Chain **70 – 80%** Conversion rate We have two core divisions and four operating segments, which are part of our reporting segments in accordance with IFRS 8: Americas, Europe/Africa, Asia/Pacific and Access Solutions (together, our “Operating Segments”) through which we conduct our customer-facing business activities. Our first core division is the new installation, service and modernization of elevators, escalators and moving walks (the “Elevator and Escalator division”). Our second core division is the new installation, service and modernization of access solutions for airports and homes (the “Access Solutions division”). The Elevator and Escalator division is divided into three Operating Segments based on geography, which enables each to tailor its products to the specific customer needs and legal and regulatory requirements in its local markets: - _Americas:_ Our Americas segment covers our Elevator and Escalator division’s activities in the Americas and is sub-divided into two further regional units, including North America, covering the United States and Canada, and Latin America, covering Brazil as the main Latin American sales area and Spanish Latin America. Our Americas segment contributed €3,306 million, or 41%, of the Operating Segments’ total sales and €489 million, or 51%, of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. - _Europe/Africa:_ Our Europe/Africa segment covers our Elevator and Escalator division’s activities in Europe and Africa and operates within a widely diverse set of geographical areas through five operational units: “DACH,” comprising Germany, Austria and Switzerland, “RET,” comprising Russia, Eastern Europe and Turkey, “FRANCE,” comprising France and Monaco, “BBNI,” comprising the Benelux countries, Britain, the Nordics and Italy and “IBA,” comprising Spain, Portugal, Angola and Morocco and, through distributors, certain African countries. Our Europe/Africa segment contributed €2,149 million, or 26%, of the Operating Segments’ total sales and €227 million, or 24%, of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. - _Asia/Pacific:_ Our Asia/Pacific segment covers our Elevator and Escalator division’s activities in the Asia/ Pacific region and is organized in six operational units: China, South Korea, India, Australia/New Zealand, Southeast Asia and the Middle East. Our Asia/Pacific segment contributed €2,307 million, or 28%, of the Operating Segments’ total sales and €178 million, or 19%, of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. Our Access Solutions division operates across all geographies and constitutes our fourth Operating Segment. It employs a number of different sales strategies and distribution channels, catering to both the business-to-business and business-to-consumer markets. The Access Solutions division accounted for 5% of the Operating Segments’ total sales and 6% of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in the 2018/2019 Financial Year.
