Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Well-established player with a leading global position
Subsubsection Text: We hold the top four market position in the global elevator and escalator market (excluding Japan) based on revenues in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. Our Elevator and Escalator division is divided into three geographical segments, the Americas, Europe/Africa and Asia/Pacific, which comprise the majority of elevator and escalator markets worldwide. Based on revenue in the 2017/2018 Financial Year, we hold the number two position in the Americas, our most profitable elevator and escalator region, the number four position in Europe/Africa, which has the largest service business by value globally, and the number five position in Asia/Pacific, the world’s largest new installations market. As of March 31, 2020, we had 1.4 million units under maintenance across the globe. The following graph shows our market position in the elevator and escalator market (excluding Japan) based on sales in the 2017/2018 Financial Year: Otis Schindler Kone thyssenkrupp Elevator Mitsubishi Hitachi Hyundai Fujitec Toshiba We believe that our status as a global leader in the elevator and escalator industry is attributable to our particularly strong and far-reaching service network, our track record of high profile infrastructure projects, and our offering of products and services across the life cycle of elevators and escalators, from new installation to service to modernization. In addition, we believe that our expertise in the manufacturing and provision of spare parts, along with our network of specialists and a strong and globally recognized German engineering heritage, have resulted in a particularly high ranking among our peers with regards to competency of our field force, which in conjunction with our innovation technology, are what we believe to be the primary purchasing criteria for customers and puts us in a position of strength relative to our peers. Our strong market position is also driven by our offering of some of the most innovative and cutting-edge elevator solutions in the world, such as our MAX technology (“MAX”), our cloud-based maintenance tool, which utilizes Internet of Things (“IoT”) technologies to collect data on installed units and make recommendations for repairs in real time, making it immensely valuable to our Service business. In addition, we are in the process of developing the innovative MULTI elevator system (“MULTI”), a rope-less elevator able to move both vertically and horizontally.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Highly resilient business model across cycles through service focused-business and balanced global footprint
Subsubsection Text: We have developed a business model that we believe is stable, balanced and resilient through economic cycles, and therefore, well-positioned for sustainable, long-term value generation, as demonstrated by our strong longterm historical growth. We have delivered resilient sales and Adjusted EBIT margins since the 2007/2008 Financial Year. Despite negative currency effects in recent financial years, our sales have increased from €7,674 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €8,048 million in the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, highlighting the stability of our business and our ability to maintain our sales and profitability over the economic cycle despite external pressures. The main driver of the resilience and stability of our overall business is the life cycle of our business model. Our New Installation business is a key driver of our growing installed base and units under maintenance and therefore 3 ----- is the entry gate to our Service and Modernization business. The Service business generates revenue streams that include fees for regular maintenance and income from repairs and spare parts. The strong profitability and the asset-light character of our Service business contribute to our high cash generation. For the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years, 70% to 80% of our New Installation units converted into Service units. In each of the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years, the Service business maintained a global retention rate of over 90%. Many of our Service business customers eventually become customers of our Modernization business, which offers us the opportunity to generate revenue from retrofitting or replacing entire systems of elevators and escalators while continuing the customer relationship. In addition, we attract many Service customers whose elevator and escalator systems were manufactured and installed by third parties, adding to our steady Service and Modernization revenue streams. The high resilience of our business is also driven by a diversified customer base with long-term contracts and high customer retention rates and a balanced global footprint, minimizing both customer and geographic concentration risks. Our top ten customers accounted for less than 3% of sales in each of the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years. Geographically, our elevator and escalator operations (including manufacturing facilities, service centers and employees) are divided across three Operating Segments: the Americas, Europe/Africa and Asia/Pacific, which accounted for 41%, 26% and 28% of our Operating Segment’s total sales, respectively, in the twelve months ended March 31, 2020. Our fourth Operating Segment, the Access Solutions division, operates globally and generated 5% of our Operating Segments’ total sales for the same period. The resilience of our business model is demonstrated by our financial performance during periods of worldwide economic distress. For example, during the global financial crisis, our total Adjusted EBIT margin and sales remained stable between the 2008/2009 Financial Year and the 2009/2010 Financial Year. Most recently, we have been able to successfully manage and limit the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business by having immediately implemented contingency measures, which we believe further proves the resilience of our business model through the economic cycles. See “Recent Developments—Coronavirus (COVID-19).”

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Highly attractive industry with structural growth drivers
Subsubsection Text: We operate in the global elevator and escalator market, which generated sales of €55.8 billion in 2019 worldwide (excluding Japan). The global elevator and escalator market grew at a CAGR of 1.7% between 2014 and 2019, and prior to taking into account the impact of COVID-19, was expected to grow at a CAGR of 3.3% between 2019 and 2024, above expected real GDP growth. Specifically, between 2019 and 2024, the new installation, service and modernization businesses were expected to grow at a CAGR of 1.7%, 3.9% and 6.9%, respectively. This growth is underpinned by structural factors and megatrends, including increasing urbanization, an aging population, a supportive regulatory environment and sustainability and digitalization trends. Increasing urbanization is one of the primary drivers for the need for more urban spaces worldwide, which increases demand for elevators and escalators, as they are an inherent component of the residential and commercial multi-story buildings that characterize urban environments. By 2050, the number of urban inhabitants is expected to increase by 55%, from approximately four billion today to nearly seven billion. In particular, the urban population is expected to increase in emerging markets, including from approximately 60% in 2018 to 80% in 2050 in China. This trend positively affects the growth of the elevator and escalator market, as urban residents increasingly demand the access and convenience provided by elevators and escalators, particularly in cities in the developed world where large-scale urban living and infrastructure projects (such as hospitals, shopping malls and train stations) are increasingly required to offer fast and efficient urban mobility solutions. Growth in the elevator and escalator market is also driven by an increasingly aging population. The ratio of people over the age of 65 years to those under the age of five years is expected to rise from approximately 1:1 in 2019 to 2:1 in 2050. This trend is likely to support demand for elevator and escalator solutions as well as home access solutions for stairs, as the growing aging population will need or prefer the mobility afforded by elevators, escalators and home access solutions. In addition, growth in the elevator and escalator market is driven by a supportive regulatory environment, which requires the owners of elevator and escalator systems to invest in basic maintenance services to ensure their systems are consistently operating safely. Currently, over 50% of elevators in North America and Europe are over 20 years old. As the installed base of elevators and escalators grows and ages, property owners are increasingly in need of modernizing their elevators and escalators to ensure they comply with applicable 4 ----- regulatory requirements and continue to operate safely. In Asia/Pacific, including China and South Korea, we believe that there is a particularly strong opportunity to grow our Service and Modernization businesses driven by the aging of the installed base in those markets and stricter safety regulations requiring regular maintenance and upgrades. We believe that long-term growth in the elevator and escalator market will also be positively impacted by a continued focus on digitalization, connectivity and sustainability, as customers increasingly value features such as improved energy efficiency and enhanced safety and maintenance monitoring. According to the Market Size/ _Growth Analysis, the market for buildings with digitally automated operations or “smart buildings” is expected to_ grow at 5% per annum through 2024. We believe that our current innovative smart mobility solutions and our strong research and development capabilities position us to benefit from this demand. For example, our TWIN elevator system (“TWIN”), which combines two independent cars in one shaft, can already reduce energy costs by up to 25% and increase usable floor space by up to 25%. In addition we estimate that our MULTI system, which we are in the process of developing and will be the world’s first rope-free elevator, will allow for space reductions of up to a further 30% to 50% compared to our TWIN system. We aim to consistently increase product efficiency and provide additional value-add to our customers across our portfolio of new and existing products and services.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: A leader in technology and innovation in the elevator and escalator market
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we are a leading innovator in the elevator and escalator market, offering disruptive innovation and transformative digital solutions. We have been able to successfully monetize IoT and digital opportunities, as demonstrated by our recently developed MAX technology and our proprietary IT system, VIEW. MAX is a cloud-based maintenance tool which utilizes IoT technologies to collect data relating to customer elevator units and make diagnostic recommendations, such as when repairs need to be undertaken or which critical parts need to be replaced. VIEW is an operational business steering tool, which, among other things, automatically dispatches qualified technicians to resolve the problems identified by MAX, often even before any visible operational issues occur. Leveraging our expertise in IoT and other digital tools enables us to improve customer satisfaction by increasing service quality and efficiency, thereby increasing our customer retention rates and decreasing cancellation rates. In addition, we believe that we have created some of the most innovative elevator concepts currently in operation in the market. We are the only supplier in the industry to have an offering similar to our TWIN elevator system, which combines two independent cars in one shaft. We are also currently in the process of developing the MULTI system, which would be the world’s first rope-free elevator, allowing for space reductions of up to a further 30% to 50% compared to our TWIN system. These systems offer customers greater space efficiency and architectural flexibility than conventional designs, making us an attractive choice for a customer base that is increasingly demanding more innovative elevator and escalator products.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Strong financial profile with significant operational improvement opportunity.
Subsubsection Text: We have a track record of long-term stable sales growth, high cash flow generation and high earnings visibility on recurring future earnings driven by a ten- to 20-year elevator life cycle with a retention rate of over 90%. Our Elevator and Escalator division has grown consistently over the years, with our Adjusted EBIT margin generally increasing since the 2011/2012 Financial Year until the 2016/2017 Financial Year. While facing some headwinds, especially from material price developments and trade tariffs implemented in recent years, we believe that, following the Transactions, there will be greater opportunity to increase our Adjusted EBIT margin. Our business benefits from high revenue visibility given the recurring and stable nature of our Service and Modernization business model. Our New Installation business represents the key enabler for growth of Service and Modernization by growing our units under maintenance and offering high visibility of future business performance due to long order-to-fulfilment times. Most of our New Installation units are converted into maintenance units, which propels our Service business. Our Service contracts on average have a gross profit margin of approximately 40%, which progressively increases over the elevator’s lifetime due to increased spare parts sales. Many of our Service business customers eventually become customers of our Modernization business, driven by an aging installed base with the need to upgrade and extend the life cycle of the elevators and escalators. The Service and Modernization businesses, which together accounted for 54% of sales and around 70% of gross profit for the 2018/2019 Financial Year, are a source of stable, recurring sales and high profit margins for the Group. Our Service contracts have an average length between one to five years. Our full life 5 ----- cycle business model, with our high conversion and retention rates across businesses and long-term customer relationships, enables high visibility on recurring future earnings. For a more complete understanding of this Offering, we encourage you to read this entire offering memorandum carefully, including “Risk Factors,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations,” “Business,” “Regulation” and the Financial Statements and the notes thereto contained elsewhere in this offering memorandum._

Section Title: NI** **SER
Subsubsection Title: Base Strategy: Continue to capitalize on our market position and structural growth
Subsubsection Text: Our Base strategy consists of leveraging the structural factors that drive growth in the market in which we operate, together with our leading position in those markets, to grow our business and increase our profitability. As one of the world’s leading elevator and escalator companies, we aim to manufacture and install a substantial portion of the new elevators and escalators expected to be installed worldwide in the coming years. As a result of our global scale and strong brand recognition in the market, we believe there is significant sales potential for our New Installation business and continued growth opportunities for increasing our units under maintenance, resulting in further revenue and profit generation in our key markets. In addition, we target continued growth in all our business segments by leveraging structural factors such as an aging population, global urbanization and stricter safety requirements driving demand for maintenance and modernization services. In particular, we believe that our Service and Modernization businesses are positioned for growth as the installed base of elevators and escalators grows and ages. In the Americas, we target growth in our New Installation business, driven by expected growth in the US construction sector and our strength in meeting customer demands for efficient execution and technical excellence, such as our expertise in the hydraulic segment. We target growth in our Service business due to customer demand for high quality services with short lead times, and through reducing cancellation rates and winning service contracts for third-party installations. We also target growth in both our Service and Modernization businesses driven by increases in the average age of the installed base of elevators and escalators in the region and a strict regulatory environment. In Europe/Africa, we expect that the large, aging installed base of elevators and escalators, supported by a strict regulatory environment and high customer retention and conversion rates, will generate attractive service and 7 ----- modernization opportunities. We further expect that strong construction output, particularly from the residential segment and a slight recovery in Southern Europe as well as a more competitive product offering due to our manufacturing optimization initiatives in Spain and Germany, will drive our New Installation business and, consequently, growth in our Service and Modernization businesses. In Asia/Pacific, we aim to benefit from the anticipated growth of the new installations market, targeting robust expansion of our New Installation business, including in India and other markets. We believe that growing customer demand for high quality services and an expanding installed base will also contribute to growth in our Service and Modernization businesses. We expect that an expanding installed base of elevators and escalators and the growing importance of IoT solutions, particularly in South Korea, will lead to strong growth opportunities in our Service and Modernization businesses. We expect China, the largest elevator and escalator market in Asia, will continue to generate our highest New Installation growth globally, and that conversion of many of these newly installed units to Service contracts will continue to drive growth in the Service business. We believe that there is a particularly strong opportunity to grow our Service and Modernization businesses in China and other developing markets, driven by the growth and the aging of the installed base in those markets and stricter safety regulations requiring regular maintenance and upgrades, which many emerging market countries are adopting as their regulatory systems mature.

Section Title: NI** **SER
Subsubsection Title: Core Strategy: Realize structural profitability upside
Subsubsection Text: Our Core strategy consists of realizing structural profitability upside by focusing on (i) standardization within our New Installation business, (ii) manufacturing optimization, (iii) service and modernization growth and digitalization, (iv) selling, general and administrative (“SG&A”) cost reduction and (v) procurement optimization. In addition, following the Acquisition, we expect to realize additional cost savings as part of the Sponsors’ Transformation Program. _Standardization of Our New Installation Business_ We plan to continue to drive the standardization of our New Installation business by simplifying the amount and types of products and components we offer our customers. Historically, in part due to our strategy of growing through acquisitions, we provided customers with a large share of customized product solutions. This resulted in a highly diverse but overlapping product portfolio and limited price competitiveness due to the high costs of designing and producing such a wide range of individualized products. In order to optimize our structure, we are in the process of simplifying our regional product portfolio and standardizing certain components. For example, the number of product platforms in the Group has been reduced by more than half in the last decade as part of a process of implementing a simplified portfolio structure with further improvements planned going forward. In Europe, we have streamlined our major platforms down to two, which cover 80% of our products. This has resulted in synergies and a strong evolution of order intake in the first half of 2019/2020 while not impacting customers’ perception of our product offering or quantity of sales. We believe this will lead us to benefit from economies of scales, focusing our resource allocation more efficiently and allowing us to provide a more cost-competitive offering without compromising on customer service. In addition, we have also standardized and harmonized components across products to allow specific modular components, such as traction machines, controllers/inverters and doors, to be used across multiple product platforms, which we expect will result in lower costs due to the use of fewer parts, a leaner set-up, less complexity, higher agility and easier external sourcing. These initiatives are aimed at focusing our sales teams on value-based selling by presenting customers with a harmonized product portfolio of key high quality, high margin products. We plan to adapt our manufacturing to focus on products that provide our customers with one of three customization levels for low-rise buildings (less than 45 meters), mid-rise buildings (between 45 and 100 meters) and high-rise buildings (above 100 meters). These customization levels comprise: (i) Value for Money “100,” which is our lower priced option with no customization; (ii) Performance “200,” which is our moderately priced option with medium customization; and (iii) Customization “300,” which is our high priced option with full customization. This value proposition model offers customers flexible and transparent pricing, which we expect will make our products especially compelling to customers in high-volume and growth markets, such as large property developers in Asia/Pacific. Our processes, in turn, will be optimized by focusing on a leaner offering and steering our salesforces and engineers toward a focus on sales efforts based on product margin potentials and the conversion of New Installation units into Service contracts and later into Modernization sales. 8 ----- _Manufacturing Optimization_ We are engaged in an ongoing effort to optimize our manufacturing operations. These measures have included closing and, where possible, consolidating manufacturing sites, increasing outsourcing of standardized products and developing factories with improved technology for greater automation. For example, in Asia/Pacific, we have established leaner manufacturing operations, with a newly established plant in India and advances in automation at our plants in China and South Korea. In the Americas, we have consolidated all North America manufacturing at our Middleton facility to enhance efficiency and reduce costs. In Europe/Africa, we have shifted our factories away from a regional focus (in which a particular factory only serves specific countries) to a model where all factories can deliver to the entire Europe/Africa region, with each factory having a dedicated product focus. As part of this shift, we have restructured our Móstoles plant in Spain and we are currently restructuring our operations in Germany to reduce costs and simplify production. In the long term, we aim to move away from a classic factory model, where the focus is on major production and shipping of complete elevator systems and requires high personnel expenses, towards a model where we produce only key, mission critical components and outsource commoditized parts, resulting in lower fixed costs and higher productivity. _Service and Modernization Growth and Digitalization_ We aim to deliver service growth through leveraging our attractive business model and IoT innovation technology. Our business model contributes to the growth of our Service and Modernization business as, on average, 70% to 80% of New Installation contracts convert into Service contracts, and many of those Service business customers eventually become customers of the Modernization business. We aim to grow our Service business, which is a source of stable and recurring sales and high margins, by pursuing multiple initiatives aimed at increasing revenues per unit while decreasing costs. In particular, we believe that our use of digital and IoT technologies, including the recently developed MAX and VIEW systems, will enable us to improve customer satisfaction by increasing service quality and efficiency, and thereby increase customer retention rates and decrease cancellation rates. Particularly, in North America, our Service business growth is driven by the reduction of cancellation rates. We have already improved our cancellation rates and we aim to reduce our cancellation rates further through strict management focus and tools like the MAX and VIEW. We expect the growth of our Service business will contribute to new Modernization customers as the installed base grows and ages, generating an additional stream of stable and recurring revenues. We also believe that we can leverage the scale and efficiency gains achieved by MAX and VIEW to reduce the costs per unit of providing services, such as technician travel time and spare parts. In addition, we intend to increase our rate of winning customers away from competitor service providers by enhancing the efficiency of our spare parts organization, increasing our service training and leveraging the superior quality of our Service business and our capability to refurbish multi-brand spare parts through our ITS unit. _SG&A costs optimization_ We aim to reduce SG&A costs by centralizing administrative functions, adopting a range of organizational efficiency measures and improving our IT systems. Specifically, we are engaged in an ongoing effort to combine a wide array of administrative processes that historically have been performed locally, such as billing, payroll and purchasing, into shared service centers. For example, in the United States, we are in the process of consolidating these functions, previously spread over 18 locations, into one shared service center at the US headquarters in Atlanta, and we intend to roll out a similar strategy in Europe and Asia. We are also in the process of harmonizing our IT processes by rolling out VIEW globally, continuing to transition to cloud-based services, adopting global templates and standards, “delayering,” or flattening, management levels to simplify our organization and reduce overhead costs and adopting other efficiency enhancements. These measures have resulted in more than €80 million in total cost savings over the last three financial years. _Procurement Optimization_ Finally, throughout our Core strategy, we aim to reduce our procurement costs by optimizing our supply chains through commercial measures, such as, for example, supplier days, clustering managed spend, and engaging in e-auctions, continuing from measures implemented historically. For example, between the 2011/2012 Financial Year and the 2018/2019 Financial Year, our purchasing savings increased by 300%, outpacing our procurement spend which increased by 50%. 9 ----- _Transformation Program_ Following the Acquisition, we expect to realize €240 million in potential cost savings within 15 to 18 months after July 1, 2020 through the Sponsors’ Transformation Program, assuming various things, including that the program will be implemented beginning on July 1, 2020 and driven by key management, including the Chief Executive Officer of the Group. The Transformation Program focuses on cost savings opportunities related to (i) commercial operations, (ii) service operations, (iii) procurement costs, (iv) G&A costs and (v) other operational costs. Some of these initiatives will be continued through the efficiency measures, which we are already in the process of implementing, as described above. As part of our commercial operations initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to improve our organizational efficiency by restructuring and centralizing our sales supports team, including by shifting employees to low cost countries. In addition, we seek to increase our sales force productivity through various measures, including improving our administrative processes and completing faster technical sales. This is facilitated by our offering of fewer customization options resulting from the optimization of our product and service portfolios. We also intend to increase our focus on sales efforts based on product margin potentials and the conversion of New Installation units into Service contracts and later into Modernization sales. We expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €7 million related to our commercial operations initiatives. As part of our service operations initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to improve our organizational efficiency by rationalizing the number of our application engineers, reducing the number of platforms in our offering, standardizing our service offering and reducing the number of our service centers, particularly in the U.S. We intend to implement other measures under these initiatives as well, including improving process, technology and performance management in order to increase the productivity of our service technicians. We expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €15 million related to our service operations initiatives. As part of our procurement initiatives under the Transformation Program, we intend to implement multiple measures to reduce costs relating to our procurement activities. For the 2018/2019 Financial Year, we believe that our estimated addressable cost base for procurement activities comprised €2.1 billion of direct costs and €0.5 billion of indirect costs. To reduce these costs, we intend to establish group-wide supply agreements with global suppliers for key categories of direct materials, such as motors, cables and doors, including through leveraging change-of-control provisions under our existing supplier agreements with local or regional suppliers. We also expect to increase our focus on supplier driven innovation in connection with, among other things, tendering processes. To pursue improvements in specification management, we seek to standardize purchases for complex parts and establish business unit sourcing boards, which will act as advisory panels in key end markets to promote best practices and streamline procurement processes. Furthermore, we continue to shift our relationships with local suppliers to regional suppliers in order to both increase the number of sites served by our suppliers and decrease the number of our total suppliers, resulting in increased efficiencies. We also continue to streamline the amount and variety of individually supplied components in order to purchase bundles of different products and higher volumes of specific products, resulting in improved purchasing ability. Moreover, where appropriate, we target shifting to agreements with suppliers in low cost countries or otherwise shifting purchases from our suppliers of local products to products sourced from low cost countries. In addition, we are working to utilize both centralized regional lead-buyers to streamline demand-management processes and defined sourcing hubs to allow for best value and benchmark sourcing through increased spend, price and margin transparency. Furthermore, we expect to realize cost savings from our commercial operations initiatives that result in the rationalization of our product offering and standardization of our SKUs. We expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €132 million in connection with our procurement initiatives. As part of our G&A cost savings initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to improve our organizational efficiency and generate attrition savings through a leaner operating model, the shifting of employees to low cost countries and increased automation, including within our shared service centers. We expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €36 million related to our G&A cost savings initiatives. As part of our other operational initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to reduce direct and indirect personnel expenses and scrappage costs by decreasing the portion of poor quality production. We target replicating the cost of poor quality levels that we have achieved at our Korean plant (where such costs are estimated to be 0.6% of internal sales) at our other plants, particularly our Middleton plant. We also intend to outsource parts and components and streamline production overhead and assembly processes to reduce costs. We expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €50 million related to our other operational initiatives. 10 ----- We expect to incur one-off costs amounting to between €240 and €294 million in connection with these initiatives, mainly as a result of (i) voluntary redundancy, early retirement and other severance costs, (ii) staff training costs, (iii) investments in IT to digitize, automate and streamline processes, (iv) investments in the existing shared service centers in Europe, Brazil and the U.S., as well as potentially operating new, regional centers in Eastern Europe and Asia and (v) consulting, financial and legal advisory fees in connection with implementing these initiatives. See also “Summary Financial and Other Data—Other Financial, Operating and Pro-Forma Information—Other _Pro Forma Information.”_

Section Title: NI** **SER
Subsubsection Title: Core+ Strategy: Deliver additional value through innovation, digitalization and bolt-on acquisitions
Subsubsection Text: Our Core+ strategy aims to deliver additional value by (i) focusing on disruptive innovation, (ii) monetizing IoT opportunities, (iii) seeking opportunistic mergers and acquisitions and (iv) continuing the measures defined under our Core strategy. We have a long-standing German engineering heritage and a history of innovative digital solutions with the potential to transform the Elevator and Escalator division. We are a leading innovator in the elevator and escalator market and strive to address what we believe are fundamental technological challenges to better serve a rapidly urbanizing society. For example, we estimate that up to 40% of usable space in buildings is utilized for elevator shafts. Our TWIN elevator system combines two independent cars in one shaft in order to increase efficiency and creates more usable area by using up to 25% less usable space than an ordinary elevator. The TWIN elevator system’s unique value-add has made it a top choice for premier buildings around the world, including the European Central Bank in Frankfurt, Germany, and the CMA Tower in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. We believe that our MULTI elevator system, which is currently in the developing phase, has the potential to be even more compelling to the market. MULTI is a rope-less elevator able to move both vertically and horizontally, which will allow new architectural designs and unlimited building height and, we estimate, will use up to 30% to 50% less usable space than an ordinary elevator. We believe that our New Installation customers place a high value on innovative solutions like TWIN and MULTI, which both have the potential to significantly increase the usable area in buildings that is available for sale or rent. We also aim to continue to monetize our IoT technologies more effectively in the future to create sustainable business value and cash flow. By the 2021/2022 Financial Year, we aim to charge connection and monthly fees to customers for using MAX, which already supported the servicing of over 129,000 units as of March 31, 2020. Other innovations currently in the pipeline include our asset performance management solution as well as our Intelligent Gate Management System, part of our Access Solutions division. We plan to follow the MAX blueprint for these and other new products by clearly demonstrating the value of the product after launch, bringing the technology to maturity and then developing a pricing and sales model that accurately reflects our value to customers. In addition, we have a track record of successful mergers and acquisitions, including most recently our acquisitions of Nashville Machine’s elevator division and O’Keefe Elevator Company, Inc. in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. We plan to further develop our profit potential by opportunistically seeking future M&A targets, which we believe can be value accretive to the Group.

Subsubsection Text: We aim to deliver strong growth in our business, including significant margin expansion, through our three key strategies, Base, Core, and Core+, as further discussed below.

Section Title: NI** **SER
Subsubsection Text: On February 26/27, 2020, Bidco, an entity indirectly owned by Advent and the Cinven Funds, entered into the Share Purchase Agreement to acquire from the Seller all of the issued and outstanding share capital of the Target. We currently expect the Acquisition to complete during the course of July 2020. The consummation of the Acquisition is, however, subject to the satisfaction of certain closing conditions, including customary antitrust and regulatory approvals and the performance of certain closing actions. Under the terms of the Share Purchase Agreement, Bidco has agreed to take all necessary steps to obtain the required clearances following the signing of the Share Purchase Agreement. If closing has not occurred on the date falling six months after the signing date of the Share Purchase Agreement, the Share Purchase Agreement may be terminated. The estimated sources and uses necessary to consummate the Transactions are shown in the table below. Actual amounts will vary from estimated amounts depending on several factors, including the actual Acquisition Closing Date, and the actual purchase price for the Acquisition, fluctuations in currency exchange rates for 11 ----- amounts not denominated in euro, the amount of the Equity Contribution or other sources made available and differences between estimated and actual fees and expenses. In particular, the purchase price under the Share Purchase Agreement as shown below reflects the agreed base consideration as adjusted for our estimates of an agreed ticker fee accruing until the Acquisition Closing Date and certain notified cash leakage items, estimates of the amount of various other liabilities transferred in connection with the sale (including pensions and leases), certain payments arising as a result of the Transactions and certain other adjustments required under the Share Purchase Agreement. This amount is expected to change depending on the timing of the Acquisition Closing Date and a number of other factors.

Section Title: NI** **SER
Subsubsection Text: Pending the consummation of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds from the Offering of the Notes into the Escrow Accounts in the names of the Issuers. The Escrow Accounts will be controlled by the Escrow Agent and will be pledged on a first-priority basis in favor of the Trustee on behalf of the holders of the respective series of the Notes. See “Summary—The Offering—Collateral.” The release of the Escrowed Property from the Escrow Accounts is subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including that the funds required to pay the consideration for the Acquisition will be applied promptly (and in any event within two business days). See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; _Special Mandatory Redemption” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.” If these conditions are not satisfied on or before the Escrow Longstop Date or upon the occurrence_ of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption. The special mandatory redemption price for the Notes will be equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of such special mandatory redemption. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption,” “Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption” and “Risk Factors— _Risks Relating to the Transactions—If the conditions precedent to the release of the Escrowed Property are not satisfied, the Issuers will be required to redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Accounts may not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption without relying on the Escrow Equity Commitment.”_ In the event of a special mandatory redemption, the SUN Issuer, in the case of the Senior Secured Notes, and Vertical Topco III, in the case of the Senior Notes, will be required to fund the relevant Issuer in such aggregate amounts as are required in order to enable the Issuers to pay any funding shortfall, including Escrow Account fees, negative interest on the Escrow Accounts’ balances and costs and accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, owing to the holders of the Notes on such special mandatory redemption date (the “Escrow Equity Commitment”), pursuant to the Equity Commitment Letter. The holders of the Notes will not have any direct right to enforce the Escrow Equity Commitment, and must rely on the Issuers’ respective rights to enforcement under the Escrow Equity Commitment. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special _Mandatory Redemption,” “Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption”_ and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—If the conditions precedent to the release of the Escrowed _Property are not satisfied, the Issuers will be required to redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Accounts may not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption without relying on the Escrow Equity Commitment.”_ 13 -----

Section Title: NI** **SER
Subsubsection Text: (1) Represents the euro-equivalent of the aggregate amount we expect to draw under the Senior Term Facilities on or about the Acquisition Closing Date. The commitment in respect of the USD TLA Facility and the USD TLB Facility is denominated in euros and will be redenominated into U.S. dollars on or about the Acquisition Closing Date. (2) Represents the euro-equivalent of the estimated gross proceeds of €1,750 million in aggregate principal amount of SSN EUR Notes and €1,250,000,000 million (USD equivalent) in aggregate principal amount of SSN USD Notes. (3) Represents the euro-equivalent of the estimated gross proceeds of €650 million in aggregate principal amount of SUN EUR Notes and €400,000,000 million (USD equivalent) in aggregate principal amount of SUN USD Notes. (4) Represents the euro-equivalent of the amount of gross proceeds of the Private Senior Notes which consist of a euro-denominated tranche and a U.S. dollar-denominated tranche. The commitment in respect of the U.S. dollar-denominated tranche is denominated in euros and will be redenominated into U.S. dollars on or about the Acquisition Closing Date. (5) Represents the expected equity contributions (based on the agreed base consideration pursuant to the Share Purchase Agreement) from the Sponsors, thyssenkrupp AG, other co-investors and management, including the proceeds of the PIK Notes, in each case, in the form of equity and subordinated shareholder funding. The amount of the equity contributions from the Sponsors and certain of its co-investors may be increased or decreased if the fees and expenses are greater or less than our current estimate or as a result of purchase price adjustments under the Share Purchase Agreement. (6) Represents the agreed base consideration payable to the Seller pursuant to the Share Purchase Agreement as adjusted for our estimates of an agreed ticker fee accruing until the Acquisition Closing Date and certain notified cash leakage items, estimates of the amount of various other liabilities transferred in connection with the sale (including pensions and leases), certain payments arising as a result of the Transactions and certain other adjustments required under the Share Purchase Agreement. The purchase price under the SPA is calculated as the agreed base consideration plus the agreed ticker fee from the locked box dated (September 30, 2019) until the closing date minus certain notified leakage and adjustments for various other liabilities transferred in connection with the sale (including pensions and leases), certain payments arising as a result of the Transactions and certain other adjustments required under the Share Purchase Agreement. The purchase price will be paid in cash at closing, other than the purchase price portion attributable to the reinvestment of thyssenkrupp AG which will be settled in kind by granting thyssenkrupp AG a participation in an indirect parent company of the SUN Issuer. See “Summary—Summary Corporate and Financing Structure.” (7) Represents estimated fees and expenses associated with the Transactions, including net interest expense that will accrue on proceeds of the Notes deposited into escrow, underwriting, financial advisory, legal, accounting, ratings advisory and other transaction costs and professional fees. (8) Represents the minimum amount of operating cash of the Group as of the Acquisition Closing Date. Any cash in excess of this amount in the Target Group as of the Acquisition Closing Date is expected (due to a related increase in the intercompany payables owed by the Target Group to thyssenkrupp AG) to increase the purchase price and to be funded through the Revolving Credit Facility. Under the Share Purchase Agreement, intercompany financing arrangements will be terminated prior to the Acquisition Closing Date. In general, intercompany receivables owed to thyssenkrupp AG by the Target will need to be acquired by the purchaser, subject to an additional purchase price, and all intercompany payables owed by thyssenkrupp AG to the Target will be paid in cash to the Target on the Acquisition Closing Date. In addition, the Share Purchase Agreement provides for a netting mechanism, pursuant to which, as of the Acquisition Closing Date, there will be no intercompany receivables owed to thyssenkrupp AG by the Target that need to be acquired and, instead, only intercompany payables owed by thyssenkrupp AG to the Target (if any) will remain outstanding. Such intercompany payables will then be off-set against the purchase price for the Acquisition. The Share Purchase Agreement contains customary warranties given by the Seller as to capacity, title and certain business matters as well as customary signing to closing covenants given by the Seller regarding, among other 12 ----- things, the conduct of the business and the affairs of the Group pending closing of the Acquisition. The Seller’s liability for any breach of a warranty is subject to certain thresholds and limitations. In addition, pursuant to the Share Purchase Agreement, the Seller has agreed to take certain actions to facilitate the ability of the Group to operate on a standalone basis, including, subject to certain exceptions, the provision of a number of services pursuant to the New TSAs and the Additional Service Agreements, including relating to accounting and risk services, IT, procurement, real estate, human resources, compliance, tax (in certain jurisdictions) and others, to the Group, following the Acquisition. See “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Ongoing _Relationships and Services Provided by the thyssenkrupp Group—Services provided by the thyssenkrupp Group to the Group—Transitional Service Agreements (“TSAs”).”_ Further, subject to certain customary exceptions and excluding the reinvestment by thyssenkrupp AG in the Group, the Seller has agreed that, for two years from the Acquisition Closing Date, neither it nor its subsidiaries will, without Bidco’s written consent, engage in the territory in which the Group will conduct business as of the Acquisition Closing Date, directly or indirectly, in the field of elevator business activities of the Group, comprising the installation, modernization, servicing or maintenance of elevators, escalators, stair-lifts, moving walks or passenger boarding bridges (as well as directly related ancillary activities, such as manufacturing and designing of elevators, escalators, stair-lifts, moving walks or passenger boarding bridges). Following the completion of the Acquisition, Bidco will hold 100% of the shares in the Target and we expect the legal form of the Target will be changed from an Aktiengesellschaft to a Gesellschaft mit beschränkter Haftung shortly after closing. Prior to the Acquisition Closing Date, Bidco will not have control over the board of directors of thyssenkrupp Elevator. The board of directors of thyssenkrupp Elevator will be required, prior to the Acquisition Closing Date, to manage thyssenkrupp Elevator under its own responsibility and in a manner that is in the best interests of thyssenkrupp Elevator. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—The Issuers do not currently _control the Target and will not control the Target until the Acquisition Closing Date.”_

Section Title: NI** **SER
Subsubsection Text: Founded in 1984, Advent is one of the largest and most experienced global private equity investors. With offices on four continents, Advent has established a globally integrated team of over 220 investment professionals focused on buyouts and growth equity investments in five core sectors. Since initiating its private equity strategy in 1989, Advent has invested $40 billion in over 350 private equity investments across 42 countries, and as of December 31, 2019, managed $56.8 billion in assets. Today, as Advent did more than 30 years ago, it seeks to invest in well-positioned companies and partner with management teams to create value through sustained revenue and earnings growth.

Section Title: NI** **SER
Subsubsection Text: Cinven is a leading international private equity firm with offices in London, Frankfurt, Guernsey, Hong Kong, Luxembourg, Madrid, Milan, New York and Paris. Since 1988, the Cinven Funds have invested in over 130 companies and led transactions totaling more than €100 billion. The firm’s investment focus is on six key sectors: healthcare, business services, consumer, financial services, industrials, and technology, media and telecommunications. Cinven’s investment strategy targets companies that are well positioned in their respective markets and require an equity investment of €200 million or more. Using its long-standing experience and proven economic growth strategies (such as buy and build), Cinven works closely with management teams to facilitate growth and help its portfolio companies reach their full potential.

Section Title: NI** **SER
Subsubsection Text: Established in 1976, ADIA is an independent, globally diversified investment institution whose sole mission is to invest funds on behalf of the Government of the Emirate of Abu Dhabi, to make available the necessary financial resources to secure and maintain the future welfare of the Emirate. ADIA manages a diversified global investment portfolio, across more than two-dozen asset classes and sub-categories, including quoted equities, fixed income, real estate, private equity, alternatives and infrastructure. In private equity specifically, ADIA, through its subsidiaries, is a leading and long-established global investor acting both as a limited partner in reputable private equity funds world-wide, and as a shareholder supporting companies and management teams to achieve long-term growth and value creation. 14 ----- Luxinva is an indirect, wholly-owned subsidiary of ADIA, and owns various private equity investments.

Section Title: NI** **SER
Subsubsection Text: Auba is a nominated investment vehicle of GIC Special Investments Pte Ltd, a wholly owned subsidiary of GIC. GIC is a leading global investment firm established in 1981 to manage Singapore’s foreign reserves. A disciplined long-term value investor, GIC is uniquely positioned for investments across a wide range of asset classes, including equities, fixed income, private equity, real estate and infrastructure. In private equity, GIC invests through funds as well as directly in companies, partnering with its fund managers and management teams to help world class businesses achieve their objectives. GIC has over US$100 billion in assets in over 40 countries and has been investing in emerging markets for more than two decades. Headquartered in Singapore, GIC employs over 1,500 people across 10 offices in key financial cities worldwide.

Section Title: NI** **SER
Subsubsection Text: The RAG-Stiftung’s business model aims to ensure the financing of perpetual obligations of RAG’s coal mining activities with the proceeds from the sale of shares in Evonik Industries AG and their reinvestment, with dividends from Evonik Industries AG and other income from investments, as well as with revenue generated from its diverse financial assets. In accordance with this business model, the primary objective is to finance the cash outflow for the sustainable financing of perpetual obligations from investment income and financial assets. A further purpose of the RAG-Stiftung is the promotion of education, science and culture in connection with German coal mining in the mining regions of North Rhine-Westphalia and Saarland.

Section Title: NI** **SER
Subsubsection Text: Since January 2020, there has been a progressive global spread of the COVID-19 pandemic, resulting in various actions, including lockdowns, by governments across the world in order to contain and control the virus. COVID-19 has impacted markets and facilities in multiple ways, depending on the local exposure to the virus and the measures taken by local governments. Our Asia/Pacific, Americas and Europe/Africa segments, which comprise our Elevator and Escalator division, have been affected in varying degrees. The effect of COVID-19 was felt in all regions, leading to complete lockdowns in some regions and milder restrictions in others. In the Asia/Pacific region, temporary restrictions were mainly observed in China after a full lockdown of manufacturing sites in February 2020 due to government restrictions, but with recovery to almost normal operations in March 2020. India has also been affected by government restrictions and our facility in Pune is currently ramping up its operations. In the Americas, some reductions were observed in Brazil, while production in the United States remained mainly at normal levels, with only temporary restrictions on construction sites and service operations. In the Europe/Africa segment, Spain, France, Italy and Germany were the most impacted countries, with some site restrictions and temporary reductions or lockdowns in productions facilities. 15 ----- The following graphs show our estimated New Installation order intake, completed maintenance visits and manufacturing capacity during April and May 2020 in China, the DACH region, the United States and (for manufacturing capacity only) Brazil, compared to management estimates as to normal levels for each of these key performance indicators based on historical experience and prior budgeting: New installations order intake (vs. estimated regular levell l[1][1]) _Mgmt. est. regular level 50%_ Jan-20 May-20y [1] Completed maintenance visits (vs. estimated regular levellevel[1][1]) _Mgmt. est. regular level 80%_ Jan-20 May-20 Manufacturing (vs. estimated regular level[1]) _Mgmt. est. regular level 50%_ Jan-20 May-20 1. Indicative management's estimates based on budget and previous years. 2. Factory: Middleton. 3. Factories: Songjiang, Zhongshan, Zhongshan, Marohn. 4. Factories: Hamburg, Norte, Neuhausen, Mostoles. 5. Factory: Porto Alegre. US China DACH China DACH US US[2] China[3] EA[4] Brazil[5] The Access Solutions division has been affected in each of its home solutions and airport solutions offerings. Activities for home solutions have been operating at a lower level with partial temporary shutdowns of production facilities, but are recovering constantly. The partial or complete shutdown of most airports has led to a decrease of New Installation and Service operations due to postponements and suspensions of some projects. We have implemented a contingency plan headed by a steering committee consisting of members of our Management Board. Our contingency plan focuses on the health and safety of our workforce, cash flexibility, workforce flexibility, business continuity, sales push and communication. Cash management measures revolve around personnel savings, tight working capital management and a capital expenditure freeze. Around 15,000 employees are currently affected by these contingency measures, which include funded and non-funded furloughs and overtime reduction. Despite the negative global macroeconomic outlook as a result of COVID-19, we believe that in the medium to long term, the outbreak will not have a material adverse effect on our overall business and results of operations, due to the underlying resilience of our business and immediate implementation of contingency measures. Our New Installation business was temporarily impacted in countries with lockdown measures, as discussed above. However, all our manufacturing plants are currently operational. Our Service business has performed largely as expected, given applicable safety and regulatory requirements. However, the COVID-19 pandemic has been evolving rapidly and we are unable to predict how the outbreak may affect our business in the future. We continue to monitor the situation to ensure the safety of our employees, react to any operational developments, logistics disruptions and macroeconomic fluctuations and assess the ongoing impact of developments on our financial condition, results of operations, cash flows and liquidity. level[1][1]) 16 -----

Subsubsection Text: _The preliminary financial data included in this section as of and for the one-month period ended April 30, 2020 and the one-month period ended May 31, 2020, presented below has been prepared by, and is the sole responsibility of, the Group’s management. PwC has not audited, reviewed, compiled, or applied agreed-upon procedures with respect to the preliminary financial data. Accordingly, PwC does not express an opinion or any other form of assurance with respect thereto. Such information has been derived from thyssenkrupp AG’s preliminary management accounts, including certain segmental information extracted therefrom, is preliminary and is subject to financial closing procedures which have not yet been completed. In particular, our Financial Statements and thyssenkrupp AG’s segmental information are not prepared on the same basis, and therefore, while we believe these preliminary results and estimates to be reasonable, our actual results could vary from these estimates and these differences could be material. As such, you should not place undue reliance on this information and this information may not be indicative of our performance in the remainder of the financial year or any future period. See “Forward looking Statements,” “Risk Factors” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” in this offering memorandum for a more complete discussion of certain of the factors that could affect our future performance. One Month Ended April 30, 2020_ Based on thyssenkrupp AG’s preliminary management accounts, including certain segmental information derived therefrom, we estimate that our sales for the one-month period ending April 30, 2020, was approximately €617 million compared to sales of approximately €671 million in the corresponding period in 2019, representing a decrease of 8%. We estimate that our Adjusted EBIT was approximately €53 million for the one-month period ending April 30, 2020, compared to approximately €70 million in the corresponding period in 2019 after giving effect to estimated additional standalone corporate costs in the 2019/2020 Financial Year of €30 million per annum distributed equally across each one-month period in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The change in Adjusted EBIT represents a decrease of 24%. We estimate that our Adjusted EBIT margin was approximately 8.6% for the one-month period ending April 30, 2020, compared to approximately 10.4% in the corresponding period in 2019, representing a decrease of 1.8% points. We estimate that our order intake was approximately €645 million for the one-month period ending April 30, 2020, compared to approximately €648 million in the corresponding period in 2019, representing a decrease of 0.5%. We estimate that our business cash flow (pre-restructuring) was approximately €166 million for the one-month period ending April 30, 2020, compared to approximately €101 million in the corresponding period in 2019 after giving effect to estimated additional standalone corporate costs in the 2019/2020 Financial Year of €30 million per annum distributed equally across each one-month period in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The change in business cash flow (pre-restructuring) represents an increase of 65%. Our results for the one-month period ending April 30, 2020, were mainly driven by the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, together with strong development in business cash flow showing positive development in all Operating Segments. _One Month Ended May 31, 2020_ Based on thyssenkrupp AG’s preliminary management accounts, including certain segmental information derived therefrom, we estimate that our sales for the one-month period ended May 31, 2020, was approximately €634 million compared to sales of approximately €689 million in the corresponding period in 2019, representing a decrease of 8%. We estimate that our Adjusted EBIT was approximately €70 million for the one-month period ended May 31, 2020, compared to approximately €74 million in the corresponding period in 2019 after giving effect to estimated additional standalone corporate costs in the 2019/2020 Financial Year of €30 million per annum distributed equally across each one-month period in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The change in Adjusted EBIT represents a decrease of 6%. We estimate that our Adjusted EBIT margin was approximately 11.0% for the one-month period ended May 31, 2020, compared to approximately 10.8% in the corresponding period in 2019, representing an increase of 0.2%. 17 ----- We estimate that our order intake was approximately €631 million for the one-month period ended May 31, 2020, compared to approximately €679 million in the corresponding period in 2019, representing a decrease of 7%. We estimate that our business cash flow (pre-restructuring) was approximately €104 million for the one-month period ended May 31, 2020, compared to approximately €71 million in the corresponding period in 2019 after giving effect to estimated additional standalone corporate costs in the 2019/2020 Financial Year of €30 million per annum distributed equally across each one-month period in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The change in business cash flow (pre-restructuring) represents an increase of 46%. Our results for the one-month period ended May 31, 2020 were impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, while sales and Adjusted EBIT were showing notable recovery compared to the one-month period ended April 30, 2020 together with a continued strong development in business cash flow.

Section Title: NI** **SER
Subsubsection Text: Elevator lifetime: c. 10-20 years of elevator lifetime prior to significant Modernization Time Maintenance fee Spare parts Maintenance Maintenance Maintenance Maintenance Maintenance Contract Contract Contract Contract Contract The profitability of our business is also driven by our fully invested global foothold, which requires limited capital expenditure and working capital given our asset-light business model, resulting in a strong cash flow profile. Our elevator technology business has significantly increased cash generation since 2011/2012, roughly doubling its business cash flow through generating higher profits and reducing operating net working capital by approximately 80%. Our cash conversion rate was approximately 90% in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. Excluding certain one-off expenditures incurred from time to time (such as €3 million, €6 million and €106 million for major mergers and acquisition projects in the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years (including the acquisitions of Nashville Machine’s elevator division and O’Keefe Elevator Company, Inc.) as well as carve-out related one-time expenditures of €1,080 million paid in connection with the Licensing Agreement fee for use of the “thyssenkrupp” brand and of €74 million for carve-out related real estate transfers, in both cases, in the 2018/2019 Financial Year), our capital expenditures were €145 million, €115 million, and €129 million for the 2016/2017 Financial Year, the 2017/2018 Financial Year and the 2018/2019 Financial Year, respectively, highlighting our generally stable and relatively limited capital investment requirements. See “Summary Financial and Other Data—Other Financial, Operating and Pro Forma Information—Other _Financial and Operating Information.” We believe that the development of business cash flow and cash_ conversion over the last three financial years demonstrates that we operate an asset-light business with relatively low capital requirements and high cash returns. In addition, we believe our business offers significant operational improvement potential and profitability upside. We have recently implemented several cost optimization initiatives that we believe will generate greater margins. For example, we have restructured our manufacturing operations by optimizing our footprint and leveraging shared services and best practices, as well as streamlining our product offerings. These initiatives have led to stable development in cost of goods sold by partially offsetting personnel cost inflation through efficiency measures and headcount management, and compensating for material cost increases through purchasing measures and the improved management of procurement volume. These efficiency measures have also reduced SG&A costs as a percentage of sales from 18.5% in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to 16.4% in the twelve months ended March 31, 2020. In addition, following the Acquisition, we expect to realize an additional estimated €240 million in potential cost savings within 15 to 18 months after July 1, 2020, as part of the Sponsors’ transformation program (the “Transformation Program”). See “—Our Strategies—Core Strategy: Realize _structural profitability upside” and “Summary Financial and Other Data—Other Financial, Operating and Pro- Forma Information—Other Pro Forma Information.”_

On the Issue Date, all of the Issue Date Guarantors will guarantee the Senior Facilities on a senior basis, pari passu with the Note Guarantees of the Senior Secured Notes and senior to the Note Guarantees of the Senior Notes. Within 150 days from (and excluding) the Acquisition Closing Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Facilities will be guaranteed by the Post-Closing Guarantors on a senior basis, pari passu with the Note Guarantees of the Senior Secured Notes and senior to the Note Guarantees of the Senior Notes. On the Issue Date, the Senior Facilities will be secured by the SSN Issue Date Collateral. Within 150 days from (and excluding) the Acquisition Closing Date and subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Facilities will be secured by the SSN Post-Closing Collateral. The SSN Collateral will also secure the Senior Secured Notes. On the Issue Date, the Notes and the Issue Date Guarantee will be secured by the Escrow Charges. Upon the definitive release of the Escrowed Property, the first-priority security interests over the Escrowed Property will be released. On the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes will also be secured by the SSN Issue Date Collateral and the SUN Collateral, respectively. The SUN Collateral will also secure the Private Senior Notes. The validity and enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the security and the liability of each Guarantor and security provider will be subject to certain limitations. See “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on _the Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and Security Interests.” The security interests in favor of the Notes and the Note_ Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances. (8) The EUR SSN Issuer is offering €750 million in aggregate principal amount of its SSN EUR Fixed Notes and €1,000 million in aggregate principal amount of its SSN EUR FRN Notes. The Senior Secured Notes will be senior obligations of the SSN Issuers and will (i) rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the SSN Issuers’ existing and future senior indebtedness, including the Senior Facilities, (ii) rank senior in right of payment to all of the SSN Issuers’ existing and future indebtedness that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes, including its obligations in respect of the Senior Notes, (iii) be effectively subordinated to all of the SSN Issuers’ existing and future indebtedness that is secured by liens that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes, to the extent of the value of such property and assets securing such indebtedness and (iv) be structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the subsidiaries of the SSN Issuers that do not guarantee the Senior Secured Notes, including their obligations to trade creditors. (9) On the Acquisition Closing Date, the Issuers intend to use the proceeds from the Senior Term Facilities, the Notes, the Private Senior Notes and the Equity Contribution to (i) fund the consideration payable for the Acquisition and (ii) pay the fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions. See “Use of Proceeds.” (10) Within 150 days from (and excluding) the Acquisition Closing Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and substantially simultaneously with the guarantees granted in favor of obligations under the Senior Facilities, the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes will be guaranteed by the Post-Closing Guarantors on a senior basis and senior subordinated basis, respectively. Within 150 days from (and excluding) the Acquisition Closing Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and substantially simultaneously with the obligations under the Senior Facilities, the Senior Secured Notes will be secured by the SSN Post-Closing Collateral. The SSN Collateral will also secure the Senior Facilities on a pari passu basis with the Senior Secured Notes. The validity and enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the security and the liability of each Guarantor and security provider will be subject to certain limitations. See “Certain _Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and Security Interests.” The_ security interests in favor of the Notes and the Note Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, on a consolidated basis and excluding statistical corporate cost allocations, the Post-Closing Guarantors generated 62.8% of the Group’s consolidated EBITDA and 44.5% of the Group’s consolidated sales. As of March 31, 2020, on a consolidated basis and excluding the value of the “thyssenkrupp” brand (the license for which will automatically terminate 18 months after the Acquisition Closing Date), the Post-Closing Guarantors accounted for 36.4% of the Group’s consolidated assets. (11) As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Target is incorporated in the form of a German stock corporation (Aktiengesellschaft). Following the consummation of the Acquisition, it is expected that the legal form of the Target will be changed from an _Aktiengesellschaft to a Gesellschaft mit beschränkter Haftung._ 21 -----
