Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsection Title: Ranking of the Notes and the Note Guarantees:
Subsubsection Text: Senior Secured Notes . . . . . . . . . . . The Senior Secured Notes will: - be general senior obligations of the SSN Issuers; - rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the SSN Issuers’ existing and future senior indebtedness, including the Senior Facilities; - rank senior in right of payment to all of the SSN Issuers’ existing and future indebtedness that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes, including their respective obligations in respect of their guarantees of the Senior Notes and the Private Senior Notes, - be effectively subordinated to all of the SSN Issuers’ existing and future indebtedness that is secured by liens that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes, to the extent of the value of such property and assets securing such indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the subsidiaries of the SSN Issuers that do not guarantee the Senior Secured Notes, including their obligations to trade creditors. 23 ----- SSN Guarantees . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . The SSN Guarantees will: - be general senior obligations of that Guarantor; - rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the existing and future senior indebtedness of that Guarantor, including the Senior Facilities; - rank senior in right of payment to all of the existing and future indebtedness of that Guarantor that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes, including its obligations in respect of its guarantee of the Senior Notes and the Private Senior Notes; - be effectively subordinated to all of the existing and future indebtedness of that Guarantor that is secured by liens that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes, to the extent of the value of such property and assets securing such indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the subsidiaries of such Guarantor that do not guarantee the Senior Secured Notes, including their obligations to trade creditors. Senior Notes . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . The Senior Notes will: - be general senior obligations of the SUN Issuer; - rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the SUN Issuer’s existing and future senior indebtedness, including the Private Senior Notes; - rank senior in right of payment to all of the SUN Issuer’s existing and future indebtedness that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Notes; - be effectively subordinated to all of the SUN Issuer’s existing and future indebtedness that is secured by liens that do not secure the Senior Notes, to the extent of the value of such property and assets securing such indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the subsidiaries of the SUN Issuer that do not guarantee the Senior Notes, including their obligations to trade creditors. Senior Note Guarantees . . . . . . . . . The Senior Note Guarantees will: - be general senior obligations of such Guarantor; - rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the existing and future senior subordinated indebtedness of such Guarantor, including, where applicable, its obligations in respect of its guarantee of the Private Senior Notes; - rank senior in right of payment to all of the existing and future indebtedness of such Guarantor that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Notes, if any; - be effectively subordinated to all of the existing and future indebtedness of such Guarantor that is secured by liens that do not secure the Senior Notes, to the extent of the value of such property and assets securing such indebtedness, including the Senior Facilities Agreement and Senior Secured Notes up to the value of the SSN Collateral; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the subsidiaries of such Guarantor that do not guarantee the Senior Notes, including their obligations to trade creditors. 24 -----

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsubsection Text: Senior Secured Notes . . . . . . . . . . . On the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes and the Note Guarantees thereof will be secured by the Escrow Charges relating thereto. Upon the definitive release of the Escrowed Property, the first-priority security interests over the Escrowed Property will be released. In addition, on the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes and Note Guarantees thereof will be secured on a first-priority basis by (collectively, the “SSN Issue-Date Collateral”): - a share pledge in respect of the SUN Issuer’s shares in the capital of the EUR SSN Issuer pursuant to a German law governed share pledge agreement; - a security assignment in respect of any structural intercompany receivables owed to the SUN Issuer by the EUR SSN Issuer pursuant to a German law governed security assignment agreement; - a share pledge in respect of the EUR SSN Issuer’s shares in the capital of Newco pursuant to a German law governed share pledge agreement; - a security assignment in respect of any structural intercompany receivables owed to the EUR SSN Issuer by Newco pursuant to a German law governed security assignment agreement; - a pledge in respect of the EUR SSN Issuer’s material bank accounts in Germany (without control over use and freely operational prior to acceleration) pursuant to a German law governed bank account pledge agreement; - a share pledge in respect of Newco’s shares in the capital of Bidco pursuant to a German law governed share pledge agreement; - a security assignment in respect of any structural intercompany receivables owed to Newco by Bidco pursuant to a German law governed security assignment agreement; - a pledge in respect of Newco’s material bank accounts in Germany (without control over use and freely operational prior to acceleration) pursuant to a German law governed bank account pledge agreement; - a pledge in respect of Newco’s shares in the capital of the USD SSN Issuer and all intercompany receivables owed to Newco by the USD SSN Issuer pursuant to a New York law governed security agreement; - a pledge in respect of Bidco’s material bank accounts in Germany (without control over use and freely operational prior to acceleration) pursuant to a German law governed bank account pledge agreement; and - security interests over all assets of the USD SSN Issuer pursuant to a New York law governed security agreement. Within 150 days from (and excluding) the Acquisition Closing Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and substantially simultaneously with the obligations under the Senior Facilities, the Senior Secured Notes and the Note Guarantees thereof will be secured by (collectively, the “SSN Post-Closing Collateral,” and together with the SSN Issue-Date Collateral, the “SSN Collateral”): - share pledges in respect of the shares in the capital of thyssenkrupp Elevator Corp., thyssenkrupp Aufzüge GmbH, Tepper Aufzüge GmbH, thyssenkrupp Elevator (Canada) Limited and thyssenkrupp Elevator Manufacturing Inc.; and 25 ----- - security over substantially all assets (subject to customary exceptions) of the Post-Closing Guarantors incorporated in the United States and Canada. The SSN Collateral will also secure the Senior Facilities on a pari passu basis and a portion of the SSN Collateral, consisting of the Shared Collateral, will also secure the Senior Notes on a second-priority basis (as set forth under “—Senior Notes” below). The Senior Notes will not benefit from any security interests in the SSN Post-Closing Collateral or any other of the SSN Collateral. See “Description _of_ _Certain_ _Financing _Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement.”_ The security interests may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability. For more information on the security interests granted, see “Description of the Senior _Secured Notes—Security,” and for more information on potential limitations_ to the security interests, see “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and _Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and Security Interests,” “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Each Series of Notes,”_ “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes” and “Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to the Senior Notes.”_ The security interests may be released under certain circumstances. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Each Series of Notes—There are _circumstances other than the repayment or discharge of the Notes under which the Collateral securing the Notes and the Note Guarantees will be released automatically without your consent or the Trustee or the Security Agent obtaining your further consent,” “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement,” and “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Security—Release of Liens.”_ Senior Notes . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . On the Issue Date, the Senior Notes and the Note Guarantees thereof will be secured by the Escrow Charges relating thereto. Upon the definitive release of the Escrowed Property, the first-priority security interests over the Escrowed Property will be released. In addition, on the Issue Date, the Senior Notes and Note Guarantees thereof will be secured by (collectively, the “SUN Collateral” and together with the SSN Collateral and the Escrow Charges, the “Collateral”): - on a first-priority basis, (i) a share pledge in respect of Vertical Topco III’s shares in the capital of the SUN Issuer pursuant to a German law governed share pledge agreement, (ii) a pledge in respect of all the material bank accounts of the SUN Issuer pursuant to a German law governed bank account pledge agreement, and (iii) a security assignment in respect of any intercompany receivables owed to Vertical Topco III by the SUN Issuer relating to any proceeds loan or other shareholder loan pursuant to a German law governed security assignment agreement; - on a second-priority basis, (i) a security assignment and/or in respect of any structural intercompany receivables owed to the SUN Issuer by the EUR SSN Issuer pursuant to a German law governed security assignment and/or receivables pledge agreement, and (ii) a share pledge in respect of the SUN Issuer’s shares in the capital of the EUR SSN Issuer pursuant to a German law governed share pledge agreement (collectively, the “Shared Collateral”). The SUN Collateral will also secure the Private Senior Notes and the Shared Collateral will also secure the SSN Notes and the Senior Facilities on a first-priority basis. The Senior Notes will not benefit from any security 26 ----- interests in the SSN Post-Closing Collateral or any other of the SSN Collateral. See “Description _of_ _Certain_ _Financing_ _Arrangements— _Intercreditor Agreement.”_ The security interests may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability. For more information on the security interests granted, see “Description of the Senior _Notes—Security,” and for more information on potential limitations to the_ security interests, see “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and _Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and Security Interests,” “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Each Series of Notes,”_ “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes” and “Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to the Senior Notes.”_ The security interests may be released under certain circumstances. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Each Series of Notes—There are _circumstances other than the repayment or discharge of the Notes under which the Collateral securing the Notes and the Note Guarantees will be released automatically without your consent or the Trustee or the Security Agent obtaining your further consent,” “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement,” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Security—Release of Liens.”_ Use of Proceeds . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The proceeds from the Offering of the Notes, together with borrowings under the Senior Term Facilities, the proceeds from the Private Senior Notes and the Equity Contribution will be used to (i) fund the consideration payable for the Acquisition and (ii) pay the fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions. See “Use of Proceeds.” Additional Amounts . . . . . . . . . . .** Any payments made by the Issuers or any Guarantor with respect to the Notes or Note Guarantees will be made without withholding or deduction for taxes unless required by law. If such withholding or deduction is required by law in any “relevant taxing jurisdiction,” the Issuers or the relevant Guarantor, as applicable, will pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amounts received after the withholding or deduction is not less than the amount that would have been received in the absence of the withholding or deduction, subject to certain exceptions. See “Description of _the Senior Secured Notes—Withholding Taxes” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Withholding Taxes.”_

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsubsection Text: Fixed Rate Notes . . . . . . . . . . . . . . All or a portion of the Fixed Rate Notes may be redeemed at any time prior to, 2023, at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the relevant series of Notes redeemed plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date plus a “make-whole” premium, as described in this offering memorandum. Prior to, 2023, the Issuers may in each calendar year redeem up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of each series of the Fixed Rate Notes (including any additional Fixed Rate Notes of the same series) at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. At any time prior to, 2023, up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of each series of Fixed Rate Notes may be redeemed with the net proceeds of one or more specified equity offerings at a redemption price equal to %, %, % and % in respect of the SSN 27 ----- EUR Fixed Notes, SSN USD Notes, SUN USD Notes and SUN EUR Notes, respectively, in each case, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date, provided that at least 50% of the original aggregate principal amount of such series of Fixed Rate Notes (including any additional Fixed Rate Notes) remains outstanding, after the redemption (unless all Fixed Rate Notes of such series are redeemed substantially concurrently). The Fixed Rate Notes may be redeemed at any time on or after , 2023, at the redemption prices set forth in price set forth under “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Optional Redemption” and “Description _of_ _the_ _Senior_ _Notes—Optional_ _Redemption,”_ as applicable. SSN EUR FRN Notes . . . . . . . . . . All or a portion of the SSN EUR FRN Notes may be redeemed at any time prior to, 2021, at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the SSN EUR FRN Notes redeemed plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date plus a “make-whole” premium, as described in this offering memorandum. The SSN EUR FRN Notes may be redeemed at any time on or after , 2021, at the redemption prices set forth in Description of the _Senior Secured Notes—Optional Redemption.”_

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsubsection Text: Reasons . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** In the event of certain developments affecting taxation that become effective on or after the Issue Date, an Issuer may redeem the applicable series of Notes in whole but not in part, at any time, upon giving written notice, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption. See “Description of the Senior Secured _Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons.”_ Change of Control . . . . . . . . . . . .** Upon the occurrence of certain defined events constituting a change of control or upon certain asset sales, each holder of Notes of any series may require the relevant Issuer, as applicable, to repurchase all or a portion of the Notes of such series at a price equal to 101% of their principal amount plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. However, a change of control will not be deemed to have occurred if, pro forma for such change of control, a specified consolidated total net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Change of _Control” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Change of Control.”_

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsubsection Text: Mandatory Redemption . . . . .** Concurrently with the closing of the Offering, and pending consummation of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds of the Offering into the Escrow Accounts, held in the name of the relevant Issuer. The Escrow Accounts will be controlled by the Escrow Agent, and pledged on a first-priority basis in favor of the Trustee on behalf of the holders of the respective series of Notes. The release of the proceeds deposited in the Escrow Accounts will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including that the funds required to pay the consideration for the Acquisition will be applied promptly (and in any event within two business days). Upon delivery to the Trustee and the Escrow Agent of an officer’s certificate stating that the conditions to the release of the proceeds from escrow are satisfied, the Escrowed Property will be released to the Issuers and utilized as described in “Use of Proceeds,” “Description of the 28 ----- _Senior_ _Secured_ _Notes—Escrow_ _of_ _Proceeds;_ _Special_ _Mandatory Redemption” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.” If the conditions to the release of the_ Escrowed Property have not been satisfied on or prior to the business day immediately following the Escrow Longstop Date, or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption. The special mandatory redemption price of the Notes will be equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, such special mandatory redemption date. In the event of a special mandatory redemption, the SUN Issuer, in the case of the Senior Secured Notes, and Vertical Topco III, in the case of the Senior Notes, will be required to fund the relevant Issuer in such aggregate amounts as are required in order to enable the Issuers to pay any funding shortfall, including Escrow Account fees, negative interest on the Escrow Accounts’ balances and costs and accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, owing to the holders of the Notes on such special mandatory redemption date (the “Escrow Equity Commitment”), pursuant to the Equity Commitment Letter. The holders of the Notes will not have any direct right to enforce the Escrow Equity Commitment, and must rely on the Issuers’ respective rights to enforcement under the Escrow Equity Commitment. In addition, the conditions applicable to the special mandatory redemption may be waived by holders of the Notes representing a majority in aggregate principal amount of the Notes outstanding. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; _Special Mandatory Redemption,” “Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption,” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—If the conditions precedent to the release of the Escrowed Property are not satisfied, the Issuers will be required to redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Accounts may not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption without relying on the Escrow Equity Commitment.”_ Certain Covenants . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Indentures will limit, among other things, the ability of the Issuers and the restricted subsidiaries to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - create or incur certain liens; - make certain restricted payments; - make certain investments; - impose restrictions on the ability of their subsidiaries to pay dividends or make other payments to the Issuers; - engage in certain transactions with affiliates; - transfer, receive or sell certain assets including subsidiary stock; - consolidate or merge with other entities; and - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. Each of the covenants in Indentures is subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain _Covenants” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Certain Covenants.”_ 29 ----- Certain of the covenants will be suspended if and for as long as we achieve investment grade ratings. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes— _Certain_ _Covenants—Termination_ _of_ _Covenants_ _on_ _Achievement_ _of Investment Grade Status” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Certain Covenants—Termination of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status”._

Section Title: THE OFFERING
Subsubsection Text: Considerations . . . . . . . . . . . . .** For a discussion of certain U.S. federal income tax considerations of an investment in the Notes, see “Certain Tax Consequences—Certain U.S. _Federal Income Tax Considerations.” You should consult your own tax_ advisor to determine the U.S. federal, state, local and other tax consequences of an investment in the Notes. Transfer Restrictions . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes and the Note Guarantees thereof have not been registered under the Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction and will not be so registered. The Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. See “Transfer Restrictions.” Holders of the Notes will not have the benefit of any exchange or registration rights. Risk Factors . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Investing in the Notes involves substantial risks. You should consider carefully all the information in this offering memorandum and, in particular, you should evaluate the specific risk factors set forth in the “Risk _Factors” section before making a decision whether to invest in the Notes._ No Prior Market . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no market. Although the Initial Purchasers of the Notes have advised us that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market making at any time without notice. Accordingly, there can be no assurance that an active trading market will develop for the Notes. Listing . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Application will be made to the Authority for the listing of the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange. There can be no assurance that the Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained. The Exchange is not a regulated market pursuant to the provisions of Directive 2014/65/EU on markets in financial instruments, as amended. ERISA . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** See “Certain ERISA Considerations.” Governing Law . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Indentures, the Notes and the Note Guarantees will be governed by the laws of the State of New York. The Intercreditor Agreement will be governed by the laws of England and Wales. Each Security Document will be governed by applicable local laws. Trustee . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Deutsche Trustee Company Limited. Security Agent . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch. Principal Paying Agent . . . . . . . .** Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch.

Ratio of pro forma net senior secured indebtedness to Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA . . . . . . . . . 4.9x Ratio of pro forma net indebtedness to Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 6.2x Ratio of Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA to pro forma interest expense . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . x (1) We define EBIT as income/(loss) before tax, finance income, finance expense and “thyssenkrupp” brand charges, but including certain finance expenses and finance income assigned to EBIT based on economic classification. We define Adjusted EBIT as EBIT, as adjusted for special items as described below. We define Adjusted EBITDA as Adjusted EBIT, as adjusted further by adding back depreciation and amortization expense. We define Lease Adjusted EBITDA as Adjusted EBITDA, as adjusted further for the estimated effect of our adoption of IFRS 16 as if it had been adopted at the beginning of each period presented. See “Presentation of Financial Information— _Non-GAAP Financial Measures—General” for further information on how Lease Adjusted EBITDA is calculated. We define Pro Forma_ Adjusted EBITDA as Lease Adjusted EBITDA, as adjusted further for certain cost savings adjustments as set forth in the tables below. EBIT, Adjusted EBIT, Adjusted EBITDA, Lease Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA are collectively referred to herein as our “EBITDA-based measures.” We believe that our EBITDA-based measures are useful to investors in evaluating our operating performance and our ability to incur and service our indebtedness. We believe that Adjusted EBITDA is useful to investors because it is adjusted for certain items that we believe are not indicative of our underlying operating performance. We believe that Lease Adjusted EBITDA is useful to investors because it gives pro forma effect to the application of IFRS 16 as if it had been adopted at the beginning of the relevant period. See “Presentation of _Financial Information—Non-GAAP Financial Measures—General” for further information on how Lease Adjusted EBITDA is_ calculated. We believe that Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA is useful to investors because it gives effect to cost saving initiatives we expect to implement after the Transactions. Our EBITDA-based measures and ratios are not measurements of our performance or liquidity under IFRS and should not be considered as alternatives to performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles. Our EBITDA-based measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies and have limitations as analytical tools and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our operating results as reported under IFRS. Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and the other EBITDA-based measures presented herein differ from Consolidated EBITDA as defined in the Indentures governing the Notes. Because of these limitations, our EBITDA-based measures should not be considered as measures of discretionary cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will be available to us to service our indebtedness. You should compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on our Financial Statements included elsewhere herein and using these non-GAAP measures only to supplement evaluation of our performance. See “Presentation of Financial Information— _Non-GAAP Financial Measures.”_ 36 ----- Set forth below is a reconciliation of each of EBIT, Adjusted EBIT, Adjusted EBITDA, Lease Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA to net income which we believe is their closest comparable IFRS measure. SUMMARY FINANCIAL AND OTHER DATA
Subsubsection Text: (A) Represents non-recurring expenses in relation to our use of the “thyssenkrupp” brand. In the periods up to September 30, 2019, the Elevator Technology Business was using the “thyssenkrupp” brand under an operating licensing model for which it incurred license fees recognized in profit or loss in other expenses. As of September 30, 2019, the operating licensing model was terminated and thus the license fees we incurred in prior periods are non-recurring and have been added back to EBIT. On September 30, 2019, the Elevator Technology Business entered into a new license agreement with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group for the right to use the “thyssenkrupp” brand for certain classified classes relevant for the Elevator Technology Business in exchange for a one-time fee and with no other recurring expenses after September 30, 2019. In connection with the Acquisition, the License Agreement was amended in March 2020, resulting in the intangible asset representing the right of use of the “thyssenkrupp” brand to be classified as held for sale in accordance with IFRS 5 in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements. The re-classification resulted in a non-recurring, non-cash impairment charge against the intangible asset, which we have added back to EBIT. See “Certain _Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Relationships with the thyssenkrupp Group in the Past—License Agreement” and_ Note 1 to the Audited Combined Financial Statements and to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements. (B) Represents restructuring expenses and net impairment losses plus certain other non-operating income and expense items if such items individually exceed a de minimis threshold of €0.5 million. In the periods presented, the majority of our restructuring costs relate to cost savings programs and operational improvement measures implemented at our European factories, our French, Spanish and German operations and our US operations. The large majority of our net impairment losses in Financial Year 2017 was due to the impairment of trade accounts receivable following a restructuring program in the Middle East, which had been initiated in 2016. Other special items include mainly (i) non-recurring costs related to project re-evaluations following the restructuring program in the Middle East in Financial Year 2016/2017, (ii) restructuring costs in Europe/Africa; legal fees, penalties and remediation costs following inspections in Ontario, Canada and impairments of receivables and inventories in the Middle East in the 2017/2018 Financial Year and (iii) restructuring related costs in Europe/Africa and an unclaimed properties provision (€24 million) already partially recorded previously by thyssenkrupp and then allocated to the Elevator Technology Business in the Financial Year 2018/2019.

Section Title: SUMMARY FINANCIAL AND OTHER DATA
Subsubsection Text: (C) Because we adopted IFRS 16 on October 1, 2019, our income statement information is presented in accordance with IAS 17 for all periods ended on or prior to September 30, 2019, whereas it is presented in accordance with IFRS 16 for all periods thereafter. Our transition to IFRS 16 resulted in an increase of interest expense on leases, an increase of depreciation of lease assets and a decrease of rent expenses on operating leases. Because interest expense and depreciation are both expenses that are added back to net income in calculating Adjusted EBITDA, our adoption of IFRS 16 had a positive impact on our Adjusted EBITDA for the six months ended March 31, 2020. We present Lease Adjusted EBITDA to illustrate the estimated impact IFRS 16 would have had on our Adjusted 37 ----- EBITDA for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 if we had adopted IFRS 16 on April 1, 2019. See “Presentation of Financial _Information—Non-GAAP Financial Measures—General” for further information on how Lease Adjusted EBITDA is calculated._ (D) Our Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve months ended September 30, 2019, has been negatively impacted by corporate cost allocations from thyssenkrupp AG that we do not consider to be representative of our standalone costs going forward because they were allocated retrospectively in accordance with carve-out accounting principles. These cost allocations were calculated as a proportion of thyssenkrupp AG’s overall corporate costs, based on allocation metrics such as revenue contribution of the Elevator Technology Business rather than a systematic review of the organization, FTEs and infrastructure that would be required to perform the relevant functions as a stand-alone business, and negatively impacted our Adjusted EBITDA by €98 million, €71 million, €73 million, €30 million and €16 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year, 2017/2018 Financial Year, 2018/2019 Financial Year, the six months ended March 31, 2019 and the three months ended December 31, 2019, respectively. We incurred actual standalone costs of €10 million in the three months ended March 31, 2020, which included some ramp-up costs that we do not expect to continue, and thus estimate that our actual standalone costs will amount to approximately €30 million per annum going forward. We have therefore taken (i) the €69 million of our combined corporate cost allocations and actual standalone costs during the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 less (ii) our €30 million estimate of actual standalone costs per annum going forward, and added the difference back to Adjusted EBITDA. While we build up additional governance and other functions, the relevant corporate services that comprise part of these standalone costs will be provided to by thyssenkrupp AG via a combination of direct service agreements and the New TSAs, which may impact our estimate of these costs in the short term. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of _Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations—Corporate cost allocations.”_ (E) In connection with the Acquisition, Advent and Cinven commissioned a third-party due diligence report from a global consulting firm to analyze the financial condition and operations of the Elevator Technology Business and its potential for achieving cost savings. This report has identified €240 million in potential cost savings, which we expect to realize through our Transformation Program within 15 to 18 months after July 1, 2020. We give effect to these cost saving initiatives in calculating Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA as if the underlying cost savings had been realized on April 1, 2019. We expect to incur one-off costs amounting to between €240 and €294 million in connection with these initiatives, mainly as a result of (i) voluntary redundancy, early retirement and other severance costs, (ii) staff training costs, (iii) investments in IT to digitize, automate and streamline processes, (iv) investments in existing shared service centers in Europe, Brazil and the U.S., as well as potentially operating new, regional centers in Eastern Europe and Asia and (v) consulting, financial and legal advisory fees in connection with implementing these initiatives. The cost savings adjustments set forth in the following table are based on various assumptions and estimates by external consultants and management regarding the future impact of our cost saving initiatives, including that implementation of the Transformation Program will commence on July 1, 2020 and will be driven by key management, including the Chief Executive Officer of the Target, even prior to the Acquisition Closing Date. We believe this assumption is reasonable because some of the initiatives under the Transformation Program are a continuation of the Target’s existing efficiency measures and the Acquisition is expected to complete during the course of July 2020. This information is inherently subject to significant business, economic and competitive risks and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those assumed in the adjustments below. As a result, while we believe that these adjustments and potential cost savings are reasonable estimates, the actual results and cost savings in any given period may differ from those estimated herein, including because much of the savings we expect to achieve are from procurement initiatives which depend on negotiations with third-party suppliers that are outside our control. We may not be able to realize these cost savings, either in the amount or within the timeframe we currently anticipate, and the costs of achieving these cost savings may be higher than expected. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business—We may fail to _achieve the targeted benefits from restructuring and operational improvement measures” and “Forward-Looking Statements.”_

Section Title: SUMMARY FINANCIAL AND OTHER DATA
Subsubsection Text: (a) Represents expected cost savings related to our commercial operations initiatives, comprising (i) €2 million of cost savings from organizational efficiency as a result of restructuring and centralizing our sales support teams, including by shifting FTEs to low cost countries, and (ii) €5 million of cost savings from sales force productivity measures, such as administrative process improvements, faster technical sales due to offering fewer customization options and beginning the process (which we expect to take several years) of reducing our offering from 52 to 25 elevator platforms and from nine to five escalator platforms and an increased focus on sales efforts based on product margin potentials and the conversion of New Installation units into Service contracts and later into Modernizations sales. (b) Represents expected cost savings related to our service operations initiatives, comprising (i) €4 million of cost savings from organizational efficiency, including the rationalization of the number of our application engineers, as a result of reducing the number of platforms in our offering and standardizing our services, (ii) €2 million of cost savings from a reduction in the number of our service centers, particularly in the U.S. and (iii) €9 million of cost savings from other initiatives, such as increased productivity of service technicians through process, technology and performance management improvements. 38 ----- (c) Represents expected cost savings related to our procurement initiatives, comprising: i. €45 million of cost savings from (1) the establishment of group-wide supply agreements with global suppliers for key categories of direct materials, such as motors, cables and doors, including through leveraging change-of-control provisions under our existing supplier agreements with local or regional suppliers, (2) increased focus on supplier driven innovation in connection with, among other things, tendering processes, (3) improvements in specification management by standardizing purchases for complex parts and (4) the establishment of business unit sourcing boards to act as advisory panels in key end markets to promote best practices and streamline procurement processes; ii. €11 million of cost savings from shifting from local suppliers to regional suppliers to increase the number of sites served by our suppliers and decrease the number of our total suppliers in order to improve efficiencies; iii. €25 million of cost savings from shifting from local suppliers to regional suppliers to streamline the amount and variety of individually supplied components in order to purchase bundles of different products and higher volumes of specific products to improve purchasing ability; iv. €17 million of cost savings from shifting purchases from our suppliers of local products to products sourced from low cost countries; and v. €34 million of cost savings from other initiatives, such as (1) the utilization of centralized regional lead-buyers to streamline demand-management processes and of defined sourcing hubs to allow for best value and benchmark sourcing through increased spend, price and margin transparency, (2) shifting to suppliers in low cost countries and (3) our commercial operations initiatives to rationalize our product offering and standardize our SKUs. The estimated addressable cost base for our procurement activities was made up of €2.1 billion of direct costs and €0.5 billion of indirect costs for the 2018/2019 Financial Year. (d) Represents expected cost savings related to our other operational initiatives, comprising (i) €28 million of cost savings from (1) increased productivity, (2) a reduction in direct and indirect personnel expenses and (3) a reduction of scrappage costs by decreasing the portion of poor quality production to replicate levels achieved at our Korean plant (where such costs are estimated to be 0.6% of internal sales), particularly at our Middleton plant, (ii) €7 million of cost savings from outsourcing parts and components and (iii) €15 million of cost savings as a result of streamlining production overhead and assembly processes. (e) Represents expected cost savings related to initiatives targeting our general and administrative costs, comprising (i) €20 million of cost savings from attrition savings and organizational efficiency through a leaner operating model and increased automation, including within our shared service centers, and the shifting of FTEs to low cost countries and (ii) €16 million of cost savings from other initiatives. (2) Pro forma net senior secured indebtedness represents the sum of the pro forma consolidated financial debt of the EUR SSN Issuer that is secured by a first-priority lien on the SSN Collateral less the pro forma consolidated cash and cash equivalents of the EUR SSN Issuer, as set forth under “Capitalization.” Pro forma net senior secured indebtedness excludes (i) guarantees of the Senior Notes and of the Private Senior Notes, (ii) all of our lease liabilities (amounting to €330 million) and (iii) amounts which may be drawn under the Revolving Credit Facility to fund cash to the Target Group as of the Acquisition Closing Date. See “Use of Proceeds” and “Capitalization.” (3) Pro forma net indebtedness represents the pro forma consolidated financial debt of the SUN Issuer, less the pro forma consolidated cash and cash equivalents of the SUN Issuer, each as set forth under “Capitalization.” Pro forma net indebtedness excludes (i) all of our lease liabilities (amounting to €330 million) and (ii) amounts which may be drawn under the Revolving Credit Facility to fund cash to the Target Group as of the Acquisition Closing Date. See “Use of Proceeds” and “Capitalization.”. (4) Pro forma interest expense represents the estimated interest expense of the Group on a pro forma basis for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, after giving effect to the Transactions as if they had occurred on April 1, 2020, subject to the assumptions set forth under “Use of Proceeds.” Pro forma interest expense includes commitment fees payable on the Revolving Credit Facility, but excludes any interest expense in respect of amounts which may be drawn under the Revolving Credit Facility to fund cash to the Target Group as of the Acquisition Closing Date. See “Capitalization.” Pro forma interest expense is presented for illustrative purposes only and does not purport to represent what our interest expense would have actually been had the Transactions occurred on April 1, 2019; nor does it purport to project our interest expense for any future period or our financial position at any future date. 39 -----

Subsubsection Text: _The following tables present our summary financial information and have been derived from, and should be read in conjunction with, our Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements that have been prepared in accordance with IFRS and are included elsewhere herein and the sections entitled “Presentation of Financial Information”, “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations”, “Selected Financial Information”, “Use of Proceeds” and “Capitalization”. We have extracted (i) the combined historical financial information of the Elevator Technology Business for the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years from the Audited Combined Financial Statements and (ii) the consolidated historical financial information of the Elevator Technology Business as of and for the six months ended March 31, 2019 and 2020 from the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements, in each case, included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. As the Elevator Technology Business did not exist as a separate group and since all companies and operating activities within the Elevator Technology Business were under the common control of thyssenkrupp AG, in each case, prior to the Reorganization, the financial information presented as of and for the financial years ended September 30, 2017, 2018 and 2019 has been prepared on a combined basis. Effective with the Reorganization, the Elevator Technology Business came into existence as a separate group and therefore, the financial information presented for the Target and its consolidated subsidiaries as of and for the six months ended March 31, 2019 and 2020 was prepared on a consolidated basis. There are important differences between the Elevator Technology Business as presented in the Audited Combined Financials as of and for the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years and the business carried out by the Target and its subsidiaries as presented in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements as of and for the six months ended March 31, 2019 and 2020. See “Presentation of Financial Information—Basis of Preparation” and our Financial Statements included elsewhere herein. The independent auditor’s report on the Audited Combined Financial Statements is qualified due to issues regarding local book keeping and financial reporting processes, which led to qualified, adverse or disclaimer of opinions on the financial information of certain entities of the Elevator Technology Business’s Operating Unit Spanish Latin America in several instances as of September 30, 2018 and 2017 and for the financial years ended September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017. The auditor’s qualification does not pertain to the combined statement of financial position as of September 30, 2019 included in the Audited Combined Financial Statements. In the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements, the issues relating to the Elevator Technology Business’s Operating Unit Spanish Latin America described above still remained for the six-month period ended March 31, 2019. See “Presentation of Financial Information” and our Financial Statements included elsewhere herein. The financial information of the Group for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, is unaudited and has been calculated by taking the financial information for the six months ended March 31, 2020 (as derived from the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements) and adding it to the difference between the results of operations for the year ended September 30, 2019 (as derived from the Audited Combined Financial Statements) and the interim financial information for the six months ended March 31, 2019 (as derived from the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements). The financial information for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020 constitutes a Non-GAAP Measure (as defined below), has not been audited or reviewed by our auditors, is not required by or presented in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles and has been prepared for illustrative purpose only. This information is not necessarily representative of our results of operations for such period or any future period or any financial position at any past or future date. This offering memorandum also includes certain unaudited pro forma financial information of the SUN Issuer and the EUR SSN Issuer as of and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, including pro forma net senior secured indebtedness, pro forma net indebtedness and pro forma interest expense, which has been prepared to illustrate the effect of the Transactions as if the Transactions had occurred (i) on March 31, 2020, for the purposes of calculating pro forma net senior secured indebtedness and pro forma net indebtedness and (ii) on April 1, 2019, for the purposes of calculating pro forma interest expense. The pro forma financial information as of and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, has been prepared for illustrative purposes only and does not represent what our indebtedness or interest expense would have been had the Transactions occurred on March 31, 2020, or April 1, 2019, respectively; nor does it purport to project our financial results, indebtedness or interest expense at any future date. The pro forma financial information as of and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, has not been prepared in accordance with IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting_ 32 ----- _standards or in accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X of the Securities Act, the Prospectus Regulation, or any other regulations of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, or any other regulator. Neither the assumptions underlying the pro forma adjustments nor the resulting pro forma financial information as of and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, have been audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted auditing standards. Results of operations for prior years or periods are not necessarily indicative of the results to be expected for the full year or any future period. Prospective investors should bear in mind that certain performance indicators and ratios that we report herein, such as Adjusted EBIT, Adjusted EBIT margin, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA margin, business cash flow (post-restructuring), business cash flow (pre-restructuring), capital expenditures, cash conversion, EBIT, EBIT margin, EBITDA, EBITDA margin, free cash flow, Lease Adjusted EBITDA, operating net working capital, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and other figures for the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, are not measurements of our performance or liquidity under IFRS, U.S. GAAP, German GAAP or any other generally accepted accounting principles, should not be considered as alternatives to performance measures derived in accordance with IFRS, U.S. GAAP, German GAAP or any other generally accepted accounting principles, may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies, have limitations as analytical tools and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our operating results as reported under IFRS._

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We operate in a highly competitive industry and are subject to pricing pressure.
Subsubsection Text: The elevator technology business is a highly competitive sector in a mature industry with a relatively small number of large, established market participants in each of the New Installation, Service and Modernization businesses. In the New Installation business, we mostly compete to sell and install the elevator technology unit, but in some instances, we also compete with market participants that sell elevators, escalators or components to third-party distributors who undertake the installation themselves. Our competitors for the New Installation business are generally consolidated in most of the markets in which we operate, but in certain countries, such as China, there is more fragmentation. Competitors in this business include global elevator manufacturers, such as KONE, Otis and Schindler; elevator technology units of large technology multinationals, such as Hitachi and Mitsubishi, both of which are particularly, but not exclusively, competitive in the Asian markets; and a number of other global, regional and local manufacturers. Key factors affecting competition in the New Installation business include initial product price, brand reputation and image, lead time for delivery, cost of ownership, warranty terms, product safety, technology and innovation, design, quality and performance. In the Service and Modernization businesses, we compete to provide maintenance and modernization services to customers irrespective of which company manufactured and installed the original equipment. The postinstallation maintenance services market is very competitive in its own right. Our customers in our New Installation business are not obliged to engage us for providing post-installation services. Further, most of our service agreements have a duration of one through five years. Therefore, there is potential for substantial churn in our customers, among various service providers in the market. Competitors in these businesses include many of our competitors in the New Installation business who also offer post-installation maintenance and modernization services, as well as companies focused on providing these services exclusively. This is particularly true in China, which has a large number of such service-only companies and, as a result, an especially competitive and fragmented elevator services market. Other areas, such as Europe and North America, have more consolidated service markets, but nonetheless, with high levels of competition. Key factors affecting competition in the Service and Modernization businesses include the quality and scope, pricing and other terms of maintenance and repair services, modernization service and technological support as well as overall customer satisfaction. Technology has become an increasingly important differentiator, as it enables service providers to plan, execute and anticipate maintenance and repair needs more precisely. In addition, our Service business and, to a certain extent, our Modernization business, are dependent on the New Installation business for a material portion of their new customers and serviced units. This is because most customers or units from the New Installation business enter into service agreements or convert into service units, as applicable, with us, and may eventually become customers of the Modernization business. As a result, a decline in customers and installed units in the New Installation business due to increasing competition would most likely have an adverse impact on the number of new customers and serviced units for the Service and Modernization businesses. 42 ----- Revenue generated by our Service business exceeded 40% of our total revenue in each of the years ended September 30, 2017, 2018 and 2019. Loss of customers due to any of the foregoing risks could have a material adverse effect on our overall results of operation and financial condition. In all of our businesses, key competitive risks include falling prices due to competition, and a consequent decline in margins, loss of customers and market share. Some of our competitors may have greater financial, marketing and operating resources than us, positioning them to potentially maintain or increase their market shares to our detriment. Companies with larger pools of service and maintenance customers than us benefit from their incumbent status with those customers and the recurring revenue generated by their service contracts. Our competitors could adapt more quickly to changes in customer requirements, technological developments and market trends than we do, differentiate themselves more effectively, for example by using technological innovation to develop a disruptive elevator model, or improve the functionality or performance of their products and services more quickly or in a more cost-effective manner. Some of the smaller service companies with which our Service and Modernization businesses compete may be more agile and price-competitive in their local markets and may as a result, undercut our ability to win new customers and retain the existing ones. If we are not able to compete effectively, our market share may reduce, there may be further pressure on our prices and our sales and margins may decline, all of which could in turn have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial position and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Our future business success depends on our ability to respond to evolving market trends with innovative products and services on competitive terms.
Subsubsection Text: The elevator technology market is characterized by a degree of technological change, as well as by product enhancements and developments, especially in the service and modernization markets. Our future success is therefore dependent on our ability to anticipate customer needs, develop and market new products and services and differentiate our product and service offerings from those of our competitors on a timely basis and on commercially attractive terms. Changes in customer requirements and preferences, new substitute technologies or evolving industry standards and practices could render our existing products obsolete or less attractive. In particular, the elevator technology market is currently subject to a number of market trends and technical developments to which we are required to respond. The trend towards digitalization and other advances has led to a growth in potential new applications across the elevator and escalator markets, such as so-called smart elevators and escalators and smart buildings, which use digital technology to enhance efficiency and performance, leading in turn to higher customer expectations. For example, customers are increasingly demanding that their elevators deliver reduced travel and waiting time, more customized and convenient travel, higher safety and quality standards and increased energy efficiency. In order to develop suitable solutions for such changing customer expectations, we have made in the past, and we expect we will continue to make in the future, substantial investments into research and development. There can be no assurance, however, that these efforts will be successful or that potential customers will not prefer solutions offered by our competitors. Moreover, developing new products and product lines is complex, time-consuming and costly, and involves a high degree of risk. Our ability to bring new products to the market may require both significant external funding and reinvestment of profit, including to acquire additional equipment and production capacity. Delays may occur irrespective of these efforts, resulting in forgone sales revenue and reputational damage. Moreover, market developments are difficult to predict and our products and technologies may not gain as wide an acceptance as we expected at the time of our investment. For example, we have recently launched products such as “MAX,” our cloud- based maintenance tool, and have products in the development pipeline, such as our MULTI elevator system, in which we have invested considerable time and money. It is not yet clear whether these products will win widespread customer acceptance or meet our financial expectations in a timely manner, if at all. Furthermore, the development and marketing of new products can lead to cost overruns in case of inaccurate planning and budgeting. If we fail to adapt to prevailing trends and customer requirements in a timely manner or if our products and services do not gain market acceptance or experience significant cost overruns, our investments in research and development may not yield expected returns, our market share could reduce and our reputation may be impacted. Any or all of these could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects. 43 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The outbreak of COVID-19 and its global economic impact may materially affect our business and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our business could be adversely affected by the outbreak of contagious diseases, including the recent outbreak of COVID-19. COVID-19 was first announced in December 2019 in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China and since then has spread to most regions of the world including Europe, Asia, North America and South America. Following the outbreak of COVID-19 in other countries, the World Health Organization declared COVID-19 to constitute a global pandemic. COVID-19 has resulted in lockdowns and various levels of restrictions of movement being imposed globally, including most countries in which we sell our products and services. The restrictions include curtailing travel, closure of schools, prohibitions of mass gatherings, mandatory remote working, and in some countries, the ability to access construction sites and office buildings. Specifically to our business, all the regions in which we operate our Elevator and Escalator division were affected by varying degrees. The Access Solutions division has been affected in each of its home solutions and airport solutions offerings. See “Summary—Recent Developments—Coronavirus (COVID-19).” Measures and restrictions by governments have caused and may continue to cause the overall macroeconomic conditions in the regions in which we operate and the end-markets in which we sell our products and services to deteriorate. Were a recession to occur, we cannot predict the length of such recession or the short- and long-term impact it may have on the global economy or our business specifically. Any or all such consequences may have an adverse impact on our business and results of operations. The extent of the impact of COVID-19 on our operational and financial performance will depend on future developments, including the duration and spread of the outbreak and related travel advisories and restrictions and the impact of COVID-19 on the overall economy and pace of its overall recovery, all of which are highly uncertain and cannot be predicted. In addition, COVID-19 may delay or diminish the global trend of increasing urbanization, which could reduce global demand for new construction and therefore impact our business. According to IHS, global residential construction spending is expected to decline by 1.5% in 2020, as opposed to pre-COVID-19 estimates of a growth of 1.9%. Further, global non-residential construction is expected to decline by 1.7% in 2020, as opposed to pre-COVID-19 estimates of a growth of 1.5%. There are no comparable recent events that provide us with guidance, and so we cannot assure you that COVID-19 and its consequent economic effects, or any future outbreak of another virus or other contagious diseases, will not have a material adverse effect on our business and results of operations. To the extent COVID-19 continues to adversely affect our business, operations, financial condition and operating results, it may also have the effect of heightening other risks described in this section, such as those related to indebtedness, our need to generate sufficient cash flows to service our high level of indebtedness, and our ability to comply with the covenants contained in the agreements that govern our indebtedness.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to adjust our personnel and production capacity in line with demand for our products and services.
Subsubsection Text: Demand for our products and services is a function of a wide range of factors, including market cyclicality and other dynamics, and can be difficult to predict. In particular, the New Installation business is closely linked with the construction sector and is therefore exposed to significant fluctuations in construction activity levels. Economic uncertainty, particularly economic downturns, may make it difficult for us to estimate the optimal level of production capacity, to match our workforce size with conditions in the affected markets and to predict our future working capital requirements. From time to time we have experienced, and we may experience in the future, under-utilization of our production and installation personnel capacity at several of our production facilities as a result of overestimating demand for our products and services. Capacity under-utilization may result in lower returns on the capital invested in building such capacity, write-offs on fixed assets and lower product prices, as well as personnel and other costs associated with maintaining an unnecessarily large workforce, each of which can result in reduced profit margins. We use measures such as flexible work hours, outsourcing of certain tasks, temporary workers and production network configuration to calibrate production and personnel capacity. However, these measures may be inadequate if the decline in demand for our products and services is greater than expected. In addition, we may not be able to adjust production capacity or personnel in response to economic or market downturns as planned for political, regulatory or legal reasons, such as employment laws and collective agreements that limit our ability to adjust the size of our workforce in certain jurisdictions, including in member states of the European Union. Restructuring measures in connection with capacity adjustments, such as those we have undertaken in our Middleton, Neuhausen and other manufacturing facilities, could also lead to significant one-off costs. 44 ----- Conversely, if we underestimate demand and have inadequate capacity to meet customer requirements, we may be compelled to turn away business or miss shipping and project deadlines, resulting in contractual penalties, loss of customers and market share, loss of revenue and damage to our reputation. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Products that do not meet customer specifications or that contain defects or errors could result in significant costs for us, including from warranty and product liability claims.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to the risk of product defects and defective installation, maintenance or modernization services. Our New Installation products typically include a contractual one to three year warranty period, but may be subject to a warranty period of up to according to statutory building laws, depending on the applicable legislation. The risks are especially present when products are first introduced or when new versions or enhancements of existing products are released. When the potential for systemic product defects is higher, such a defect may impact an entire class of products. Product defects or negligence in the provision of services, or allegations of such, can give rise to contractual warranty, product liability, negligence and other claims. This can be the case even if the product defect in question is caused by a faulty component or equipment provided by a third-party supplier. Moreover, we are often contractually required to indemnify customers for damages or losses resulting from defective products or negligently performed services. Product defects may also necessitate costly product recalls. In addition, defects in our products could have severe consequences on end-users and third parties, including injury and loss of life. In the event of an accident involving our products or services, we could be subject to claims for negligence, claims in relation to fatal accidents, personal injury, physical damage, product liability and other lawsuits. Such lawsuits and other similar proceedings can be expensive to defend and may divert the attention of management and other personnel, regardless of the ultimate outcome. While we have a third-party product liability insurance program, there can be no assurances that such insurance will provide coverage against all potential liabilities or that we will be able to maintain such insurance on commercially reasonable terms, if at all. Similarly, we generally record warranty provisions in our accounts based on past experience and known claims, but there can be no assurance that such provisions will be adequate for any liability ultimately incurred as a result of potential product defects or negligence in connection with any of our businesses. In addition, product defects could require costly product re-designs, recall actions and could damage our reputation, which could in turn harm our customer relationships and lead to reduced sales. It is also possible that product defects could result in criminal liability for members of our management regarding their conduct relating to the relevant product defect, including charges of involuntary homicide or negligent physical injury, which could also damage our reputation and divert the attention of management from its responsibilities. Any of the foregoing risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Our products and services are subject to a range of different legal and regulatory requirements worldwide, compliance with which is costly and burdensome and non-compliance with which may result in significant costs and liabilities.
Subsubsection Text: Our products and services must comply with a broad range of complex legal and regulatory requirements in the numerous jurisdictions in which we operate. Such laws and regulations include, among others, building codes, health and safety regulations, industry standards, laws governing public bidding processes, and labor laws governing local employee and sub-contractor relationships. Such laws and regulations may vary substantially by jurisdiction, and even within certain jurisdictions. For example, within the United States, each individual state has adopted a specific building code which references standards for elevators and escalators and which is based, in most cases, on the International Building Code (“IBC”), in some cases with local variations. Within the EU, an array of directives and regulations relating to lifts and public safety apply to our business, including technical lift regulations and safety norms for existing lifts, complemented by laws promulgated by individual member states such as Germany, France, Italy and Spain. Other key jurisdictions where we do business, including mainland China, have their own building codes, safety regulations and other laws and regulations which apply to our products and services. Many jurisdictions regularly revise and update these regulations. In addition, we are subject to an array of labor laws in the markets where we do business, which are particularly restrictive in Europe, but can also impact our business in all of our other markets. For example, in South Korea the government recently passed a directive regulating the degree and conditions under which companies can rely on local sub-contractors, due to which we will need to employ more service technicians on our rolls to perform 45 ----- services directly and also employ two service technicians for certain services, such as monthly maintenance. The laws and regulations applicable to our products and services can vary considerably in their content, interpretation and enforcement from jurisdiction to jurisdiction. As a result, our cost of compliance with all applicable legal and regulatory requirements is considerable, and such costs may increase further in the future, given the expected stricter enforcement by regulators globally, particularly in the areas of safety and energy efficiency. Such laws and regulations are also subject to change on short notice, imposing an additional compliance burden on us. Any changes to the laws and regulations governing our products and new product approvals could require modifications to our products as well as our manufacturing equipment, requiring additional labor and material costs in order to ensure compliance. A violation by us of applicable laws or regulations or the failure to meet legal or regulatory standards could lead to the imposition of penalties, fines, damages, recalls, restrictions on or prohibitions of business operations and other adverse consequences. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations, reputation and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Demand for our products and services depends on economic conditions globally and in our principal regional areas of activity.
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations depend significantly on economic conditions globally and in our key jurisdictions of activity, particularly in Europe/Africa, the Americas and Asia/Pacific. We operate in these key jurisdictions mainly through our Europe/Africa, Americas and Asia/Pacific segments, which contributed 26%, 41% and 28%, respectively, of our Operating Segments’ total sales in the 2018/2019 Financial Year, with the outstanding percentage contributed by our remaining segments for which we do not present geography-based sales splits. Demand for our products and services, especially in the New Installation business, is driven by activity levels and capital expenditures within the industries we serve, in particular the residential and commercial construction industry. These industries are highly cyclical and sensitive to changes in global economic conditions, GDP growth in the relevant markets, inflation, the interest rate environment and conditions in the credit markets. This cyclicality may result in significant fluctuations in revenue and profitability from period to period and over the business cycle. Our New Installation business also serves customers in certain specialized industry segments, mainly industrial applications and large infrastructure projects (such as subway or metro stations), which are also sensitive to economic conditions. A weak or uncertain economic environment in one of our key regions or globally may result in fewer construction, industrial and infrastructure projects and lower business volume for our customers. This, combined with rising costs of capital and low business and consumer confidence, may cause customers to delay, cancel, or altogether refrain from New Installation of our products and lower our revenues from the segment. Even if some customers were to proceed with new installations, the decline in activity levels in a particular region would likely lead to more competition and pricing pressure on our New Installation business, which could adversely impact our margins. This risk may be more pronounced in countries like China, where our New Installation business accounts for a higher proportion of revenue than in other regions, and where demand for new installations has experienced downturns in the past due to excessive housing supply and restrictive government policies on new construction in certain metropolitan cities. Our Service and Modernization businesses are generally impacted to a lesser extent than New Installations by an economic downturn as customers in most markets are legally obligated to comply with elevator services and safety requirements. However, our New Installation business is an important source of new customers for the Service and Modernization businesses. Therefore, a decline in our New Installation business could therefore eventually lead to fewer new customers in our Service and Modernization businesses, resulting in lower sales as well as more competition for services and modernization contracts, putting pressure on the prices we charge for our services and consequently resulting in lower margins. Poor economic conditions could also encourage customers to delay modernization initiatives. Volatility in global financial markets, higher interest rates, unemployment rates, trade policy and conflicts, consumer confidence, lower corporate earnings, tighter credit conditions and public and private debt levels could impact economic conditions. Furthermore, geopolitical tensions, terrorism, natural catastrophes, pandemics or other unforeseen events may prompt unexpected, short-term responses from the markets and declines in demand for our products, leading to lower sales. For example, Europe, our largest geographic market, is facing sharply slowing economic growth and a number of structural issues, including lingering debt crises and political instability in certain EU member states and deteriorating confidence in the institutions of the European Union, each of which could pose a threat to future European integration and cause prolonged economic uncertainty or an economic downturn. In addition, economic and financial conditions may continue to be adversely affected by the United Kingdom’s exit from the European Union. 46 ----- Global economic developments are also currently subject to a high degree of uncertainty with respect to the stability of the global trade and tariff framework. The trade war between the United States and China, withdrawal from or renegotiation of bi- and multi-lateral trade agreements by the United States, or any countermeasures by regional or global trading partners, including the European Union, could have a negative impact on the global economic environment. These could result in lower investment in residential and commercial construction projects, as well as industrial and infrastructure projects, and a decline in construction levels generally, leading in turn to less demand for our products. In China, one our most significant individual sales areas, economic growth decelerated to the slowest annual rate in decades in 2018, as consumer spending and capital investment declined amid the country’s trade conflict with the United States. The slowing Chinese economy has reportedly adversely impacted the credit supply, triggering defaults and other payment problems by several construction companies and leading to suspensions of certain high-rise projects. Any economic slowdown, downturn or uncertainty, either globally or locally in our markets, could have a material adverse effect on demand for our products and services. Such events could put pressure on the prices we charge, resulting in declines in our sales and margins and have a material adverse effect on our business, overall financial condition and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Our business could be adversely affected by the imposition of protectionist measures, including tariffs and other barriers to trade.
Subsubsection Text: As an international business with production and sales operations across important trading regions, we face significant risks from a further escalation of tensions between the United States and its trading partners, as well as a general increase in protectionist measures affecting global trade. Tariffs and other barriers to trade can adversely affect us in a variety of ways, including by causing less favorable conditions for the import and export of parts and components and by increasing our cost of production. Barriers to trade can increase the cost of raw materials, such as steel and aluminum, increasing the cost of parts and components used to manufacture our products, as well as of spare parts used in our Service and Modernization businesses. For example, our US operation imports a significant number of components from external suppliers in China, such as electronic parts and guiderails, which have become more expensive as a result of the ongoing trade tensions between the United States and China. Trade barriers can also disrupt our operations within certain countries or markets by delaying imports and exports or by interrupting international supply lines upon which we rely.
