Finally, trade barriers can also adversely affect demand for our products indirectly through the impact they have on our customers’ business growth and investment activities and their impact on general economic conditions. See “—Demand for our products and services depends on economic _conditions globally and in our principal regional areas of activity.”_ Any barriers to trade or other protectionist measures may limit our ability to make use of opportunities from globalized supply chains and other advantages of the global trading system, increase our cost of production or our products’ prices and could therefore undermine our competitiveness and have an adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are dependent on third-party suppliers, contractors and distributors.
Subsubsection Text: We are dependent on third-party suppliers, contractors and sub-contractors and distributors for the timely delivery of high-quality materials, components and equipment for the manufacture of our products. _Dependence on suppliers._ If a supplier fails to provide materials, components and equipment as contractually required, or provides materials, components and equipment that are not of an acceptable quality or which contain defects or errors or which are delivered on a delayed basis, we may be required to source those supplies or equipment services from alternate sources. This may result in higher costs, production downtime, inventory backlogs, costly adjustments to or a re-engineering of our products and delayed completion of project milestones. If we use low quality or defective components or equipment, we may be exposed to contractual warranty, product liability, negligence and other claims. Supply and service interruptions can be the result of a number of factors beyond our control, including product shortages, labor strikes, capacity constraints, regulatory issues or financial distress of the supplier. The risk of supply interruptions is heightened in instances in which we rely on a small number of suppliers for the provision of a product or service. In addition to the risk of supply interruptions, the supplier of a key product or service potentially could exert significant bargaining power over price, quality, warranty or other terms relating to the product or service. We seek to mitigate such risks through the use of supply agreements containing provisions designed to avoid such scenarios and aim to have at least two suppliers for important parts and components. However, such agreements and measures may not always be effective. 47 ----- _Dependence on contractors and sub-contractors._ In addition to external suppliers of goods, we also depend on the services of third-party contractors and sub-contractors for a significant portion of the work performed, especially in our New Installation business. We may not always be able to hire qualified contractors and sub-contractors at acceptable prices, especially during periods of high demand when our competitors may block the installation capacities of our main installation contractors, rendering them unavailable to us. If we are unable to hire qualified contractors or sub-contractors, our ability to maintain our customer relationships could be impaired. Moreover, we remain responsible for the successful completion of our contractors or sub-contractors’ work towards our own contractual partners. As a result, we may be subject to significant reputational damage, losses or liabilities if contractors or sub-contractors fail to perform, if serious accidents involving the contractors or sub-contractors occur, or should the contractors or sub-contractors become insolvent. In addition, a failure by a third-party contractor or sub-contractor or supplier to comply with applicable laws, rules or regulations could negatively impact our business and reputation and could result in fines, penalties, suspension or, in the case of government contracts, even debarment, which in turn could adversely impact our reputation and financial results. Although we seek to shift liability for contractor or sub-contractor underperformance, contract breach or damages to the specific contractor or sub-contractor via contract, such provisions may not always be effective, in particular where the contractor or sub-contractor in question is insolvent or otherwise unable to meet its obligations, or in jurisdictions where such contracts may not always be reliably enforced by local courts. Many jurisdictions also have laws regulating the treatment of contractors and sub-contractors, with which we must comply. See “—We are subject to various laws and regulations relating to the protection of the _environment, health and safety worldwide, compliance with which can be burdensome and non-compliance with which may result in substantial costs.” Dependence on distributors._ We are also dependent on third-party distributors for our sales in a number of jurisdictions. We have a global sales and services network covering a majority of the world’s countries. More than 60 countries are covered by our own field operations, whereas approximately 40 countries, most of which are in emerging markets, are served via distributors. In some countries, where we have our own field operations, we nonetheless use distributors as an additional sales channel. Our distributing partners sell our products and services either on an exclusive or non-exclusive basis. Although we believe that our distributors are properly incentivized to sell our products, there is no assurance that they will not favor a competitor’s products, particularly where we have a non-exclusive sales relationship with them, or that they will sell our products as effectively as our competitors sell their products in those markets, or that our distributors will always succeed in meeting our sales targets and other expectations. If our distributors fail to effectively sell our products, this could have a material adverse effect on our New Installations sales, and we could lose market share to our competitors in those markets. Any of the foregoing risks relating to our dependence on third-party suppliers, contractors and distributors could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition or prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We may fail to achieve the targeted benefits from restructuring and operational improvement measures.
Subsubsection Text: Efficiency improvements and cost savings are crucial for us to maintain our competitiveness and improve our profitability. In recent years, our most significant operating expenses have been on an upward trend, pressuring our profit margins. Our future success will therefore depend, in part, on our ability to implement operational improvement measures. Such measures could seek to simplify our product portfolio, increase manufacturing efficiency through restructuring production and optimize supply chains. They could also seek to reduce our SG&A expenses by streamlining management, centralizing administrative costs and improving IT systems. In developing our financial targets relating to sales growth and profitability, we have made certain assumptions about the financial impact that these operational improvement measures will have on our future financial results. However, there can be no assurance that these initiatives will yield the targeted benefits, or that they will not entail higher implementation costs than expected or take longer to implement than expected. In addition, the adjustments to Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA annualizing the impact of certain cost saving measures and adding back expected synergies from certain operational improvement initiatives presented in this offering memorandum should be treated with caution when making an investment decision. The assumptions we have made with respect to Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA that we present in this offering memorandum are based on our current estimates and they involve risks, uncertainties, assumptions and other factors that may cause actual results, performance or achievements to be materially different from any anticipated future results, performance or achievements expressed or implied by such adjusted financial information. Our anticipated cost 48 ----- saving and operational run-rate synergies are based upon assumptions about our ability to implement cost saving measures in a timely fashion and within certain cost parameters. Our ability to achieve planned cost saving and operational run-rate synergies is dependent upon a significant number of assumptions, some of which may be beyond our control, including the development of the markets for our products and services, political, legal, fiscal, market and economic conditions, regulatory developments, and tariff and wage increases. If one or more of our underlying assumptions regarding these measures proves to have been incorrect, these efforts could lead to substantially higher costs than planned and we may not be able to realize fully, or realize in the anticipated timeframe, the expected benefits from our cost saving and operational measures. In addition, cost saving and operational efficiencies from improved production processes may not be able to be sustained due to changes in customer needs, changes in regulations, availability and cost of materials or other cost variables. Our new business initiatives could also result in unintended consequences, such as the loss of key customers and suppliers and strikes and other industrial actions by our employees, which could undermine the benefits of the operational improvements by disrupting production and leading to different costs. Operational efficiency measures generally require a significant amount of management attention and resources, which may disrupt or otherwise have an adverse effect on our ongoing business operations. These factors may offset the cost savings we anticipate and which we have included in our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA. Consequently, our inability to realize our anticipated cost savings could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operation.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to project management and execution risks in connection with our New Installation business.
Subsubsection Text: Our installation work may require complex project management and execution by our supervisors, employees and sub-contractors, in particular to ensure completion deadlines are met and costs are managed to ensure appropriate margins. Costs and contractual completion dates are based on many assumptions which include, in particular, the cost and availability of labor, equipment and materials, and can be adversely affected by local weather conditions, delays in the commencement of construction work, strikes or other work stoppages, quality problems with products and components, the timely performance of suppliers and sub-contractors or other third parties and unanticipated technical problems, among other events over which we may have no or only limited control. We have in the past borne time and cost overruns due to unforeseen reasons, including project-delay costs not chargeable to customers, and re-work issues and in some cases, suffer consequential contractual penalties. If we are unable to control these factors in our ongoing or future projects, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Our business depends on the price and availability of high-quality raw materials, parts and components.
Subsubsection Text: We purchase a broad range of components and parts in connection with our manufacturing operations. These include electric and electronic components like traction machines and printed circuit board assembly, as well as mechanical components like guiderails, shaft/cabin doors, speed governors and escalator steps, among others. These components often contain raw materials such as steel, aluminum and rare earths (which are used in magnets), and therefore their price and availability is impacted by fluctuations in the underlying raw material costs. The cost of parts and components represents a significant portion of our total costs. Prices for raw materials, components and parts are susceptible to fluctuations, driven by global or regional supply/demand dynamics in commodity and end markets, production capacity constraints of suppliers, availability of certain materials, transportation costs, infrastructure failures, government regulations and tariffs, geopolitical events, changes in currency exchange rates, the economic climate and other factors. Price increases attributable to such price fluctuations, along with increasing transportation costs, can create pressure on our profit margins. If the prices of these parts and components increase in the future, and we are not able to at least partially pass such increases on to customers in the form of higher prices or otherwise mitigate costs, this could negatively affect our profitability. We do not hedge our exposure to raw material price increases. We are also subject to the risk of supply shortages for key raw materials used in our parts and components. A shortage of these could arise from increases in demand due to strong economic and market conditions, decreases in extraction and production due to natural disasters, political instability or unrest or production limits imposed in extracting and producing countries. For example, China, which is currently the predominant producer of rare earth elements, has limited the export of such elements in the past and is increasingly using other mechanisms, such as an export licensing system or the imposition of higher raw material duties, which has caused adverse price movements in the past and could limit access to such materials. Shortages in the availability of key parts and components due to shortages in the underlying raw materials may result in production shortfalls that could, if significant, result in the inability to fulfill customer orders and complete projects, and result in a loss of business 49 ----- volume. Any of the foregoing risks could have a material adverse effect on our reputation, business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Unforeseen business interruptions at production facilities or other operational problems may lead to production bottlenecks or project delays.
Subsubsection Text: Our success depends on the uninterrupted and reliable operation of our manufacturing operations. Unforeseen disruption of a production facility could be caused by a number of events, including a maintenance outage, power or equipment failure, fires, floods, earthquakes or other natural disasters, social unrest or terrorist activity, work stoppages, public health concerns (including pandemics), regulatory measures or other operational problems. For instance, many of our manufacturing facilities experienced temporary shutdowns due to COVID-19 recently. Serious construction site accidents, particularly those resulting in fatalities, can lead to production disruptions and even lengthy work stoppages caused by regulatory or other official interventions. A prolonged disruption at a manufacturing facility could result in production downtimes or temporary operation at reduced capacity preventing us from completing production orders in a timely manner, loss of business volume, and reduced productivity or profitability at a particular production site. Even less severe problems involving our production facilities, such as missed shipment dates, split shipments, defective software or materials, or logistics problems, could lead to project delays or other problems in our New Installation business. It could also result in significant repair costs and, in severe cases, injuries or loss of life that are not or not completely covered by our insurance coverage. Any production downtime, stoppage at our facilities or project sites, serious accidents or other operational problems and delays, if significant, could have a material adverse effect on our reputation, business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to risks relating to public sector contracts and non-compliance with regulations on public procurement.
Subsubsection Text: We derive a material portion of our revenues from governmental entities, quasi-governmental organizations and state-owned businesses. Projects involving governments or governmental agencies carry various risks inherent in the government contracting process. For example, business generated from public or quasi-public entities may be affected by political and administrative decisions concerning levels of public spending or changes in governments and their economic policies. Decisions to decrease public spending or changes in priorities or other unforeseen issues may result in the termination or downscaling of public sector contracts, which could result in a loss of revenue and limit our recovery of incurred costs, reimbursable expenses and profits on work completed prior to the termination. Contractual non-compliance, failure to comply with procurement regulations and laws regarding the protection of classified information, violation of non-discrimination rules or environmental, health and safety regulations and other improper or illegal activities, may result in various civil and criminal penalties and administrative sanctions, which may include termination of contracts, forfeiture of profits, exclusion from future tenders, suspension of payments, fines and suspensions or debarment from doing business with the government. Government contracts are also often subject to more extensive scrutiny and publicity than other contracts. Any negative publicity related to such contracts, regardless of the accuracy of such publicity, may adversely affect our business and reputation. The realization of any of these risks could have a material adverse effect on our reputation, business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We may fail to successfully identify, enter into or integrate acquisitions and/or successfully execute disposals.
Subsubsection Text: We have made acquisitions and disposals in the past and we anticipate we will enter into such transactions in the future. For example, in May 2019, we announced the acquisition of Nashville Machine Elevator Co., Inc., followed in July by the announcement that we had acquired O’Keefe Elevator Company Inc., both in the United States. Corporate acquisitions and disposals are associated with significant risks. We may not be able to identify suitable acquisition candidates in the future. Even if we do identify a suitable acquisition candidate, we may not be able to finance such acquisition on favorable terms, if at all. Diligence reviews of acquisition targets may not identify all of the material issues necessary to accurately estimate the cost or potential loss contingencies with respect to a particular transaction, including potential exposure to regulatory sanctions resulting from an acquisition target’s previous activities. We may incur unanticipated costs or expenses in connection with such transactions, including post-closing asset impairment charges, expenses associated with eliminating duplicate facilities, litigation and other liabilities, including related to warranties. We may also encounter difficulties in integrating acquisitions with our operations, applying our internal controls processes to these acquisitions or in managing strategic investments. Target companies may be located in countries in which the underlying legal, 50 ----- economic, political and cultural conditions do not correspond to those customary in our key areas of activity or have other national peculiarities with which we are not familiar. Moreover, any planned acquisition may be subject to review and approval by the competition and other regulatory authorities of a number of jurisdictions, which may impede a planned transaction. We may not realize the targets for growth, economies of scale, cost savings, development, production and distribution targets, or other strategic goals that we seek from the acquisition to the extent or in the timeframe anticipated, and the attention of management and other personnel may be diverted for long periods of time. Moreover, the purchase price may prove to have been too high or unforeseen restructuring or integration expenses may become necessary. Failure to successfully complete our corporate acquisitions or the acquisition of equity interests in companies could adversely affect our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects. Furthermore, we may make strategic disposals from time to time. Disposals may result in continued financial involvement in the divested businesses, such as through guarantees or other financial arrangements, following the completion of the respective transactions. Under these arrangements, non- performance by those divested businesses could result in financial obligations for us and could affect our future financial results. In addition, we could be subject to potential liabilities resulting from contractual warranties and indemnities, as well as regulatory risks of not being able to obtain required approvals. The materialization of any of the foregoing risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to foreign exchange translation and transaction risks, which may reduce our operating results, and our hedging activities may not be effective.
Subsubsection Text: Our reporting currency is the euro. However, we conduct our business in a large number of countries across the globe and in several international currencies. In the years ended September 31, 2017, 2018 and 2019, 77% of our net sales were generated by operating subsidiaries with a functional currency (generally the local currency) other than the euro. In terms of our results of operations, the US dollar, the Chinese renminbi, the Brazilian real, the Canadian dollar and the South Korean won are the most important foreign currencies. Any change in exchange rates between foreign currencies and the euro affects our reported results of operations and assets and liabilities when the results of those subsidiaries are translated into euro for reporting purposes. In preparing combined and consolidated financial statements, assets and liabilities of subsidiaries are translated into euro at the foreign exchange rates at the balance sheet date. Income statements of subsidiaries are translated to euro at the average exchange rates for the period. Accordingly, fluctuations in the value of other currencies against the euro reduce or increase these subsidiaries’ contribution to, among other things, our net sales and profit and thus also affect our statement of financial position. Among the factors that affect foreign exchange rates are trade balances, short-term interest rates, differences in relative values of similar assets in different currencies, long-term opportunities for investment and capital appreciation, and other macroeconomic and political developments, including deliberate manipulation by certain countries of their currencies. The exchange rates between the foreign currencies and the euro have fluctuated significantly in recent years and may continue to do so in the future. Unfavorable fluctuations in the values of the currencies in which our international subsidiaries’ financial statements are prepared against the euro could have a material negative impact on our future consolidated financial statements. We are also exposed to transactional risk to the extent our subsidiaries and us execute transactions in a currency other than our functional currency, which arises mainly when we import components from one jurisdiction, incurring a cost in that jurisdiction’s currency, and invoice for our products and installation in the local currency. Our transactional risk exposure is less significant than our translation risk exposure, because we produce and install our products predominantly in our key markets, which generally has the effect of matching the currencies of our costs with those of our sales. Nonetheless, adverse exchange rate movements can impact the profitability of our New Installation business and, to a lesser degree, the Modernization business, to the extent key imported components become more expensive in our local sales areas. We generally manage our transactional foreign currency risk related to booked transactions through different foreign exchange hedging strategies, mainly consisting of derivative foreign exchange instruments and split currency sales contracts. There can be no assurance that we can always enter into such arrangements on acceptable terms, that such arrangements will be available at all times when we wish to use them, that the relevant over-the-counter counterparty will always be able to fulfill our contractual obligations or that these strategies will be sufficient to effectively mitigate the transactional foreign exchange risks described above. In addition, we do not hedge our foreign currency translation risk exposure. 51 ----- Our exposure to exchange rate volatility, our unsecured translation risks and a failure to adequately hedge transactional risks could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to risks related to our international operations.
Subsubsection Text: We have manufacturing operations, customers, and projects worldwide, including in a number of emerging markets. As a result, we are subject to various risks inherent in international business operations, including: - political and economic instability and exposure to potentially undeveloped legal systems; - unexpected or unfavorable changes in foreign laws, regulatory requirements and related interpretations; - difficulties in attracting and retaining locally qualified management and employees; - staffing challenges, including those related to works councils, labor unions and immigration laws; - exposure to economic sanctions, laws and regulations, trade barriers, local content requirements and import and export licensing requirements; - logistical and communications difficulties; - requirements to expend a portion of funds locally and governmental industrial cooperation requirements, coups, increased risk of fraud and political corruption, terrorism, or acts of war; - exposure to local public health issues and the resulting impact on economic conditions; - the complexity of managing competing and overlapping tax regimes; - foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations and currency controls; - greater risk of uncontrollable accounts and longer collection cycles; - the risk of government-sponsored competition; and - controls on the repatriation of cash. In particular, we have significant operations in mainland China and derive a significant portion of our revenues from Chinese customers. As a consequence, we are increasingly subject to economic and political risks in mainland China, as well as certain Chinese laws and regulations regarding foreign-invested enterprises, including foreign currency exchange rules. Moreover, as laws and regulations in mainland China are gradually evolving, there may be uncertainty in their interpretation and enforcement. The administrative and court authorities in China have significant discretion in interpreting and implementing statutory terms. Thus, it may be more difficult for us to evaluate the outcome of administrative and court proceedings in China, should they arise, than in other systems. Our overall success as a global business depends to a considerable extent on our ability to anticipate and effectively manage differing legal, political, social and regulatory requirements and economic conditions and unforeseeable developments. The materialization of local business risks or our inability to adapt to changing conditions in markets outside of our core markets could have significant adverse effects on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to risks arising from legal disputes and government proceedings.
Subsubsection Text: We are, and may in the future become involved in or threatened with, legal proceedings in the ordinary course of our business, including disputes with suppliers, sub-contractors, customers, employees and investors concerning, among other things, breaches of contract, product defects and liability, intellectual property, labor and environmental or shareholder rights issues. Furthermore, we may become subject to proceedings by governmental authorities in connection with our compliance with laws and regulatory requirements, including in the areas of antitrust, tax, environmental and safety matters. For example, we have in the past been fined a total of €319.8 million by the European Commission for violation of EU antitrust rules and currently face private enforcement claims in relation to our participation in elevator cartels in several EU jurisdictions, the current total value of the claims being approximately €150 million. See “—We are exposed to legal risks regarding antitrust _regulation and related enforcement actions and damage claims.” In addition, four fatal accidents in South Korea_ resulting in the deaths of five employees from consortium partners of our South Korean subsidiary have led to criminal and administrative proceedings for alleged violation of various health and safety-related rules, as well as construction industry and elevator regulations in connection with the use of sub-contractors. The alleged 52 ----- violations of health and safety and construction industry regulations may result in the imposition of monetary fines and a suspension of the New Installation business license in South Korea for a period of time ranging from several months to, in a worst case scenario, a much longer period, depending on the final outcome of the proceedings. The alleged violations of the elevator regulations could result in monetary fines as well as suspension of our Service business license in South Korea for at least two years. In addition, we could suffer reputational damage in South Korea as a consequence of the proceedings. Although we do not anticipate lengthy suspensions of the New Installation or Service business licenses to be a likely outcome of the proceedings, there is no guarantee that this will prove to be correct. The outcome of pending or potential future legal or regulatory proceedings is, as a general matter, difficult to predict. If such proceedings are resolved against us, we may be subject to civil, criminal or other penalties, as well as damages, as described above, which may exceed any provisions set aside or any available insurance coverage or be required to change our business practices. Even if we ultimately prevail in legal and regulatory proceedings, defending such actions can be costly and result in the diversion of management’s attention away from our business. Any legal or regulatory proceeding pending or threatened against us could have a material adverse effect on our reputation, business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to legal risks regarding antitrust regulation and related enforcement actions and damage claims.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to antitrust regulation in the European Union and other jurisdictions and therefore face a number of legal risks in connection with anticompetitive business practices. A finding of infringement of antitrust regulations can result in: significant fines, based on, among other factors, the infringing entity’s annual turnover; private enforcement claims by third parties, such as customers and/or competitors; a requirement to change business practices that may result in reduced revenues and/or margins; and reputational damage. In addition, antitrust rules and regulations in certain jurisdictions may impose restrictions on our ability to carry out certain acquisitions, enter into joint ventures, or require forced divestments or the implementation of other measures. The elevator technology industry has seen heightened scrutiny by antitrust authorities in recent years and we have faced, and may in the future face, significant antitrust enforcement actions. In 2007, the European Commission imposed fines on thyssenkrupp AG, the Target’s holding company, and its affiliates as well as other global elevator manufacturers for participation in cartels for the installation and maintenance of lifts and escalators in Germany, Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands in violation of EU antitrust rules. The European Commission decision cited impermissible restrictive business practices, including rigged bids for procurement contracts, price fixing, allocation of projects among competitors, and the exchange of business secrets and other confidential information, among other offenses. thyssenkrupp AG and its subsidiaries were fined €479.7 million in 2007, an amount that was subsequently reduced to €319.8 million. We avoided a fine from similar investigations by the Austrian Federal Competition Authority by acting as a crown witness. Private enforcement claims in connection with these matters have been filed both in and out of court against thyssenkrupp AG and its subsidiaries in a number of jurisdictions, including Belgium, Austria and the Netherlands. The claimants allege that the cartel led to cartel overcharges and umbrella damages in relation to sales by third-party competitors not participating in the cartel, the total value of the claims being approximately €150 million plus interest. Our indemnity under the Share Purchase Agreement for these claims is capped to €29 million and is only applicable for existing claims. We have set aside provisions for those pending claims which, in our opinion, will probably lead to cash outflows. Adverse judgments in these or potential future antitrust matters could result in substantial liability for us, which could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial condition and reputation.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The pricing of cross border transactions is often the subject of negotiation with tax authorities, and any adjustments imposed may lead to the greater or double taxation of profits.
Subsubsection Text: Most national tax authorities follow the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development or United Nations guidelines when considering the arm’s length nature of cross border pricing of goods and services. Adjustments made by a national tax authority may not lead to a corresponding adjustment in the other tax jurisdiction. Also, even where a corresponding tax adjustment is allowed, national tax rates may be different and may therefore increase our overall burden of taxation. Our cross border trade is increasing and, although we benchmark our intercompany pricing regularly, the risk of an adverse adjustment will require constant monitoring, which may require a substantial amount of management resources. Potential discrepancies in the adjustments made by the tax authorities in certain jurisdictions may result in an increased tax burden on our Group. 53 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We may be exposed to transfer price risks in connection with our operating activities.
Subsubsection Text: We take advantage of our international network and centralize our strategic functions. In particular, we transfer and provide goods and services among the companies of the Group by adopting a corporate tax transfer frame model for the billing of intercompany services. There is a risk that tax authorities in individual countries will assess the relevant transfer prices differently from our tax transfer pricing model and address retroactive tax claims against one of our companies. While our tax transfer pricing model has been audited by the competent authorities in certain countries, in others such model is still under discussion with the authorities. A German Group company had been subject to a tax audit related to transfer pricing issues for the financial years 2010 to 2012. According to the view of the German tax authorities, the transfer prices for supplies of products between such Group company and foreign Group companies had been determined incorrectly. Consequently, those transfer prices had been adjusted for the financial years 2010 to 2012. Such adjustment was rolled-over to the financial years 2013 to 2015. Presumably, such transfer pricing adjustments will also be undertaken in the course of audits for subsequent financial years. Also in other cases, there can be no assurance that our transfer prices will be accepted by all the relevant authorities. If they fail to be accepted, this could have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, results of operations and ability to perform our obligations under the Notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are dependent on good relationships with our employees and their trade unions as well as employee representative bodies and stakeholders and are party to a number of collective agreements.
Subsubsection Text: We are dependent on good relationships with our employees, trade unions, employee representative bodies such as works councils (Betriebsräte) and other stakeholders to successfully operate our business. Personnel expenses make up a significant portion of our costs and we are obliged to comply with various collective agreements, such as collective bargaining agreements and works council agreements that are in place with trade unions as well as works councils and other employee representative bodies. Employees at our German locations and at a number of foreign subsidiaries have traditionally been heavily unionized and we regularly conduct, or are involved in, negotiations with the relevant trade unions and employee representative bodies. Any deterioration of these relationships could adversely impact our business operations. We have faced strikes and other types of conflicts with trade unions and our employees in the past and may face them again in the future. In particular, these could come up again when current collective agreements expire or are to be negotiated. Solidarity strikes at other entities within our Group may also occur. Any such strikes, conflicts, work stoppages or other industrial actions may disrupt our production and sales activities, damage our reputation and adversely affect our customer relations, which could in turn have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects. Many collective agreements impose obligations and restrictions on us that may adversely affect our flexibility to undertake adjustments to our workforce, restructurings, reorganizations and similar corporate actions. Approximately 4,751 of our 52,567 employees as of March 31, 2020 enjoy some form of special protection against dismissal based on contractual commitments which are contained in, inter alia, collective agreements (in particular, the “Future Elevator” agreement concluded in March 2020), which means that ordinary dismissals of these employees are in general not possible or, depending on the scope of the additional protection, are subject to special requirements. These commitments are over and above the requirements under applicable labor laws. For example, in March 2020, thyssenkrupp Elevator concluded a collective bargaining agreement “Future Elevator” with German IG Metall in connection with the Acquisition. The “Future Elevator” collective bargaining agreement excludes forced redundancies (Ausschluss betriebsbedingter Beendigungskündigungen) and site guarantees (Standortsicherungszusagen) for the German production and essential service sites and is valid until March 31, 2027. Further, we also have in place a collective agreement including a site guarantee (Standortsicherungszusage) for the site in Neuhausen (Germany) until September 30, 2022. In addition, we have in place collective agreements excluding ordinary dismissals (Beschäftigungssicherung) for Neuhausen until September 30, 2022 and for 390 employees of the German field organization until September 30, 2026, with an option to terminate the agreement on September 30, 2022. Any restructuring or reorganizational measures, including the commercial operations cost savings measures that we succeed in carrying out as part of the Transformation Program, may strain relations with employees and their representatives. This may make it more difficult for us to subsequently negotiate, renew or extend collective agreements in a favorable and timely manner. We may also become subject to new collective agreements, which may increase our operating costs. In addition, our competitors may obtain competitive advantages compared to us, if they succeed in negotiating collective wage agreements or other collective agreements on more favorable terms and conditions. Any failure to negotiate wages and other key employment conditions that are reasonable and fair from our perspective could have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations or prospects. 54 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Our success depends substantially on our ability to attract, hire, train and retain experienced management and personnel.
Subsubsection Text: Our management team has substantial expertise and industry experience and the loss of key members of management could adversely affect our ability to implement our strategic objectives. Further, we are also dependent on personnel that are highly skilled and qualified in scientific, mechanical and technical fields. In some jurisdictions, the technicians servicing our products are required by local regulations to have special qualifications, limiting the supply of such technicians. In the United States, a shortage in qualified technicians has already led to hiring constraints and in the Asia/Pacific market, technicians typically need to receive extensive in-house training before they can start servicing our products. Our success in attracting and retaining such personnel depends on a variety of factors, including the supply of qualified candidates in the relevant market, as well as our compensation and benefit programs, work environment, career development opportunities, commitment to diversity and public image. These factors may pose greater risks in connection with the Reorganization and the Acquisition. Competition for qualified personnel is increasing. There can be no assurance that we will be successful in attracting and retaining experienced management and key technical personnel and any failure to do so could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The value of goodwill, brand names or other intangible assets reported in our financial statements may need to be partially or fully impaired as a result of revaluations.
Subsubsection Text: As of March 31, 2020, our carrying amount of intangible assets, including goodwill, recorded on our consolidated statements of financial position was €1,922 million. Under IFRS, we are required to annually test our recorded goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets and to assess the carrying values of other intangible assets when impairment indicators exist. Because of such tests, we could be required to recognize impairment losses in our income statement, if the carrying value is in excess of the fair value or value in use. Factors that could trigger an impairment of such assets include the underperformance of our business relative to projected future operating results, negative industry developments or economic trends, including changes in borrowing rates or weighted average cost of capital, applicable tax rates or changes in working capital. Should we have to book any impairment losses, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We have a substantial pension and other similar employee benefits-related obligations and are subject to risks related to the development of these obligations and to funding requirements of our pension and other post- employment benefit plans.
Subsubsection Text: We maintain various pension plans providing for company pension and retirement benefits, including defined benefit pension plans, and have other similar plans providing for long-term employee related benefits, mainly in our subsidiaries in Germany, the United States, France, South Korea, the United Kingdom and Switzerland. As of March 31, 2020, our accrued pension obligations amounted to €319 million. The valuation and development of the defined benefit obligation under these plans depends, among other factors, upon agreed contributions rates, future asset performance, longevity and the actuarial profile of the plan participants, level of interest rates used to calculate future liabilities, actuarial assumptions and experience, effectiveness of amendments made to the benefit plans and government regulations and potential court rulings in relation to the plan administration and the calculation. Depending on these variables, future cash funding requirements for our pension plans and other long-term employee related benefit plans could be significantly higher than the amounts estimated as of March 31, 2020, which could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial condition or prospects. If the market value of the plan assets decreases, we may also have to substantially increase our pension provisions. For example, fluctuations in currency, interest rates, actuarial assumptions and changes in the valuation of any funding assets may adversely affect the net liabilities for pension plans and similar plans providing for long-term employee related benefits or, in the case of multi-employer plans like the National Elevator Industry Pension Plan, the failure of any of the key contributing employers to make adequate contributions may adversely affect the value of the plan assets. In such event, we may have to cover the shortfall of funding assets or face significant additional funding obligations, which could have a material adverse effect on our net assets, financial position and results of operations. Any significant increase in the present value of our pension and other obligations related to employee benefits and/or significant decrease in the fair value of the plan assets for a funding of the obligations, could have a material adverse effect on our net assets, financial position and results of operations. 55 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Our insurance coverage may not be sufficient and insurance premiums may increase.
Subsubsection Text: We maintain insurance coverage in relation to a number of risks associated with our business activities, including third-party (product) liability, property damage and business interruption, environmental damage, directors and officers liability, and transport and vehicle insurance. These insurance policies may not cover all losses or damages resulting from the materialization of any of the risks we are subject to. There can moreover be no assurance that our insurance providers will continue to grant coverage on commercially acceptable terms or at all. In addition, there are risks left intentionally uninsured (such as, but not limited to, customer or supplier insolvency, industrial disputes or specific natural hazards), and we therefore have no insurance against these events. Further, agreed limits and other restrictions (for example, exclusions) within the insurance coverage may prove to be too low or inadequate for compensating potential damages or losses, ultimately resulting in a gap in the insurance coverage. If we sustain damages for which there is no or insufficient insurance coverage, or if we have to pay higher insurance premiums or encounters restrictions on insurance coverage, this may have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial position and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Our operations, products, systems and services rely on complex information technology systems and networks that are subject to the risk of disruption and security breaches.
Subsubsection Text: We heavily rely on IT systems and networks to support research, procurement, manufacturing, sales, logistics, business and other processes. In addition, our products, services and systems contain increasingly complex IT. The consistent, efficient and secure operation of IT is therefore critical to the successful performance of our operations and the products, services and systems we sell. Despite IT maintenance and security measures, our IT systems and networks are exposed to the risk of malfunctions and interruptions from a variety of sources, including equipment damage, deficient database design, power outages, computer viruses and a range of other hardware, software and network problems. We have experienced temporary outages in our IT systems in the past. The occurrence of any of these events could compromise the operational integrity of these systems and networks. In the case of technology included in our products, services and systems, malfunctions and disruptions could impact their functionality and jeopardize the safety of users such as elevator passengers. The risk in this respect is heightened as we increasingly sell digitally enhanced products, systems and services. In addition, our IT systems have in the past, been the target of cyber-attacks. For instance, in 2016, cyberattackers gained access to our IT systems, following which we undertook a complex remediation project to improve our systems. Further, in November 2018, a data center in Spain, of which we were a customer, was subject to a cyber-attack, leading to a shutdown of the center’s Internet connection over a weekend. We implement mitigation measures from time to time, as we identify new threats and risks. We cannot assure you that such measures will be effective or that breaches or other cyber-attacks, including industrial espionage or ransomware attacks will not occur in the future. Failure to effectively prevent, detect and remediate security breaches, including attacks on our IT infrastructure by hackers, viruses, employee error or misconduct, or other disruptions could seriously harm our operations and the operations of our customers. Such breaches may result, among other things, in unauthorized access to trade secrets, confidential business information and personal information, data losses, business interruptions, non-compliance with legal requirements, legal claims or proceedings, deterioration in customer relationships and reputational harm. Our shift to using cloud-based maintenance tools in our Service business could amplify the risk of such breaches, since providers of cloud-based products and services have been and are expected to continue to be targeted, and providers of remote connectivity services may be particularly attractive to attackers. Any disruptions of our IT systems, including as a result of cyber-attacks and industrial espionage, may disrupt operations, result in legal liability or reduce the competitive advantage we seek to derive from our investment in advanced technologies. The materialization of any of the above risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to various laws and regulations relating to the protection of the environment, health and safety worldwide, compliance with which can be burdensome and non-compliance with which may result in substantial costs.
Subsubsection Text: Our operations must comply with a broad range of regulatory requirements relating to the protection of health and safety and the environment. We have incurred, and will continue to incur, substantial costs in complying with these laws and regulations. Our operations involve a number of occupational health and safety risks. For example, our employees and sub-contractors who install or maintain our elevator technology products in the field, where they sometimes work 56 ----- at significant heights or at hazardous construction sites, have in the past experienced, and may in the future experience, injuries and fatalities. We continuously monitor our health and safety record and continue to implement safety and health measures to comply with applicable health and safety regulations. Notwithstanding the preventive measures that we have already taken, or may take in the future, there can be no assurance that such measures will be effective in reducing the number of incidents, and any such incidents may result in disruption to our New Installation, Service and Modernization businesses, as well as legal and regulatory consequences and reputational damage. For example, see “Business—Legal Proceedings—Criminal and administrative proceedings _against thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea Ltd.”._ In the area of environmental regulation, our operations are required to comply with laws and regulations relating to air, water and noise pollution, laws regulating greenhouse gas emissions, toxic and other chemicals and materials, waste treatment and disposal methods, and the energy efficiency of production processes, among other things, in various jurisdictions in which we operate. We are also subject to periodic monitoring by environmental protection authorities in various jurisdictions. Any failure on our part to comply with any present or future environmental regulations could result in the assessment of damages or imposition of fines against us, suspension of production or a loss of license to operate certain facilities. In addition, customers increasingly scrutinize the labor and environmental standards of industrial companies, particularly in emerging markets. Additional, more stringent social responsibility and anti-discrimination laws, regulations and practices may be adopted in the future, which may result in an increase in our cost of compliance. In addition, if we fail to comply with such laws, regulations and practices, we may be subject to fines, penalties, legal judgments, customer boycotts or other measures, which may adversely affect our reputation, operating results and financial condition. A finding of non-compliance, or the perception that we have not responded appropriately to growing consumer concern for issues relating to social responsibility, whether or not we are legally required to do so, may adversely affect our business and reputation. If any of the above risks materialize, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Our operations are subject to sanctions, anti-corruption and money-laundering laws and regulations.
Subsubsection Text: In connection with our worldwide business operations, we must comply with a broad range of legal and regulatory requirements relating to export controls, economic sanctions, anti-bribery and corruption laws, and anti-money laundering laws. Our entities and personnel are subject to various economic sanctions, including economic sanctions administered by the United Nations, the EU and the United States (including U.S. sanctions administered by OFAC). These economic sanctions restrict our ability to engage in business dealings with certain countries and persons. Currently, we have direct and indirect business activities in Russia and Myanmar and indirect business activities in Iraq, Belarus, Ivory Coast, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Lebanon, Ukraine, Venezuela and Zimbabwe. All of these countries are subject, to varying degrees, to economic sanctions. However, we conduct restricted party screening of both direct and indirect business counterparties and, insofar as we are aware, have not engaged in any business with any persons targeted by list-based sanctions administered by the United Nations, the European Union, or the United States. We have not engaged in any new direct or indirect business dealings with Iran or Libya since 2018 and 2019, respectively. We are still subject to certain warranty liabilities via our former distributors stemming from historical business in these countries. Furthermore, as of March 2020, we have stopped all new business dealings with Cuba and Sudan, although we are still subject to certain warranty liabilities via our former distributors stemming from historical business in these countries. Our entities and personnel are also subject to various anti-corruption laws, including the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act of 1977 and the United Kingdom Bribery Act of 2010. In addition, our entities and personnel are subject to anti-money-laundering laws and regulations, including the general, non-regulated sector provisions of the EU’s 5th Money-Laundering Directive, which came into force in 2018. Some of the countries in which we operate and make sales are perceived to have higher levels of corruption. Our geographical diversification (including in emerging markets), joint ventures, other business relationships, and employment of local agents, dealers and distributors in the countries where we operate increases our risk of violating applicable anti-corruption laws, economic sanctions, and anti-money laundering laws. Violation of such laws and regulations can be punishable by criminal penalties, civil fines, denial of export privileges, injunctions, asset seizures, debarment from government contracts (and termination of existing contracts), and revocations or restrictions of licenses. In addition, violations of these laws could impact our reputation, and, consequently, on our ability to win future business and maintain long-term commercial relationships with our customers. 57 ----- Economic sanctions, anti-corruption laws, and anti-money-laundering laws change over time. It is difficult for us to predict how these laws will change in the future or impact our business. While we have adopted and continuously review compliance policies and procedures reasonably designed to ensure compliance with applicable laws and regulations, including applicable export controls, economic sanctions, anti-corruption laws, and anti-money laundering laws, there can be no assurance that these policies and procedures will be followed at all times or that our internal controls will effectively detect and prevent all violations of applicable law by our employees, consultants, agents or partners. If we do not adequately manage the above risks, we could be subject to some or all of the consequences described above, which, in turn, could adversely affect our business, operations, financial condition, and future prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Our internal controls, procedures, compliance systems and risk management systems may prove to be inadequate to prevent and discover previous or future breaches of laws and regulations and generally to manage risks.
Subsubsection Text: Members of our governing bodies, employees, authorized representatives or agents may intentionally or unintentionally violate applicable laws and internal standards and procedures, in particular in relation to anticorruption, money-laundering, antitrust and sanctions compliance as well as compliance with laws and regulations regarding sales practices, products and services, environment, finance, employment and general corporate and criminal law. However, there can be no certainty that our internal controls, procedures, compliance systems and risk management systems will be able to identify such violations, ensure that they are reported in a timely manner, evaluate them correctly or take the appropriate countermeasures, and that they will be adequate for an enterprise of our scale and complexity. For instance, issues regarding local book keeping and financial reporting processes led to qualified, adverse or disclaimer of opinions on the financial information of certain entities of the Elevator Technology Business’s Operating Unit Spanish Latin America in several instances as of September 30, 2018 and 2017 and for the financial years ended September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017. It was revealed that certain individuals in the local accounting and reporting teams of the Elevator Technology Business’s Operating Unit Spanish Latin America requested and made adjustments based on best estimates to figures representing cash and cash equivalents as well as other balance sheet positions, profit and loss positions and Group KPIs, such as EBIT and business cash flow without documentation properly justifying those adjustments. It was determined that the adjustments were made at least partially as a result of the long working hours and high turnover rate in the relevant accounting and controlling departments, the complexity within local reporting systems and processes and a lack of formal control and procedures in the relevant departments. As a result, our management has made certain adjustments to the financial information for the periods affected based on their best estimates. For more information and a list of these adjustments, see Note 1 of the Audited Combined Financial Statements and the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements and “Presentation _of Financial Information—Historical Financial Information.” However, the independent auditor’s report on the_ Audited Combined Financial Statements is qualified since the auditor was not able to obtain sufficient information and evidence required to assess the existence, completeness, valuation and cut-off of the assets and liabilities of these entities as of September 30, 2018 and 2017 as well as the income and expense for the financial years ended September 30, 2019, 2018, 2017 of these entities. In addition, in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements, the issues relating to the Elevator Technology Business’s Operating Unit Spanish Latin America described above still remained for the six-month period ended March 31, 2019 (see Note 1 of the other explanatory notes of the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements). There can further be no certainty that any countermeasures implemented by us in respect of the above or any such issues in the future will be appropriate to reduce the corresponding business risks effectively or that as of yet undetected breaches of law or regulations have not occurred in the past, and that their discovery would not result in significant liability or reputational damage for us. Moreover, in light of continuously evolving legal and regulatory requirements, and internal developments such as corporate reorganizations, there can be no certainty that our risk management systems, internal controls and compliance systems and related governance structures will adequately identify and address all relevant requirements. Any failure to effectively prevent, identify or address violations of our legal obligations as a result of inadequate internal controls, procedures, compliance systems and risk management systems could result in penalties and other sanctions, liabilities, the assertion of damages claims by third parties, and reputational damage, each of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, operations, financial condition or prospects. 58 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We may not adequately protect our intellectual property and know-how or may be liable for the infringement of third-party intellectual property.
Subsubsection Text: Our success in maintaining our competitive position depends, to a significant extent, on our ability to obtain and enforce intellectual property rights worldwide. We seek to protect our intellectual property and proprietary rights through a combination of patents, registered designs, trade secrets, trademarks, copyrights and similar protections. With respect to proprietary know-how that is not patentable and production processes for which patents are difficult to enforce, we rely on trade secret protections and confidentiality agreements to safeguard our interests. Steps taken by us to protect our intellectual property and proprietary information may not be adequate to prevent misappropriation of our technology as the existence of laws or contracts prohibiting such actions may not always serve as sufficient deterrents. Policing the unauthorized use of our intellectual property may be expensive and time-consuming. Our intellectual property rights may be, and have in certain instances been, challenged, and we may not be able to secure such rights in the future. In addition, the laws of certain countries may not protect our proprietary rights to the same extent as the laws of the European Union or the United States. Consequently, third parties, including our competitors, may be able to use the technology behind our products and processes without a license. The undue exploitation of our intellectual property or know-how by third parties may reduce or eliminate our competitive advantage derived from our own technology, limiting our ability to develop further innovative technologies as well as our capacity to compete in the markets where we operate and to attract new customers. We may also infringe patents, trademarks or other third-party rights and is currently subject to certain infringement claims from third parties. If we are found to have infringed third-party intellectual property rights, we may have to pay royalties, damages, modify manufacturing processes, or redesign products or may be barred from marketing certain products. Should we have to redesign products or become barred from marketing certain products, we could face significant production and delivery delays or be unable to sell certain products altogether, both of which could result in lost business volume. The defense of intellectual property suits, patent opposition proceedings and related legal and administrative proceedings may moreover be both costly and timeconsuming. Finally, we may not be able to obtain the licenses to use certain third-party intellectual property that we may require on reasonable terms in the future. The materialization of any of these risks could lead to delivery and production restrictions or interruptions and have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to regulatory and legal risks relating to data protection.
Subsubsection Text: Our business operations generate and store significant volumes of personal and sensitive business information, including personally identifiable information of customers, employees, partners and suppliers. The volume and complexity of electronically processed data, moreover, continues to increase as we increasingly sell data-driven service solutions, which involve the transfer and analysis of data. We are subject to privacy and information security regulations with respect to, among other things, the use and disclosure of personal data, and the confidentiality, integrity and availability of such information. In particular, we are subject to the stringent requirements of the EU’s General Data Protection Regulation (“GDPR”), violation of which carries fines of up to 4% of our global turnover. In addition, the GDPR grants individual data subjects the right to claim damages for violations of their rights under the GDPR. We cannot ensure that the confidentiality of such data and information will not be breached as a result of cybersecurity attacks or otherwise, or that doubts may arise regarding the security of the data and information collected and managed by us. If we fail to adequately safeguard confidential personal or other sensitive data, we could be subject to damages, significant fines, penalties and other liabilities and the loss of customers and reputation, which could in turn have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to complex tax laws, and changes in tax laws or challenges to our tax position could adversely affect our results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: Changes in tax laws could adversely affect our tax positions, including our effective tax rate or tax payments. We often rely on generally available interpretations of applicable tax laws and regulations. We cannot be certain that the relevant tax authorities are in agreement with our interpretation of these laws. If our tax positions are challenged by relevant tax authorities, the imposition of additional taxes could require us to pay taxes that we currently do not collect or pay or increase the costs of our services to track and collect such taxes, which could increase our costs of operations and have a negative effect on our business, financial condition, operating results and cash flows. 59 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to tax risks, which could arise in particular as a result of tax audits or past measures.
Subsubsection Text: Due to the global nature of our business, we are subject to income and other taxes in multiple jurisdictions. Significant judgement and estimation are required in determining our calculation and provision for income, sales, value-add and other taxes, including withholding taxes. In the ordinary course of our business, there are various transactions, including, for example, intercompany transactions based on cross-jurisdictional transfer pricing and transactions with specific documentation requirements, for all of which the ultimate tax assessment or the timing of the tax effect is uncertain. We are regularly audited by tax authorities, and our tax calculations and our interpretation of laws are reviewed by tax authorities which may disagree with our tax estimates or judgements. Although we believe our tax estimates are reasonable, the final determination of any such tax audits or reviews could differ from our tax provisions and accruals and any additional tax liabilities resulting from such final determination or any interest or any penalties or any regulatory, administrative or other sanctions relating thereto could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or reputation. While we attempt to assess in advance the likelihood of any adverse judgments or outcomes to these proceedings or claims it is difficult to predict final outcomes with any degree of certainty. The final determination of any tax investigation, tax audit, tax review, tax litigation, and appeal of a tax authority’s decision or similar proceedings may differ materially from our estimate or which is reflected in our financial statements. An adverse outcome could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and result of operations. In addition, changes in tax legislation or guidance could result in additional taxes and/or affect our tax rate, the carrying value of deferred tax assets or our deferred tax liabilities. Any tax audit, tax proceeding or changes in tax legislation or guidance could, as a result of the realization of any of the above risks, have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. In addition, certain entities of our Group were in the past or are currently part of fiscal unities, tax groups and other tax consolidation schemes. We cannot ensure that these entities will not be held liable for unpaid taxes of the members of such tax consolidation schemes (including members outside of our Group) under statutory law or the contracts which formed or form the basis for the tax consolidation schemes. Furthermore, should such tax consolidation schemes not be accepted by the tax authorities and/or a tax court, taxes, interest and penalties may be imposed against entities of our Group. Such liabilities may be substantial and could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial condition and reputation. However, pursuant to the provisions of the Share Purchase Agreement, the Seller would be required to bear certain taxes resulting from prior tax periods up to an agreed cap. Such indemnity is subject to certain exclusions and limitations. Should such exclusions or limitations be applicable or should the tax liability in question exceed the cap, or should the Seller not have sufficient funds to settle its indemnification obligation vis-à-vis the Target, such liability would have to be borne by the Group, which could in turn have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The Acquisition is subject to certain conditions and risks and, if it is not consummated, the Issuers will redeem the Notes at 100% of the issue price, plus accrued and unpaid interest.
Subsubsection Text: On February 26/27, 2020, Bidco entered into the Share Purchase Agreement to acquire, directly or indirectly, from the Seller all of the issued and outstanding share capital of the Target. The Acquisition is subject to the satisfaction of certain closing conditions, including, customary antitrust and regulatory approvals and the performance of certain closing actions. Pending the consummation of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds from the Offering into the Escrow Accounts on the Issue Date. The release of the Escrowed Property is subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including that the funds required to pay the consideration for the Acquisition will be applied promptly (and in any event within two business days). As of the date of the offering memorandum, we do not yet know whether the Acquisition will be successful. If the conditions precedent to the Acquisition are not satisfied or waived, as applicable, by the Escrow Longstop Date, then the Acquisition will not be consummated. If the conditions to the release of the Escrowed Property, as more fully described under “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory _Redemption” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption” have_ not been satisfied on or prior to the Escrow Longstop Date or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a Special Mandatory Redemption as described in “Description of Senior Secured Notes— _Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption” and you may not obtain the return you expect to receive on the_ Notes. 60 -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: If the conditions precedent to the release of the Escrowed Property are not satisfied, the Issuers will be required to redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Accounts may not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption without relying on the Escrow Equity Commitment.
Subsubsection Text: The Escrowed Property will be limited initially to the gross proceeds of the Offering and will not be sufficient to pay the Special Mandatory Redemption Price, which is equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the Special Mandatory Redemption Date. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory _Redemption” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.” In_ the event that the Special Mandatory Redemption Price payable upon such Special Mandatory Redemption exceeds the amount of the Escrowed Property, the SUN Issuer, in the case of the Senior Secured Notes, and Vertical Topco III, in the case of the Senior Notes, will be required to fund the relevant Issuer with an amount sufficient to cover the difference between the Special Mandatory Redemption Price and the amount of the Escrowed Property, including accrued interest and additional amounts (if any) due with respect to the Notes from the Issue Date to the Special Mandatory Redemption Date and any negative interest which has accrued on the Escrow Accounts, pursuant to the Escrow Equity Commitment. Holders of the Notes will not have any direct right to enforce the Escrow Equity Commitment, and must rely on the Issuers’ respective rights to enforcement under the Escrow Equity Commitment. There can be no assurance that the relevant entities providing such commitment will have sufficient funds to make this payment, and the Issuers may not have access to the funds necessary to allow them to pay the full amount of the required redemption price in the event of a Special Mandatory Redemption. Your decision to invest in the Notes is made at the time of purchase. Changes in the business or financial position of the Target and its subsidiaries, or the terms of the Acquisition, between the Issue Date and the Escrow Release Date, may have an impact on our creditworthiness, and you will not be able to rescind your decision to invest in the Notes as a result thereof.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The Issuers do not currently control the Target and will not control the Target until the Acquisition Closing Date.
Subsubsection Text: As of the date of this offering memorandum, the Issuers do not, directly or indirectly, hold any issued and outstanding common shares of the Target. As a result, the Issuers’ ability to influence the Target’s management is limited. In particular: - The Target’s Management Board may not operate the business of the Target until the Acquisition Closing Date in the same way that the Issuers and the Sponsors would. - Much of the information contained in this offering memorandum relating to the Target had to be derived from public sources and, in the case of certain additional information relating to the Target, has been provided to the Issuers by the Target, and the Issuers have relied on such information that is publicly available or was supplied to them by the Target in their preparation of this offering memorandum. - The Acquisition has required, and will likely continue to require, substantial time and focus from the Target’s management, which could adversely affect their ability to operate the Target’s business.
