Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our sales in the Europe/Africa segment increased by €54 million, or 2.6%, from €2,063 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €2,117 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by higher sales in the New Installation business as a result of major infrastructure projects delivered by the Europe/Africa segment to our Middle East region. There was marginal sales growth in the Service and Modernization 114 ----- businesses, mainly driven by operations in the DACH operating unit (comprising Germany, Austria and Switzerland), supported by strong conversion and retention rates. These increases were partly offset by negative currency effects with respect to the Turkish lira and the Russian ruble. Our sales in the Americas segment decreased by €136 million, or 4.4%, from €3,119 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €2,983 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by negative currency effects in the U.S. dollar and Brazil real, which mainly impacted the New Installation business, partially mitigated by strong levels of construction activity and growth in the Service businesses as a result of management’s focus on increasing repair sales and increased growth in Modernizations contracts in the United States. Our sales in the Asia/Pacific segment increased by €39 million, or 1.7%, from €2,298 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €2,337 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. Strong conversion rates in China and South Korea resulted in significant Services growth, which was partly offset mainly by negative currency effects with respect to the Chinese renminbi and the South Korean won. Sales in the New Installation business Unit suffered mainly due to a weaker market in South Korea. Our sales in the Access Solutions segment increased by €4 million, or 1.1%, from €368 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €372 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by growth in New Installations as a result of major airport projects in Turkey and the United States, partially offset by declines in Services and Modernizations sales as a result of the expiry of certain Service agreements and the completion of several Modernizations projects. _Cost of sales_ Our cost of sales remained relatively constant at €5,561 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year and €5,552 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. Cost of sales increased slightly as a percentage of sales from 72.5% in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to 73.3% in the 2017/2018 Financial Year due to material costs increases in the Asia/Pacific segment as a result of negative price developments in China and South Korea, which mainly impacted New Installation, the largest business in that region. These increases were offset by decreases in the Americas segment as a result of favorable currency effects with respect to the U.S. dollar and Brazilian real, although material prices in the Americas were also adversely impacted by U.S. tariffs, mainly on steel imports from China, over the period. Material price increases were also partly offset by positive impacts from purchasing volume savings programs. Personnel costs were broadly stable over the period, as labor cost inflation effects were offset by increased labor efficiency measures and favorable currency effects. _Research and development cost_ Our research and development cost decreased by €19 million, or 21.8%, from €87 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €68 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by the capitalization, in accordance with IAS 38, of certain research and development expenses in the 2017/2018 Financial Year (including global projects such as MULTI and other mature and professionalized global research and development projects). _Selling expenses_ Our selling expenses decreased by €76 million, or 13.8%, from €552 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €476 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by a decline in allowances for financial assets, mainly due to allowances in connection with a restructuring program in the Middle East which were recorded in the 2016/17 Financial Year. Further decreases resulted from SG&A improvement measures globally, particularly in Asia/Pacific where we made progress centralizing administrative costs and carrying out other cost savings initiatives in China, and favorable exchange rates with respect to the U.S. dollar. _General and administrative expenses_ Our general and administrative expenses decreased by €42 million, or 4.8%, from €867 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €825 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by reduced corporate cost allocations from thyssenkrupp AG, operational improvements and a positive impact from exchange rates mainly in relation to the U.S. dollar. 115 ----- _Other income_ Our other income increased by €10 million, or 24.4%, from €41 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €51 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year, primarily due to a one-time legal settlement. _Other expenses_ Our other expenses increased by €49 million, or 36.0%, from €136 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €185 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by increased expenses relating to license fee payments to thyssenkrupp AG in connection with our use of the “thyssenkrupp” brand. _Financial income/(expense), net_ Our financial income/(expense), net decreased by €4 million, or 14.8%, from €27 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €23 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by a €27 million decrease in finance income over the period mainly due to lower interest income earned on thyssenkrupp Group intragroup financial accounts which was offset by a €23 million decrease in finance expense as a result of lower interest expenses owed on thyssenkrupp Group intragroup financial accounts. _Income tax (expense)/income_ Our income tax (expense)/income decreased by €151 million, or 54.3%, from €(278) million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €(127) million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by the US tax reform, which resulted in a devaluation of deferred tax liabilities in the United States as well as a lower applicable tax rate on US profits in the 2017/18 financial year. _Adjusted EBIT_ The table below sets forth our Adjusted EBIT by segment and the period on period percentage of change for the 2017/2018 and 2016/2017 Financial Years.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our Adjusted EBIT decreased by €49 million, or 6%, from €812 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €763 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by reduced profit contribution from the New Installation business in the Asia/Pacific and Europe/Africa segments and negative exchange rate developments mainly related to the US dollar, as offset by the growth of the Service business in the Americas segment. Our Adjusted EBIT in the Europe/Africa segment decreased from €223 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €212 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by lower profitability in the New Installation business due to performance issues in both project execution in Turkey and France as well as in the Group’s European manufacturing operations, which was only partly offset by Service business growth and positive impacts from restructuring and efficiency measures in Germany, Austria, Switzerland and France. Our Adjusted EBIT in the Americas segment decreased from €509 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €476 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by lower profitability in the New Installation business due to adverse currency effects with respect to the US dollar and Brazilian real, as well as increased costs arising from US tariffs, in particular for steel imports from China, only partly offset by positive effects from Service growth and efficiency measures. Our Adjusted EBIT in the Asia/Pacific segment decreased from €203 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €148 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by decreased profitability in the New Installation business as a result of negative material cost developments in China and South Korea. These 116 ----- effects were partially offset by profit gains from efficiency measures in China in the form of centralization and other cost savings initiatives as well as Service business growth due to conversion of units from the New Installation business. Our Adjusted EBIT in the Access Solutions division increased from €55 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €58 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by higher sales volumes, in particular two major airport projects in Turkey and the United States, and operational improvements as a result of SG&A cost reductions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Following the completion of the Transactions, we expect that our principal sources of liquidity will be cash flows from operations and drawings under our Revolving Credit Facility. The availability of our Revolving Credit Facility will be subject to certain conditions. We aim to manage capital to ensure that all companies within the Elevator Technology Business can continue to operate as a going concern. Our ability to generate cash flow from operations depends on our future operating performance, which is in turn dependent on general economic, financial, competitive, market and other factors, many of which are beyond our control. In addition, we anticipate that we will be highly leveraged for the foreseeable future and our ability to generate future financing cash flows will be limited by the Indentures and the Senior Facilities, which may have important negative consequences for you. See “Risk Factors,” “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Indebtedness,” “Description of the _Senior Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Indebtedness” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.” Any additional indebtedness that we do incur could reduce the amount of our cash flow available_ to make payments on our then existing indebtedness, including under the Notes offered hereby, and increase our leverage. The proceeds from the Offering will be used as set forth under “Use of Proceeds.”

Subsubsection Text: Our capital expenditures primarily relate to expansion and major products, such as acquisitions and the operational expansion of manufacturing facilities, and maintenance, such as information technology and research and development expenditures, as well as investments in regular business activities. Our capital expenditures as a percentage of sales was equal to 1.9%, 1.6%, and 17.4% in the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years (on a combined basis), respectively, and 1.6% and 88.8% in the six months ended March 31, 2019 and 2020 (on a consolidated basis), respectively. 118 ----- The following table sets forth our capital expenditures for the periods indicated:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Operating cash flows_ Our operating cash flows on a consolidated basis increased by €113 million, or 146.8%, from €77 million in the six months ended March 31, 2019 to €190 million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The increase was primarily driven by the increased net income (before non-cash items like depreciation, amortization and deferred taxes) partially offset by an overall increase in net working capital. Our operating cash flows on a combined basis increased by €200 million, or 72.5%, from €276 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year to €476 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by declines in working capital, including positive cash flow effects from development of inventories, trade accounts receivable and contract assets, partially offset by net negative cash flow effects from net development of contract liabilities and provisions. The increase was also due to minor effects resulting from an increase in net income before non-cash items, mainly comprising deferred tax effects. 117 ----- Our operating cash flows on a combined basis decreased by €217 million, or 44.0%, from €493 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €276 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year, despite an increase in net income before changes in working capital. The decrease was primarily driven by the significant overall increase in net working capital, including negative cash flow effects from development of trade accounts receivable, contract assets, provisions and trade payables, partially offset by positive cash flow effects from development of contract liabilities. The decrease was also due to effects resulting from increased net income before non-cash items, including depreciation, amortization and deferred taxes. _Cash flows from investing activities_ Our cash outflows on a consolidated basis from investing activities strongly increased by €3,228 million from €58 million in the six months ended March 31, 2019 to €3,286 million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The increase was primarily driven by acquisitions of shares in the Group companies from thyssenkrupp Group during the six months ended March 31, 2020 as part of the legal reorganization of the Group finalized as of December 31, 2019. Our cash outflows on a combined basis from investing activities increased by €1,267 million from €116 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year to €1,383 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. This increase was primarily driven by the one-time €1,080 million fee paid in connection with the Licensing Agreement for the use of the “thyssenkrupp” brand (see “Business—Intellectual Property”), increased expansions and major project expenditure, specifically the acquisitions of Nashville Machine Elevator and O’Keefe Elevator Company Inc. and advance payments in connection with thyssenkrupp Group internal asset transfers, including €74 million of real estate assets, in preparation for the operational carve-out of the elevator technology business. Our cash outflows on a combined basis from investing activities decreased by €29 million, or 20.0%, from €145 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €116 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease was primarily driven by a decrease in cash outflow for capital expenditures mainly with respect to property, plant and equipment following the finalization of several major investments in the Asia/Pacific segment. _Cash flows from financing activities_ Our cash flows on a consolidated basis from financing activities strongly increased by €3,052 million from an outflow of €32 million in the six months ended March 31, 2019 to an inflow of €3,020 million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The increase was primarily driven by a significant increase in amounts received from thyssenkrupp Group due to the existing integration of the Group into the cash pooling of thyssenkrupp Group and due to capital increases. These increased cash inflows were mainly associated with the already mentioned legal reorganization of the Group. Our cash flows on a combined basis from financing activities increased by €1,156 million, or 583.8%, from an outflow of €198 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year to an inflow of €958 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The increase was primarily driven by an increase in amounts received pursuant to thyssenkrupp Group intragroup financing arrangements. Our cash outflow on a combined basis from financing activities decreased by €151 million, or 43.3%, from outflows of €349 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to outflows of €198 million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. The decrease in cash outflows was primarily driven by a net decrease in amounts paid pursuant to thyssenkrupp Group intragroup financing arrangements.

(2) Includes the cash flow line items, “Proceeds from disposal of shares in remaining thyssenkrupp Group companies,” “Proceeds from disposals of investments accounted for using the equity method and non-current financial assets,” “Proceeds from disposals of property, plant and equipment” and “Proceeds from disposals of intangible assets.” (3) Includes “Expenditures for acquisitions of consolidated companies net of cash acquired,” “Purchase of investments accounted for using the equity method and non-financial assets,” “Expenditures for acquisitions of shares in thyssenkrupp ET group companies from thyssenkrupp Group,” “Cash advances and loans classified as investing activities,” “Capital expenditures for property, plant and equipment (inclusive of advance payments)” and “Capital expenditures for intangible assets (inclusive of advance payments).” (4) Because we adopted IFRS 16 on October 1, 2019, IFRS 16 was not applicable during the financial years ended September 30, 2017, 2018 and 2019 or for the six months ended March 30, 2019. Corresponding cash out has been recognized within carve-out effects in the 2018/2019 Financial Year in the course of the advance payment. (5) Capital expenditures for the six months ended March 31, 2020 include €3,340 million in purchase costs paid in connection with the Reorganization. Our capital expenditures on a consolidated basis increased by €(3,386) million, from €(60) million in the six months ended March 31, 2019, to €(3,446) million in the six months ended March 31, 2020. The increase was primarily driven by acquisitions of shares in the Group companies from the thyssenkrupp Group during the six months ended March 31, 2020 as part of the legal reorganization of the Group finalized as of December 31, 2019. Our capital expenditures on a combined basis increased by €(1,268) million, from €(121) million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year to €(1,389) million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year, primarily as a result of the one-time €1,080 million fee payed in connection with the Licensing Agreement (see “Business—Intellectual _Property”) and also increased due to expansions and major project expenditure, specifically the acquisitions of_ Nashville Machine Elevator and O’Keefe Elevator Company Inc., and investments in the MULTI elevator system. Higher information technology and other research and development investment also contributed to the increase. Our capital expenditures on a combined basis decreased by €27 million, or 18.2%, from €(148) million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €(121) million in the 2017/2018 Financial Year, primarily due to a decrease in capital expenditures mainly with respect to property, plant and equipment following the finalization of several major investments in the Asia/Pacific segment, namely manufacturing investments and the new test tower at our facility in Zhongshan, China. 119 -----

Subsection Title: Contingent Liabilities and Other Financial Commitments
Subsubsection Text: _Contingencies_ In the past, a holding company in Spain that was part of the thyssenkrupp Group issued certain guarantees on behalf of other companies within the thyssenkrupp Group to customers of the thyssenkrupp Group who were not customers of the Elevator Technology Business as well as, in October 2019, to Spanish tax authorities for tax audits at thyssenkrupp Group companies which do not belong to the elevator technology business that raised the need to grant a collateral to the Spanish tax authorities. The Spanish holding company has since become part of the Group. We expect that these guarantees will be either transferred to an entity within the thyssenkrupp Group but outside of the Group before the Acquisition Closing Date (after which they will no longer be obligations of the Group) or the thyssenkrupp Group will provide adequate collateralization to the Group. The following table shows obligations under such guarantees as of the dates indicated.

Subsubsection Text: The terms of these guarantees depend on the type of guarantee and may range from three months to five years. The basis for possible payments under the guarantees is the non-performance of the principal debtor under a contractual agreement, such as late delivery, delivery of non-conforming goods under a contract or 120 ----- non-performance with respect to the warranted quality as well as a final ruling of the Spanish tax authorities. All guarantees are issued at the instruction of a combined company of the Group upon the request of the principal debtor obligated by the underlying contractual relationship and are subject to recourse provisions in the case of default. _Material legal disputes_ As of March 31, 2020, we had contingencies for the following material legal disputes: - A claim by the creditors of a former owner of an acquired business in Brazil for the reversal of the acquisition in order to access the acquired assets to satisfy claims against the former owner (€48 million); and - Private enforcement claims in relation to our participation in elevator cartels in several EU jurisdictions (€150 million). For more information on contingent liabilities in relation to existing and potential legal and arbitration actions and official investigations and proceedings, see Note 20 to the Audited Combined Financial Statements and Note 9 to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We have off-balance sheet items relating to operating leases and sales of receivable transactions. The operating leases primarily comprise lease contracts for property, plant and equipment in the Americas, Europe/Africa and Asia/Pacific segments as well as leases for carpooling and real estate within the thyssenkrupp Group. Information about the exposure to future lease payments resulting from operating leases can be found in Note 20 to the Audited Combined Financial Statements. Due to the implementation of IFRS 16, operating leases will be reported on the statement of financial position from the 2019/2020 Financial Year onwards. See Note 2 to the Audited Combined Financial Statements and Note 1 to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements for more information about the application of IFRS 16 by the Group. Finally, we have sales of receivable transactions which primarily relate to revolving factoring contracts in Spain as well as one-time transactions in China and Italy. As of March 31, 2020, sales of receivables transactions amounted to €36.9 million, of which €35.4 million were attributable to the revolving factoring program in Spain.

Our obligations under these plans vary depending on legal, tax and economic circumstances in the various countries in which we operate, and, in most of the countries, they generally depend on the length of service and remuneration of the specific employee concerned. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk Management
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk (default risk) is the risk of the Group incurring financial losses due to the non-fulfilment or partial fulfilment of existing debt obligations. Credit risk management is governed by corporate guidelines. Companies and business operating activities of the Group are required to implement credit risk management in accordance with these guidelines. In order to minimize default risks (credit risks) from the use of financial instruments, we only conclude such transactions with counterparties that meet our internal minimum requirements. We currently conclude our financial instruments with thyssenkrupp AG or with financial institutions. After the Acquisition Closing Date, we expect to conclude new financial instruments with financial institutions only. We generally manage default risks by requiring suitable advance as well as progress payments. In rare cases where a credit risk analysis suggests a potentially higher default risk, letters of credit and payment guarantees from banks, insurance companies and management companies are requested. In order to minimize default risks from operating activities, our corporate guidelines provide for the assessment of default risk based on the risk profile of the business partner using suitable internal and, where available, external information, such as ratings and credit reports, in conjunction with the corresponding estimation of financial risk exposure regarding the respective business transaction from our perspective. We make a credit decision for each transaction with each business partner using the aforementioned approach. Considering the individual characteristics of our customer structures and business models, we lay down clear process rules for determining which measures are to be taken in the event of a payment default in order to mitigate the maximum default risk as far as possible. Transactions the value of which exceeds specified materiality thresholds, especially in the area of major sales contracts, also require prior approval at different management levels within the Group. Among other things, the amount and hedging of default risks are assessed.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk Management
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to translation and transactional foreign exchange risks. Translational risk arises when we translate the financial statements of our subsidiaries which have a functional currency other than our functional reporting currency, the euro. Transactional risk arises when our subsidiaries execute transactions in a currency other than their functional currency. In the years ended September 31, 2017, 2018 and 2019, 77% of our net sales were generated by operating subsidiaries with a functional currency (generally the local currency) other than the euro. In terms of our results of operations, the US dollar, the Chinese renminbi, the Brazilian real, the Canadian dollar and the South Korean won are the most important foreign currencies, though for the purposes of sensitivity analysis under IFRS 7, the US dollar is the only relevant risk variable. Our policy is to continuously monitor such risks through our risk management system. There have been no significant risk concentrations in the past financial year, as less than 5% of net sales require derivative foreign currency hedging as of the financial year ended September 30, 2019, of which approximately 75% is linked to the euro and U.S. dollar. Of our sales for the 2018/2019 Financial Year, 55% were either in euro or U.S. dollar. Foreign currency hedging is used to fix prices on the basis of hedging rates as protection against any unfavorable exchange rate fluctuations in the future. Hedging periods are generally based on the maturities of underlying transactions. Foreign currency derivative contracts usually have maturities of twelve months or less, but can also be up to six years in exceptional cases. The U.S. dollar is the only relevant risk variable for sensitivity analyses under IFRS 7, as the vast majority of foreign currency cash flows occur in U.S. dollars. As hedging transactions are generally used to hedge underlying transactions, opposite effects in underlying and hedging transactions are almost entirely offset over the total 122 ----- period. Thus, the transactional currency risk exposure results from hedging relationships with off-balance sheet underlying transactions, i.e., hedges of firm commitments and forecasted sales. Both the proceeds from the offering of, and the liabilities incurred under, the SSN USD Notes, the SUN USD Notes and the USD TLB Facility will be denominated in U.S. dollar. We may consider entering into certain derivative agreements for hedging all or a portion of our exposure to fluctuations in the euro-value of these liabilities. We have not yet completed our analysis and procedures to determine the accounting treatment of such potential derivative agreements. For more information on our foreign currency risk exposure, including a sensitivity analysis, see Note 21 to the Audited Combined Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk Management
Subsubsection Text: Interest rate instruments can result in cash flow risks, opportunity effects, as well as interest rate risks affecting the statement of financial position and earnings. Refinancing and variable-rate financial instruments are subject to cash flow risk which expresses the uncertainty of future interest payments. We measure cash flow risk by means of cash flow sensitivity. Opportunity effects arise from non-derivatives, as these are measured at amortized costs rather than fair value, in contrast to interest derivatives. The difference, the so-called opportunity effect, affects neither our statement of financial position nor the statement of profit or loss. Opportunity effects and interest rate risks affecting the statement of financial position and earnings are determined by calculating fair value sensitivity analyses and changes. Borrowings under the Senior Facilities, the SSN EUR FRN Notes and the Private Senior Notes will be variable rate debt. We may consider entering into certain derivative agreements, for hedging all or a portion of our exposure to fluctuations in the interest rate of these liabilities. We have not yet completed our analysis and procedures to determine the accounting treatment of such potential derivative agreements. For more information on our interest rate risk exposure, including a sensitivity analysis, see Note 21 to the Audited Combined Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk Management
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity risk is the risk that we are unable to meet our existing or future obligations associated with financial liabilities due to insufficient availability of cash or cash equivalents. To counter this risk, cash inflows and outflows and due dates are continuously monitored and managed. Cash requirements are primarily met by cash generated from operations and until the Acquisition Closing Date, will also be met with borrowings from thyssenkrupp AG and cash in connection with cash management and cash pooling services performed by thyssenkrupp AG. As of March 31, 2020, on a consolidated basis, we had cash and cash equivalents of €220 million. Further, we had cash and cash equivalents of €307 million, €256 million and €313 million, respectively, September 30, 2017, September 30, 2018 and September 30, 2019 on a combined basis, respectively. As a result, there were no material concentrations of liquidity risk in the period under review. Following the Transactions, we will mitigate our liquidity risks by rolling liquidity planning, maintaining adequate liquidity reserves in the form of cash, and by drawing the Revolving Credit Facility. For more information on our liquidity risk, including future undiscounted cash outflows, see Note 21 to the Audited Combined Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk Management
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to financial risks in the form of credit risk (default risk), market risk (foreign currency and interest rate risk) and liquidity risk during the course of our ordinary business activities. Market risk is the risk that fair values or future cash flows of non-derivative or derivative financial instruments will fluctuate due to changes in risk factors. Among market risks relevant to our business are foreign currency and interest rate risks. Associated with these risks are fluctuations in income, equity and cash flow. The analyses and amounts discussed below that are determined by means of sensitivity analyses represent hypothetical, future-oriented data that can differ from actual outcomes because of unforeseeable developments in financial markets. Moreover, non-financial or non-quantifiable risks, such as business risks, are not considered here. Credit risk, market risk and liquidity risk are described below and in more detail in Note 21 to the Audited Combined Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As a result of acquisitions, we recognized goodwill in our statement of financial position. In a business combination, all identifiable assets, liabilities and contingent liabilities acquired are recorded at the date of acquisition at their respective fair value. One of the most significant estimates relates to the determination of the fair value of these asset and liabilities. Land, buildings and equipment are usually independently appraised while marketable securities are valued at market price. If any intangible assets are identified, depending on the type of intangible asset and the complexity of determining our fair value, we either consult with an independent external valuation expert or develop the fair value internally, using an appropriate valuation technique which is generally based on a forecast of the total expected future net cash flows. These evaluations are linked closely to the assumptions made by management regarding the future performance of the assets concerned and any changes in the discount rate applied.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We test annually, and also when any indicators exist, whether goodwill has suffered an impairment loss. If there is an indication, the recoverable amount of the cash-generating unit has to be estimated, which is the greater of the fair value less costs to sell and the value in use. The determination of the value in use involves making assumptions and estimates related to the projection and discounting of future cash flows. See Note 4 to the Audited Combined Financial Statements. Although management believes the assumptions used to calculate recoverable amounts are appropriate, any unforeseen changes in these assumptions could result in impairment charges to goodwill, which could adversely affect the future financial position and operating results.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: At each balance sheet date, we assess whether there is any indication that the carrying amounts of our property, plant and equipment, investment property or intangible assets may be impaired. If any such indication exists, we estimate the recoverable amount of the asset. The recoverable amount is the greater of the fair value less costs to sell and the value in use. In assessing the value in use, we have to determine discounted future cash flows from the related assets. Estimating the discounted future cash flows involves significant assumptions, including particularly those regarding future sale prices and sale volumes, costs and discount rates. See Notes 4 and 5 to the Audited Combined Financial Statements. Although management believes that our estimates of the relevant expected useful lives, our assumptions concerning the economic environment and developments in the industries in which we operate and our estimations of the discounted future cash flows are appropriate, changes in the assumptions or circumstances could require changes in the analysis. This could lead to additional impairment charges in the future or to reversal of impairments if the trends identified by management reverse or the assumptions or estimates prove incorrect.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The recognition and measurement of other provisions are based on the estimation of the probability of a future outflow of resources as well as empirical values and the circumstances known at the reporting date. This means that the actual later outflow of resources may differ from the other provisions. See Note 15 to the Audited Combined Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Revenue Recognition from Contracts with Customers
Subsubsection Text: Certain entities of the Group report some of their business transactions as construction contracts, in which sales are recognized over time using the percentage-of-completion method. This method requires accurate estimates of the extent of progress towards completion. Depending on the methodology to determine contract progress, the significant estimates include total contract costs, remaining costs to completion, total contract sales, contract risks and other judgments. The managements of the operating companies continually review all estimates involved in such contraction contracts and adjust them as necessary. The expected variable consideration amount is estimated at the inception of a contract with a customer. The estimate is made using either the probability-weighted expected value or the most likely amount. The estimation method giving the better forecast for the respective contract is always used. The variable consideration amount estimated at contract inception is reviewed at each reporting date and adjusted as necessary. In the case of contracts with customers which have distinct performance obligations, the required allocation of the transaction price to the distinct performance obligations is carried out by reference to the relative standalone selling prices. The relative standalone selling prices used generally correspond to directly observable market 124 ----- prices at which we separately sell the performance obligations to other customers. If the standalone selling price is not directly observable, we make a best estimate of the standalone selling price. In these cases, we use an adjusted market assessment approach, an expected cost plus a margin approach, or a residual approach.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The recognition and measurement of current and deferred tax receivables and liabilities depend on management estimates of tax uncertainties and future business performance. These include both the interpretation of existing tax regulations and the testing of deferred tax assets for impairment. We adjust these estimates when there is sufficient evidence of the need for such adjustment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We account for pension and other post-retirement benefits in accordance with actuarial valuations. These valuations rely on statistical and other factors in order to anticipate future events. These factors include key actuarial assumptions including the discount rate, expected salary increases, mortality rates and health care cost trend rates. These actuarial assumptions may differ materially from actual developments due to changing market and economic conditions and therefore may result in a significant change in post-retirement employee benefit obligations, of equity and the related future expense. See Note 14 to the Audited Combined Financial Statements for further information.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Various entities within the Group are party to litigations related to a number of matters as described in greater detail in “Business—Legal Proceedings.” The outcome of these matters may have a material effect on the financial position, results of operations or cash flows. Management regularly analyzes current information about these matters and provides provisions for probable contingent losses including the estimate of legal expense to resolve the matters. For the assessments, internal and external lawyers are used. In making the decision regarding the need for loss provisions, management considers the degree of probability of an unfavorable outcome and the ability to make a sufficiently reliable estimate of the amount of loss. The filing of a suit or formal assertion of a claim against any of these entities within the Group or the disclosure of any such suit or assertions, does not automatically indicate that a provision of a loss may be appropriate. See Note 20 to the Audited Combined Financial Statements for further information.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The combined financial information presented in our Audited Combined Financial Statements does not necessarily reflect the net assets, financial position, results of operations and capital structure that would have occurred if we had existed as a separate, standalone group in the reporting periods under consideration. The fact that we did not historically exist therefore limits the validity of the combined financial information. It also means that the combined financial information cannot be used to forecast the future development of the operations that have been combined to form the Group. In preparing the Audited Combined Financial Statements, our management made additional assumptions and estimates, particularly in connection with operating activities to be transferred and allocable expenses for administrative services provided by remaining thyssenkrupp Group companies. These assumptions and estimates affect the amounts and the reporting of recognized assets and liabilities, income and expenses and contingent liabilities. The actual amounts may vary from these estimates. We apply estimates and judgments by management especially in the following accounting policies. 123 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, new accounting pronouncements are issued by the IASB or other stand setting bodies that are adopted by us as of the specified effective date. Except for the adoption of IFRS 16 (see “—Factors Affecting _Comparability of Our Results of Operations and Financial Condition— Changes to Accounting Standards–IFRS 16”), we believe that the adoption of these new standards did not have a significant impact on our financial_ statements. Please refer to our Financial Statements included elsewhere in this offering memorandum for additional information on recently issued accounting standards and our plans for adoption of those standards. 125 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The discussion and analysis below provide information that we believe is relevant to an assessment and understanding of our historical financial position and results of operations. You should read this discussion and analysis in conjunction with the Financial Statements included elsewhere herein and the sections entitled “Presentation of Financial Information” and “Selected Historical Financial Information.” This section includes forward-looking statements, including those concerning future sales, costs, capital expenditures and financial condition. Such forward-looking statements are subject to risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. Results of operations for prior financial periods are not necessarily indicative of the results to be expected for the current or any future period. See “Forward-looking Statements” and “Risk Factors.” The following discussion of our results of operations also makes reference to certain Non-GAAP Measures. Prospective investors should bear in mind that these Non-GAAP Measures are not financial measures defined in accordance with IFRS, may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies, have limitations as analytical tools and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our operating results as reported under IFRS. See “Presentation of Financial Information—Non-GAAP Financial Measures.”_

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Overview of the Elevator and Escalator Market
Subsubsection Text: The New Installation business encompasses the sale of new equipment and the associated manufacturing, delivery and installation at the desired site. The market for new installations of elevator and escalator projects is driven by demand from the broader construction industry. It is therefore largely project-based and often subject 126 ----- to a competitive tender process, and selection by developers or contractors will depend on a number of factors, including budget, technical specifications and service offerings post-installation. In connection with the new installation tender process, OEMs also seek to secure longer-term, recurring service contracts for installed units. OEMs term this the conversion process, and often measure their performance in part based on their conversion rate of New Installations units to Service contracts. New Installation business is therefore an important driver for growth of the Service business. OEMs also consistently work to increase the efficiency of their manufacturing supply chain. Components may be sourced from third-party suppliers or produced in-house depending on the level of complexity and customization required. Whereas in the past a large share of the components were often manufactured in-house by the OEM itself, there has been a trend in the industry to outsource a larger range of components, such as elevator doors, to third-party suppliers. This has reduced the complexity of the production process for OEMs as their factory sites increasingly shift from deep manufacturing to component configuration. Once manufactured, elevators are typically shipped in pieces and assembled on site, whereas escalators are typically assembled in the factory and shipped as a complete product. Installation may be completed by an OEM’s own employees or outsourced to sub-contractors. Additionally, producers attract business through technology and innovation that reduces product downtime and fulfills other buyer requirements. For instance, energy-saving technologies can help buyers reach sustainability goals for their projects and advanced destination controls can increase the number of passengers able to be dispatched per hour. Furthermore, recent developments in IoT technology, such as real-time diagnosis and reporting of events by the elevator itself to an OEM’s service center, present an attractive proposition to New Installations buyers with the prospect of more efficient service during the lifetime of the elevator or escalator and enhanced contract retention for OEMs.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Overview of the Elevator and Escalator Market
Subsubsection Text: The Service business involves the full range of steps required to properly maintain an elevator or escalator throughout its usable life and is mission-critical in nature. For business owners, regular service of elevators and escalators is essential to maintain consistent uptime and safety of users in their facilities. Furthermore, elevators and escalators are subject to broad and sometimes diverse sets of regulations and safety standards across jurisdictions which typically require maintenance on elevators and escalators by licensed service professionals in certain intervals. In addition, Service customers are often property owners who are able to pass through maintenance costs to tenants, making them somewhat less price sensitive when choosing a Service provider. Based on long-term customer relationships through service contracts, the Service business can provide recurring and reliable sales streams to Service providers at higher margins than the New Installation business. Service providers as a result are able to achieve a higher degree of visibility into resilient and recurring future earnings through the elevator or escalator lifecycle, as illustrated by the graphic below: t h y s s e n k r u p p E l e v a t o r v a l u e c h a i n ( i l l u s t r a t i v e ) Elevator lifetime: c. 10-20 years of elevator lifetime prior to significant Modernization Warranty Maintenance fee Spare parts Time Service agreements tend to fall into one of three categories based on service scope: full maintenance, partial maintenance and oil & grease. Terms of service agreements may vary by jurisdiction and customer, but often last one to five years. Depending on the scope of the service agreement, the Service provider may charge a flat fee for regular maintenance and on an individual invoice basis for additional repairs and spare parts. Usually, the OEM of the elevator or escalator product has an advantage in winning a service contract for its own products. Participants in the elevator and escalator market however also have the ability to service the products of third parties, provided they have the required technical expertise internally available. This can be a further valuable revenue stream for Service providers at various points throughout a product’s lifecycle as contracts come up for renewal. 127 ----- While the elevator and escalator Service business is primarily local in its operation, Service providers benefit from greater scale as they are able to maintain more competitive cost structures, network density and technological leadership. Having a dense network of service branches with technicians trained on all types of elevator and escalator units enables providers to increase their market coverage and further solidify their brand reputation. Greater scale also allows for operational efficiencies such as faster sourcing of spare parts. Moreover, recent technological advancements, such as those in the IoT landscape, allow Service providers with global reach to further benefit from their scale as they are able to develop efficient service solutions based on their deep experience in the field across regions. IoT solutions include real-time diagnosis and reporting of events by the elevator itself to a Service provider’s service center, which can reduce product downtime, add value for the Service customer and make service technicians more efficient. The advantages of IoT-powered maintenance solutions have the potential to not only improve an OEM’s conversion rate from New Installations units to recurring service contracts, they also help ensure customer retention over the long-term.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Overview of the Elevator and Escalator Market
Subsubsection Text: As an elevator or escalator ages, it requires increasing amounts of maintenance to operate efficiently and maintain compliance with local regulations. Maintenance expenses for older systems also tend to increase as spare parts become outdated and therefore less common. Modernization helps solve these issues by providing customers with a range of options to prolong the usable life of an elevator or escalator system and postpone a more capital-intensive full replacement. With the age of the installed base of escalators and elevators generally increasing across regions, Modernizations represent a further source of recurring revenue alongside the New Installation and Service businesses. Modernizations can range from the replacement or upgrade of a single component (such as a traction machine) to the exchange of an entire system within a building (with a result akin to a New Installations project). OEMs seek to win modernization work from both existing Service customers and from new customers. Many modernization providers have the ability to modernize third-party elevator or escalator systems in addition to their own systems, representing opportunities to expand their installed base. The large and aging global installed base means that OEMs have the potential to derive significant recurring revenues from modernization customers. Moreover, OEMs have the potential to convert the modernized units into service contracts, increasing their number of units under maintenance. 128 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Overview of the Elevator and Escalator Market
Subsubsection Text: We are primarily active in the elevator and escalator market (referred to as “E&E”). The E&E market is worth approximately €56 billion (excluding Japan) according to the Market Size/Growth Analysis, and there are approximately 16 million elevators and escalators installed globally, with more than 900,000 new units installed each year. The E&E market encompasses (i) elevators for office buildings, apartment buildings, shopping centers, hotels, hospitals, train and metro stations, airports and other similar applications and (ii) escalators and moving walks with the ability to handle heavy traffic and frequent use utilized in a broad range of applications. A mixture of global, pure play elevator and escalator manufacturers, industrial conglomerates with elevator and escalator divisions and smaller regional and local companies make up the competitive landscape of the elevator and escalator market. For buyers of elevator and escalator products, key purchasing criteria include price (in particular for new installation tenders), customer relationships, brand reputation, operational scale, cost of ownership, terms of maintenance and repair services, efficiency and innovative product offerings. With a relatively fragmented, localized customer base and a diverse regulatory environment, local expertise is important to obtain both new installation and recurring service contracts. Elevators are typically divided into high-, mid- and low-rise categories, with varying regulatory and technical requirements. High-rise units generally serve commercial applications above 100 meters. Mid-rise units usually serve commercial or public projects with a height of 45-100 meters. Low-rise units mostly serve residential projects under 45 meters. Due to regional differences in product demand and regulation, elevator and escalator products from a manufacturer may also differ depending on the location of the intended customer. Within the elevator and escalator market, there are generally three discrete lines of business driven by the product lifecycle and customer relationship: New Installation, Services and Modernizations. After their initial manufacture and installation, elevators and escalators require continuous maintenance throughout their lifespan before requiring varying levels of modernization. The graphic below illustrates the typical sales lifecycle for an original equipment manufacturer (OEM) alongside the customer relationship for an elevator or escalator: **>90%** Retention rate 3[rd] party wins 10-20 years elevator lifetime prior to significant Modernization 3[rd] party wins New Manufacturing Selling Installation InstallationInstallation & Supply Chain **70 – 80%** Conversion rate

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Addressable Global Market Size and Market Development
Subsubsection Text: According to the Market Size/Growth Analysis, the elevator and escalator market is a structural growth market, which is mainly driven by urbanization, increasing demand for better access within cities across the globe and the continuous need for Service. For the five-year period from 2014 to 2019, the global elevator and escalator market (excluding Japan) grew from €51.3 billion to an estimated €55.8 billion at a CAGR of 1.7%, based on sales. The market is expected to further grow at a 3.3% CAGR between 2019 and 2024, reaching €65.6 billion in 2024, as illustrated by the graphic below:

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: ESTIMATED GLOBAL E&E MARKET GROWTH (€ billion) 2019-2024
Subsubsection Text: 14-19 19-24 54.2 55.8 57.5 10.4 10.9 11.3 +4.1% +4.1% 51.3 50.8 50.6 52.2 9.6 10.0 9.3 8.9 7.6 7.9 8.2 8.6 20.3 18.5 19.4 (1.4%) +4.3% 17.8 15.6 16.4 17.1 17.7 15.9 14.6 14.9 11.4 12.0 12.6 13.1 13.5 13.5 13.7 14.0 14.3 14.6 14.8 +3.3% +2.0% 14.6 15.0 15.2 15.6 16.2 16.6 17.1 17.6 18.1 18.6 19.1 +2.6% +2.8% 2014A 2015A 2016A 2017A 2018A 2019E 2020E 2021E 2022E 2023E 2024E Sources: Management, IHS, Freedonia, ELA, NEII, Oxford Economics, EIU, industry reports/experts, broker research, BCG (November 2019) Note: Historical numbers FX-adjusted. Excludes Japan There are approximately 16 million elevators and escalators currently installed globally, and over 900,000 new elevators and escalators are being installed each year, supported by an estimated increase in growth in China and ongoing growth in construction activity driving New Installations. Today, the global population, and in particular the urban population, continues to grow. More than 200,000 people move to cities each day (Source: United Nations, 2018). By 2050, the number of urban inhabitants is expected to increase by 55%, from approximately 4 billion today to nearly 7 billion (Source: United Nations, 2018). Within cities there is an increasing demand for better access and convenience, renovation activity of existing infrastructure, new large-scale infrastructure and urban living projects and demand for innovative products. As elevators and escalators are an inherent component of the residential and commercial multi-story buildings that characterize urban environments, this will drive structural growth for the elevator and escalator market. The elevator and escalator New Installations market is forecast to grow at a 1.7% CAGR between 2019 and 2024, driven in part by solid global macroeconomic output and construction output (source: Market Size/ Growth Analysis). Based on forecasts incorporating the COVID-19 impact, global residential construction spending is expected to decline by 1.5% in 2020 (compared to +1.9% growth expected pre-COVID-19 outbreak) and global non-residential construction is expected to decline by 1.7% (compared to +1.5% growth expected pre-COVID-19 outbreak) (source: IHS). The medium term outlook remains positive with global residential spending projected to grow at a 1.7% CAGR 19-24E and non-residential structures spending projected to increase at a 1.6% CAGR 19-24E (source: IHS). 129 ----- The elevator and escalator Service market is also forecast to outpace the greater global market with a 3.9% CAGR between 2019 and 2024, driven by increasing regulatory requirements and customer demands for safety and convenience as well as appreciation of service quality. This is particularly relevant in highly regulated and developed markets such as North America and Europe, with an ageing installed base. The elevator and escalator market is subject to a variety of laws and regulations which require the owners of elevator and escalator systems to invest in maintenance to ensure their systems are operating safely. The need for maintenance of a growing installed base is expected to fuel Service growth. In addition, the elevator and escalator modernization market is forecast to grow at a 6.9% CAGR between 2019 and 2024. As the installed base of elevators and escalators ages, property owners increasingly need to invest in modernization of their elevators and escalators to further ensure they comply with applicable regulatory requirements and continue to operate safely and efficiently. The trend towards sophisticated IoT solutions and general digitalization of transportation technologies is also estimated to support growth in the elevator and escalator Service market, as customers across regions demand increasing levels of service quality and uptime from their products. The availability of big data from elevators and escalators in real time allows OEMs to improve their Service offerings and increase the retention of their customers. Furthermore, new concepts in urbanization and architecture require innovative new elevator and escalator products that can increase usable space, passenger capacity and safety. Rope-less, multidirectional elevators (such as our MULTI elevator) are presenting architects and urban planners with new opportunities for building and infrastructure design. In addition, during the 2009 global financial crises, the elevator and escalator market delivered favorable growth rates and in particular, delivered more favorable returns than the broader industrial segment, demonstrating the resilience of the elevator and escalator market, as illustrated by the figures below:

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: As set out above, a mixture of global, pure play elevator and escalator manufacturers, industrial conglomerates with elevator and escalator divisions and smaller regional and local companies make up the competitive landscape of the elevator and escalator market. The below table illustrates the approximate market positions at the global level, excluding Japan: Otis Schindler Kone thyssenkrupp Elevator Mitsubishi[(2)] Hitachi Hyundai Fujitec Toshiba (1) Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis.
