Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Geographic Dynamics of the Elevator and Escalator Market
Subsubsection Text: Within the Americas, North America is a large and stable region, with an elevator and escalator market estimated at €11 billion as of September 30, 2019 (Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis). As a service-driven market, North America is characterized by its globally leading margins driven by the high value per unit under maintenance, which we estimate to be approximately five times that of China based on our order intake in the years ended September 30, 2018 and September 30, 2019. The United States represents the most important area within the Americas. The share of elevators in commercial operation (as opposed to residential) within the United States is expected to be 61% by 2021 (Source: Freedonia). Latin America represents a young market with significant upside potential. According to our estimates, we occupy a number two position in the Americas. Specific market dynamics include: - In New Installation, market value in North America was estimated at €3.9 billion and in Latin America was estimated at €0.8 billion as of 2019 (Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis). In the US, the market demands fast execution, a high level of cost efficiency and a quick turnover of finished products to drive growth. Furthermore, the market in North America has some of the highest technical requirements (for instance, regulatory requirements for more complex elevator brakes) in the industry, resulting in higher pricing compared to other regions. In addition, building code regulations in the United States mandating wheelchair accessibility drive growth for elevator and escalator products and service. The New Installations market in Latin America is expected to grow in terms of value at a CAGR of 3.1% for the five-year period from 2019 to 2024 due to a favorable macroeconomic outlook and changing trends from single-family to multi-family housing. (Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis) 131 ----- - In the Service business, market value (including service and repair sales) in North America was estimated at €5.1 billion as of 2019. (Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis) North America is a mature market with a relatively high number of installed units translating into a high Service share. Growth is expected to be driven by customer demand for high quality services and a willingness to pay for such service to ensure product uptime. Strict regulatory requirements for inspection and maintenance are also expected to contribute to growth. - In the Modernization business, market value in North America was estimated at €2.0 billion as of 2019. (Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis) There is an increasing potential for growth, as the average age of the installed base in North America increases and regulations remain strict. Over 50% of the installed base in the United States is more than 20 years old (Source: Third Party and Company Industry Analysis), driving a continuing need for further Modernizations.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Geographic Dynamics of the Elevator and Escalator Market
Subsubsection Text: Europe/Africa represents the world’s largest Service market based in part on an estimated six million units under maintenance as of 2019. The overall Europe/Africa elevator and escalator market is forecast to grow at a CAGR of 2.8% from 2019 to 2024. According to our estimates, we occupy a number four position in Europe/Africa. Specific market dynamics include: - In the New Installation business, market value in Europe/Africa was estimated at €5.3 billion as of 2019. Market volume in units is expected to grow at a CAGR of 2.2% for the five-year period from 2019 to 2024, driven by strong construction output, particularly from the residential segment and a slight recovery in Southern Europe (e.g., Spain). - In the Service business, market value (including service and repair sales) in Europe/Africa was estimated at €8.8 billion as of 2019. Europe is characterized by attractive conversion rates above the global average. The Service market in terms of sales in Europe is expected to grow at a CAGR of 2.7% for the five-year period from 2019 to 2024. Growth is expected to be driven by a number of factors, including customer demand for high quality and regulatory requirements. - In the Modernization business, market value in Europe/Africa was estimated at €2.5 billion as of 2019. (Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis) The large and aging installed base in Europe is expected to spur growth. Moreover, beneficial changes in EU regulations regarding modernization are expected to lead to further opportunities.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Geographic Dynamics of the Elevator and Escalator Market
Subsubsection Text: The Asia/Pacific region (excluding Japan) is the world’s largest New Installations market, with an approximately 700,000 new units estimated installed in 2019. In terms of market value within Asia/Pacific, in China, the market contracted at an estimated -1.4% CAGR from 2014 to 2019, in part due to government restrictions on construction in top-tier cities to counteract housing oversupply. A rebound is however expected in China with substantial growth expected from 2019 to 2024, supported by increasing opportunities for new installations. Significant growth is expected in the Asia/Pacific region more broadly as well, with an estimated CAGR of 4.2% from 2019 to 2024, mainly driven by the region’s increasing demand for Services and Modernizations and a turnaround in new installations in China. The market in Asia/Pacific is fragmented, with more than 50% of market share currently going to service companies smaller than the top providers in the region. This represents an opportunity for market share gain. According to our estimates, we occupy a number five position in Asia/Pacific, as well as a leading position in South Korea. Specific market dynamics include: - In New Installation, market value in Asia/Pacific was estimated at €16.2 billion as of 2019. (Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis) The absolute quantity of new units installed in 2019 was approximately 540,000 in China and approximately 160,000 in the rest of Asia/Pacific (India being the second largest New Installations market by volume), compared to approximately 220,000 units in the Americas and Europe/Africa regions combined. New Installations in China represent approximately 43% of the value of newly installed units per annum globally. The New Installations market in terms of value is expected to grow by a CAGR of 1.6% between 2019 and 2024. Robust growth is expected in China, India and other Asia/Pacific countries. - In the Service business, market value (including service and repair sales) in Asia/Pacific was estimated at €7.8 billion as of 2019. (Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis) Units under maintenance in 2019 were estimated at approximately eight million, having surpassed the European market in 2016. The share of the Service business in the overall elevator and escalator market has increased by 8.8 percentage points during the five-year period from 2013/2014 to 2018/2019, supported by increasing regulation governing 132 ----- maintenance and repairs. The Service market is expected to grow at a CAGR of 6.4% for the five-year period from 2019 to 2024. Drivers include an expanding installed base, especially in China, growing customer demand for high quality services and increasing regulation of the sector. The relatively mature South Korean market in particular is expected to place increasing importance on successful IoT service solutions. - In the Modernization business, market value in Asia/Pacific was estimated at €1.6 billion as of 2019. (Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis) The market is estimated to grow at a CAGR of approximately 15.6% forecast for the five-year period from 2019 to 2024. This is expected to be driven by the large installed base in China which was built during the earlier construction waves and is now, due to aging, reaching the first waves of modernization.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Geographic Dynamics of the Elevator and Escalator Market
Subsubsection Text: Due to factors including market maturity, regulatory variations and macroeconomic trends, the elevator and escalator market differs in important ways across regions.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We are also active in the market for airport and home solutions. Airport solutions include passenger boarding bridges and related group support equipment, as well as intelligent gate systems. Home solutions include chairlifts, platform lifts and home elevators that enable customers to move independently and comfortably in their homes and other buildings. The business-to-consumer nature of the home solutions business leads to a scattered customer landscape. The market for airport and home solutions is somewhat analogous to the elevator and escalator market in that the product characteristics are similar, there is crossover in parts of the customer base and it is generally organized around the same lines of business: New Installations, Services and Modernizations. Depending on individual product lines within the market, the competitive landscape can range from quite fragmented (platform lifts and home elevators) to more concentrated (passenger boarding bridges and chairlifts). Overall the market is characterized by a variety of opportunities for OEMs, with strong growth drivers and attractive margins. The home solutions business represents a structural growth market driven by an aging population globally. The world’s population is expected to age across all regions, with the ratio of people over the age of 65 years to those under the age of five years expected to rise from approximately 1:1 in 2019 to 2:1 in 2050 (Source: United Nations, 2019). The global market for home mobility accessibility solutions was an estimated €2.3 billion in 2019, and the market is expected to grow at a CAGR of approximately 5% for the five-year period from 2019 to 2024. According to our estimates, it occupies a number three global position for home solutions. The airport solutions business also represents a growth market, driven by an increasing number of air travel passengers worldwide together with rising infrastructure investments. Customer demand for high quality service and digital solutions are also expected to drive further growth. The global market for airport solutions was an estimated €1.0 billion in 2019, and the market is expected to grow at a CAGR of approximately 4% for the fiveyear period from 2019 to 2024. (Source: Market Size/Growth Analysis). According to our estimates, our airport solutions business occupies the number one position globally. 133 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We are one of the world’s leading providers of elevator and escalator technology, with top market positions in the Americas, Europe and Africa and a strong platform to capture growth opportunities in the Asia Pacific region. We design, manufacture, install, service and modernize state-of-the-art passenger and freight elevators, escalators, moving walkways, passenger boarding bridges and chair and platform lifts, covering the entire product life cycle from new installation to service and modernization. Building on our German engineering heritage, we are an innovation leader in the digital age, leveraging Internet of Things technologies to collect data and make recommendations for repairs in real time to better serve rapidly urbanizing societies with a focus on product safety and efficiency. Operating from approximately 1,000 locations worldwide and serving customers in more than 100 countries, our business is characterized by a global sales and service network to ensure optimum proximity to clients. High-profile infrastructure projects such as One World Trade Center in New York, the tallest building in the Americas, the Beijing International Airport T3 Terminal and the Federation Tower in Russia have all featured our elevator and escalator products, illustrating our strengths and global reach. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, our sales and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA were €8,048 million and €1,323 million, respectively. Our operations comprise three business lines: - _New Installation:_ Our New Installation business covers the design, manufacture and installation of elevators, escalators and moving walks for all major markets and industries, including for both commercial and residential projects, and includes low-rise, mid-rise and high-rise solutions offered at different customization levels. Our New Installation business contributed 45% of sales in the twelve months ended March 31, 2020. - _Service:_ Our Service business offers a broad range of maintenance services both for our own and thirdparty equipment, with a view to ensuring the continued safety, performance and efficiency of elevators, escalators and moving walkways throughout their usable lives. Depending on the scope agreed in our service contracts, our services range from basic oil and grease maintenance to bespoke full-service packages that include the sale and installation of replacement parts. As of March 31, 2020, we had approximately 1.4 million units under maintenance. Our Service business contributed 43% of sales in the twelve months ended March 31, 2020. - _Modernization:_ Our Modernization business offers comprehensive solutions ranging from partial modernization to complete replacement of existing elevator and escalator systems and other solutions, both for our own and for third-party systems. Our Modernization business contributed 12% of sales in the twelve months ended March 31, 2020. Our life-cycle business model is built on our New Installation business, which serves as the entry to our Service business. On average, we convert 70% to 80% of new elevator and escalator installations into ongoing Service contracts. This provides a source of stable and recurring sales as we also succeeded in retaining more than 90% of our Service customers in each of our last three financial years. In addition, we win Service and Modernization contracts from third parties where another manufacturer undertook the New Installation. The Service and Modernization businesses, which together accounted for 54% of sales and around 70% of gross profit in the 2018/2019 Financial Year, are a source of stable, recurring sales and high profit margins for the Group, which provides visibility on future earnings. Driven by our high conversion rate and high retention rates, we have been able to maintain longstanding customer relationships. Given our global reach and high level of diversification, our top ten customers in aggregate typically account for less than 3% of our annual revenue. 134 ----- The following graphic illustrates the elevator life-cycle: **>90%** Retention rate 3[rd] party wins 10-20 years elevator lifetime prior to significant Modernization 3[rd] party wins New Manufacturing Selling Installation InstallationInstallation & Supply Chain **70 – 80%** Conversion rate We have two core divisions and four operating segments, which are part of our reporting segments in accordance with IFRS 8: Americas, Europe/Africa, Asia/Pacific and Access Solutions (together, our “Operating Segments”) through which we conduct our customer-facing business activities. Our first core division is the new installation, service and modernization of elevators, escalators and moving walks (the “Elevator and Escalator division”). Our second core division is the new installation, service and modernization of access solutions for airports and homes (the “Access Solutions division”). The Elevator and Escalator division is divided into three Operating Segments based on geography, which enables each to tailor its products to the specific customer needs and legal and regulatory requirements in its local markets: - _Americas:_ Our Americas segment covers our Elevator and Escalator division’s activities in the Americas and is sub-divided into two further regional units, including North America, covering the United States and Canada, and Latin America, covering Brazil as the main Latin American sales area and Spanish Latin America. Our Americas segment contributed €3,306 million, or 41%, of the Operating Segments’ total sales and €489 million, or 51%, of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. - _Europe/Africa:_ Our Europe/Africa segment covers our Elevator and Escalator division’s activities in Europe and Africa and operates within a widely diverse set of geographical areas through five operational units: “DACH,” comprising Germany, Austria and Switzerland, “RET,” comprising Russia, Eastern Europe and Turkey, “FRANCE,” comprising France and Monaco, “BBNI,” comprising the Benelux countries, Britain, the Nordics and Italy and “IBA,” comprising Spain, Portugal, Angola and Morocco and, through distributors, certain African countries. Our Europe/Africa segment contributed €2,149 million, or 26%, of the Operating Segments’ total sales and €227 million, or 24%, of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. - _Asia/Pacific:_ Our Asia/Pacific segment covers our Elevator and Escalator division’s activities in the Asia/ Pacific region and is organized in six operational units: China, South Korea, India, Australia/New Zealand, Southeast Asia and the Middle East. Our Asia/Pacific segment contributed €2,307 million, or 28%, of the Operating Segments’ total sales and €178 million, or 19%, of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. Our Access Solutions division operates across all geographies and constitutes our fourth Operating Segment. It employs a number of different sales strategies and distribution channels, catering to both the business-to-business and business-to-consumer markets. The Access Solutions division accounted for 5% of the Operating Segments’ total sales and 6% of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The following graphs show the sales contribution of our business lines to each Operating Segment for the 2018/2019 Financial Year:

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Well-established player with a leading global position
Subsubsection Text: We hold the top four market position in the global elevator and escalator market (excluding Japan) based on revenues in the 2017/2018 Financial Year. Our Elevator and Escalator division is divided into three geographical segments, the Americas, Europe/Africa and Asia/Pacific, which comprise the majority of elevator and escalator markets worldwide. Based on revenue in the 2017/2018 Financial Year, we hold the number two position in the Americas, our most profitable elevator and escalator region, the number four position in Europe/Africa, which has the largest service business by value globally, and the number five position in Asia/Pacific, the world’s largest new installations market. As of March 31, 2020, we had 1.4 million units under maintenance across the globe. The following graph shows our market position in the elevator and escalator market (excluding Japan) based on sales in the 2017/2018 Financial Year: Otis Schindler Kone thyssenkrupp Elevator Mitsubishi Hitachi Hyundai Fujitec Toshiba We believe that our status as a global leader in the elevator and escalator industry is attributable to our particularly strong and far-reaching service network, our track record of high profile infrastructure projects, and our offering of products and services across the life cycle of elevators and escalators, from new installation to service to modernization. In addition, we believe that our expertise in the manufacturing and provision of spare parts, along with our network of specialists and a strong and globally recognized German engineering heritage, have resulted in a particularly high ranking among our peers with regards to competency of our field force, which in conjunction with our innovation technology, are what we believe to be the primary purchasing criteria for customers and puts us in a position of strength relative to our peers. Our strong market position is also driven by our offering of some of the most innovative and cutting-edge elevator solutions in the world, such as our MAX technology (“MAX”), our cloud-based maintenance tool, which utilizes Internet of Things (“IoT”) technologies to collect data on installed units and make recommendations for repairs in real time, making it immensely valuable to our Service business. In addition, we are in the process of developing the innovative MULTI elevator system (“MULTI”), a rope-less elevator able to move both vertically and horizontally.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Highly resilient business model across cycles through service focused-business and balanced global footprint
Subsubsection Text: We have developed a business model that we believe is stable, balanced and resilient through economic cycles, and therefore, well-positioned for sustainable, long-term value generation, as demonstrated by our strong longterm historical growth. We have delivered resilient sales and Adjusted EBIT margins since the 2007/2008 Financial Year. Despite negative currency effects in recent financial years, our sales have increased from €7,674 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €8,048 million in the twelve months ended March 31, 2020, highlighting the stability of our business and our ability to maintain our sales and profitability over the economic cycle despite external pressures. The main driver of the resilience and stability of our overall business is the life cycle of our business model. Our New Installation business is a key driver of our growing installed base and units under maintenance and therefore is the entry gate to our Service and Modernization business. The Service business generates revenue streams that include fees for regular maintenance and income from repairs and spare parts. The strong profitability and the 136 ----- asset-light character of our Service business contribute to our high cash generation. For the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years, 70% to 80% of our New Installation units converted into Service units. In each of the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years, the Service business maintained a global retention rate of over 90%. Many of our Service business customers eventually become customers of our Modernization business, which offers us the opportunity to generate revenue from retrofitting or replacing entire systems of elevators and escalators while continuing the customer relationship. In addition, we attract many Service customers whose elevator and escalator systems were manufactured and installed by third parties, adding to our steady Service and Modernization revenue streams. The high resilience of our business is also driven by a diversified customer base with long-term contracts and high customer retention rates and a balanced global footprint, minimizing both customer and geographic concentration risks. Our top ten customers accounted for less than 3% of sales in each of the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years. Geographically, our elevator and escalator operations (including manufacturing facilities, service centers and employees) are divided across three Operating Segments: the Americas, Europe/Africa and Asia/Pacific, which accounted for 41%, 26% and 28% of our Operating Segment’s total sales, respectively, in the twelve months ended March 31, 2020. Our fourth Operating Segment, the Access Solutions division, operates globally and generated 5% of our Operating Segments’ total sales for the same period. The resilience of our business model is demonstrated by our financial performance during periods of worldwide economic distress. For example, during the global financial crisis, our total Adjusted EBIT margin and sales remained stable between the 2008/2009 Financial Year and the 2009/2010 Financial Year. Most recently, we have been able to successfully manage and limit the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business by having immediately implemented contingency measures, which we believe further proves the resilience of our business model through the economic cycles. See “Recent Developments—Coronavirus (COVID-19).”

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Highly attractive industry with structural growth drivers
Subsubsection Text: We operate in the global elevator and escalator market, which generated sales of €55.8 billion in 2019 worldwide (excluding Japan). The global elevator and escalator market grew at a CAGR of 1.7% between 2014 and 2019, and prior to taking into account the impact of COVID-19, was expected to grow at a CAGR of 3.3% between 2019 and 2024, above expected real GDP growth. Specifically, between 2019 and 2024, the new installation, service and modernization businesses were expected to grow at a CAGR of 1.7%, 3.9% and 6.9%, respectively. This growth is underpinned by structural factors and megatrends, including increasing urbanization, an aging population, a supportive regulatory environment and sustainability and digitalization trends. Increasing urbanization is one of the primary drivers for the need for more urban spaces worldwide, which increases demand for elevators and escalators, as they are an inherent component of the residential and commercial multi-story buildings that characterize urban environments. By 2050, the number of urban inhabitants is expected to increase by 55%, from approximately four billion today to nearly seven billion. In particular, the urban population is expected to increase in emerging markets, including from approximately 60% in 2018 to 80% in 2050 in China. This trend positively affects the growth of the elevator and escalator market, as urban residents increasingly demand the access and convenience provided by elevators and escalators, particularly in cities in the developed world where large-scale urban living and infrastructure projects (such as hospitals, shopping malls and train stations) are increasingly required to offer fast and efficient urban mobility solutions. Growth in the elevator and escalator market is also driven by an increasingly aging population. The ratio of people over the age of 65 years to those under the age of five years is expected to rise from approximately 1:1 in 2019 to 2:1 in 2050. This trend is likely to support demand for elevator and escalator solutions as well as home access solutions for stairs, as the growing aging population will need or prefer the mobility afforded by elevators, escalators and home access solutions. In addition, growth in the elevator and escalator market is driven by a supportive regulatory environment, which requires the owners of elevator and escalator systems to invest in basic maintenance services to ensure their systems are consistently operating safely. Currently, over 50% of elevators in North America and Europe are over 20 years old. As the installed base of elevators and escalators grows and ages, property owners are increasingly in need of modernizing their elevators and escalators to ensure they comply with applicable regulatory requirements and continue to operate safely. In Asia/Pacific, including China and South Korea, we believe that there is a particularly strong opportunity to grow our Service and Modernization businesses driven by the aging of the installed base in those markets and stricter safety regulations requiring regular maintenance and upgrades. 137 ----- We believe that long-term growth in the elevator and escalator market will also be positively impacted by a continued focus on digitalization, connectivity and sustainability, as customers increasingly value features such as improved energy efficiency and enhanced safety and maintenance monitoring. According to the Market Size/ _Growth Analysis, the market for buildings with digitally automated operations or “smart buildings” is expected to_ grow at 5% per annum through 2024. We believe that our current innovative smart mobility solutions and our strong research and development capabilities position us to benefit from this demand. For example, our TWIN elevator system (“TWIN”), which combines two independent cars in one shaft, can already reduce energy costs by up to 25% and increase usable floor space by up to 25%. In addition we estimate that our MULTI system, which we are in the process of developing and will be the world’s first rope-free elevator, will allow for space reductions of up to a further 30% to 50% compared to our TWIN system. We aim to consistently increase product efficiency and provide additional value-add to our customers across our portfolio of new and existing products and services.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: A leader in technology and innovation in the elevator and escalator market
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we are a leading innovator in the elevator and escalator market, offering disruptive innovation and transformative digital solutions. We have been able to successfully monetize IoT and digital opportunities, as demonstrated by our recently developed MAX technology and our proprietary IT system, VIEW. MAX is a cloud-based maintenance tool which utilizes IoT technologies to collect data relating to customer elevator units and make diagnostic recommendations, such as when repairs need to be undertaken or which critical parts need to be replaced. VIEW is an operational business steering tool, which, among other things, automatically dispatches qualified technicians to resolve the problems identified by MAX, often even before any visible operational issues occur. Leveraging our expertise in IoT and other digital tools enables us to improve customer satisfaction by increasing service quality and efficiency, thereby increasing our customer retention rates and decreasing cancellation rates. In addition, we believe that we have created some of the most innovative elevator concepts currently in operation in the market. We are the only supplier in the industry to have an offering similar to our TWIN elevator system, which combines two independent cars in one shaft. We are also currently in the process of developing the MULTI system, which would be the world’s first rope-free elevator, allowing for space reductions of up to a further 30% to 50% compared to our TWIN system. These systems offer customers greater space efficiency and architectural flexibility than conventional designs, making us an attractive choice for a customer base that is increasingly demanding more innovative elevator and escalator products.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Strong financial profile with significant operational improvement opportunity.
Subsubsection Text: We have a track record of long-term stable sales growth, high cash flow generation and high earnings visibility on recurring future earnings driven by a ten- to 20-year elevator life cycle with a retention rate of over 90%. Our Elevator and Escalator division has grown consistently over the years, with our Adjusted EBIT margin generally increasing since the 2011/2012 Financial Year until the 2016/2017 Financial Year. While facing some headwinds, especially from material price developments and trade tariffs implemented in recent years, we believe that, following the Transactions, there will be greater opportunity to increase our Adjusted EBIT margin. Our business benefits from high revenue visibility given the recurring and stable nature of our Service and Modernization business model. Our New Installation business represents the key enabler for growth of Service and Modernization by growing our units under maintenance and offering high visibility of future business performance due to long order-to-fulfilment times. Most of our New Installation units are converted into maintenance units, which propels our Service business. Our Service contracts on average have a gross profit margin of approximately 40%, which progressively increases over the elevator’s lifetime due to increased spare parts sales. Many of our Service business customers eventually become customers of our Modernization business, driven by an aging installed base with the need to upgrade and extend the life cycle of the elevators and escalators. The Service and Modernization businesses, which together accounted for 54% of sales and around 70% of gross profit for the 2018/2019 Financial Year, are a source of stable, recurring sales and high profit margins for the Group. Our Service contracts have an average length between one to five years. Our full life cycle business model, with our high conversion and retention rates across businesses and long-term customer relationships, enables high visibility on recurring future earnings. 138 ----- The following graph illustrates how the elevator life-cycles allow high visibility on future recurring earnings: t h y s s e n k r u p p E l e v a t o r v a l u e c h a i n ( i l l u s t r a t i v e ) Elevator lifetime: c. 10-20 years of elevator lifetime prior to significant Modernization Time Maintenance fee Spare parts Maintenance Maintenance Maintenance Maintenance Maintenance Contract Contract Contract Contract Contract The profitability of our business is also driven by our fully invested global foothold, which requires limited capital expenditure and working capital given our asset-light business model, resulting in a strong cash flow profile. Our elevator technology business has significantly increased cash generation since 2011/2012, roughly doubling its business cash flow through generating higher profits and reducing operating net working capital by approximately 80%. Our cash conversion rate was approximately 90% in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. Excluding certain one-off expenditures incurred from time to time (such as €3 million, €6 million and €106 million for major mergers and acquisition projects in the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years (including the acquisitions of Nashville Machine’s elevator division and O’Keefe Elevator Company, Inc.) as well as carve-out related one-time expenditures of €1,080 million paid in connection with the Licensing Agreement fee for use of the “thyssenkrupp” brand and of €74 million for carve-out related real estate transfers, in both cases, in the 2018/2019 Financial Year), our capital expenditures were €145 million, €115 million, and €129 million for the 2016/2017 Financial Year, the 2017/2018 Financial Year and the 2018/2019 Financial Year, respectively, highlighting our generally stable and relatively limited capital investment requirements. See “Summary Financial and Other Data—Other Financial, Operating and Pro Forma Information—Other _Financial and Operating Information.” We believe that the development of business cash flow and cash_ conversion over the last three financial years demonstrates that we operate an asset-light business with relatively low capital requirements and high cash returns. In addition, we believe our business offers significant operational improvement potential and profitability upside. We have recently implemented several cost optimization initiatives that we believe will generate greater margins. For example, we have restructured our manufacturing operations by optimizing our footprint and leveraging shared services and best practices, as well as streamlining our product offerings. These initiatives have led to stable development in cost of goods sold by partially offsetting personnel cost inflation through efficiency measures and headcount management, and compensating for material cost increases through purchasing measures and the improved management of procurement volume. These efficiency measures have also reduced SG&A costs as a percentage of sales from 18.5% in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to 16.4% in the twelve months ended March 31, 2020. In addition, following the Acquisition, we expect to realize an additional estimated €240 million in potential cost savings within 15 to 18 months after July 1, 2020 as part of the Sponsors’ transformation program (the “Transformation Program”). See “—Our Strategies—Core Strategy: Realize _structural profitability upside” and “Summary Financial and Other Data—Other Financial, Operating and Pro- Forma Information—Other Pro Forma Information.”_

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Highly experienced and execution focused management team
Subsubsection Text: We are led by an experienced, entrepreneurial management team that is committed to continuing our strong track record of growth, with a focus on product quality, customer service and delayering. Peter Walker, the Group’s chief executive officer, began his career as an entrepreneur and has more than 25 years’ experience in the elevator industry. Among other achievements, he was instrumental, as chief executive officer of Asia/Pacific, to the successful establishment of the Group’s footprint in Asia/Pacific, where he helped drive increases in revenue and profitability and is credited with turning around the then loss-making South Korea business. Mr. Walker served as the Group’s chief operating officer before being appointed chief executive officer in 2019. Ercan Keles has served as the Group’s chief financial officer for eight years and has previously served in various positions for entities in the thyssenkrupp Group and externally for more than 13 years. Mr. Keles has been key to driving the Group’s profitability and cost efficiency measures in recent years. Dr. Detlef Hunsdiek, the Company’s chief human resources officer, has deep restructuring experience and is responsible for rolling out the Group’s efficiency programs across its global network. In addition to our senior executive team, our business benefits 139 ----- from our experienced and dedicated local management teams, including the chief executive officers of our business units, who each have a deep understanding of the elevator and escalator market and geographic expertise. Together, our management team has successfully grown our business to become the fourth-largest elevator and escalator company globally (excluding Japan) and increased our sales from €7,674 million in the 2016/2017 Financial Year to €8,048 million in the twelve months ended March 31, 2020. We have operated largely as an independent company while under thyssenkrupp AG’s ownership. Our management team, which is strategically positioned around the globe, has maintained responsibility for the continued operational excellence of our company while under thyssenkrupp AG and has succeeded in improving performance during that time. Following the completion of the Acquisition, we also expect our business to benefit from the market expertise, business relationships, knowledge and experience of the Sponsors. Advent and Cinven have strong expertise and an extensive and successful track record of investing in the industrials and business services sectors and in carve-out transactions, particularly in Germany, where each of them have had a presence for more than 20 years and successfully invested individually in more than 39 companies. Worldwide, Advent and Cinven have invested in 130 companies in the industrials and business services sectors, further demonstrating considerable experience in the relevant markets. For example, Advent has successfully invested in Laird, Innio, Allnex, Cobham and Rubix in the industrials sector, Nets and Hune in the business services sector and Walmart Brasil and Innio in carve-out transactions, while the Cinven Funds have successfully invested in CeramTec, SLV, and Tractel in the industrials sector, Envirotainer, JLA and Barentz in the business services sector and CeramTec, Ufinet and Viridium in carve-out transactions. Advent and Cinven also have a strong track record in successfully executing value creation plans. In addition, it is expected that thyssenkrupp AG or one or more of its affiliates will invest in an indirect parent company of Bidco, retaining a minority interest of approximately 19% in the Group. Such shareholding percentage is indicative and may be subject to variation.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Base Strategy: Continue to capitalize on our market position and structural growth
Subsubsection Text: Our Base strategy consists of leveraging the structural factors that drive growth in the market in which we operate, together with our leading position in those markets, to grow our business and increase our profitability. As one of the world’s leading elevator and escalator companies, we aim to manufacture and install a substantial portion of the new elevators and escalators expected to be installed worldwide in the coming years. As a result of our global scale and strong brand recognition in the market, we believe there is significant sales potential for our New Installation business and continued growth opportunities for increasing our units under maintenance, resulting in further revenue and profit generation in our key markets. In addition, we target continued growth in all our business segments by leveraging structural factors such as an aging population, global urbanization and stricter safety requirements driving demand for maintenance and modernization services. In particular, we believe that our Service and Modernization businesses are positioned for growth as the installed base of elevators and escalators grows and ages. In the Americas, we target growth in our New Installation business, driven by expected growth in the US construction sector and our strength in meeting customer demands for efficient execution and technical excellence, such as our expertise in the hydraulic segment. We target growth in our Service business due to customer demand for high quality services with short lead times, and through reducing cancellation rates and winning service contracts for third-party installations. We also target growth in both our Service and Modernization businesses driven by increases in the average age of the installed base of elevators and escalators in the region and a strict regulatory environment. In Europe/Africa, we expect that the large, aging installed base of elevators and escalators, supported by a strict regulatory environment and high customer retention and conversion rates, will generate attractive service and modernization opportunities. We further expect that strong construction output, particularly from the residential segment and a slight recovery in Southern Europe as well as a more competitive product offering due to our manufacturing optimization initiatives in Spain and Germany, will drive our New Installation business and, consequently, growth in our Service and Modernization businesses. 140 ----- In Asia/Pacific, we aim to benefit from the anticipated growth of the new installations market, targeting robust expansion of our New Installation business, including in India and other markets. We believe that growing customer demand for high quality services and an expanding installed base will also contribute to growth in our Service and Modernization businesses. We expect that an expanding installed base of elevators and escalators and the growing importance of IoT solutions, particularly in South Korea, will lead to strong growth opportunities in our Service and Modernization businesses. We expect China, the largest elevator and escalator market in Asia, will continue to generate our highest New Installation growth globally, and that conversion of many of these newly installed units to Service contracts will continue to drive growth in the Service business. We believe that there is a particularly strong opportunity to grow our Service and Modernization businesses in China and other developing markets, driven by the growth and the aging of the installed base in those markets and stricter safety regulations requiring regular maintenance and upgrades, which many emerging market countries are adopting as their regulatory systems mature.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Core Strategy: Realize structural profitability upside
Subsubsection Text: Our Core strategy consists of realizing structural profitability upside by focusing on (i) standardization within our New Installation business, (ii) manufacturing optimization, (iii) service and modernization growth and digitalization, (iv) selling, general and administrative (“SG&A”) cost reduction and (v) procurement optimization. In addition, following the Acquisition, we expect to realize additional cost savings as part of the Sponsors’ Transformation Program. _Standardization of Our New Installation Business_ We plan to continue to drive the standardization of our New Installation business by simplifying the amount and types of products and components we offer our customers. Historically, in part due to our strategy of growing through acquisitions, we provided customers with a large share of customized product solutions. This resulted in a highly diverse but overlapping product portfolio and limited price competitiveness due to the high costs of designing and producing such a wide range of individualized products. In order to optimize our structure, we are in the process of simplifying our regional product portfolio and standardizing certain components. For example, the number of product platforms in the Group has been reduced by more than half in the last decade as part of a process of implementing a simplified portfolio structure with further improvements planned going forward. In Europe, we have streamlined our major platforms down to two, which cover 80% of our products. This has resulted in synergies and a strong evolution of order intake in the first half of 2019/2020 while not impacting customers’ perception of our product offering or quantity of sales. We believe this will lead us to benefit from economies of scales, focusing our resource allocation more efficiently and allowing us to provide a more cost-competitive offering without compromising on customer service. In addition, we have also standardized and harmonized components across products to allow specific modular components, such as traction machines, controllers/inverters and doors, to be used across multiple product platforms, which we expect will result in lower costs due to the use of fewer parts, a leaner set-up, less complexity, higher agility and easier external sourcing. These initiatives are aimed at focusing our sales teams on value-based selling by presenting customers with a harmonized product portfolio of key high quality, high margin products. We plan to adapt our manufacturing to focus on products that provide our customers with one of three customization levels for low-rise buildings (less than 45 meters), mid-rise buildings (between 45 and 100 meters) and high-rise buildings (above 100 meters). These customization levels comprise: (i) Value for Money “100,” which is our lower priced option with no customization; (ii) Performance “200,” which is our moderately priced option with medium customization; and (iii) Customization “300,” which is our high priced option with full customization. This value proposition model offers customers flexible and transparent pricing, which we expect will make our products especially compelling to customers in high-volume and growth markets, such as large property developers in Asia/Pacific. Our processes, in turn, will be optimized by focusing on a leaner offering and steering our salesforces and engineers toward a focus on sales efforts based on product margin potentials and the conversion of New Installation units into Service contracts and later into Modernization sales. _Manufacturing Optimization_ We are engaged in an ongoing effort to optimize our manufacturing operations. These measures have included closing and, where possible, consolidating manufacturing sites, increasing outsourcing of standardized products and developing factories with improved technology for greater automation. For example, in Asia/Pacific, we 141 ----- have established leaner manufacturing operations, with a newly established plant in India and advances in automation at our plants in China and South Korea. In the Americas, we have consolidated all North America manufacturing at our Middleton facility to enhance efficiency and reduce costs. In Europe/Africa, we have shifted our factories away from a regional focus (in which a particular factory only serves specific countries) to a model where all factories can deliver to the entire Europe/Africa region, with each factory having a dedicated product focus. As part of this shift, we have restructured our Móstoles plant in Spain and we are currently restructuring our operations in Germany to reduce costs and simplify production. In the long term, we aim to move away from a classic factory model, where the focus is on major production and shipping of complete elevator systems and requires high personnel expenses, towards a model where we produce only key, mission critical components and outsource commoditized parts, resulting in lower fixed costs and higher productivity. _Service and Modernization Growth and Digitalization_ We aim to deliver service growth through leveraging our attractive business model and IoT innovation technology. Our business model contributes to the growth of our Service and Modernization business as, on average, 70% to 80% of New Installation contracts convert into Service contracts, and many of those Service business customers eventually become customers of the Modernization business. We aim to grow our Service business, which is a source of stable and recurring sales and high margins, by pursuing multiple initiatives aimed at increasing revenues per unit while decreasing costs. In particular, we believe that our use of digital and IoT technologies, including the recently developed MAX and VIEW systems, will enable us to improve customer satisfaction by increasing service quality and efficiency, and thereby increase customer retention rates and decrease cancellation rates. Particularly, in North America, our Service business growth is driven by the reduction of cancellation rates. We have already improved our cancellation rates and we aim to reduce our cancellation rates further through strict management focus and tools like the MAX and VIEW. We expect the growth of our Service business will contribute to new Modernization customers as the installed base grows and ages, generating an additional stream of stable and recurring revenues. We also believe that we can leverage the scale and efficiency gains achieved by MAX and VIEW to reduce the costs per unit of providing services, such as technician travel time and spare parts. In addition, we intend to increase our rate of winning customers away from competitor service providers by enhancing the efficiency of our spare parts organization, increasing our service training and leveraging the superior quality of our Service business and our capability to refurbish multi-brand spare parts through our ITS unit. _SG&A costs optimization_ We aim to reduce SG&A costs by centralizing administrative functions, adopting a range of organizational efficiency measures and improving our IT systems. Specifically, we are engaged in an ongoing effort to combine a wide array of administrative processes that historically have been performed locally, such as billing, payroll and purchasing, into shared service centers. For example, in the United States, we are in the process of consolidating these functions, previously spread over 18 locations, into one shared service center at the US headquarters in Atlanta, and we intend to roll out a similar strategy in Europe and Asia. We are also in the process of harmonizing our IT processes by rolling out VIEW globally, continuing to transition to cloud-based services, adopting global templates and standards, “delayering,” or flattening, management levels to simplify our organization and reduce overhead costs and adopting other efficiency enhancements. These measures have resulted in more than €80 million in total cost savings over the last three financial years. _Procurement Optimization_ Finally, throughout our Core strategy, we aim to reduce our procurement costs by optimizing our supply chains through commercial measures, such as, for example, supplier days, clustering managed spend, and engaging in e-auctions, continuing from measures implemented historically. For example, between the 2011/2012 Financial Year and the 2018/2019 Financial Year, our purchasing savings increased by 300%, outpacing our procurement spend which increased by 50%. _Transformation Program_ Following the Acquisition, we expect to realize €240 million in potential cost savings by September 30, 2021 through the Sponsors’ Transformation Program, assuming the program will be implemented beginning on July 1, 2020 and driven by key management, including the Chief Executive Officer of the Group. The Transformation Program focuses on cost savings opportunities related to (i) commercial operations, (ii) service operations, (iii) procurement costs, (iv) G&A costs and (v) other operational costs. Some of these initiatives will be continued through the efficiency measures, which we are already in the process of implementing, as described above. 142 ----- As part of our commercial operations initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to improve our organizational efficiency by restructuring and centralizing our sales supports team, including by shifting employees to low cost countries. In addition, we seek to increase our sales force productivity through various measures, including improving our administrative processes and completing faster technical sales. This is facilitated by our offering of fewer customization options resulting from the optimization of our product and service portfolios. We also intend to increase our focus on sales efforts based on product margin potentials and the conversion of New Installation units into Service contracts and later into Modernization sales. We expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €7 million related to our commercial operations initiatives. As part of our service operations initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to improve our organizational efficiency by rationalizing the number of our application engineers, reducing the number of platforms in our offering, standardizing our service offering and reducing the number of our service centers, particularly in the U.S. We intend to implement other measures under these initiatives as well, including improving process, technology and performance management in order to increase the productivity of our service technicians. We expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €15 million related to our service operations initiatives. As part of our procurement initiatives under the Transformation Program, we intend to implement multiple measures to reduce costs relating to our procurement activities. For the 2018/2019 Financial Year, we believe that our estimated addressable cost base for procurement activities comprised €2.1 billion of direct costs and €0.5 billion of indirect costs. To reduce these costs, we intend to establish group-wide supply agreements with global suppliers for key categories of direct materials, such as motors, cables and doors, including through leveraging change-of-control provisions under our existing supplier agreements with local or regional suppliers. We also expect to increase our focus on supplier driven innovation in connection with, among other things, tendering processes. To pursue improvements in specification management, we seek to standardize purchases for complex parts and establish business unit sourcing boards, which will act as advisory panels in key end markets to promote best practices and streamline procurement processes. Furthermore, we continue to shift our relationships with local suppliers to regional suppliers in order to both increase the number of sites served by our suppliers and decrease the number of our total suppliers, resulting in increased efficiencies. We also continue to streamline the amount and variety of individually supplied components in order to purchase bundles of different products and higher volumes of specific products, resulting in improved purchasing ability. Moreover, where appropriate, we target shifting to agreements with suppliers in low cost countries or otherwise shifting purchases from our suppliers of local products to products sourced from low cost countries. In addition, we are working to utilize both centralized regional lead-buyers to streamline demand-management processes and defined sourcing hubs to allow for best value and benchmark sourcing through increased spend, price and margin transparency. Furthermore, we expect to realize cost savings from our commercial operations initiatives that result in the rationalization of our product offering and standardization of our SKUs. We expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €132 million in connection with our procurement initiatives. As part of our G&A cost savings initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to improve our organizational efficiency and generate attrition savings through a leaner operating model, the shifting of employees to low cost countries and increased automation, including within our shared service centers. We expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €36 million related to our G&A cost savings initiatives. As part of our other operational initiatives under the Transformation Program, we aim to reduce direct and indirect personnel expenses and scrappage costs by decreasing the portion of poor quality production. We target replicating the cost of poor quality levels that we have achieved at our Korean plant (where such costs are estimated to be 0.6% of internal sales) at our other plants, particularly our Middleton plant. We also intend to outsource parts and components and streamline production overhead and assembly processes to reduce costs. We expect to realize cost savings in an aggregate amount of €50 million related to our other operational initiatives. We expect to incur one-off costs amounting to between €240 and €294 million in connection with these initiatives, mainly as a result of (i) voluntary redundancy, early retirement and other severance costs, (ii) staff training costs, (iii) investments in IT to digitize, automate and streamline processes, (iv) investments in the existing shared service centers in Europe, Brazil and the U.S., as well as potentially operating new, regional centers in Eastern Europe and Asia and (v) consulting, financial and legal advisory fees in connection with implementing these initiatives. See also “Summary Financial and Other Data—Other Financial, Operating and Pro-Forma Information—Other _Pro Forma Information.”_ 143 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Core+ Strategy: Deliver additional value through innovation, digitalization and bolt-on acquisitions
Subsubsection Text: Our Core+ strategy aims to deliver additional value by (i) focusing on disruptive innovation, (ii) monetizing IoT opportunities, (iii) seeking opportunistic mergers and acquisitions and (iv) continuing the measures defined under our Core strategy. We have a long-standing German engineering heritage and a history of innovative digital solutions with the potential to transform the Elevator and Escalator division. We are a leading innovator in the elevator and escalator market and strive to address what we believe are fundamental technological challenges to better serve a rapidly urbanizing society. For example, we estimate that up to 40% of usable space in buildings is utilized for elevator shafts. Our TWIN elevator system combines two independent cars in one shaft in order to increase efficiency and creates more usable area by using up to 25% less usable space than an ordinary elevator. The TWIN elevator system’s unique value-add has made it a top choice for premier buildings around the world, including the European Central Bank in Frankfurt, Germany, and the CMA Tower in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. We believe that our MULTI elevator system, which is currently in the developing phase, has the potential to be even more compelling to the market. MULTI is a rope-less elevator able to move both vertically and horizontally, which will allow new architectural designs and unlimited building height and, we estimate, will use up to 30% to 50% less usable space than an ordinary elevator. We believe that our New Installation customers place a high value on innovative solutions like TWIN and MULTI, which both have the potential to significantly increase the usable area in buildings that is available for sale or rent. We also aim to continue to monetize our IoT technologies more effectively in the future to create sustainable business value and cash flow. By the 2021/2022 Financial Year, we aim to charge connection and monthly fees to customers for using MAX, which already supported the servicing of over 129,000 units as of March 31, 2020. Other innovations currently in the pipeline include our asset performance management solution as well as our Intelligent Gate Management System, part of our Access Solutions division. We plan to follow the MAX blueprint for these and other new products by clearly demonstrating the value of the product after launch, bringing the technology to maturity and then developing a pricing and sales model that accurately reflects our value to customers. In addition, we have a track record of successful mergers and acquisitions, including most recently our acquisitions of Nashville Machine’s elevator division and O’Keefe Elevator Company, Inc. in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. We plan to further develop our profit potential by opportunistically seeking future M&A targets, which we believe can be value accretive to the Group.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We aim to deliver strong growth in our business, including significant margin expansion, through our three key strategies, Base, Core, and Core+, as further discussed below.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: The heritage of thyssenkrupp dates back to 1811, when Friedrich Krupp founded a cast steel factory in his hometown of Essen, Germany, and 1871, when August Thyssen established Thyssen & Co. Both companies separately evolved into major industrial conglomerates until they were combined into thyssenkrupp through a merger in 1999. While the Elevator Technology Business was historically integrated with thyssenkrupp’s operations, thyssenkrupp began a separation process to facilitate the Acquisition in 2019. On December 31, 2019, all assets and liabilities that form part of the Elevator Technology Business were transferred to thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding GmbH, which was subsequently converted to an Aktiengesellschaft and renamed as thyssenkrupp Elevator AG (the “Target”). thyssenkrupp Elevator AG is the top holding company of the Elevator Technology Business, the sole shareholder of thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding and a wholly-owned indirect subsidiary of thyssenkrupp AG. The Elevator Technology Business was incepted in the second half of the 20th century, when the industrial conglomerate that is now thyssenkrupp acquired several elevator manufacturers in Germany and Western Europe, including Rheinstahl AG, a specialist in the construction and installation of transportation equipment, elevators, escalators and jet bridges. Leveraging this new industry experience and its German engineering heritage, the Elevator Technology Business flourished and soon delivered major advances in elevator and escalator technology. Building on its early success in Europe, thyssenkrupp continued to broaden its footprint in the global elevator and escalator market through further acquisitions in Germany, Canada, the Netherlands and the United States in the 1980s and 1990s, which also expanded its service scope into home solutions such as chairlifts. Having constructed a dedicated elevator factory in Neuhausen, near Stuttgart, Germany in the 1970s, thyssenkrupp further expanded its production capacities as the Elevator Technology Business continued to grow, adding an escalator factory in Spain in 1991 and an elevator and escalator factory in Zhongshan, China in 1995, which also marked the business’s entry into the Asia/Pacific region. After the turn of the century, thyssenkrupp made targeted acquisitions to further build up its market position, primarily including the purchase of KONE 144 ----- Oy’s Latin America business in 2001, Tepper Aufzüge in 2003, Dongyang Elevator Co., Ltd. (South Korea) in 2003 and General Elevator Sales & Service, Inc. in 2011.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Our first core business is the new installation, service and modernization of elevators, escalators and moving walks (the “Elevator and Escalator division”). The Elevator and Escalator division (which includes our Europe/ Africa, Americas and the Asia/Pacific segments) accounted for 95% of the Operating Segments’ total sales and 94% of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. The Elevator and Escalator division is divided into three geographic areas, which enables each geographic segment to tailor its products to the specific customer needs and legal and regulatory requirements in its local markets: - _Americas: Our Americas segment covers our Elevator and Escalator division’s activities in the Americas, and contributed €3,306 million, or 41%, of the Operating Segments’ total sales and €489 million, or 51%, of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. In the 2018/2019 Financial Year, New Installation contributed between 35% and 40% of total sales in the region, and Service and Modernization combined contributed between 65% and 60% of total sales. The segment is sub-divided into two further regional units, including North America (with its headquarters in Atlanta, Georgia), covering the United States and Canada, and Latin America (with its headquarters in Porto Alegre, Brazil), covering Brazil as the main Latin American sales area and Spanish Latin America. - _Europe/Africa: Our Europe/Africa segment covers our Elevator and Escalator division’s activities in Europe and Africa, and contributed €2,149 million, or 26%, of the Operating Segments’ total sales and €227 million, or 24%, of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. In the 145 ----- 2018/2019 Financial Year, New Installation contributed between 25% and 30% of total sales in the region, and Service and Modernization combined contributed between 75% and 70% of total sales. Our Europe/ Africa segment operates within a widely diverse set of geographical areas through five operational units: “DACH,” comprising Germany, Austria and Switzerland, “RET,” comprising Russia, Eastern Europe and Turkey, “FRANCE,” comprising France and Monaco, “BBNI,” comprising the Benelux countries, Britain, the Nordics and Italy and “IBA,” comprising Spain, Portugal, Angola and Morocco and, in certain African countries, through distributors. Our Europe/Africa segment’s headquarters is located in Essen, Germany. - _Asia/Pacific: Our Asia/Pacific segment covers our Elevator and Escalator division’s activities in the Asia/ Pacific region, and contributed €2,307 million, or 28%, of the Operating Segments’ total sales and €178 million, or 19%, of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. In the 2018/2019 Financial Year, New Installation contributed between 70% and 80% of total sales in the region, and Service and Modernization combined contributed between 30% and 20% of total sales. Our Asia/Pacific segment is organized in six operational units: China, South Korea, India, Australia/New Zealand, Southeast Asia and the Middle East, with its headquarters located in Hong Kong.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Our second core business is our offering of access solutions for airports and homes (“Access Solutions division”). Our Access Solutions division operates across all geographies and is headquartered in Essen, Germany. It employs a number of different sales strategies and distribution channels, catering to both the business-to-business and business-to-consumer markets. The Access Solutions division accounted for 5% of the Operating Segments’ total sales and 6% of the Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. In the 2018/2019 Financial Year, New Installation contributed between 80% and 85% of Access Solutions total sales, and Service contributed between 15% and 20% of total sales. Our Access Solutions division is divided into two operational units. One operational unit offers airport access solutions, such as passenger boarding bridges, ground support equipment, visual docking guidance systems, ancillary equipment products and maintenance services (“Airport Solutions”). The other operational unit offers home access solutions, such as chairlifts, platform lifts and home elevators (“Home Solutions”).

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We have five reporting segments, including the Corporate Elevator segment that carries out certain administrative services and four Operating Segments through which we conduct our customer-facing business activities. The following diagrams provide an overview of the contribution of our Operating Segments to our Operating Segments’ total sales and Operating Segments’ Adjusted EBIT for the 2018/2019 Financial Year: ### Total sales contribution by Operating Segment 18/19A1 5% 28% 41% 26% Americas Europe/Africa Asia/Pacific Access Solutions ### Adjusted EBIT contribution by Operating Segment 18/19A[1] 6% 19% 51% 24% Americas Europe/Africa Asia/Pacific Access Solutions (1) The charts show the portion of aggregated total sales and aggregated Adjusted EBIT that each Operating Segment contributes, before Corporate Elevator and Reconciliation as presented in the segment reporting of the Audited Combined Financial Statements. We have a global footprint with field operations in more than 60 countries. As of March 31, 2020, we operated 16 factories in nine countries and had 52,567 employees worldwide (52,417 full-time equivalents), consisting of 17,360 in the Americas, 14,032 in Europe/Africa, 18,540 in Asia/Pacific, 2,135 in Access Solutions and 500 in the Corporate Elevator segment.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Our operations comprise three business lines: - _New Installation: Our New Installation business covers the design, manufacture and installation of elevators, escalators and moving walks for all major markets and industries, including for both commercial and residential projects and includes low-rise, mid-rise and high-rise solutions offered at different customization levels. We are a global leader in the new installations and believe we are renowned for our global reach, innovation capability (including the development of digital solutions) and ability to execute the most advanced elevator projects, having been involved in some of the most prominent architectural projects in recent years. Our New Installation business contributed 49%, 48% and 46% in sales in the Financial Years 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019, respectively. - _Service: Our Service business offers a broad range of maintenance services both for our own and third-party equipment, with a view to ensuring the continued safety, performance and efficiency of elevators, escalators, moving walks and access solutions throughout their usable lives. Depending on the scope agreed in our service contracts, our services range from basic oil and grease maintenance to bespoke full-service packages that include the sale and installation of replacement parts. Our Service business had approximately 1,000 service branches servicing approximately 1.4 million units under maintenance (including 60,000 units from the Access Solutions division) worldwide as of March 31, 2020. Since services have to be provided regularly to keep elevators and our other solutions in operation, our Service business creates a recurring and stable revenue stream. Our Service business contributed 41%, 42% and 42% in sales for the Financial Years 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019, respectively. - _Modernization: Our Modernization business offers comprehensive solutions ranging from partial modernization to complete replacement of an existing elevator and escalator systems and other solutions, both for our own and for third-party systems. Our Modernization business contributed 10%, 11% and 12% in sales for the Financial Years 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 respectively. 146 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Products of the Elevator and Escalator division
Subsubsection Text: _Elevator Products_ We are a leading elevator and escalator company in terms of global reach and innovation (including the development of digital solutions) and have the ability to execute the most prestigious elevator projects in our industry. We cover the entire design and installation of elevator systems for all major markets and industry types. Some of our recent credentials include the Hudson Yards development and the One World Trade Center, New York, the Beijing International Airport T3 Terminal and the Federation Tower, Russia. We provide elevator solutions for office buildings, apartment buildings, shopping centers, hotels, hospitals, train and metro stations, airports and other similar applications. This includes the design, manufacture and installation of traction drive elevators (driven by electric motor and cable), with or without a machine room, and hydraulic drive elevators (driven by hydraulic cylinder). In North America, hydraulic drive elevators are more commonly used, compared to the rest of the world, where traction drive elevators are more common. We cover all classes and applications, from economical residential to more demanding commercial projects. These include low-rise, mid- rise and high-rise solutions; as well as several innovative high-end elevator technologies. Our offerings are driven by demand in the relevant markets, as well as applicable legal and regulatory requirements. Where possible, we strive to utilize the same components (such as doors, controllers and traction machines) across product types and models. However, since each elevator must be tailored to the specific building and the regulatory requirements of the jurisdiction where it is installed, there can be significant differences between individual elevators from the same product line. We aim to categorize our product lines into three platforms, including solutions for low-rise, mid-rise and highrise buildings. Each product platform generally offers three primary options with regards to their performance, durability and customization level: “Value for Money” (no customization), “Performance” (medium customization) and “Customization” (full customization). We offer four core elevator product lines, which may be marketed under different brands in certain regions. A product line forms the basis for each individual elevator’s design, which we develop in accordance with each customer’s specific customization needs and the applicable local technical and regulatory requirements. Accordingly, elevators from the same product line can have different technical specifications when installed in different regions of the world. We also offer additional elevator products to provide greater client-driven optionality. Our four core elevator product lines are described below: - _evolution / meta—Our Americas and Europe/Africa segments market the evolution elevator product line in the Americas, Europe and Africa. Our Asia/Pacific segment offers a product that is similar to the “evolution” elevator product line under the meta brand. - _momentum / zeta—Our Americas and Europe/Africa segments also offer the momentum elevator product line across the Americas, Europe and Africa. Our Asia/Pacific segment offers a similar product under the _zeta brand._ - _synergy / enta—The Europe/Africa segment offers the synergy product line, which is primarily meant for low-rise constructions. Our Asia/Pacific segment offers a similar product under the enta brand. - _endura—The Americas segment also sells the endura product line, which is a hydraulic model in accordance with the technological preference in North America. 147 ----- Our core elevator product lines’ key features are illustrated below: ## Customization Level #### Value for money (“100”) #### Performance (“200”) #### Customization (“300”) #### Standard process, few options #### More flexible, allowing certain modifications #### Full customization for appropriate price momentum 300 zeta 300 #### High rise >100m Mid rise 45-100m momentum 200 zeta 200 evolution 300 enta 300 meta 100 evolution 200 meta 200 synergy 200 endura1 enta 200 synergy 300 #### Low rise <45m enta 100 synergy 100 (1) Local hydraulic product for the U.S. market. Maximum travel height of 18 meters. In addition to our core product lines described above, we also sell freight elevators and other specialized elevators tailored to serve specific transportation purposes, as well as our innovative products and solutions. These include the following: - _TWIN—The TWIN elevator system has two separate cars which are arranged on top of one another within the same single elevator shaft and operate independently of one another. The TWIN allows one elevator shaft to handle up to 40% more passengers and to save labor and material expenses since only one elevator shaft is needed for two cars. This increases leasable and otherwise usable space in buildings by up to 25%. The TWIN has made it a top choice for premier buildings throughout the world, including the European Central Bank in Frankfurt, Germany and the CMA Tower in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. - _MULTI—The MULTI elevator system is expected to be the world’s first rope-less, linear motor driven elevator system. It is designed to operate with multiple cars existing within one shaft, and also to move seamlessly between horizontal and vertical shafts within a building. In a practical sense, this reduces passenger wait times, significantly increases potential passenger capacity and reduces elevator weight and mass for energy reduction and increased usable space in building design. While TWIN saves up to 25% of usable space in buildings, the MULTI increases those savings up to approximately 30-50% in high-rise buildings. Beyond these practical benefits, the MULTI’s unique design also opens up a significant range of new possibilities for architects in the design of modern buildings by removing the building height and breadth restrictions presented by traditional elevator systems. The MULTI system is currently in prototype design stage with a test version running in our test tower in Rottweil, Germany. In addition, we also manufacture solutions to enhance the efficiency of existing elevator systems. For instance, our AGILE solution, which is a digital user interface and building management system, based on the IoT technology, allows building managers to intelligently group and assign passengers to elevators and facilitate rapid movement of people to their destination.
