AGILE comes with four core elements, which revolve around destination control, enhanced security, a design center featuring a touch screen interface and an elevator management center. _Escalator and Moving Walk Products_ Our escalators and moving walk product lines provide state-of-the-art technology and have the ability to handle heavy traffic and frequent use. Similar to our capabilities in the elevator market, we are able to develop, 148 ----- manufacture and install top-quality escalators and moving walks for the most demanding projects. Our escalator and moving walk offerings include products for all applications, including train stations, airports and office buildings, and are designed to meet the highest operational and safety standards. Escalators and moving walks traditionally consist of a robust drive unit/electric motor, steps, handrail/balustrade, step chain, truss, coverings of various materials and a central control unit. We customize these elements in close cooperation with each particular customer for any of our product lines. Many of the world’s largest recent infrastructure and commercial building projects have featured our escalators, including the Lester B. Pearson International Airport, Toronto, the Indira Gandhi International Airport, New Delhi, the One World Trade Center, New York, as well as the Amsterdam and Shenzhen metro networks. We offer three types of escalators, with minor regional variations, each helping to move passengers safely, efficiently and comfortably: - _velino: the velino commercial-duty escalator is designed to preserve the architectural integrity of buildings, and, with our compact dimensions, is ideal for shopping malls. The dual CPU controllers and the optional variable voltage variable frequency (“VVVF”) drive technology, save energy and help keep operating costs low. - _tugela: the tugela heavy-duty escalator is designed for high-rise applications and locations with heavy traffic. Featuring larger motors and chains than the velino, combined with reinforced handrail drives, it is well-suited for convention centers, stadiums, smaller airports or other places where large numbers of people need to be transported. - _victoria: the victoria transit-duty escalator represents our most rugged escalator, ideal for non-stop applications for transport hubs, such as the busiest and most technically challenging metro and train stations, as well as larger airports. It is our most powerful escalator, featuring a specially reinforced drive system capable of delivering nonstop maximum performance throughout the day even when operating at full load capacity. We manufacture three core types of moving walks, which transport passengers safely and quickly to their destination in metro and train stations, airports or other buildings: - _orinoco: the orinoco moving walks offer indoor and outdoor transportation solutions, allowing the transportation of large volumes of passengers carrying luggage and allowing sufficient space to pass standing passengers safely. - _iwalk: the iwalk moving walks offer indoor and outdoor transportation solutions, allowing pit or pit-less installation. To address building settings that offer minimal or no clearance for drive mechanisms directly underneath the moving walk, our iwalk is a modular solution that opens up opportunities for architects and developers. The modular nature of the product means that it can be easily customized, and pieces can be removed for repair or replacement with simply a forklift, requiring minimal or no modification work to the existing structure. - _ACCEL: the ACCEL is our innovative, high-speed moving walk product, which is currently being introduced to the market. Building on linear motor technology that thyssenkrupp first developed for its work on the Transrapid magnetic train project, the new ACCEL moving walk provides an initial speed of 0.65 m/s and then accelerates to 2.0 m/s using a cutting-edge overlapping pallet system and synchronized handrail system. ACCEL is able to transport passengers up to three times faster than a conventional moving walk. In airport terminals, this can reduce connection times between gates by up to 70%, as shown by operations at the Toronto Pearson Airport. _New Installations of Elevators, Escalators and Moving Walks_ New Installations of elevators, escalators and moving walks refer to installations of these products in a new site. Elevators are typically shipped as components and are assembled on site, whereas escalators are assembled in the factory and subsequently shipped as a complete product. The installation work is either carried out by us directly or outsourced to sub-contractors.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Products of the Access Solutions division
Subsubsection Text: _Airport Solutions_ An airport is often a traveler’s first and last impression of a city or country. Passenger numbers at airports are expected to double until 2037 (Source: The International Air Transport Association, market size (OI) based on 149 ----- _the Target’s internal estimations, public domain data and statistical calculations). We are focused on improving_ a traveler’s critical impressions while also providing intelligent solutions that elevate airport performance and drive industry innovation. Our Airport Solutions, consisting of passenger boarding bridges, related ground support equipment, visual docking guiding systems (VDGS) and intelligent gate management systems (IGMS), serve airports across the world. We are a global player, outfitting some of the largest airport projects. We offer comprehensive and flexible passenger boarding bridge options, which consider customers’ requirements and allow them to select optimal configurations to suit their specific needs. _Passenger boarding bridges_ Noseloader bridges are specifically designed to enable precise docking in areas with restricted aircraft size and/or parking constraints, since they use a telescopic tunnel which extends from the terminal to connect with the aircraft. A hydraulic elevation system ensures smooth operation while automated systems, such as pre-positioning, reduce human error. An apron drive bridge has more free movement by using telescopic, elevation and rotation axes to deliver maximum docking flexibility while taking up minimal space. Our two and three-tunnel models feature customizable steel, glazed glass or steel-and-glass walls. For those terminals that do not provide a direct boarding bridge connection or that present design challenges such as steep inclines, our Bridge Link (the “Bridge Link”) solution provides easy connectivity. These adaptable “fixed tunnels” link the boarding bridge to the building. They are also customized to match the boarding bridge’s look, feel and dimensions for a seamless passenger arrival and departure experience. Our passenger boarding bridges can serve all commercial passenger aircraft, up to the largest in operation, the Airbus A380, and our global footprint allows it to fulfill some of the world’s largest customer orders. Istanbul’s new airport (IST), which opened in April 2019, is outfitted with 143 passenger boarding bridges, all provided by us—our largest single passenger boarding bridge contract to date. We have the most comprehensive passenger boarding bridges in the industry and are able to service our customers along the entire value chain, from New Installations to Services and Modernizations. We have the largest global installation base of passenger boarding bridges, with a market share of approximately 33%. _Ground support equipment_ To support airports in their need to respond to growing air traffic worldwide, we provide ground support equipment such as preconditioned airflow system (PCA) or ground power (400Hz) and potable water units, which are essential to improve aircraft service operations and to avoid tarmac delays. We typically sub-contract this equipment for manufacturing and offer these along with our passenger boarding bridges. _Intelligent gate systems_ Our intelligent gate systems are innovative solutions that help major airports around the world avoid costly ground operation incidents by increasing their gates’ efficiency. Solutions like our integrated management airport system (IMAS) and atlantis (formerly FMT Atlantis) enable monitoring of integrated equipment at the gate, including ground power units (400Hz), visual docking guidance systems, preconditioned air, surveillance cameras and automatic doors. We have a comprehensive offering of digital solutions, which enable real time monitoring of asset operations, automate operations and enable efficient maintenance. We believe that our APIS (formerly FMT APIS) system is the only visual docking guidance systems that delivers 100% accurate aircraft identification, resulting in increased gate safety, decreased turnaround times and reduced environmental impact. We believe that these intelligent solutions simplify formerly time and labor-consuming tasks, reduce human error and deliver a smoother passenger experience, in addition to improving aircraft turnaround times at the gate. Our key strength is to provide the right software for the hardware, which enables a one-stop solution for ensuring that all components work together and ensures safety, reliability and overall quality of our products and services. _Home Solutions_ Our Home Solutions address mobility issues for aging segments of the world’s population as well as those with disabilities by offering products that are robust and reliable. From chairlifts and platform lifts to home elevators, we enable people to move independently and comfortably in their homes and other buildings. _Chairlifts_ Chairlifts eliminate the barrier posed by stairs by providing a seat attached to a track which runs along the staircase. In many cases, chairlifts are retrofitted onto an existing structure, which can make each installation 150 ----- complex and unique. Our chairlifts strive to balance design and functionality, offering optimal accessibility, while meeting ergonomic requirements. We believe that our patented advanced swiveling and leveling (ASL) technologies make our chairlifts among the industry’s best. Both elderly customers and government institutions use our chairlift solutions. We believe we are a technology leader for chairlifts. Our HoloLinc[®] application, of which more than 100 units are already being used in the field, is the world’s first mixed reality chairlift solution, which employs a new headmounted, mixed-reality HoloLinc device from Microsoft to allows our customers and employees to more quickly and accurately measure the space in which a chairlift is to be installed, which we believe reduces overall lead time, helping to reduce customer stress and to lower costs. _Platform lifts_ Our platform lifts provide people in wheelchairs with independent access to areas with inclines or vertical rises, improving access to indoor and outdoor public spaces, such as government buildings, tourist sites and public transportation systems, as well as to private areas. The platform lifts come equipped with ergonomic design elements, including joystick control and safety features. _Home elevators_ Drawing on our decades of experience in commercial elevators, we have developed a line of customized lifts for private homes or standardized lifts for housing construction projects. They can be designed with or without a shaft and can be integrated easily into existing or new homes.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Service Offering of the Service Business
Subsubsection Text: We consider the Service business, a source of stable, recurring sales and high margins for us, as our most important product and the heart of our business model. We service approximately 1.4 million units under maintenance as of March 31, 2020. We offer a broad range of Services, from basic oil and grease maintenance to bespoke full-service packages, to ensure highest safety, performance and efficiency of elevators, escalators and moving walks. We also have an ITS Unit, a part of our Elevators and Escalators division, which reverse engineers elevator and escalator products manufactured by third parties to develop capability of providing services for such equipment. Since our products have to be serviced regularly throughout their entire life span, the Service business typically creates a recurring and stable revenue stream for us. Our net sales in the Service business are driven by the conversion of New Installations units into service contracts. This is evidenced by our average conversion rate of approximately 70% to 80% globally (the conversion rate being calculated as the percentage of New Installations units (excluding distributor sales, which do not directly result in access to servicing the relevant units) that have been converted into Service contracts). We also have an average retention rate globally of above 90% for our Service customers (calculated as units under maintenance at the end of the year divided by units under maintenance at the beginning of the year, adjusted for new units under maintenance at the end of that financial year). As of September 30, 2019, our units under maintenance were served by approximately 1,000 branches, of which 300 branches were in the Americas segment, 300 branches in the Europe/Africa segment and 400 branches were in the Asia/Pacific segment. We have also recently begun implementing shared service centers, designed to enhance efficiency by centralizing a number of administrative processes across regions. Our Services are provided based on service contracts with the customers. The service contracts set out the scope of the service package for the customers and range from basic packages, including inspection and testing, to full maintenance packages which may include services such as preventative maintenance, repair, parts repair and replacement, quality assurance, annual safety testing, after hours emergency service, quality assurance or release of passengers trapped in cabins. Pricing for our Services depends upon the type of contract. In a full service contract, the main costs are those of labor and components. In an oil & grease service contract, the main cost is labor. The majority of our service contracts have a term of one to five years but may also go up to ten years in some regions. Typically, we include the first one or two years of maintenance for a newly installed elevator or escalator in the New Installations price, depending on the region. MAX, our cloud-based digitally enhanced maintenance solution, is designed to increase service quality by reducing downtime by up to 50% through creating information transparency for the customer. As of March 31, 2020, more than 129,000 MAX units had been installed globally. We collaborated with Microsoft on MAX to develop an IoT based end-to-end solution to digitally transform service operations and create new customer solutions. MAX is supported by VIEW, our operational business steering tool which automatically dispatches qualified technicians to resolve the problems identified by MAX. 151 ----- MAX enables machine data from elevators and escalators to be collected globally in real-time using a proprietary IoT device. This and additional internal data is then transmitted to the cloud through highly secure channels and analyzed using VIEW to generate actionable insights for our technicians, improve reliability and availability of the elevator or escalator units and create transparency for our customers. This real-time diagnosis draws the technician’s attention to necessary action not only when shutdowns happen but even before the defect occurs. The cloud-based modular and extendable nature of the MAX platform sets us apart from our competitors’ offerings, which are extensions of traditional systems. We also use real-time troubleshooting with online diagnostic and customer service tools, as well as remote monitoring to service our approximately 1.4 million units under maintenance as of March 31, 2020. Changes in the legal and regulatory environment applicable to the products are a key factor that influences the services provided by our Service business. The different legal and regulatory regimes also determine the scope of service provided by us within the Operating Segments.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: With the average age of buildings steadily growing in many countries, property owners increasingly need to invest in modernizing their people transportation systems. We therefore offer comprehensive elevator and escalator modernization to enable our customers to comply with applicable legal requirements and to prolong their elevator and escalator system’s lifespan safely and cost efficiently. Our Modernization business addresses challenges relating to the customers’ need to comply with constantly evolving standards and regulations, age-related wear and tear, efficiency and capacity optimization. Modernization benefits may include lower operating costs, greater energy efficiency and increased tenant satisfaction, as well as an increase in the building’s value. Our partial Modernization solutions for elevators include safety and regulatory retrofits (e.g. fire control systems), the replacement of individual components to match existing ones (e.g., door drives and operating panels), a new look for the cabin and entrance, retrofits for increased comfort (e.g., door zone monitoring systems), more functionality (e.g. access control) and optimizing energy consumption (e.g., LED lighting that switches off when the cabin is standing still). We offer modernization solutions not only for elevator systems which we have manufactured and installed, but also for elevators manufactured and installed by third-party companies. Our solutions can be adapted to all existing installations, regardless of the component type and its manufacturer. We utilize widely used and tested technologies, plus flexibility in parts supplied for such modernization projects. We also offer a wide range of tailored replacement solutions for existing elevator systems (with or without a machine room). These solutions go beyond simple modernization upgrades to encompass the complete replacement of an existing elevator system. Our replacement solutions seek to make use of the existing shaft and avoid additional masonry, structural modification and painting. This not only limits costs, but also reduces the amount of dust and noise produced by the modernization process. Our replacement solutions range from very small lift systems to our high-end TWIN system, depending on the particular customer’s needs and the available infrastructure, which offers the potential to expand transport capacity within the same shaft footprint. In addition, we offer modernization solutions not only for elevators, but also for escalators, moving walks and airport solution systems. For escalators and moving walks, the modernization solutions include the replacement of individual components such as steps and handrails or, if necessary, the entire system. We offer retrofitting measures to increase the system’s energy efficiency, such as energy efficiency controller (EEC), LED lighting or skirt brushes.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Our manufacturing processes begin with the order intake for a new elevator, escalator or our other products and culminate with installing and assembling the system at our customer’s site. The manufacturing process is not only a key element for the New Installation business, but also for the Modernization business, if significant system upgrades are required. The main steps of the manufacturing process include the configuration of the system, as well as the production of components by us or the procurement of components from third-party suppliers. Whether a segment purchases components for its products from third-party suppliers in accordance with our procurement strategy (for more details on our procurement process, see “Procurement and Supply _Management”) or whether it produces them itself depends on a variety of factors. Standardized and commodity_ components are often sourced from third parties whereas technically complex and bespoke components are 152 ----- typically produced by us. Our manufacturing operations are steered centrally from our headquarters, but have their organizational structures within each Operating Segment to accommodate the particularities of the markets in which such segment operates.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: In Europe, the main manufacturing facilities for the Elevator and Escalator divisions are located in Neuhausen and Hamburg in Germany and Móstoles (Madrid), Andoain and Norte (Mieres) in Spain. The facilities in Hamburg and Mieres are focused on escalators and moving walks, manufacturing high-end products for high-end markets, including escalators for metro and train stations. The elevator factory in Neuhausen serves the high-rise business, but also the mid-rise business, including the evolution line, for the European market, but also for export of components such as traction drives to other regions. The factory in Móstoles (Madrid) manufactures the synergy line, mainly for the European markets, and, to a lesser extent, for export to other regions. It is supported by Andoain, which is mainly assembling electrical controllers. The facility in Mieres, Spain is focused on escalators for the European and Latin American markets. In North America, the factory is located in Middleton, Tennessee, United States, and the order management organization is located in Germantown, Tennessee, United States, one hour away from the factory, serving not only the manufacturing process of the New Installation business, but also providing the configuration services and components for the Modernization business in the United States. The factory in Guaiba, Porto Alegre, Brazil, manufactures elevators for the Latin American market, including Mexico. In the Asia/Pacific region, the main manufacturing facilities for the Elevator and Escalator divisions are located in: Songjiang, China; Shanghai, China; Zhongshan, China; Cheonan City, South Korea; and Pune, India. Songjiang is the headquarter for Asia manufacturing and includes a production facility for traction machines, doors and controllers. Shanghai serves the value for money market in China and is a manufacturing facility only, as all production processes are outsourced, and components are bought in the market. Zhongshan comprises two separate manufacturing facilities for high-rise elevators, including a test tower, and escalators. Cheonan in South Korea is one of the manufacturing facilities with the best operational KPIs within the Group (such as sales per employee) and is strategically important to serve the South Korean market. The facility in Pune is our newest and was built to serve the Indian market, which is otherwise difficult to access due to high import taxes, specific code requirements and a heavily localized supply chain. The main manufacturing facilities for the Access Solutions division are located in: Fort Worth (Texas), United States; Krimpen aan den Ijssel, the Netherlands; Pisa, Italy; Mieres, Spain; and Shanghai, China. Our Access Solutions division’s key manufacturing facilities are strategically located in close proximity to our end-markets and customers. The division has five manufacturing facilities: three with respect to Home Solutions (located in the Netherlands, Italy and China), and two with respect to Airport Solutions (located in the United States and Spain). Our Access Solutions division operates 14 service stations focused on Airport Solutions and ten field locations focused on Home Solutions. The unit is headquartered in Essen, Germany.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We manage our global purchasing activities through a group-wide procurement organization, in order to leverage the demand and benefit from economies of scale in our procurement of doors, controllers, traction machines, guiderails and transmission means. Our material field strategies are based on an extensive knowledge of customer needs and business requirements, global supply markets, and supplier capabilities. Under the material field strategies, spending is actively steered towards selected suppliers. However, due to diverging regional regulatory requirements and customer demands, procurement decisions are still made at the local level, subject to compliance with the global procurement framework. In particular, differences exist between demands driven by code requirements for North America and other markets where we operate. Therefore, a major portion of our procurement staff works at the operational level.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We aim to generate the highest possible added value and sustainable reduction of material costs while ensuring high levels of material availability and quality, and evaluate whether components should be sourced from supply 153 ----- markets or manufactured in-house. This decision is mainly driven by the competitiveness of the supply chains for specific components. Specialized components on the other hand are usually manufactured in-house in order to safeguard the technological features of such components. In order to avoid dependencies on individual suppliers, we aim to have at least two suppliers for each of its components in different geographic regions, and, ideally, five or six, to be able to auction our demands and award the contract to the most competitive offer. Typically, supply contracts include no volume commitments, ensuring high flexibility for us.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: In order to install, manufacture and service our products, we rely on sourcing a wide range of components, technical goods and raw materials, as well as services, such as elevator installation services, IT services and marketing.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We operate numerous manufacturing facilities worldwide and use land with office buildings, warehouses, research and development facilities, and other facilities in a large number of countries as either owner or lessee. Our lease contracts are currently centrally managed by thyssenkrupp Real Estate GmbH and are in the process of being transferred to thyssenkrupp Elevator on a decentralized approach, to take effect from the Acquisition Closing Date. We lease some of our premises, including our current headquarters in Essen, from thyssenkrupp AG. We are currently proposing to move our headquarters to a standalone location in 2021, but are likely to continue leasing several other premises from thyssenkrupp AG, after the Acquisition Closing Date. Lease payments and service fees payable under the relevant lease agreement are on an arm’s length basis. Operational expenditure and external costs incurred by thyssenkrupp group-companies in connection with a specific lease agreement are either included in the monthly lease payable under the lease agreement, or passedthrough to the relevant user of the space according to a pre-determined contractual distribution key or according to the space occupied by a relevant user on a pro rata basis.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We have different types of customers from both the public and the private sector. In the New Installation and Modernization businesses, we typically enter into contracts with construction companies, developers or directly with the owners of a building. In some cases, contracts are entered into with dealers or resellers who then sell our products to the end-customers. Home Solutions is our only business where we sell to consumers directly as well as through our dealer network. In the Service business, our contracting partner is typically the owner of the building where maintenance work is carried out. In some regions, the services are contracted by a property or facility manager. Since the New Installation business is project-driven, the customer base is very fragmented. The Service business on the other hand is shaped by long-term customer relationships, but equally has a highly diversified customer base. Our Services contracts have tenors of varying periods. Full service contracts could go up to five years, whereas oil & grease service contracts generally have a one-year tenor, often with an automatic renewal clause. Generally, our top 10 customers change every year and typically account for less than 3% of revenues in a given financial year, leading to a highly diversified customer base. We aim to build long lasting customer relationships where the New Installation business leads to Service business and ultimately to Modernization business. For competitors to maintain our service equipment installed by us would require investment into the diagnostic, tooling, training, operational systems and inventories that we continually develop. We believe that our customers generally rationalize the value of our support structure and our consistent service delivery, even if it comes at a slight premium. Our retention rate has been more than 90% for each of the 2016/2017, 2017/2018 and 2018/2019 Financial Years and the six months ended March 31, 2020. Ideally, customers become long-term customers of all three businesses.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We have an extensive sales and services network around the globe covering the majority of the world’s countries. As of March 31, 2020, more than 60 countries are covered by our own field operations, whereas approximately 40 countries are being served via distributors. Distributors are our strategic partners that sell our products and services either exclusively or non-exclusively. In the 2018/2019 Financial Year, approximately 17% of our sales were generated through third party intermediaries, such as our distributors. Our sales intermediaries’ landscape is highly fragmented and we are not materially dependent on any specific intermediary to conduct our business. The sales network follows our sales process named “EAGLE”. EAGLE sets out guidelines to provide a harmonized sales process throughout the Operating Segments, to increase efficiency and transparency and to focus on customer interaction by implementing a common sales vision that aims to ensure that the same customer 154 ----- approach is followed across our branches. It is supported by three bespoke training modules that the respective sales representatives, sales managers and branch managers, as well as sales support personnel, call center personnel and technicians have to undergo to ensure that the objectives set by EAGLE are adequately fulfilled. The sales process is tracked through clearly defined performance indicators throughout the Group. We endeavor to base business relationships on our own terms and conditions to the extent possible and have a process of internal review in case a customer proposes different terms. The EAGLE methodology does not apply to our third party distributors, but our distributors’ performance control is generally oriented towards this methodology to ensure comparability our direct and indirect sales channels.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Strategically, our focus is to perpetuate the innovation for which we and our brand are known. On the product side, the emphasis is on steadily improving the existing products and trying to design products that will meet customers’ design expectations while satisfying their practical needs. These include features such as ‘INSIGHT’, which can monitor, control and schedule elevators and escalators and air-purification and anti-bacterial ultraviolet light and face & voice recognition features, which help improve safety of elevators during the COVID-19 crisis. With regards to the Services and Modernization, the goal is to continuously use state-of-the-art digitalization and technology in conjunction with big data to progress the market further into the digital age, enhancing efficiency, safety, and effectiveness, leading to greater customer satisfaction and providing recognizable daily improvements. We are constantly on the hunt for the next new, industry-disruptive technology, starting from incremental improvements of our existing products to entirely new product categories and functionalities. While we are always aiming at improving product efficiency, our research and development focus depends on customers’ needs and interests within a particular geographic region (e.g. cost is a key driver within the Asia/ Pacific region, whereas value-add is generally more important in Europe and North America). Through research and development, we aim to consistently provide new value-add to our customers across new and existing products and services offered, decrease customer costs and increase product efficiency. We believe that certain market trends and challenges will determine the main areas of our research and development efforts in the near future. These factors include urbanization, as well as the emphasis on the safe and efficient flow of people within cities. We also believe that opportunities exist in certain areas which complement our broader strategy of growing our business. We will continue to deploy research and development resources to capitalize on these perceived selective opportunities.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Group-wide research and development work is driven by the Corporate Functions “Product Life Cycle Management” (“PLM”) and R&D. These functions are established in the Operating Segments and regions where we are active. PLM and R&D formulate and coordinate joint procedures for research and development and secure patent and trademark protection for our innovations. Whereas PLM monitors market demands and defines what R&D should achieve, R&D executes the research and development work to meet the goals that PLM sets. 155 ----- _PLM_ PLM has product managers for the different product segments. Product managers analyze trends, customer needs, market potentials, competitive technologies and products under technical and commercial aspects; and translate these trends into future products. Pre-product development, PLM defines the product requirements, develops the business case and indicates differentiation aspects and unique selling points. PLM aligns the product development with the segment strategy and plans the market introduction, following which it tracks and prioritizes the product development pipeline. Subsequently, we work to ensure the seamless integration and real-time availability of all information generated over the lifetime of a product. The product manager defines and evaluates KPIs to measure product market performance. The PLM process includes not only innovation and portfolio management, but also our engineering and manufacturing through to the end of the product life cycle when we take a product off the market. We require PLM for all our products, ensuring a process which enables us to harmonize and manage all stages of a product life cycle, while also giving our individual segments the ability to tailor the requirements to their specific markets. We are therefore able to provide customers with products customized exactly to their requirements. _Core research and development_ After PLM has set out the requirements for our products, R&D is in charge of finding solutions which satisfy the market needs reflected in PLM’s product roadmap. The pillars of our R&D structure are the “Research and Innovation” and “Product Design”, as well as “Test and Qualification”. Research and Innovation is responsible for technology discovery and scouting, overseeing feasibility studies, the coordination and initiation of research networks and the setup and management of research cooperation with universities and industry associations. Product Design designs all standardized products which are introduced to the markets. They are responsible for ensuring that the designs meet the applicable standards and specifications and they define the product concept and the details of the design. Test and Qualification processes ensure that designs comply with regional national (safety) codes, standards and product specifications via verification and validation procedures. Tests are planned and conceptualized for normal and severe operations under specific lifetime and maintenance perspectives at in-house Test and Qualification centers and our test towers. All Test and Qualification processes are documented in a standardized way. Our research and development approach combines a pragmatic mix of globalized and regional goals and management, with regional teams across our Operating Segments who are positioned close to the local markets and products. Over recent years, we have worked to further globalize what has historically been regionally segmented teams across different Operating Segments. Through the introduction of global platforms, teams across the Operating Segments employ common tools, work on common products and utilize shared resources to affect our research and development shared goals. Simultaneously, these teams across the Operating Segment maintain a distinct advantage of specialized knowledge due to their proximity to the specific local products and market mechanics. This dual track approach allows globalized management to follow product footprints, yet localized autonomy to leverage regional know-how.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We collaborate with external scientific and academic institutions. These collaborations are mainly based in the United States and Europe. Majority of our research projects are often pursued in cooperation with globally recognized universities or research institutes, such as Georgia Tech University, Universidad de Oviedo, the University of Stuttgart and the University of Northampton. These critical partnerships accomplish two goals: firstly, they assist us in accomplishing our specific research and development projects, and secondly, they provide access to a pool of top talent from which we may hire new team members. We also participate in industry associations and other organizations such as the European Lift Association (ELA) and the LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) certification program of the US Green Building Council (USGBC). Our innovation capability is supported by collaborations with customers or other industry sectors, typically regarding the implementation of specific technologies in an effort to realize a specific product. 156 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We believe we are recognized as a technology leader in our industry due to our continuous investment in our research and development (“R&D”) capabilities. We have 16 research and development centers spread across countries in the Americas, Europe/Africa and Asia/Pacific. We are the only supplier in the industry to have an offering similar to our TWIN elevator system, which combines two independent cars in one shaft. We are also currently in the process of developing the MULTI system, which would be the world’s first rope-free elevator. Our R&D work is focused on what we consider to be the fundamental technological challenges to better serve a growing, aging and rapidly urbanizing society. Central among these are the digital transformation of industry, climate change and energy transition. At the same time, customer demand for high quality applications, increased functionality, design flexibility and lower cost manufacturing processes are also driving our research and development efforts. We believe that taking a leading position in the development of sustainable products manufactured in a sustainable way will ultimately strengthen our position and help to distinguish us from our competitors. Throughout our research and development process, the core principle guiding innovation is product safety. To execute these plans, we manage the entire life cycle of our products beginning with the development of an idea and ending with the decision on whether to launch a product. Our research and development costs and capitalized development costs related to internally developed innovations amounted to €106 million in the 2018/2019 Financial Year. We employed approximately 800 fulltime employees in research and development- related activities as of March 31, 2020.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: As of March 31, 2020, we employed 52,567 employees (52,417 full-time equivalent). The following table sets forth the number of our employees by region as at the dates indicated (not included: externals, corporate and employees on parental leave).

Section Title: INDUSTRY
INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Many companies in our Group are members of local employers’ associations (Arbeitgeberverbände) of the elevator and escalator industry and/or the metal and electronics industry. Since these industries tend to be highly unionized, many of our employees are organized in country-specific union organizations. In Germany, as an example, many of the employees are organized in the German Industrial Union of Metalworkers (IG Metall). Several German companies of the Group are subject to various relevant industry-wide collective bargaining agreements (Flächentarifverträge) for the metal and electronics industry and/or apply collective bargaining agreements which have been concluded specifically for one or several Group companies. For example, in March 2020, thyssenkrupp Elevator concluded a collective bargaining agreement “Future Elevator” with German IG Metall in connection with the Acquisition. The “Future Elevator” collective bargaining agreement excludes forced redundancies (“Ausschluss betriebsbedingter Beendigungskündigungen”) and provides for site guarantees (“Standortsicherungszusagen”) for the German production and essential service sites and is valid until March 31, 2027. In many other countries in which we operate, we are bound by collective bargaining agreements with trade unions in France, Spain, the United States, Canada and Brazil as amended from time to time. In several countries including Germany, France, Spain, Belgium and Italy, employee representative bodies have been established. These employee representative bodies enjoy numerous information and consultation rights relating to personnel, social and economic matters, especially with regard to dismissals, compensation and benefits and in case of restructurings or redundancies. Collective agreements which are in place in various countries provide for additional protection and benefits (e.g. severance entitlements) of employees, as well as enhanced information and consultation rights of employee representatives in connection with lay-offs, restructurings, reorganizations and other corporate actions. In some countries, collective agreements have been entered into with local employee representative bodies covering a broad range of topics, in particular remuneration and working time. A minority of our employees enjoy some form of special protection against dismissal, not only due to explicit commitments in collective agreements, but also for other reasons, in particular statutory or contractual provisions regarding, among other things, maternity and sick leave or works council and/or union membership. Since 2016, we have from time to time experienced strikes at sites in France and Spain, though these have not caused material disruptions. Good relationships with our employees are especially important to us, and we believe that we generally have good and constructive relationships with our employees, their trade unions and representative bodies.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Depending on the situation in the specific countries, we grant current and former employees and their dependents pension and (early) retirement benefits. The pension benefits are based on various pension plans in the form of defined benefit or defined contribution pension plans in various countries. Our obligations under these plans vary, depending on legal, tax and economic circumstances in the various countries in which we operate, and, in most of the countries, they generally depend on the length of service and remuneration of the employee concerned. 157 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Our global intellectual property (“IP”) strategy aims to protect and enhance our competitive position in the various geographic regions in which we operate. This is achieved by effective management of our IP rights, including patents, designs and trademarks. The Group gives high priority to protecting our innovations and the actual and future business value that we can derive therefrom. IP rights are currently centrally managed and coordinated by thyssenkrupp Intellectual Property Services GmbH based in Essen, Germany, which provides this service to us, with support and assistance from in-house IP professionals in key countries such as the United States and China. After the Acquisition Closing Date, we will be managing our intellectual property with our own in-house IP professionals and external counsel. As of March 31, 2020, we owned approximately 900 granted patents, 570 patent families, 550 registered trademarks and 160 trademark families and had applied for approximately 800 patents and 90 trademarks. We also owned approximately 117 designs and applied for registration of approximately 26 designs, as of March 31, 2020. While IP is an essential part of our business and IP assets are, in the aggregate, of material importance to our business, we believe that no single IP asset is material to our business as a whole. On September 25, 2019, thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation entered into a licensing agreement with thyssenkrupp AG (the “Licensing Agreement”), allowing us to indefinitely use certain trademarks, including the trademark “thyssenkrupp” in carrying out the business of the Group against payment of a one- time fee. Under the terms of the Share Purchase Agreement, the Licensing Agreement will be terminated prior to the Acquisition Closing Date, with effect as on a date falling 18 months after the Acquisition Closing Date. We are required to use our commercially reasonable best efforts to introduce a new brand for our business within a period of six months from the Acquisition Closing Date. As part of the thyssenkrupp-wide IP policy, approximately 20 of our companies have concluded IP trust agreements with thyssenkrupp AG in 2013 pursuant to which certain IP assets are co-owned by (i) the respective company of the Group and (ii) thyssenkrupp AG as trustee for the respective company of the Group. The IP trust agreements cover patents, trademarks and design rights, in each case as registered or acquired after the date of the IP trust agreements. All IP trust agreements have been terminated. The process of de-registering thyssenkrupp AG as co-owner from the IP registers will continue until all IP assets previously covered by the IP trust agreements are registered in the sole name of the relevant entity of the Group. This applies to approximately 800 IP rights that the Group created or acquired during the relevant period.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Antitrust proceedings and private follow-on litigation
Subsubsection Text: Starting in January 2004, the European Commission conducted raids on elevator and escalator manufacturers in Belgium, Germany, Luxembourg and the Netherlands. Following these inspections, the European Commission opened an investigation into Otis, KONE, Schindler and the thyssenkrupp Group. According to the European Commission, between 1995 and 2004, cartel members rigged bids for procurement contracts, fixed prices and allocated projects to each other, shared markets and exchanged competitively sensitive information. The thyssenkrupp Group was fined a total of €479.7 million in February 2007 for its involvement in this cartel. The thyssenkrupp Group appealed the decision which resulted in a reduced fine of €319.8 million. This decision has become final and binding and the fine has been paid. Similar proceedings, including several raids on elevator and escalator manufacturers, were launched by the Austrian Federal Competition Authority, but thyssenkrupp Group applied for leniency under the applicable Austrian leniency program and received full immunity from fines in Austria. As a result of the European Commission’s decision of February 2007 and the investigation by the Austrian Federal Competition Authority, thyssenkrupp AG and some of its subsidiaries were subject to private follow-on litigation. Although final judgments have been issued or settlements have been entered into in the majority of the cases, we remain exposed to possible joint and several liabilities arising from ongoing claims up to the amount of €150 million in total in Belgium, the Netherlands and Austria. The Group has made appropriate provisioning for the sums we may be liable to pay, as well as the costs of the proceedings. We also have an indemnity under the Share Purchase Agreement of up to €29 million from these claims. 158 ----- _Civil cartel claims Belgium_ The European Commission is suing the Group jointly and severally with competitors for damages of €6.1 million plus interest for cartel overcharges of our products in the EU buildings in Belgium. The case was originally dismissed by the Brussels Commercial Court in 2014 and is currently pending at the court of appeals. We have made a provision of €2.6 million to cover the risk of this litigation, which is equivalent to 75% of the claimed amount relating to projects involving thyssenkrupp Elevator, plus potential interest as of September 30, 2019. _Civil cartel claims the Netherlands_ In 2011, a foundation, Stichting Elevator Cartel Claim (representing, among others, H&M, C&A and NH Hotels), brought action against us as well as our competitor KONE, for a declaration of liability, alleging cartelrelated damages following the European Commission’s decision of 2007 and claiming damages of €22.3 million plus interest. The case is currently pending before the District Court of Rotterdam. We have made a provision of €3.3 million to cover the risk of this litigation, which is equivalent to 50% of the claimed amount relating to projects involving thyssenkrupp Elevator, plus potential interest as of September 30, 2019. _Civil cartel claims Austria_ Eight lawsuits by public institutions or corporations and companies (including the City of Vienna, the City of Linz, the SPAR corporate group and various real estate companies) against the Group jointly and severally with the other participants of the cartel are currently pending. The total value of the claims is approximately €117.3 million plus interest, of which claims related to thyssenkrupp Elevator’s projects are approximately €14.7 million plus potential umbrella claims of €5.1 million. The claimants allege that the cartel in Austria led to cartel overcharges and umbrella damages in relation to sales by third-party competitors who did not participate in the cartel. Ultimately, we do not expect to be fully liable for the total amount based on the number of our products involved but rather for a fraction, if at all, of the value in dispute based on our products involved. We have made a provision of €20.8 million as of September 30, 2019 to cover the risk of this litigation.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Ciacorp International Corporation vs. thyssenkrupp Elevadores, S.A.
Subsubsection Text: Ciacorp International Corporation sued thyssenkrupp Elevadores, S.A. over an alleged debt of BRL 207 million (approximately €48 million) owed to some business partners of the former principal shareholder of Sur, Mr. Aumonde. thyssenkrupp Elevadores S.A. acquired Sur from Aumonde in 1999, and Aumonde’s former partners in an otherwise unrelated business venture in Uruguay claim that the structure of the Sur acquisition enabled Aumonde to avoid having liquidity in Brazil, thereby allowing him to escape payment of his debts. Aumonde’s former partners have brought thyssenkrupp Elevadores, S.A. into the suit by claiming that the transfer of control of Sur should be found null and void as a fraudulent conveyance, thus returning control of the company to Aumonde or his holding company, whereby the former partners could then access Aumonde’s Brazilian assets to cover Aumonde’s debt to them. thyssenkrupp Elevadores, S.A. already won in the local and regional court. The judgment on the third appeal is pending. The appeal was allocated to one of the Panel Courts at the Superior Court of Justice in Brasilia.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Criminal and administrative proceedings against thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea Ltd.
Subsubsection Text: Four fatal accidents resulting in five deceased employees of consortium partners (installation companies) of thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea Ltd. (“thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea”) on four different sites in South Korea in the years 2018 and 2019 have led to the initiation of criminal and administrative proceedings, inter alia, against thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea, mainly for indicted non- performance of certain safety measures as the owner of the business. Three of these proceedings are currently in initial criminal and administrative proceedings in lower courts, and a fourth has been appealed by the prosecution and by thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea. In March 2019, the Korean environment and labor committee (“ELC”) of the national assembly began to investigate these incidents. The ELC ordered (i) a two-week special investigation, which concluded on November 5, 2019 against the safety management at sites and the legality of certain related contracts and (ii) all relevant government ministries to audit the four major elevator companies in South Korea for any violations against certain statutory laws. On November 7, 2019, the ELC conducted an audit where thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea and the relevant government ministries were present for questioning. These ongoing administrative proceedings may eventually result in the imposition of administrative sanctions against thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea for violations of health and safety-related rules as well as construction industry and elevator regulations governing sub-contracting, specifically on the following grounds: 159 ----- (i) responsibility of thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea as a ‘business owner’ for the infringement of safety-related rules; and (ii) violation of the 50% rule on subcontracting under the Elevator Act, forbidding the outsourcing of more than 50% to third parties in connection with maintenance services. The potential sanctions for violation of the health and safety provisions range from a fine of €0.2 million to suspension of the New Installation business in South Korea for a period of three to eleven months. The potential sanctions for violation of the provisions of the Elevator Act range from monetary fine of €0.9 million to a suspension of the Service business in South Korea for at least two years. thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea, however believes that the relevant authority is considering limiting penalties for violation of the Elevator Act to fines only, since all major elevator companies are facing potential violations. In addition to these proceedings, thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea was also facing charges of violations of certain provisions of the Framework Act on Construction Industry, relating to rules on sub-contracting, for which it was recently fined €32,000. In the event that thyssenkrupp Elevator Korea becomes subject to further fines or business suspensions, it must be compliant with the restriction on subcontracting for a period five years following the imposition, in order to avoid the revocation of its construction business license. Due to settlements with the heirs of the deceased, there is no pending civil liability in connection with the fatalities.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Audit of thyssenkrupp North America, Inc. by the State of Delaware
Subsubsection Text: In 2011, the state of Delaware initiated an audit of thyssenkrupp North America, Inc., a Delaware corporation, and its subsidiaries and related entities (collectively, “thyssenkrupp NA”) to determine thyssenkrupp NA’s compliance with the Delaware Escheats laws, also known as abandoned and unclaimed property laws. The thyssenkrupp NA audit involves an examination of the books and records of certain large entities within thyssenkrupp NA (called proxy companies) covering the years 1996 to 2014 (which end date rolls forward every year that the audit continues and is not completed). Initial preliminary estimates of liability applicable to thyssenkrupp NA received from Delaware amount to USD 30 million. We have been able to negotiate a settlement agreement with the state of Delaware, which involves an overall payment of US$7.9 million, of which US$7.2 million is required to be paid by thyssenkrupp Elevator in connection with the audit, which concluded on December 11, 2019.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, in the ordinary course of business, the Elevator Technology Business is subject to litigation. Except as set forth in this offering memorandum, there were no governmental, regulatory, administrative, civil, labor or other proceedings ongoing, pending or to our knowledge, threatened, that would have a material adverse impact on the Elevator Technology Business as a whole.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We believe that our businesses have reasonable insurance protection, to the extent customary in the industry. We are insured under global group policies held by thyssenkrupp AG, including third-party (product) liability, property damage and business interruption, and directors and officers liability insurance. In addition, there are local insurance policies to be obtained by us via the thyssenkrupp AG mandated insurance broker. Both, global group insurance policies and local insurance policies remain to be mandated via the thyssenkrupp AG’s insurance broker. We are currently in the process of establishing our own global group insurance policies, which would come into effect on the Acquisition Closing Date, with support of a mandated insurance broker. For further information on risks related to our insurance coverage, see “Our insurance coverage may not be sufficient and _insurance premiums may increase.”_

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Our compliance program comprises the following three elements: “Inform and Advise,” “Identify,” and “Report and Act” and focuses in particular on antitrust, anti-corruption, anti-money-laundering, export control and data protection. It is closely interlinked with risk management and with our internal control system. 160 ----- Central components of the “Inform and Advise” pillar are antitrust law, anti-money laundering, export control and corruption prevention training programs carried out by the compliance officers as well as compliance advice given on business transactions and processes. In the training programs, employees are informed about compliance requirements, risks, and possible sanctions. The requirements are based on law and Group-wide policies and serve to implement international standards. We keep all our employees informed about compliance measures and new developments through training, intranet and various forms of communication adapted to target groups and content. We provide compliance support on important business transactions, for instance in connection with major projects, acquisitions or the engagement of intermediaries. Our compliance officers also advise the operating units on integrating compliance into their business processes. The “Identify” pillar focuses on regularly reviewing critical business operations based on a risk-oriented, structured audit process. Anti-money laundering screenings of high-risk payments are carried out when red flags are raised. An additional element is the identification of compliance risks through our whistleblowing system. Alongside the options of directly contacting a supervisor or the compliance department, this system provides employees with a further channel for reporting possible infringements of laws or policies without revealing their identity. The third pillar, “Report and Act,” encompasses intensive compliance reporting in all three dimensions of our organizational matrix. We investigate all reports of legal violations. Any violations identified are sanctioned as necessary, regardless of the name and function of the person involved. Substantive compliance responsibility in these areas remains with the competent corporate functions and segments. This ensures that in all areas of the company compliance is understood in accordance with our mission statement, an intensive exchange of knowledge takes place between the compliance function and those responsible for content, and the resultant synergies in organization, processes and methods are utilized.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Our risk strategy is focused on securing our existence and increasing our sustainably. Our business success requires opportunities to be recognized and associated risks to be identified and evaluated. Our risk strategy dictates that business risks should be entered into consciously and responsibly and managed proactively by all employees. Risks threatening our ability to continue as a going concern are to be avoided. The Group bases our risk management approach on the “Governance, Risk and Compliance (GRC) Policy” (the “GRC Policy”) applicable for all consolidated companies of the Group. In this policy, we define basic principles for corporate governance and risk management and also describe the universally applicable risk policy principles in the Group as a framework for meeting the requirements of proper, consistent and proactive risk management. The principles serve as guidelines for professional and responsible risk management. The aims of risk management at the Group are to increase risk awareness and establish a value-based risk culture at all corporate levels. Risks and opportunities in the Group are therefore analyzed transparently and are systematically incorporated into business decisions. In the GRC Policy, the risk management system methodology is embedded in a “three lines of defense” model. The first line of defense consists of functions that own and manage risks via management controls and internal controls. The second line of defense consists of functions such as Controlling, Accounting and Risk, Compliance and Legal, which oversee risks and help proactively manage them. Additionally, we have a department for our Internal Control System (“ICS”) responsible for setting ICS strategy and ICS processes at our subsidiaries. The goal of the ICS is to reduce operational risks, to ensure the reliability of financial reporting and to comply with laws, policies and internal guidelines. Depending on a company’s size, a control testing or a control selfassessment is annually performed to ensure that controls are implemented and designed to mitigate the underlying risks. Identified control deficiencies are assessed with regards to their impact and action plans defined. The third line of defense consists of Corporate Function Internal Audit, which independently reviews the appropriateness and efficiency of the process and systems implemented by the first two lines of defense. The “three lines of defense” model is also supplemented by the work of our external financial statement auditors. The design of various risk management instruments ensures that the sub-processes are integrated in a continuous risk management loop and all risk managers are involved appropriately in the risk management process. Methods and tools to identify, assess, control and report risks are implemented throughout the Group and are continually improved. Our main focus in using risk management instruments is to assess possible deviations in the key performance indicators such as adjusted EBIT and cash flow. Standard reporting of estimated opportunities and risks occurs at monthly intervals and once yearly for budget purposes. The opportunities and risks not included in the monthly updated estimations or in the budget are part of standard business unit reporting. 161 ----- To record relevant event risks in a structured way in specific areas of responsibility, all Group companies worldwide use a standardized IT risk management application to prepare risk maps biannually. The assessment period used for the risk map goes beyond the period covered by the forecast and provides multiple-year transparency on the local risk assessments. The regular reporting and updating of risks at local level also ensures that risk awareness remains high throughout the Group. Risks already recognized in the form of balance sheet provisions are also the subject of standardized analyses and risk reporting, ensuring systematic control of these risks as well. Ad hoc risks are communicated immediately to the risk management officers and are also documented via the established reporting channels. Risks are also further evaluated by the Risk and Internal Control Committee on a regular basis. These standardized risk management processes ensure that the Management Board and Supervisory Board are informed promptly and in a structured way about our current risk situation. However, despite comprehensive risk analysis, the occurrence of risks cannot be systematically ruled out. Risk transfer to insurers is currently handled centrally by the insurance department of the thyssenkrupp Group and will be taken over by us on the Acquisition Closing Date. Binding standards are in place for all Group companies to keep risk prevention at a sustainable and appropriate level. Such standards are updated as required.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We control our business and operations with what we believe to be state-of-the-art compliance and risk management systems. We established a standalone compliance and risk management system specific to thyssenkrupp Elevator with effect from January 1, 2020. This built-upon and enhanced the existing compliance program of the thyssenkrupp Group to specific needs of the elevator business. Our risk management system operates Group-wide and is a fundamental part of our corporate governance system. We continuously seek to reduce the likelihood and/or potential impact of the various risks to which we are exposed. The aim of our compliance and risk management system is to enable us to observe all applicable legal regulations, including those relating to anti-corruption, anti-money laundering, antitrust regulations and data protection on an ongoing and sustainable basis.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Sustainability is a core component of our corporate strategy. According to Neilsen’s Global Corporate Sustainability Report, 2015, 66% of consumers are willing to spend more on a product from a sustainable company. In our strategic sustainability management, we continuously work to identify the requirements of our stakeholders and develop corresponding targets and measures to improve our performance. Aligned with this approach on sustainability, at the Group, sustainability means investing in innovative mobility solutions that tackle the challenges of urbanization while making cities and buildings smarter and the best places to live. It also involves reducing our operational footprint, increasing our social contribution and ensuring our financial strength. We have a “Sustainability Committee,” consisting of members of our Management Board and heads of relevant functions. This committee manages sustainability activities in the Group and decides on measures and on our targets. The committee is supported by a Sustainability Council, which consists of sustainability managers of all the business units and representatives of the relevant functions. The Sustainability Committee has set targets in the areas of technology and innovations, environment, climate, energy, purchasing, and people. Our targets include energy and environmental management, annual energy efficiency gains, sustainable adjusted research and development intensity, a share of women in leadership positions, accident frequency rate and supplier sustainability audits. Progress towards these targets is factored into variable compensation for our Management Board and business area boards via a sustainability multiplier. For more information on our management, see “Management.” We aim to have our suppliers, along the entire chain, act responsibly and in line with environmental and social standards based on principles of sustainability. To be able to work with us, suppliers must sign our “Supplier Code of Conduct” or comply with equivalent standards. The Supplier Code of Conduct addresses possible risks and negative impacts along the supply chain, including areas such as human rights, fair working conditions, environmental protection, combating corruption and transparency into the origin of conflict minerals. Based on standard risk criteria for specific countries and sectors, the business areas select certain suppliers each year in order to carry out sustainability audits and evaluate compliance with our sustainability principles. We seek to engage positively with the communities around our locations and to support local residents. Accordingly, we are actively involved in various local projects, collaborations, multi-stakeholder initiatives and associations. We promote enthusiasm for technology and innovation, education, and local engagement. To ensure we maintain high compliance standards in all our work, we have implemented, among other things, a global documentation and approval system for corporate citizenship activities.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: The health and safety of employees is of primary importance to us. We seek to reduce the number of workplace accidents by employing exemplary practices, emphasizing concern for fellow employees, and eliminating unsafe conditions and potentially dangerous activities. We actively identify safety weaknesses and risks to health in order to discuss ways of making targeted improvements. We implement improvement ideas and monitors their effect. We apply detailed regulations and precise controls, notably with respect to the protection of employees, 162 ----- suppliers, service providers, manufacturing processes, plants, research, product development, workflow and transportation. There is an equal focus on the protection of the environment and the well-being of all who have contact with our products. Our goal is to reduce the frequency of workplace accidents and completely eliminate fatal accidents, which unfortunately still occur. Fatalities increased from six in the year ended September 30, 2018 to ten in the year ended September 30, 2019. We record and analyze each occupational incident in an effort to eliminate possible hazard sources. Standardized and systematic procedures, as well as compliance with global regulations, help to enhance safety. Our plants and processes are subject to continuous review and are kept up-to-date with state-of-the-art technology. All of our facilities aim to satisfy government requirements for operators of industrial plants and other facilities in the jurisdictions in which they operate. Because many raw materials, services, technical goods and other supplies have to be sourced from third parties, we work together with all parties concerned to ensure that deliveries comply with required specifications, standards and regulations. We have implemented an integrated management system, defining global minimum standards and requirements according to internationally recognized standards such as ISO 9001 (quality management), ISO 14001 (environmental management), ISO 50001 (energy management) and OHSAS 18001 (occupational health and safety management) and ISO 45001 (occupational health and safety management).

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Information Technology (“IT”) is an integral part of our operations, enabling process optimization, productivity increases and digitalization. Our IT landscape covers the entire business value chain, from research and development, engineering, manufacturing to New Installations, Services and Modernization. In addition, it supports the functional roles of finance, human resources, quality, safety, purchasing etc. The key application platforms include SAP (ERP), PTC Windchill, ConfigIT and VIEW (a proprietary solution for field sales and operations). These key applications have been designed as templates and are currently being rolled out globally based on business priorities and funding, which reduces the complexity of the system landscape and enables the business to operate at a global level while taking advantage of the substantial operational benefits these modern technologies offer. The end-to-end integration of these templates enables digitalization initiatives such as IoT, machine learning and advanced analytics. We are responsible for the entire infrastructure and application management of all local and global IT systems, and regularly monitor and update these systems and processes to ensure reliability, compliance, business continuity and performance. We are moving our application and infrastructure services to the cloud as we refresh and consolidate to deliver efficient and secure IT operations throughout the service life cycle. Our core IT governance is managed by global IT functional leaders with each of the business units supporting an IT organization that is tightly aligned to globally executes the IT strategy and its corresponding templates. Certain common services are currently provided by thyssenkrupp AG and, after the Acquisition Closing Date, thyssenkrupp AG will continue to provide the IT Services to us under the New TSAs and otherwise the Additional Agreements. The IT Services shall continue to be provided essentially in the same manner and scope as prior to the Acquisition Closing Date. However, we will seek to migrate all provision of the IT Services to our own independent IT services, either internally or through third parties, in order to support our critical business functions.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We are part of several joint venture agreements, primarily with the aim to gain access to markets where this is required for regulatory reasons (such as the Middle East). We have two material joint venture contracts; the first is with Marohn thyssenkrupp Elevator Co., Ltd. in China for supplying second-brand products to the Chinese market, in which we own 51% and the second with Braun thyssenkrupp Elevator LLC, USA, which provides such services in Wisconsin, USA, in which we own 50%.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Other than the Licensing Agreement, our joint venture agreements with Marohn thyssenkrupp Elevator Co., Ltd. in China and with Braun thyssenkrupp Elevator LLC, USA, our transitional service agreements and the financing arrangements described elsewhere herein, there are no industrial, commercial or financial agreements that we consider material to our business or profitability. 163 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: In all jurisdictions where we operate, our products and services are subject to laws, rules, regulations and technical standards (collectively “laws”) at international, EU, national, state and municipal levels. In particular, such laws include laws governing the design, manufacture, installation, operation and product safety of our products and services, and are mainly outlined in applicable building laws, building codes, specific safety codes for elevators and escalators and other product safety laws, as well as laws governing airport ground equipment and airport buildings. These laws differ substantially from jurisdiction to jurisdiction. In addition, our business is subject to environmental laws, product warranty and product liability laws, employee health and safety laws, labor and employment protection laws, intellectual property laws, hazardous substances and chemicals laws, export control laws, public procurement laws, competition and antitrust laws, tax laws, anti-money laundering laws, sanction laws, anti-bribery laws, anti- terrorism laws, data protection laws and criminal and other laws. In the area of environmental regulation, our operations are required to comply with laws and regulations relating to air, water and noise pollution, greenhouse gas emissions, toxic and other chemicals and materials, waste treatment and disposal methods, and the energy efficiency of production processes, among other things, in various jurisdictions in which we operate. We are also subject to periodic monitoring by environmental protection authorities in various jurisdictions. For example, at the EU level the legal and regulatory environment in which we operate includes many EU directives and regulations, which are either applied directly or otherwise implemented in the individual EU member states through national legislation. By contrast, in the United States numerous federal laws apply at the national level, while individual states and other more local jurisdictions have their own laws (e.g. building codes). In addition, international agreements, including bilateral and multilateral agreements between countries concerning customs duties or other regulations related to the import and export of products, apply directly or indirectly to us. The legal and regulatory requirements applicable to us are broad and diverse and may impose conflicting obligations and limitations on us. The cost of compliance with legal and regulatory requirements may be significant and we undertake significant efforts to stay up-to-date with all relevant requirements. The most material laws and regulations applicable to our business operations, broken down by our key jurisdictions (the EU, the United States and China, based on revenue as well as production output during the financial years 2016/2017 to 2018/2019), and by the general category of regulation, are described in further detail below. References in this section to any legislation or regulation are deemed to refer to such legislation or regulation as amended, supplemented or otherwise modified, and all further rules and regulations promulgated thereunder, unless such context requires otherwise.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Laws governing our products and services
Subsubsection Text: _Product Safety Directive_ Directive 2001/95/EC of the EU Parliament and of the Council of December 3, 2001 (last amended by Regulation (EC) No 596/2009 of the EU Parliament and of the Council of June 18, 2009) on general product safety (the “Product Safety Directive”) applies to any product – including in the context of providing a service – which is intended for consumers or likely, under reasonably foreseeable conditions, to be used by consumers even if not intended for them, in the absence of specific provisions among the EU regulations governing the safety of products concerned, or if sectorial legislation is insufficient. Under the Product Safety Directive, producers and distributors must place on the market only products which comply with general safety requirements.
