Therefore, manufacturers must provide consumers with the necessary information in order to assess a product’s inherent threat, particularly when this is not inherently obvious, and take the necessary measures to avoid such threats (for example, withdraw products from the market, inform consumers, recall products which have already been supplied to consumers). Appointed national authorities must monitor the compliance of products available on the market, ensure product safety legislation and rules are applied by manufacturers and business chains and apply sanctions when necessary. For example, Regulation (EC) No 765/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of July 9, 2008 sets out the requirements for 164 ----- accreditation and market surveillance relating to the marketing of products, and its most prominent feature is the “CE Marking” which can be used to attest the conformity of a product with the applicable requirements of the relevant legislation. In addition, the Product Safety Directive introduces an EU rapid alert system for dangerous non-food products. Commission Implementing Decision (EU) 2019/417 sets out guidelines for the management of the EU Rapid Information System (“RAPEX”), an information system for the rapid exchange of information between the EU member states and the EU Commission on measures and action taken in relation to products posing a serious risk to the health and safety of consumers. In addition to RAPEX, the Commission has set up the “Product Safety Business Alert Gateway,” enabling producers and distributors to report their dangerous products to the relevant Member State authorities. _Lifts Directive_ In light of the requirements for certain products and equipment, further directives have been adopted to harmonize national legislation regarding health and safety requirements across the EU. Of particular importance to us in this context is Directive 2014/33/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of February 26, 2014 (the “Lifts Directive”), regarding the harmonization of the laws of the Member States relating to lifts and safety components for lifts (as defined in Annex III of the Lifts Directive). This Lifts Directive on the sale and putting into service of lifts and safety components for lifts has two key objectives: (i) to allow lifts and their safety components to be sold throughout the EU market; and (ii) to ensure a high level of safety for lift users and maintenance staff. It generally applies to all lifts permanently serving buildings and constructions, intended for the transport of persons and goods, and operating at a speed of more than 0.15 m/s. The Lifts Directive lays down uniform rules on the sale and putting into service of lifts and safety components for lifts and defines the responsibilities of manufacturers, importers, distributors, installers and authorized representatives in the context of the sale of lifts and safety components for lifts. All lifts and safety components for sale in the EU must bear the CE Marking (as described above) to demonstrate that they meet all essential safety requirements of EU legislation. Before obtaining the CE Marking, the manufacturer must conduct a safety and conformity assessment and establish technical documentation for its lifts and components. Lifts and safety components for lifts which conform with harmonized standards or parts thereof, the references of which have been published in the Official Journal of the European Union, shall be presumed to conform to the essential health and safety requirements set out in Annex I of the Lifts Directive covered by those standards or parts thereof. “Harmonized standard,” as defined in Article 2 No 1 lit. c of Regulation (EU) No 1025/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of October 25, 2012 on European standardization, means technical specifications, adopted by a recognized standardization body, for repeated or continuous application, with which compliance is not compulsory, and which is one of the following: (i) an “international standard” meaning a standard adopted by an international standardization body; (ii) a “European standard” meaning a standard adopted by a European standardization organization; (iii) a “harmonized standard” meaning a European standard adopted on the basis of a request made by the Commission for the application of Union harmonization legislation; and (iv) a “national standard” meaning a standard adopted by a national standardization body. Of particular importance here are the EN 81-20 and EN 81-50 safety rules for the construction and installation of lifts and EN 13015 specifying how maintenance must be organized to keep lift safety up to the level required by the Lifts Directive. _Machinery Directive_ The Lifts Directive does not apply to funicular railways, hoists, escalators, moving walks and low-speed (< 0.15 m/s) home elevators. These are covered under Directive 2006/42/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of May 17, 2006 on machinery and amending Directive 95/16/EC (recast) (the “Machinery Directive”). The Machinery Directive outlines both compulsory as well as voluntary standards, and only applies to products when they are first placed on the EU market. This directive covers machinery, interchangeable equipment, safety components, lifting accessories, chains, ropes and webbing, removable mechanical transmission devices and partly completed machinery. This directive does not cover other types of machinery, such as machinery used in fairgrounds, the nuclear industry, laboratories and mines or by the military or police. _Product Liability Directive_ Council Directive 85/374/EEC of July 25, 1985, as amended by Directive 1999/34/EC of the EU Parliament and of the Council of May 10, 1999 (the “Product Liability Directive”), applies to movables which have been industrially produced, whether or not the movables have been subsequently incorporated into another movable or into an immovable. It establishes the principle of strict liability in cases of damage deemed to be caused by a defective product. Under a strict liability regime, the producer may be liable even without negligence or fault on 165 ----- its part. “Producer” means the manufacturer of a finished product, the producer of any raw material or the manufacturer of a component part and any person who, by putting his or her name, trademark or other distinguishing feature on the product, presents himself as its producer. Producers can be cleared of liability under certain conditions, notably, if they prove that they did not put the product into circulation, the defect was due to the compliance of the product with mandatory regulations issued by public authorities or the state of scientific or technical knowledge at the time that the product was put into circulation could not detect the defect. The Product Liability Directive applies to damage causing death or personal injuries and damage to private property. It sets out a time limit of three years for the recovery of damages and forbids clauses limiting or excluding the liability of the producer. The Product Liability Directive does not restrict compensation for non-material damage under national legislation. Within the chain of producers, we are theoretically entitled to seek compensation from our suppliers if the defect giving rise to product liability stems from a component supplied by such supplier. However, clear responsibility can be difficult to prove and, in order to maintain good relations to our suppliers, we are often required to refrain from holding our suppliers accountable. _Electromagnetic Compatibility Directive_ Directive 2014/30/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of February 26, 2014 on electromagnetic compatibility (the “Electromagnetic Compatibility Directive”) aims to ensure that electrical and electronic equipment complies with an adequate level of electromagnetic compatibility. It outlines uniform rules to ensure protection against electromagnetic disturbance in order to guarantee the free movement of electrical and electronic equipment within the EU’s internal market. The equipment covered by the Electromagnetic Compatibility Directive includes both apparatus and fixed installations. It does not apply to: radio and telecommunications terminal equipment; aircraft or equipment intended to be installed in aircraft; custom-built evaluation kits for professional use at research and development facilities; and radio equipment used by radio amateurs, unless the equipment is made available on the market for the general public. _Regulation on Market Surveillance and Product Compliance_ On June 20, 2019, Regulation (EU) 2019/1020 on market surveillance and compliance of products (Market Surveillance Regulation) was adopted by the European legislators. The Market Surveillance Regulation will apply from 16 July 2021, and will lead to a tightening of conformity checks and additional powers for national market surveillance authorities. The EU’s stated objective is to reinforce trust in the EU single market by ensuring compliance with, and enforcement of product legislation in cooperation with customs authorities. The powers of national market surveillance authorities will include at least (ii) the power to require economic operators to provide relevant document (including access to embedded software, information on their supply chain), (ii) the power to enter any premises, and (iii) the power to take samples. The measures implemented by the Market Surveillance Regulation will particularly have impact on online sales; however, also the elevator industry is also affected because elevators are also subject to harmonized EU legislation (i.e., Lifts Directive) and are therefore covered by the Market Surveillance Regulation. _Public Procurement Directive_ Since we regularly sell our products to public entities in the course of large infrastructure projects, we are also subject to public procurement laws. Directive 2014/24/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of February 26, 2014 on public procurement and repealing Directive 2004/18/EC (the “Public Procurement Directive”) regulates how public contracts above certain threshold amounts can be awarded by or on behalf of EU member states’ authorities. Within the meaning of the Public Procurement Directive, procurement is the acquisition by means of a public contract of works, supplies or services by one or more contracting authorities from economic operators chosen by those contracting authorities, whether or not the works, supplies or services are intended for a public purpose. Procurement processes which are subject to the Public Procurement Directive must comply with the requirements for a specific set of procedures as set out in the Public Procurement Directive. _German implementation measures and other material legislation_ In Germany, the Product Safety Directive has been implemented through the Product Safety Act (Produktsicherheitsgesetz). Section 8 of the Product Safety Act provides for the possibility of issuing ordinances. In this context, the Lifts Directive was implemented in the 12th ordinance to the Product Safety Act (12. VO zum _Produktsicherheitsgesetz – Aufzugsverordnung, the “Elevator Ordinance”) and the Machinery Directive in the_ 166 ----- ninth ordinance to the Product Safety Act (9. VO zum Produktsicherheitsgesetz, Maschinenverordnung, the “Machine Ordinance”). Both are essentially aligned to the provisions of the corresponding directives. Section 5 para. 5 of the Elevator Ordinance obliges the installer of an elevator to take “corrective measures” (Korrekturmaßnahmen), which can be interpreted as more than the warnings which may be sufficient in typical product safety cases, therefore requiring the installer to provide a fully functional product even after the expiration of any relevant warranty period, which could in turn result in significant costs for us. In addition to European standards, technical standards such as DIN 15306 on passenger lifts in residential buildings and DIN 15309 on passenger lifts in non-residential buildings continue to exist in Germany. The Product Liability Directive has been implemented through the Product Liability Act (Produkthaftungsgesetz). Furthermore, the German Civil Code (Bürgerliches _Gesetzbuch) obliges the manufacturer of a product to observe and put in place adequate safety precautions. Thereby, defective products shall be prevented from causing personal injury or damage. In particular, the manufacturer must avoid faults relating to the design and/or manufacture of the product. Furthermore, the manufacturer must instruct the users on the intended use of the product. For products that are already on the market, the manufacturer must monitor how its products are used and must inform the users about potential harmful uses which were not originally anticipated. According to the legal definition, “manufacturer” is anyone who produces a product, including suppliers and sub-suppliers. If the manufacturer fails to comply with its obligations, it shall be liable for the damage incurred. While potential claimants must prove that a product is defective and that this defect caused personal injury or damage, the manufacturer is obliged to evidentially prove that it has fulfilled its duties relating to design, manufacture and monitoring of the products as well as regarding adequately informing the users. The Electromagnetic Compatibility Directive is implemented in Germany via the law on electromagnetic compatibility of equipment (Gesetz über die elektromagnetische Verträglichkeit von Betriebsmitteln). In addition, there are regulations on lifts within the German building law (Bauordnungsrecht), specifically with respect to fire protection regulations. The Public Procurement Directive is implemented in Germany through several legal acts, in particular, Part IV of the Act against Restraints of Competition (Gesetz gegen Wettbewerbesbeschränkungen), the Public Procurement Ordinance (Vergabeverordnung), and the Regulations on Contract Awards for Public Works (Vergabe- und _Vertragsordnung für Bauleistungen – Teil A, “VOB/A”) which also covers public procurement processes that are_ outside the scope of the Public Procurement Directive.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Laws governing our products and services
Subsubsection Text: _International building Code and regional adaptations_ Building laws in the United States are generally governed by the International Building Code (“IBC”), but most individual states have made bespoke adoptions of the IBC and have implemented different variations, leading to a highly fragmented building law landscape. Within the IBC and its local adaptations, there are also varying provisions governing how our products may be used as part of a building. _Safety standards from ASME and ANSI_ The American Society of Mechanical Engineers (“ASME”) and the American National Standards Institute (“ANSI”) are both involved in setting the standards pertaining to how our products may be built and integrated into an existing structure. The ASME 17.1 elevator and escalator safety code covers the design, construction, operation, inspection, testing, maintenance, alteration, and repair of hoisting and lowering mechanisms (equipped with a car or platform) when that hoisting mechanism is located in or adjacent to a structure. This includes (among others): elevators, power-driven stairways and moving walks, escalators and moving walks, hoisting and lowering mechanisms, dumbwaiters and cargo lifts. It does not, however, cover personnel hoists, which are instead covered by ANSI A10.4. Similarly, material hoists are covered by ANSI A10.5 and stairway chairlifts are covered by ASME A18.1. _Maintenance standards from ASME and OSHA_ In California, the Occupational Health and Safety Administration (“OSHA”) and ASME work in conjunction to upkeep maintenance requirements for elevators. In general, state governments monitor elevator certification and inspections. Periodic maintenance is required on elevators, and certain maintenance, as well as records must be maintained in order to be certified by the relevant state and local government authorities. ASME, as well as 167 ----- OSHA, requires that all operating components which can be hazardous to individuals must be inspected and repaired immediately if problems are found. The safety equipment includes door operation, floor-to-floor travel, acceleration and deceleration of the elevator and emergency and safety equipment. _Product liability in the United States_ Under US product liability law, manufacturers, distributors, suppliers, retailers, and other parties who make products available to the public can be held responsible for the injuries deemed to be caused by those products. If a consumer, user or bystander is injured by a product that is defective or unreasonably dangerous, the manufacturer or anyone else in the supply chain can be held responsible for that injury. Product liability lawsuits brought by individual consumers or groups of consumers can become costly and lengthy. No uniform product liability statute or common law exists in the United States. Each state defines product liability law under its own standards. However, product liability claims are generally brought under the scope of strict product, tort (negligence or fraud) and warranty claims. The diversity of product liability law in the United States and the general availability of punitive damages, class actions and contingency fees create fertile ground for product liability claims in the United States.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Laws governing our products and services
Subsubsection Text: _Safety rules for the construction and installation of electric lifts (GB 7588-2003+XG1-2015)_ The safety rules for the construction and installation of electric lifts (GB 7588-2003+XG1-2015) were implemented on July 1, 2016 and describe both compulsory and voluntary standards. These standards stipulate minimum safety requirements which must be followed when manufacturing and installing passenger elevators, sickbed elevators (for example, in hospitals) and cargo elevators in order to prevent accidents that may injure passengers or damage cargo when elevators are operating. _Construction law of the People’s Republic of China_ The Construction Law of the People’s Republic of China must be followed when engaging in construction activities and in the exercise of supervision and administration over construction activities within the territory of the People’s Republic of China. The construction activities referred to in this law mean construction of all types of housing and the construction of their ancillary facilities, as well as the corresponding installation work of wiring, piping and equipment. Therefore, the provisions of this law on construction works also apply to work involving elevators, escalators or our other products. _Law of the People’s Republic of China on bid invitation and bidding_ Certain construction projects to be undertaken within the territory of the People’s Republic of China, including the surveying, design, construction and supervision of such projects, as well as the purchase of key equipment and materials for such projects, are subject to bid invitation, which is regulated by the Law of the People’s Republic of China on Bid Invitation and Bidding. Construction projects that require a formal bid invitation are: (i) large infrastructure and public utility projects that concern public interests and security; (ii) projects invested in wholly or partly by state-owned funds or financed by the state; and (iii) projects using loans or aid funds from international organizations or governments of other countries. Tenders for the above types of elevator projects are also subject to this law. _Law of the People’s Republic of China on Product quality_ Anyone who manufactures or sells any product within the territory of the People’s Republic of China shall comply with the Law of the People’s Republic of China on Product Quality. For the purpose of this regulation, products are defined as products processed or manufactured for sale. Although the law does not apply to construction projects, construction materials, structural components and fittings, and equipment that are used for construction projects are within the scope of the legislation, therefore also covering our products. _Special equipment safety law of the People’s Republic of China_ The Special Equipment Safety Law of the People’s Republic of China applies to elevators as they fall under the law’s definition of special equipment. The law applies to the production (including the design, manufacture, installation, modification and maintenance), operation, use, inspection, testing of and the supervision and administration of elevators. Elevator recalls are also governed by this law. 168 ----- _Product liability in the People’s Republic of China_ Pursuant to the Product Quality Law of the People’s Republic of China (as promulgated on February 22, 1993, implemented on September 1, 1993 and amended in 2000 and 2009), the Law of the People’s Republic of China on the Protection of the Rights and Interests of Consumers (as promulgated on October 31, 1993 and amended on October 25, 2013) and the Tort Law of the People’s Republic of China (as promulgated on December 26, 2009 and implemented on July 1, 2010), a producer shall be responsible for the quality of the products it has produced. Where any harm is caused by a defective product, the victim may claim for compensation either from the producers or sellers. If the liability lies on the producers and the compensation has been paid by the sellers, the sellers have the right to recover their losses from the producers. If the liability lies on the sellers and the compensation has been paid by the producers, the producers have the right to recover their losses from the sellers.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Laws governing our products and services
Subsubsection Text: The International Organization for Standardization (“ISO”) issues standards that are adhered to internationally. For example, elevators, escalators and moving walks are governed by ISO 14798, power- operated lifting platforms for persons with impaired mobility are governed by ISO 9386 and passenger boarding bridges are governed by ISO 16004.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsection Title: Laws governing our products and services
Subsubsection Text: The laws most relevant to our products and services are mainly contained in the applicable building laws and product safety laws. The following sets out the most relevant building, product liability and product safety laws in the jurisdictions of our most important markets.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: _Minimum Safety and Health Requirements Directive_ According to the Directive 2009/104/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of September 16, 2009, concerning the minimum safety and health requirements for the use of work equipment by workers at work (the “Minimum Safety and Health Requirements Directive”), employers must take every measure to ensure the safety of work equipment made available to workers. In selecting the work equipment, employers must pay attention to the specific working conditions which exist in the workplace with a view towards the safety and health of workers. Where risks cannot be fully eliminated in the operation of the work equipment, employers must take appropriate measures to minimize them. Where EU legislation governing work equipment exists, employers must ensure that the equipment meets its requirements or, if no such requirements exist, then the equipment must meet the requirements outlined in Annex I of the Minimum Safety and Health Requirements Directive. Where work equipment is likely to involve a specific risk to worker health and safety, employers must ensure that access to it is restricted only to those tasked with using that equipment. Employers must also ensure that only specially qualified workers carry out repair, modification, maintenance or servicing work. Employers must ensure that workers are appropriately trained, especially with regard to specific-risk equipment, and are made aware of any risks which the use of equipment may entail. In Germany, the “Ordinance on Industrial Safety and Health (Betriebssicherheitsverordnung)” implements the Minimum Safety and Health Requirements Directive and is further refined by the “Technical rules for operational safety” (Technische Regeln für Betriebssicherheit – TRBS). The “Act on the Implementation of Occupational Health and Safety Measures to Improve the Safety and Health Protection of Employees at Work” (Arbeitsschutzgesetz – ArbSchG) stipulates additional requirements to ensure the safety and health of employees.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: _Occupational Safety and Health Act 29 U.S.C. (1970)_ The Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 is a US labor law governing occupational health and safety in the United States and is administered by OSHA, which is an agency of the United States Department of Labor that covers most private sector employers and their employees within the United States, as well as individual 169 ----- states. Its primary goal is to ensure that employers provide employees with an environment free from recognized hazards, such as exposure to toxic chemicals, excessive noise levels, mechanical dangers, heat or cold stress, or unsanitary conditions. OSHA creates rules which are, together with all other rules created by federal regulatory agencies, collected into a multi-part document called the Code of Federal Regulations (“CFR”). Individual states also have established their own occupational health and safety standards, and these are in some cases more stringent than those promulgated by OSHA. Under the “General Duty Clause” found at Section 5(a)(1) of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970, employers are required to provide their employees with a place of employment that is “free from recognized hazards that are causing or are likely to cause death or serious physical harm.” In addition, most relevant for us are the following standards:

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: OSHA 29 CFR 1910, General Industry Standards: These standards generally apply to employers and employees
Subsubsection Text: engaged in general industry, and they cover a broad spectrum of activities, including the production of our products and provision of our services.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: OSHA 29 CFR 1926, Construction Standards: These standards apply to employers and employees in the
Subsubsection Text: construction industry. The New Installations, the Modernizations and most repair work carried out by us is governed by these standards.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: OSHA 29 CFR 1904, Record Keeping Standards: These standards cover the accident and training record-
Subsubsection Text: keeping requirements. _Robotic Industries Association Safety Standards_ The Robotic Industries Association (“RIA”) issues the ANSI/RIA R15.06-2012 safety standard for robotic equipment. This standard, which is an adoption of ISO 10218:2011 Parts 1 and 2, provides the industry with guidance on the proper use of safety features embedded within robots, as well as how to safely integrate robots into factories and work areas. OSHA relies on industry standards such as ANSI/RIA R15.06-2012, when determining compliance with applicable safety regulations. _National Fire Protection Association Standards_ OSHA’s electrical standards are based on the National Fire Protection Association (“NFPA”) standards NFPA 70, the National Electrical Code, any regionally adopted standards for the safe installation of electrical wiring and equipment, and NFPA 70E, the Standard for Electrical Safety in the Workplace, which governs the manufacturing of our products. _Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (1976)_ The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (“RCRA”) gives the United States Environmental Protection Agency, as well as individual states, the authority to control hazardous waste from cradle-to-grave. This includes the generation, handling, transportation, treatment, storage, and disposal of hazardous waste. RCRA also sets forth a framework for the management of non-hazardous solid wastes. RCRA also includes rules on how the Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labeling of Chemicals (GHS) is applied in the United States, which in turn also affects our products and services.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: ISO 45001 is the first international standard on occupational health and safety. It has been developed to improve employee safety, reduce workplace risks and create better, safer working conditions. ISO 45001 was introduced in 2018 and has a significant impact on how we organize our health and safety systems.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: In all jurisdictions in which we operate, we must comply with applicable laws and regulations to protect employees against occupational injuries. Under such laws and regulations, employers typically must establish and maintain working conditions that effectively prevent danger to employees. In particular, employers must comply with certain medical and hygiene standards, and meet certain health and safety requirements at work, such as carrying out risk assessments as well as adopting measures for the safety of employees. This is based on, for example, permissible maximum levels for noise in the workplace, regulations for the use of personal protective equipment and requirements for ambient temperature, ventilation and lighting, as well as working time and work break regulations.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Cross-border import and export of our Products
Subsubsection Text: Most countries in which we conduct business have import and export control regulations. We manufacture and handle products which are subject to export control and sanction regulations, as well as trade policy measures such as tariffs. We are required to comply with sanctions restrictions imposed by multiple authorities, such as the United Nations, the EU and the United States, in particular with respect to its commercial interactions with parties in sanctioned countries. In addition, the EU’s, the United States’ and other applicable sanctions and embargo laws and regulations vary in their application: they do not all apply to the same covered persons or prescribe the same activities, and such sanctions and embargo laws and regulations may be amended or strengthened over time.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Requirements in Member States of the EU
Subsubsection Text: Within the EU’s internal market, the principle of free movement of goods applies. When importing and exporting goods to non-EU countries, we have to comply with national and European foreign trade and customs regulations, including applicable trade sanctions law. At the EU level, the relevant regulatory framework concerning customs is the Union Customs Code (Regulation (EU) No 952/2013). For foreign trade regulations, a number of EU level regulations and national laws are applicable, as further described further below. We must also comply with EU compliance screening lists of specific persons and entities per Council Regulations, including (EC) No 881/2002 and 2580/2001, and with anti-money laundering regulations, including the Fifth Anti-Money Laundering Directive (EU) 2018/843. The EU has also imposed sanctions on certain persons, entities and dual-use exports to Russia via Regulation (EU) No 692/2014 and Regulation (EU) No 833/2014. To ensure compliance with these laws and regulations, each Group company screens its transactions and potential business partners and the export control team at thyssenkrupp AG conducts an additional postscreening of all debtors/creditors to detect any changes on sanctions lists.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Requirements under United States laws and regulations
Subsubsection Text: In the United States, the US Customs and Border Protection agency, among others, regulates the import of goods to and the export of goods from the United States. Imports are governed by a number of laws, including the Tariff Act of 1930. The US Departments of Justice, Commerce, State and Treasury and other federal agencies and authorities have a broad range of civil and criminal penalties they may seek to impose against corporations and individuals for violations of economic sanctions laws, export controls laws, anti-money laundering laws and other federal statutes and regulations, including those established by the US Department of Treasury’s Office of Foreign Assets Control (“OFAC”). Various government agencies may seek to impose modifications to business practices, including cessation of business activities in sanctioned countries or with sanctioned persons or entities as well as modifications to compliance programs, which may increase compliance costs, and may subject us to fines, penalties and other sanctions. A violation of these laws or regulations could adversely impact our business, results of operations and financial condition. Our current business in Russia and our former business in Iran, which still involves servicing and warranty claims, are subject to the regulatory framework of US secondary sanctions. The United States have imposed primary sanctions on certain Russian individuals, companies and sectors of the Russian economy. As a result of the Countering America’s Adversaries Through Sanctions Act of 2017, non-US persons must comply with certain secondary sanctions against Russia, even if such activities have no connection to the US. Among other things, non-US persons may face penalties for knowingly facilitating significant transactions or significant financial transactions for or on behalf of a party subject to the United States’ sanctions against Russia. Moreover, on November 5, 2018, the US announced it would withdraw from the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action which had previously eased US sanctions on Iran under the authority of, among others, the Iran Sanctions 171 ----- Act, the Comprehensive Iran Sanctions, Accountability and Divestment Act of 2010, the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012, the Iran Threat Reduction and Syria Human Rights Act of 2012, the Iran Freedom and Counter-Proliferation Act of 2012, and various Executive Orders. In broad terms, the US has reimposed US extraterritorial sanctions measures against Iran in connection with activity related to Iran’s energy, petrochemical, automotive, shipping, shipbuilding, port operating, and financial sectors. Persons engaged in such activities involving Iran will face exposure to secondary sanctions or enforcement actions under US law. Additionally, the US government has included certain Iranian persons and entities on the Specially Designated Nationals And Blocked Persons List (“SDN List”) and other sanctions lists as administered by OFAC. We have some business in Sudan, which is not prohibited under current US (or EU) sanctions. We have however ceased any new business and are in the process of winding down any existing business in Sudan.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We must observe various antitrust laws and regulations applicable in the jurisdictions in which it operates. Of particular relevance are: provisions on merger control, the prohibition of anti-competitive agreements, collusive behavior, the prohibition of abuse of a dominant position and the receipt of advantages in violation of state aid rules within the market. In general, such competition and antitrust laws and regulations are designed to preserve free and open competition in the marketplace in an effort to enhance competitiveness and economic efficiency. National and supranational competition and antitrust authorities may initiate investigations and proceedings for alleged infringements of competition or antitrust laws, which may result in significant fines or other forms of liability or impose certain limitations or conditions regarding acquisitions and certain business practices. We have been involved in antitrust proceedings with European authorities and is still subject to certain related third-party claims. For more information, see “Business—Legal Proceedings—Antitrust proceedings and private _follow-on litigation.”_ 170 ----- Within the EU, compliance with applicable European and national competition laws is monitored by the European Commission and in some cases the national competition authorities (for instance, in Germany, the Federal Cartel Office (Bundeskartellamt)). The EU’s antitrust rules are set out in articles 101 and 102 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (“TFEU”). Article 101(1) of the TFEU prohibits anticompetitive agreements to the extent they are not otherwise exempted by article 101(3) of the TFEU. The assessment of whether the exemption criteria of article 101(3) of the TFEU are met must be made by us in a “self-assessment.” This self-assessment of compliance of our agreements with dealers, suppliers or competitors generally carries the risk that the European Commission, national competition authorities or national courts could arrive at a different conclusion as to whether there is an infringement of the relevant competition law at issue.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: When processing personal data in the European Economic Area, we are subject to the General Data Protection Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (“GDPR”) and the respective implementation legislation in the national laws of the Member States, which is in Germany the Federal Data Protection Act (Bundesdatenschutzgesetz, “BDSG”). Both the GDPR and BDSG have been applicable since May 25, 2018. The GDPR has significantly changed the legal framework for data protection in the EU and triggered additional compliance efforts and costs for German companies in general. The GDPR introduced substantial sanctions for non-compliance. A violation of obligations under the GDPR may constitute an administrative offense, which can result in fines or investigative measures imposed by the competent data protection authority, as well as civil liabilities or even criminal sanctions. We have incurred and expects to continue to incur costs to implement various measures throughout its operations (including appropriate training of employees, fulfillment of additional documentation duties, adjustments of processes and monitoring by our data protection and compliance teams) as a result of the GDPR and the national data protection laws. Furthermore, the GDPR generally requires us to inform the competent supervisory authority of any breaches of personal data stored or processed by us within 72 hours of becoming aware of such breach. Where the relevant breach is likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of the affected data subjects, we are also required to inform these data subjects of such breach without undue delay.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to numerous Federal and State privacy laws in the US. These refer to general prohibitions of unfair or deceiving practices, which includes the prohibition to handle personal data in an unexpected manner, as well as to data protection in specific sectors. There are specific rules on cybersecurity and data breaches notification requirements. Each state has developed their own data breach notification requirements. Data privacy and protection laws are evolving in the U.S. and can vary significantly.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Regarding our activities in China, we are bound by Chinese data privacy law, which consists of numerous laws and industry-specific regulations, complemented by standards. In addition, data privacy considerations can be inferred from general principles of civil law including tort law. The legal landscape is complex and subject to frequent changes. Therefore, uncertainty remains as to the specific application of Chinese data privacy law as well as to the practical steps needed in order to achieve compliance. In December 2019, China’s authorities announced new legislation on protection of personal data. 172 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Due to the increasingly digital nature of our offerings and its plan to further develop connectivity and digitalization for its customers, regulations governing the protection of our various stakeholders’ personal data could have a significant impact on our business.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: As of the date of this offering memorandum, the Supervisory Board of thyssenkrupp Elevator is composed of 16 members, of which eight are representatives of the shareholders and eight are representatives of the employees. It is expected that the majority of the members of the Supervisory Board will change in connection with the Acquisition. Set forth below are the names and respective ages of each member of thyssenkrupp Elevator’s Supervisory Board who is expected to remain after consummation of the Acquisition.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: The Supervisory Board has the power to form committees in accordance with the law and decide the composition, powers and procedures of such committees. Where permitted under law, decision-making powers of the Supervisory Board may be conferred upon such committees. As of the date of this offering memorandum, the Supervisory Board has formed the Executive Committee, the Mediation Committee and the Personnel Committee, brief descriptions of which are set forth below. _Executive committee_ The Executive Committee (Präsidium) advises and supports the chairperson and the vice chairperson of the Supervisory Board and prepares the Supervisory Board meetings. The Executive Committee also has, among others, the following responsibilities: (i) dealing with questions calling for possible immediate action by the Management Board or potentially relating to confidential inside information; (ii) consulting on questions of corporate governance and issuing recommendations in cases which require the Supervisory Board’s approval; (iii) preparation of the Supervisory Board’s efficiency review; and (iv) decision-making in certain cases transferred to the Executive Committee by the full Supervisory Board. The Executive Committee consists of the chairperson of the Supervisory Board, the vice chairperson of the Supervisory Board and two further members of the Supervisory Board – one elected at the proposal of the employee representatives and one elected at the proposal of the shareholder’s representatives. The current members of the Executive Committee who are expected to remain after consummation of the Acquisition are Knut Kiesler (Vice-Chairman) and Susanne Herberger. _Mediation Committee_ The Mediation Committee (Vermittlungsausschuss) pursuant to section 27 para. 3 German Co- Determination Act (Mitbestimmungsgesetz) has the task of making proposals for the appointment and dismissal of members of the Management Board in cases where section 31 paras. 3 and 5 German Co-Determination Act (Mitbestimmungsgesetz) apply. The Mediation Committee consists of the chairperson of the Supervisory Board, the vice chairperson of the Supervisory Board and two further members of the Supervisory Board – one elected at the proposal of the employee representatives and one elected at the proposal of the shareholder’s representatives. The current members of the Mediation Committee who are expected to remain after consummation of the Acquisition are Knut Giesler (Vice-Chairman) and Susanne Herberger. _Personnel Committee_ The Personnel Committee (Personalausschuss) prepares the personnel decisions of the Supervisory Board and in particular make proposals for the appointment and termination of the appointment of members of the Management Board. It also makes, among other things, a proposal for the target share of women on the Management Board and a deadline for achieving this target and submits to the Supervisory Board proposals for resolution on the compensation of the individual member of the Management Board. The Personnel Committee consists of the chairperson of the Supervisory Board, the vice chairperson of the Supervisory Board and two further members of the Supervisory Board – one elected at the proposal of the employee representatives and one elected at the proposal of the shareholder’s representatives. The current members of the Personnel Committee who are expected to remain after consummation of the Acquisition are Knut Giesler and Susanne Herberger.

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Title: Remuneration and other benefits of the members of the Management Board and the Supervisory Board
Subsubsection Text: The Management Board of the Target received total remuneration of €6.0 million, €8.1 million and €3.7 million in the years ended September 30, 2017, 2018 and 2019, respectively. Remuneration consisted of short-term benefits, post-employment benefits, termination benefits and share-based compensation. The Supervisory Board received total remuneration of €0.1 million in each of the years ended September 30, 2017, 2018 and 2019, respectively. Remuneration consisted of short-term benefits (inclusive of meeting attendance fees). 176 -----

Section Title: INDUSTRY
Subsubsection Text: Hans-Hermann Lotter . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 55 Managing Director Set forth below is a short biography of the EUR SSN Issuer’s managing director. _Hans-Hermann Lotter was appointed as managing director of the EUR SSN Issuer and the SUN Issuer with_ effect from February 25, 2020. Hans has been Operating Partner at Advent International since December 2010 and has more than 20 years’ experience in representing private equity investors at supervisory board levels in portfolio companies. Hans is Chairman of the board of directors of AI Alpine (Luxembourg) and of the supervisory boards of Addiko Bank, in Vienna, Zagreb, Sarajevo and Banja Luka and holds several other professional and advisory positions. Hans holds a Master of Business Administration from the University of Miami and a Master in Mathematical Economics (Dipl.-Math) from the University of Ulm. Raj Rupani . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 33 Director Don Whitt . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 53 Director Set forth below is a short biography of each member of the board of directors of the USD SSN Issuer, to the extent not described above. _Raj Rupani was appointed as a member of the board of directors of the USD SSN Issuer on April 24, 2020. Raj is_ currently the Head of US Tax at Cinven. Prior to joining Cinven, Raj was a Senior Manager in International Tax Services at Deloitte, providing tax advisory services on US inbound and outbound tax issues, including acquisitions, restructuring and new investments. Raj has a master’s in business taxation from the University of Southern California. _Don Whitt was appointed as a member of the board of directors of the USD SSN Issuer on April 24, 2020. Don is_ the Vice President, Global Tax at Advent International. Prior to joining Advent International, Don was Corporate Vice President,—Global Tax & Treasury at Micron Technology and Vice President of Tax Planning at Pfizer, Inc. Don holds a Doctor of Law (J.D.) from the University of Toledo College of Law and a Master of Science (M.S.) in Taxation from the University of Toledo. Hans-Hermann Lotter . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 55 Managing Director For a short biography of Hans-Hermann Lotter, see “—EUR SSN Issuer.” Peter Walker . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 57 Chief Executive Officer Ercan Keles . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 49 Chief Financial Officer Dr. Detlef Hunsdiek . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 63 Chief Human Resources Officer Set forth below is a short biography of each of the members of our Management Board: _Peter Walker was appointed Chief Executive Officer of the Group on January 10, 2020. Prior to his current_ appointment, Mr. Walker served as chief executive officer of the elevator technology business within the thyssenkrupp Group since 2019 and, prior to that, as chief operating officer and member of the board of directors since 2018. Mr. Walker has served in several roles since joining the elevator business of the thyssenkrupp Group in 1995, including chief executive officer for Asia/Pacific from 2005 to 2018, chief operating officer (field) for thyssenkrupp Elevator China from 2004 to 2005, and managing director of the thyssenkrupp Group’s Australia operation from 1998 until 2004. Before joining the thyssenkrupp Group, Mr. Walker was the general manager of City Elevator Service in Australia, where he started his profession in the elevator business in 1989 and was involved in the sale of the elevator company to the thyssenkrupp Group in 1995. Mr. Walker graduated from Macquarie University with a master’s degree in business administration. _Ercan Keles was appointed Chief Financial Officer of thyssenkrupp Elevator on January 10, 2020. Prior to this_ appointment, Mr. Keles served as chief financial officer and board member of the elevator technology business in the thyssenkrupp Group since 2012. Mr. Keles has served in various roles since joining the thyssenkrupp Group plant industry division in 2006, including most recently chief financial officer of the business area “Components” of thyssenkrupp Technologies AG from 2009 to 2012, and prior to that, head of controlling of the ThyssenKrupp Technologies AG, financial director at ThyssenKrupp Uhde Services GmbH, and head of controlling at ThyssenKrupp Uhde GmbH. Mr. Keles started his professional career in 1998 at Carl Zeiss Industrielle Messtechnik GmbH, where he held various positions within the controlling and financial departments of companies in Germany and Japan and served for four years as financial director at Carl Zeiss Ltd, England. Mr. Keles graduated with honors from the Justus-Liebig-University Gießen with a degree in business administration. _Dr. Detlef Hunsdiek was appointed Chief Human Resources Officer of thyssenkrupp Elevator on January 10,_ 2020. Prior to this appointment, Dr. Hunsdiek served as chief human resources officer and member of the management board of thyssenkrupp Elevator from 2017 until 2020. Dr. Hunsdiek served in several roles since joining the thyssenkrupp Group in 2006, including head of human resources and executives management as chief representative and executive officer at thyssenkrupp AG from 2006 to 2017, chairman of the management board of the thyssenkrupp Academy GmbH from 2006 to September 2019, and member of the supervisory board of thyssenkrupp Steel Europe AG and thyssenkrupp Materials Services GmbH from 2009 until 2017. Prior to joining the thyssenkrupp Group, Dr. Hunsdiek worked at Bertelsmann AG since 1991, and most recently as 174 ----- executive president of human resources. Dr. Hunsdiek studied at the University of Cologne and Pennsylvania State University and graduated with a degree in business administration (Dipl.-Kaufmann). Furthermore, he graduated from the University of Bonn with a doctorate (PhD). Knut Giesler . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 56 Supervisory Board Member and Vice-Chairman Markus Goretzki . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 48 Supervisory Board Member Jürgen Groß . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 63 Supervisory Board Member Susanne Herberger . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 55 Supervisory Board Member Wolfgang Krause . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 58 Supervisory Board Member Jörn Kruse . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 50 Supervisory Board Member Georgios Triantafillidis . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 44 Supervisory Board Member Yusuf Tüfekci . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 47 Supervisory Board Member Set forth below is a short biography of each of the above members of the Supervisory Board. _Knut Giesler has been vice chairman of the Supervisory Board since March 11, 2020. Mr. Giesler is a trained_ power plant electrician and district manager (Bezirksleiter) of the union body IG Metall Nordrhein-Westfalen. Mr. Giesler is a member of the supervisory boards of Aptiv Services Deutschland GmbH (vice chairman) and Vodafone GmbH. In addition, he is a member of the administrative board of the independent economic research institute Rheinisch-Westfälisches Institut für Wirtschaftsforschung, Essen. _Markus Goretzki has been appointed as a member of the Supervisory Board in May 2020. He graduated with a_ mechanical engineering degree (Dipl.-Ing) from the Technical University of Munich in 1998 and immediately joined the former Thyssen Industries AG where he has since held various national and international positions at headquarter and operation level. In 2005 he joined the thyssenkrupp Elevator AG headquarter from where he moved from the position of branch manager to currently serving as branch manager Nürnberg and Bayreuth and holding the position of head of EAGLE DACH since 2012. _Jürgen Groß has been a member of the Supervisory Board since March 11, 2020. Mr. Groß began his career as a_ trade union secretary at IG Metall in Gaggenau. In 1988, he moved to IG Metall Esslingen, initially as trade union secretary, and was elected as second representative (Geschäftsfiihrer) in 2011. She joined thyssenkrupp_ Aufzüge GmbH in 1991 after working previously at Takraft, data center in Leipzig and Sächsischer Bühnen- und Stahlhochbau, elevator construction department in Dresden. She is currently vice chairperson of the works council of the thyssenkrupp Group and also serves as a member of the supervisory board of thyssenkrupp AG. Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Ongoing Relationships and Services Provided by the thyssenkrupp Group
Subsubsection Title: Relationship Agreement between the Target and thyssenkrupp AG
Subsubsection Text: On December 18, 2019, with effect as of January 1, 2020, the Target and thyssenkrupp AG entered into an agreement that governs certain general principles regarding the future relationship and cooperation between the Target and thyssenkrupp AG (the “Relationship Agreement”). The Target and thyssenkrupp AG have agreed to cooperate, align and collaborate on certain matters in order to allow thyssenkrupp AG, inter alia, (i) to prepare its consolidated financial statements, prospectuses, other mandatory reports, tax returns and other tax reporting obligations and budget planning, (ii) to ensure compliance with its organizational and compliance duties and (iii) to ensure compliance with its reporting and capital markets related obligations. The Relationship Agreement will be terminated as of the Acquisition Closing Date.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Ongoing Relationships and Services Provided by the thyssenkrupp Group
Subsubsection Title: Services provided by the thyssenkrupp Group to the Group
Subsubsection Text: _Transitional Service Agreements (“TSAs”)_ Certain companies of our Group have entered into 14 TSAs with different companies in the thyssenkrupp Group (covering entities in Germany, China, USA and Brazil), pursuant to which we receive a number of services, such as accounting and risk services, IT, procurement, intellectual property, real estate, human resources, legal and compliance, tax and others (the “Existing TSAs”). The terms under which such services are to be provided and the respective fees for such services are set out in the relevant Existing TSAs and are effective as of January 1, 2020. Pursuant to the Existing TSAs, the services shall continue to be provided essentially in the same manner, kind and scope as prior to January 1, 2020. The Existing TSAs have indefinite terms but are intended to last for a maximum duration of two years from their effective dates, whereupon the services covered by such Existing TSAs will be transitioned to, and thereafter will be provided directly by, the Group. The parties to the respective Existing TSAs may terminate the agreement in whole or in part following a notice period of six months which may be given at the end of each calendar month; however, such termination notice shall not be delivered within six months after the completion of the Offering. In accordance with the terms of the Share Purchase Agreement, the thyssenkrupp Group and the Group are negotiating, at arm’s length, necessary amendments to the Existing TSAs to reflect the requirements of the Acquisition, including scope of services, changes to service charge levels, duration, and liability, as well as including additional required services or removing certain services. As per the Share Purchase Agreement, this negotiation process will result in each of the Existing TSAs being amended and restated on the Acquisition Closing Date (the “New TSAs”). Under the New TSAs, the thyssenkrupp Group will continue to provide a number of services, including relating to accounting and risk services, IT, procurement, real estate, human resources, compliance, tax (in certain jurisdictions) and others, to the Group, following the Acquisition. The New TSAs will supersede the Existing TSAs and will include this reduced selection of services to reflect the build-up of internal resource in the Group by the Acquisition Closing Date. The duration of each New TSA after the Acquisition Closing Date varies based on the scope and necessary support for each service. In addition to the Existing TSAs, certain companies of our Group have entered into over 500 different agreements with companies in the thyssenkrupp Group pursuant to which we receive a number of additional services and/or provide services to the thyssenkrupp Group (the “Additional Service Agreements”). The majority of these services are IT services and services of thyssenkrupp AG’s global shared services centers (GSS). Although a process is underway to terminate a significant number of the Additional Service Agreements prior to the Acquisition Closing Date, many of the Additional Service Agreements are expected to continue after the Acquisition Closing Date. In relation to those Additional Service Agreements which will not terminate prior to the Acquisition Closing Date, the thyssenkrupp Group and the Group are negotiating, at arm’s length, the extension of the minimum duration of various critical services provided by the thyssenkrupp Group under the Additional Service Agreements to allow a sufficient period to migrate those critical services away from the thyssenkrupp Group. 177 -----

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Relationships with the thyssenkrupp Group in the Past
Subsubsection Text: Historically, we have entered into certain operational and financial transactions with certain subsidiaries of the thyssenkrupp Group in the ordinary course of business. Below are descriptions of certain of these key transactions. For further details on our relationship with the thyssenkrupp Group, see Note 22 of the Audited Combined Financial Statements. _Service agreements_ Prior to the separation of the Target from the thyssenkrupp Group, service agreements concluded on an arm’s length basis were in place to regulate the provision of various services. In addition to these contractual services, additional costs mainly related to general overhead functions such as accounting and risk, IT, procurement, intellectual property, real estate, human resources, legal and compliance, tax and other functions of the thyssenkrupp Group have been allocated based on certain allocation metrics such as revenue contribution of the Group in relation to the thyssenkrupp Group for the past. These corporate cost allocations amounted to €98 million, €71 million and €66 million in the years ended September 30, 2017, 2018 and 2019, respectively. It is intended that, with effect from the Acquisition Closing Date, the New TSAs will replace some of these agreements and general services, whereas the existing contractual services will continue until the services covered by them can be transitioned to the Group or to other third party service providers. _License Agreement_ On September 25, 2019, against the background of a then-proposed initial public offering, thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation entered into a brand licensing agreement with thyssenkrupp AG (the “Brand Licensing Agreement”), allowing thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and its subsidiaries to indefinitely use certain trademarks, including the trademark “thyssenkrupp” in carrying out the business of the Group, against payment of a one-time fee of €1,080 million. Subsequently, in light of the Acquisition, thyssenkrupp AG, thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and thyssenkrupp Elevator have entered into an addendum agreement (“License Addendum”) to the Brand Licensing Agreement, pursuant to which thyssenkrupp AG will refund the original license fee paid to it under the Brand License Agreement. thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation has agreed to pay a compensation for use of €172.8 million, of which €98.7 million relates to the period until the Acquisition Closing Date and €74 million relates to the period thereafter. The refund of the original license fee (together with applicable value added tax) by thyssenkrupp AG and the payment of the compensation for use by thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation, are being settled through intercompany accounts. The Brand License Agreement, as supplemented by the License Addendum, will be automatically terminated 18 months after the Acquisition Closing Date. _Guarantees/surety bonds_ The thyssenkrupp Group has provided guarantees and surety bonds aggregating to €1,228 million in favor of the Group as of March 31, 2020, of which €97 million relate to corporate guarantees and €1,131 million to bank guarantees and surety bonds. _Financing_ Historically, the Group was integrated into the cash pooling and cash management systems of the thyssenkrupp Group. In the six months ended March 31, 2020, the interest expenses and interest income generated in connection with such financing activities with thyssenkrupp AG and the remaining thyssenkrupp Group amounted to €28 million and €14 million, respectively. Under the Share Purchase Agreement, all existing intercompany finance agreements between the Group and the thyssenkrupp Group shall be terminated at least three business days prior to the Acquisition Closing Date. Further, any outstanding balances under such intercompany finance agreements are required to be settled on or prior to the Acquisition Closing Date in the manner provided under the Share Purchase Agreement. _Leasing_ Historically, the Group entered into leasing transactions with the thyssenkrupp Group. As of September 30, 2019, these consisted in particular of operating lease agreements and the finance lease of the test tower in Rottweil, Germany with respect to real estate. The lease agreement regarding the test tower in Rottweil is expected to terminate on the Acquisition Closing Date and thereafter, the title would be transferred to the Group.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: We intend to establish the structure for a management equity participation program prior to the Acquisition Closing Date to which certain managers of the Group will be able to subscribe to after the Acquisition Closing Date. The subscribing managers will be invested through a vehicle in the form of a German limited partnership (GmbH&Co KG) which will hold securities in a Luxembourg holding company of the SUN Issuer and will be expected to enter into certain customary documentation. 178 -----

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: In the course of our ordinary business activities, we enter into related party transactions with our shareholders, companies within the Group, key management personnel and associates. We believe that all transactions with such parties are negotiated and executed on an arm’s-length basis and that the terms of these transactions are comparable to those currently contracted with unrelated third-parties. In addition, we will engage in various financing transactions with our new shareholders and enter into new related party transactions in connection with the Transactions.

Section Title: PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS Senior Facilities Agreement
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the financing of the Acquisition, the SSN Issuers are expected on or prior to the Issue Date to enter into a senior facilities agreement with, among others, a certain financial institution as agent, the Security Agent, and Goldman Sachs International, Barclays Bank PLC, Credit Suisse Loan Funding LLC, Credit Suisse International, UBS Europe SE, Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch and Royal Bank of Canada, as mandated lead arrangers (“Senior Facilities Agreement”). The Senior Facilities Agreement provides for (i) senior term loan facilities in principal amounts of USD equivalent of €500 million (“Facility A”), €1,000 million (“TLB1”) and the USD equivalent of €2,050 million (“TLB2” and together with TLB1, “Facility B”) (ii) a revolving credit facility in a principal amount of €1,000 million (the “Revolving Credit Facility”), and (iii) a revolving guarantee facility in a principal amount of €1,000 million (the “Guarantee Facility”) (Facility A, Facility B, the Revolving Credit Facility and the Guarantee Facility are collectively referred to as the “Original Senior Credit Facilities” for the purposes of this description and Facility A and Facility B are collectively referred to as the “Original Term Facilities”). Incremental facilities may also be established under the Senior Facilities Agreement from time to time (including by way of an increase to any existing facilities or the establishment of new facilities) (“Incremental Senior Secured Facilities” and, together with the Original Senior Credit Facilities, the “Senior Secured Facilities”).

Section Title: PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS Senior Facilities Agreement
Subsubsection Text: The Original Term Facilities may be utilized by the EUR SSN Issuer and certain of its restricted subsidiaries which enter into the Senior Facilities Agreement as borrowers of such facility or otherwise accede to the Senior Facilities Agreement as additional borrowers of that facility (the “Term Facility Borrowers”). The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized by the EUR SSN Issuer and certain of its restricted subsidiaries which enter into the Senior Facilities Agreement as borrowers of such facility or otherwise accede to the Senior Facilities Agreement as additional borrowers (the “RCF Borrowers”), in AUD, CAD, CHF, DKK, EUR, GBP, HKD, NOK, SEK and USD and certain other currencies readily available in the relevant interbank market and freely convertible into EUR (subject to obtaining the consent of all the relevant lenders under the Revolving Credit Facility) by the drawing of cash advances, the issue of letters of credit and ancillary facilities (on a bilateral and/or fronted basis). The Guarantee Facility may be utilized by the EUR SSN Issuer and certain of its restricted subsidiaries which enter into the Senior Facilities Agreement as borrowers of such facility or otherwise accede to the Senior Facilities Agreement as additional borrowers (the “Guarantee Facility Borrowers”), in AED, ARS, AUD, BDT, BHD, BRL, CAD, CHF, CLF, CLP, CNY, COP, CZK, DKK, EGP, EUR, GBP, GTQ, HKD, HNL, HRK, HUF, IDR, ILS, INR, JOD, KRW, KWD, MAD, MXN, MYR, NOK, PEN, PLN, PYG, QAR, RON, RUB, SAR, SEK, SGD, THB, TRY, TWD, USD, VND and certain other currencies readily (subject to obtaining the consent of all the relevant lenders under the Guarantee Facility) by the issuance of “Bank Guarantees” (comprising sureties (Bürgschaften), sureties on first demand (Bürgschaften auf erstes Anfordern), guarantees, bonds or standby or documentary letters of credit or similar instruments in any form requested by a Guarantee Facility Borrower but not financial guarantees or guarantees which back indebtedness) on a bilateral and/or fronted basis.

Section Title: PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS Senior Facilities Agreement
Subsubsection Text: All amounts borrowed under the Original Term Facilities shall be applied directly or indirectly, in or towards (including by way of on-lending to, or investment in, any other member of the Senior Secured Group (as defined below) or Target Group) (directly or indirectly): (i) financing or refinancing consideration paid or payable in connection with the Acquisition (including any purchase price adjustments); (ii) the payment of certain costs relating to the Acquisition and all other fees, costs, expenses and other amounts incurred in connection with the Transactions; (iii) refinancing or otherwise discharging existing debt of the Target (including back-stopping or providing cash cover in respect of any letters of credit, guarantees or ancillary, revolving, working capital or local facilities or other arrangements) and paying any breakage costs, redemption premium, make-whole costs and other fees, costs and expenses payable in connection with such refinancing and/or acquisition; (iv) financing any other payments identified in or for any other purpose contemplated by the tax structure memorandum or the funds flow statement or otherwise arising in connection with the Transaction; (v) financing other related amounts, including fees, costs and expenses; and/or (vi) to the extent not applied for a purpose set out in sub-paragraphs (i) to (v) above, financing or refinancing the general corporate purposes and/or working capital requirements of the Senior Secured Group (including, for the avoidance of doubt, as cash over-funding). 180 ----- The Revolving Credit Facility may be used for: (i) financing or refinancing the general corporate purposes and/or working capital requirements of the Senior Secured Group; (ii) to backstop or provide cash cover in respect of any existing ancillary facilities, guarantees, indemnities, letters of credit, revolving, working capital or local facilities or other arrangements of the Target Group (if applicable) and financing or refinancing any other transactions contemplated by the Transaction; and/or (iii) financing any other payments identified in, or for any other purpose contemplated by, the tax structure memorandum or the funds flow statement or otherwise arising in connection with the Transaction, in each case, together with related fees, costs and expenses (and including, for the avoidance of doubt, as cash over-funding). Each Bank Guarantee requested by a Guarantee Facility Borrower to be issued under the Guarantee Facility must be issued:(i) to the Vendor in the form of a Purchaser/Vendor Acquisition Guarantee; (ii) in respect of projects, transactions or other contractual obligations entered into in the ordinary course of business of the Senior Secured Group (where, for the avoidance of doubt, any such instruments may be drawn under the Guarantee Facility directly in favor of beneficiaries or indirectly in favor of beneficiaries (by way of “back-to-back” or equivalent arrangements)) provided that each such Bank Guarantee covers liabilities in relation to advance payments, performance of contracts, bidding processes or other obligations in ordinary course of business where the instrument itself or the underlying obligation to which it relates does not constitute Indebtedness (including payment obligations in relation to an acquisition, investments, capital expenditures, obligations in relation to employee overtime accounts (Ansprüche der Arbeitsnehmer aus Überstunden auf Arbeitszeitkonten), the protection of credits under partial retirement schemes from insolvency (Zahlungsavale zur Insolvenzsicherung _von Wertguthaben aus Altersteilzeit) or (iii) to counter-indemnify any local facility provided by a branch or_ affiliate of a Lender under the Guarantee Facility or any other person to a member of the Group provided that such local facility is used solely by that member of the Group to issue bank guarantees as permitted to be issued pursuant to sub-paragraph (ii) above.

Section Title: PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS Senior Facilities Agreement
Subsubsection Text: The Original Term Facilities will be available to be utilized from (and including) the date of the Senior Facilities Agreement to (and including) the earliest to occur of (i) 30 December 2020 (ii) the date falling one Business Day after the longstop date under the Acquisition Agreement; (iii) the first date on which both the (a) Acquisition Closing Date has occurred, and (b) the first utilisation of the Original Term Facilities has been made (the “Closing Date”) and (iv) the date on which the EUR SSN Issuer (or its Affiliate) determines and notifies the agent under the Senior Facilities Agreement that the Acquisition Agreement has been validly and conclusively terminated prior to the longstop date under the Acquisition Agreement. The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized from (and including) the date of the Senior Facilities Agreement to (and including) the maturity date of the Revolving Credit Facility. The Guarantee Facility may be utilized from (and including) (and including) the date of the Senior Facilities Agreement to (and including) the maturity date of the Revolving Credit Facility. Utilizations of the Original Senior Credit Facilities are subject to customary conditions precedent.

Section Title: PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS Senior Facilities Agreement
Subsubsection Text: Loans under the Original Senior Credit Facilities will initially bear interest at rates per annum equal to EURIBOR or, for loans denominated other than in Euro, the applicable IBOR, plus an applicable margin, which in each case will be subject to a decreasing margin ratchet based on the ratio of consolidated senior secured net debt to consolidated pro forma EBITDA (each as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) (the “Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio”). If EURIBOR is less than zero, EURIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under TLB1 or the Revolving Credit Facility (as applicable). If another IBOR, including LIBOR is less than zero, LIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under the Revolving Credit Facility, Facility A or TLB2 (as applicable). A commitment fee will be payable (A) on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of the Revolving Credit Facility from the Closing Date to the end of the availability period applicable to the Revolving Credit Facility at a rate of 30% of the applicable margin for the Revolving Credit Facility; and (B) on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of the Guarantee Facility from the Closing Date to the end of the availability period applicable to the Guarantee Facility at a rate of 30% of the applicable margin for the Guarantee Facility. Such commitment fees will be payable quarterly in arrears (provided that the EUR SSN Issuer may elect that accrued commitment fee shall instead be paid on each Quarter Date or the last date of each Interest Period applicable to a Facility B), on the last day of the availability period applicable to the Revolving Credit Facility or Guarantee Facility (as applicable) and on the date the Revolving Credit Facility or Guarantee Facility (as applicable) is cancelled in full or on the date on which the relevant lender cancels its commitment. 181 ----- Any letter of credit issued under the Revolving Credit Facility shall be subject to such issuing bank and fronting fees as may be agreed between the Company and the applicable issuing bank and a letter of credit fee equal to the margin that would have been applicable to a cash drawn under the Revolving Credit Facility in the applicable currency. Any Bank Guarantee issued under the Guarantee Facility shall be subject to certain fees (including with respect to a fronted Bank Guarantee, fees agreed with the relevant issuing bank and fronting fees as may be agreed between the Company and the applicable issuing bank and certain other customary bank guarantees fee), subject to certain conditions as set out in the Senior Facilities Agreement. Default interest will be calculated as an additional 1% per annum on the defaulted amount.

Section Title: PRINCIPAL SHAREHOLDERS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS Senior Facilities Agreement
Subsubsection Text: The Loans under Facility A will be repaid in instalments by repaying an agreed amount on each Quarter Date following a repayment holiday of up to three years and the balance on the maturity date which shall be no longer than seven years. The loans made under TLB1 will be repaid in full on the date that is seven years from the Closing Date. The loans made under TLB2 will be repaid in instalments by repaying on each Quarter Date (commencing, with respect to each Facility B (USD) Loan, with the last day of the first full Financial Quarter ending after the Closing Date) an amount which reduces the principal amount of such loans drawn during the availability period by 0.25 per cent of their outstanding principal amount from time to time, with the balance to be repaid in full on the date that is seven years from the Closing Date. In respect of the Revolving Credit Facility, each advance will be repaid on the last day of the interest period relating thereto, subject to an ability to roll over cash drawings. All outstanding amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility will be repaid on the termination date of the Revolving Credit Facility, being the date falling six and a half years from the Closing Date. Amounts repaid by the borrowers on loans made under the Revolving Credit Facility may be reborrowed, subject to certain conditions. In respect of the letters of credit, each will be repaid on the termination date of the relevant Revolving Credit Facility, being the date falling six and a half years from the Closing Date (or such earlier date in accordance with the Senior Facilities Agreement), provided that if any letter of credit has an expiry date ending on or after the termination date applicable to the applicable Revolving Credit Facility, on such termination date each letter of credit shall be repaid unless the relevant issuing bank agrees that such letter of credit shall continue as between that issuing bank and the relevant member of the Senior Secured Group on a bilateral basis and not as part of or under the documentation for the Senior Secured Facilities.
