Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Selected Notes to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements 01 Basis of preparation •** **General information
Subsubsection Text: On May 21, 2019, the Supervisory Board of thyssenkrupp Aktiengesellschaft, Duisburg and Essen, Germany (hereafter “thyssenkrupp AG”) unanimously approved the Executive Board’s plans for a fundamental strategic realignment of the group. As part of this new strategy, the Executive Board proposed an initial public offering (hereafter “IPO”) of thyssenkrupp Elevator Technology Business (hereafter “Elevator Technology Business”) to the Supervisory Board. In addition to the IPO thyssenkrupp AG was also contemplating a full trade sale of the Elevator Technology Business to potential interested parties. On February 27, 2020, the Executive Board’s decision to sell its entire Elevator Technology Business to a consortium led by Advent, Cinven and RAG foundation (hereafter “the transaction”) was approved by the Supervisory Board of thyssenkrupp AG. The closing of this transaction is expected by the end of the current fiscal year. thyssenkrupp AG will reinvest part of the purchase price in a stake in the Elevator Technology Business. The thyssenkrupp Elevator Technology Group (hereafter “thyssenkrupp ET Group”)—which designs and delivers passenger transportation solutions—has been separated from thyssenkrupp AG and its subsidiaries (hereafter “thyssenkrupp Group”). In an initial preparatory step, the thyssenkrupp ET Group operating activities that had previously not been operating as separate companies were transferred to separate legal entities. In a second step, all companies making up the thyssenkrupp ET Group were transferred to wholly-owned subsidiaries of thyssenkrupp AG, i.e. thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V., Roermond, Netherlands or to thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and Operations AG, Düsseldorf, Germany, which was previously named thyssenkrupp Elevator AG until December 10, 2019. On June 2, 2020 thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and Operations AG changed its legal form to thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovations and Operations GmbH (hereafter “thyssenkrupp Elevator laO[1]”). In further steps, thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V. and its subsidiaries and the thyssenkrupp Elevator laO and its subsidiaries were then transferred at December 6, 2019 and at December 31, 2019, respectively, to a new company named thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding GmbH, Essen, Germany (formerly thyssenkrupp Industrials GmbH, Essen, Germany, that was founded in June 2018 under the name thyssenkrupp Carbon2Chem Management GmbH, Duisburg, Germany). As of December 31, 2019, both companies are therefore 100%-subsidiaries of thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding GmbH, which is the parent company of the thyssenkrupp ET Group. On January 16, 2020, name and legal form of the thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding GmbH was changed to thyssenkrupp Elevator AG (hereafter “the Company[2]”). The transferred Elevator Technology Business operations are comprised of legal entities as well as assets and liabilities that have been transferred to the Company with effect from December 31, 2019, as part of the legal reorganization that in accordance with IFRS 10.B97 “Consolidated Financial Statements” are deemed linked transactions. This reorganization is a transaction under common control, since all transferred legal entities as well as assets and liabilities are ultimately controlled by thyssenkrupp AG. Up to and until December 31, 2019, the date of the completion of the legal reorganization, there was no obligation for the Company to prepare consolidated financial statements for the thyssenkrupp ET Group because the Elevator Technology Business was not a group of entities under control of a parent as defined by IFRS 10 “Consolidated Financial Statements” and has historically not prepared consolidated financial statements for internal or external reporting purpose. Combined financial statements in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) as applicable in the European Union were prepared for the Elevator Technology Business as of and for the fiscal year ended September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017. The combined annual financial statements are hereinafter referred to as the “Combined Financial Statements”. The Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business reflect the Elevator Technology Business as historically included in the IFRS consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG under application of the predecessor accounting (book value) approach in accordance with established practice in accounting for business combinations under common control under IFRS. These Combined Financial Statements are expected to be published for the purpose of a bond offering in June 2020. 1 Until December 10, 2019, thyssenkrupp Elevator IaO refers to thyssenkrupp Elevator AG. Subsequent to December 10, 2019 until June 2, 2020, thyssenkrupp Elevator IaO refers to thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and Operations AG. Starting on June 2, 2020, thyssenkrupp Elevator IaO refers to thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and Operations GmbH. 2 Until January 16, 2020, the Company refers to thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding GmbH. Starting on January 16, 2020, the Company refers to thyssenkrupp Elevator AG. F-8 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Selected Notes to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) 01 Basis of preparation (Continued) •** **First-time adoption of International Financial Reporting Standards
Subsubsection Text: Since December 31, 2019, the date of the completion of the legal reorganization, the Elevator Technology Business is a group of entities under the control of the Company as defined by IFRS 10 “Consolidated Financial Statements.” Therefore, first-time consolidated financial statements as of September 30, 2020 have to be prepared in accordance with the rules of IFRS 1 “First-Time adoption of International Financial Reporting Standards”. The interim financial statements as of and for the 1st half year ended March 31, 2020 (the

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: “Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements”) for the group of entities under the control of the
Subsubsection Text: Company are also prepared in accordance with IFRS 1. The Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements presented here are based on uniform IFRS accounting policies with an opening statement of financial position as of October 1, 2018. As consolidated financial statements were previously not prepared for the thyssenkrupp ET Group, the reconciliations envisioned in principle pursuant to IFRS 1 are not required. For purposes of the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements the above noted transactions of the legal reorganization have been accounted for as common control transactions by applying predecessor accounting (book value) in accordance with recognized industry practice for business combinations under common control[3]. The Company’s interim consolidated financial statement include the results of the thyssenkrupp ET Group as of and for the 1st half year ended March 31, 2020 as well as the comparatives results as if the transfer of the business activities of the Elevator Technology Business into the Company had already taken place for all periods presented. The financials of the Elevator Technology Business activities prior to the reorganization as of December 31, 2019 are presented on a combined basis under the application of the same principles as applied in the Combined Financial Statements. IFRS accounting standards adopted by thyssenkrupp AG in the 1st half year ended March 31, 2020 for the first time were incorporated in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements of the Company in accordance with the respective date of first-time adoption of thyssenkrupp AG to reflect the book values as historically included in the IFRS consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG under application of the predecessor accounting (book value) approach. Since thyssenkrupp AG applies IFRS 16 “Leases” using the modified retrospective approach starting October 1, 2019 in its consolidated financial statements, IFRS 16 will be applied at the same date using the same approach in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements in accordance with the rules described above.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: •** **Information on the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: The Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements comprise interim consolidated statements of financial position, interim consolidated statements of profit or loss, interim consolidated statements of comprehensive income, interim consolidated statements of cash flows, interim consolidated statements of changes in equity and selected notes to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements as of and for the 1st half year ended March 31, 2020 including the corresponding comparative information as of and for the 1st half year ended March 31, 2019, and in addition for the comparative information as of September 30, 2019 and October1, 2018 for the interim consolidated statements of financial position. The interim consolidated statement of profit or loss has been prepared using the cost-of-sales method. Assets and liabilities are classified by maturity. They are classified as current if they mature within one year or within the normal business cycle of the companies and operations included in the thyssenkrupp ET Group or are held for sale. Inventories and trade accounts receivable and payable are generally presented as current. Deferred tax assets and liabilities as well as pension provisions are generally presented as noncurrent. The interim consolidated statement of changes in equity presents changes in capital stock, additional paid-in capital, retained earnings as well as changes in other comprehensive income attributable to shareholders of thyssenkrupp Elevator AG and the changes in equity to non-controlling interest in the respective reporting period. Since the thyssenkrupp ET Group has a complex financial history and not constituted a group with a parent entity for the comparative periods presented, no share capital is presented in the statements of changes in equity for the comparative periods. The interim consolidated statements of cash flows is prepared using the indirect method. 3 In line with IDW RS HFA 50 Module IFRS 3M2 published by the German Institute of Public Auditors F-9 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Selected Notes to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) 01 Basis of preparation (Continued)
Subsubsection Text: The Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements are presented in euros, with all amounts rounded to the nearest million (million €) except when otherwise indicated; this may result in differences compared to the unrounded figures. For further explanations of the Elevator Technology Business and additional information reference is made to the Combined Financial Statements for the fiscal years ended September 30, 2019, September 30, 2018 and September 30, 2017. This Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements should be read in conjunction with these Combined Financial Statements. The Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements were prepared on [•], 2020 by the Executive Board of the Company. - **Basis of preparation of the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements In addition, holding companies such as thyssenkrupp AG have provided various central services including governance to the thyssenkrupp ET Group. These services were historically reported in the thyssenkrupp Group and either were transferred to the thyssenkrupp ET Group as part of the legal reorganization or will be provided as a service under transitional service agreements (hereafter “TSAs”) starting January 1, 2020. As of now, there are TSAs for almost all central services (e.g. IT, HR, Legal) provided by the thyssenkrupp Group. Going forward, it is planned to terminate these existing TSAs and to establish these central services at the thyssenkrupp ET Group. The respective income and costs for such services that were historically recharged to the thyssenkrupp ET Group, have been included in the interim consolidated statement of profit or loss at their historical amounts. Where income and costs for such services in the periods until December 31, 2019 were historically not recharged but were essential to the operational business of the thyssenkrupp ET Group, such income and costs were either directly attributed or, where this was not possible, allocated using appropriate allocation keys and are reflected in the interim consolidated statements of profit or loss at their historical cost. Furthermore, assets or liabilities relating to administrative services, service companies or the central activities of the holding companies pertained to the thyssenkrupp ET Group were attributed in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements based on the legal reorganization principle. Shared assets relating to such holding companies that did not legally transfer to the thyssenkrupp ET Group were not included in the interim consolidated statements of financial position of the Company. However, for such an appropriate usage charge was reflected in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements in the reporting periods until December 31, 2019. Shared assets relating to such holding companies that did legally transfer to the thyssenkrupp ET Group, were included in the interim consolidated statements of financial position of the Company. The usage by the remaining thyssenkrupp Group was accounted for by way of appropriate usage income charges to the remaining thyssenkrupp Group in the reporting periods until December 31, 2019. Administrative services or central activities will be continued after closing of the transaction by TSAs that have been implemented January 01, 2020. Services as part of the TSAs might result in different cost charges compared to the current allocation. For companies or operations that did not constitute a separate tax payer in the historical reporting period (e.g. companies being part of a fiscal unity or asset deal companies) the following particularities apply: - Tax expense and tax income are recognized in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements in the years in which they arose as contributions or withdrawals by the shareholders immediately settled in equity; - Current losses trigger tax income, if it is probable that sufficient future taxable profit will be available. This tax income is treated as withdrawal by the shareholders in the respective year; - Tax receivables, tax liabilities and deferred tax assets from current losses are not shown in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements unless the company has own tax loss carryforwards which are legally assessed. In the interim consolidated statements of cash flows, the taxes actually paid to tax authorities as well as current taxes allocated based on the separate tax return approach were included as inflows/outflows from operating activities. Taxes allocated to thyssenkrupp ET Group under the separate tax return approach were deemed immediately settled. Payments made to the remaining thyssenkrupp Group under historical tax group arrangements are also included as inflows/outflows from operating activities. The management of the thyssenkrupp ET Group deems this approach as applied for the comparative period as appropriate but not necessarily indicative of the tax expense or income as well as tax payments that would result for thyssenkrupp ET Group as a separate group. - a decrease/increase in trade accounts receivable of €(8) million as of September 30, 2019 (March 31, 2019: €23 million; Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The following Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements of the Company were prepared in accordance with IFRS as well as the related interpretations of the IFRS Interpretation Committee (“IFRIC”) as they are to be applied in the EU at the end of the last reporting period presented. They also satisfy the requirements for first-time consolidated financial statements in accordance with the rules of IFRS 1 and have been prepared in a condensed form according to IAS 34 “Interim Financial Reporting” as endorsed by the EU. In the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements of the Company, the predecessor accounting approach has been applied in accordance with recognized industry practice for business combinations under common control. The Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements of the Company reflect the Elevator Technology companies and the operating activities assigned to the Elevator Technology Business as historically included in the IFRS consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG. In general, the Company applied the same accounting policies and measurement principles in preparing the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements as were used in preparing the IFRS consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG (using the “extraction method”). This approach was adjusted with respect to transactions with remaining thyssenkrupp Group companies and to ensure IFRS compliance. Transactions between the thyssenkrupp ET Group and the remaining thyssenkrupp Group were recognized in accordance with IFRS and classified as related party transactions as defined in IAS 24 “Related Party Disclosures”. Reference is made where appropriate to the Combined Financial Statements in particular to the combination, recognition and measurement principles. For further information concerning the basis of preparation see also the Combined Financial Statements.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: In the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements, the direct and indirect subsidiaries of the Company were fully consolidated in accordance with the principles of IFRS 10. In addition, joint ventures were accounted for in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements using the equity method in accordance with IAS 28 “Investments in Associates and Joint Ventures”. For a full list of the companies and Elevator Technology Business operating activities included in the scope of combination see the Combined Financial Statements. There have been no material changes in the scope of consolidation in the 1st half year ended March 31, 2020.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: In the periods up to September 30, 2019, the Elevator Technology Business was using the thyssenkrupp brand under an operating licensing model for which it incurred expenses recognized directly in profit or loss in other expenses. As of September 30, 2019, as part of the proposed IPO, the Elevator Technology Business had entered into a new license agreement with thyssenkrupp AG for the right to use the thyssenkrupp brand for certain specified classes relevant for the Elevator Technology Business in exchange for a one-time fee and with no other recurring expenses after September 30, 2019 (hereafter “new license agreement”). This license has been recognized as an intangible asset with indefinite useful life in accordance with IAS 38 “Intangible Assets” as of September 30, 2019. Historically recognized expenses for the use of the brand remain unchanged for the periods up to September 30, 2019. Based on the Executive Board’s decision as of February 27, 2020 to sell the entire thyssenkrupp ET Group the above described new license agreement, entered into on September 30, 2019, was adjusted in March 2020 via an addendum agreement, since the governance model in the new license agreement was only suitable with an IPO. In substance, the terms and conditions of the addendum agreement lead to a limitation of the initially agreed indefinite useful life. The terms of the addendum agreement become effective subject to the condition precedent of all closing conditions of the transaction being fulfilled and will result in the repayment of the initially agreed fully paid up one-time fee in the amount of €1,080 million reduced by a fixed amount of €99 million for the use of the brand starting October 1, 2019 until closing. In addition, a fixed amount of €74 million for the use of the brand for the period of no longer than 18 months after closing was agreed. Both, the amount receivable and the amount payable, are due immediately prior to closing. With the signing of the addendum agreement the intangible asset for the right of use of the thyssenkrupp brand is classified as held for sale in accordance with IFRS 5. Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Selected Notes to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) 01 Basis of preparation (Continued) Capital structure
Subsubsection Text: The consolidated statement of changes in equity presents capital stock (of thyssenkrupp Elevator AG), additional paid-in capital (of thyssenkrupp Elevator AG), retained earnings as well as cumulative other comprehensive income and non-controlling interest for the interim reporting period ending March 31, 2020. Since the thyssenkrupp ET Group has a complex financial history and did not constitute a consolidated group with a parent entity for the reporting periods until December 31, 2019, no capital stock, additional paid-in capital retained earnings are presented in the statement of changes in equity for the comparative period. For such periods the equity of the thyssenkrupp ET Group consists of the invested equity attributable to the thyssenkrupp Group, other components of equity and the invested equity attributable to non-controlling interest. Since the thyssenkrupp ET Group had no share capital and reserves in its own right, any equity presented until December 31, 2019 represents the parent’s net investment. Thus, the presentation of the equity for the reporting periods until December 31, 2019 of the thyssenkrupp ET Group differs from the presentation of equity as prescribed in IAS 1 “Presentation of Financial Statements”. During the reporting period under consideration, the thyssenkrupp ET Group was mainly financed by the remaining thyssenkrupp Group. The capital structure of the thyssenkrupp ET Group at the time of the closing of the transaction will differ from the capital structure presented in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Until closing of the transaction, thyssenkrupp ET Group is integrated into the cash pooling and cash management systems of the thyssenkrupp Group. During the last months thyssenkrupp ET Group has implemented an additional cash pooling and cash management system with the cash pool leader thyssenkrupp Elevator AG. With Closing the settlement of all intercompany balances with thyssenkrupp Group is expected to result in a slightly positive cash balance for thyssenkrupp ET Group. Additionally selected thyssenkrupp ET Group companies, which were not integrated in the cash pooling and cash management systems of the thyssenkrupp Group due to commercial or regulatory purposes, are expected to show positive cash balances at closing. Against this background and under consideration of a sufficient free cash flow according to the latest planning thyssenkrupp ET Group management expects to be able to fulfill all of its future payment obligations. In order to additionally secure the financing of operating activities, thyssenkrupp ET Group plans to have access to a Revolving Credit Facility in an amount of €800 million. After closing the thyssenkrupp ET Group plans to have access to appropriate guarantee facilities, either under a central Revolving Guarantee Facility or under additional bilateral agreements of thyssenkrupp ET Group companies, fully satisfying the operative business requirements.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Current and deferred income taxes are recognized in accordance with IAS 12 and IAS 34 in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements. For the comparative period, income taxes were determined using the separate tax return approach based on the assumption that the companies and operations of the Elevator Technology Business constitute separate tax payers. This assumption implies that current and deferred taxes for all companies (share deal companies) and operations (asset deal companies) within Elevator Technology Business are calculated separately and that the recoverability of deferred tax assets is assessed on this basis. Legal entities and business operating activities are treated for purposes of the separate tax return approach as a tax group if such legal entities and business operations have historically been included in a tax group and as of December 31, 2019 have operated under a new tax group or are still included within the historical tax group. Deferred tax assets resulting from tax loss carryforwards are recognized in the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements to the extent that it is probable that they can be offset against positive results from the respective thyssenkrupp ET Group companies or operations in the future. This is only applicable if the legal entity is part of the thyssenkrupp ET Group and to the extent the legal entity has tax loss carryforwards legally assessed. F-12 ----- Current and deferred income taxes are recognized in accordance with IAS 12 “Income Taxes”. For purposes of the Combined Financial Statements, income taxes were determined using the separate tax return approach based on the assumption that the companies and operations of the Elevator Technology Business constitute separate tax payers. This assumption implies that current and deferred taxes for all companies (share deal companies) and operations (asset deal companies) within Elevator Technology Business are calculated separately and that the recoverability of deferred tax assets is assessed on this basis. Legal entities and business operating activities are treated for purposes of the separate tax return approach as a tax group if such legal entities and business operations have historically been included in a tax group and as of December 31, 2019 have operated under a new tax group or are still included within the historical tax group. In such cases, the legal entity or business operating activities representing the head of the tax group is considered as the separate tax payer. Deferred tax assets resulting from tax loss carryforwards are recognized in the Combined Financial Statements to the extent that it is probable that they can be offset against positive results from the respective Elevator Technology Business companies or operations in the future. This is only applicable if the legal entity is part of the thyssenkrupp ET Group and to the extent the legal entity has tax loss carryforwards legally assessed. For companies or operations that did not constitute a separate tax payer in the historical reporting period (e.g. companies being part of a fiscal unity or asset deal companies) the following particularities apply: - Tax expense and tax income are recognized in the Combined Financial Statements in the years in which they arose as contributions or withdrawals by the shareholders immediately settled in equity; - Current losses trigger tax income, which is treated as withdrawal by the shareholders in the respective year; - Tax receivables, tax liabilities and deferred tax assets from current losses are not shown in the Combined Financial Statements. US companies being part of a fiscal unity are allowed to utilize its own tax losses after leaving the fiscal unity. Thus, for US companies deferred tax assets on tax loss carryforwards are reflected in the Combined Financial Statements to the extent the tax loss carryforwards can be used in the future. In the combined statements of cash flows, the taxes actually paid to tax authorities as well as current taxes allocated based on the separate tax return approach were included as inflows/outflows from operating activities. Taxes allocated to Elevator Technology Business under the separate tax return approach were deemed immediately settled. Payments made to the remaining thyssenkrupp Group under historical tax group arrangements are also included as inflows/outflows from operating activities. The management of the Elevator Technology Business deems this approach as appropriate but not necessarily indicative of the tax expense or income that would result in Elevator Technology as a separate group.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Control and profit or loss transfer agreements
Subsubsection Text: The control and profit or loss transfer agreement (Beherrschungs- und Gewinnabführungsverträge) between the German thyssenkrupp ET Group companies and the remaining thyssenkrupp Group has been terminated as of December 31, 2019. For the purposes of the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements of the Company, receivables and liabilities to the remaining thyssenkrupp Group in connection with control and profit or loss transfer agreement were presented as other financial assets and other financial liabilities, respectively. The related impacts of the profit or loss transfer agreement are shown as contributions or withdrawals from reserves by the shareholders and are included in the line item “Other transactions with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group” of the interim consolidated statement of changes in equity and the line item “Payments received under profit and loss transfer agreements” of the interim consolidated statement of cash flows. The control and profit or loss transfer agreements (Beherrschungs- und Gewinnabführungsverträge) between the thyssenkrupp ET Group and thyssenkrupp AG as well as other thyssenkrupp Group companies have been terminated on December 31, 2019). For the purposes of the Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business, receivables and liabilities to the remaining thyssenkrupp Group in connection with control and profit or loss transfer agreements were presented as other financial assets and other financial liabilities, respectively. The related impacts of the profit or loss transfer agreements are shown as contributions or withdrawals from reserves by the shareholders and are included in the line item “Transactions with thyssenkrupp Group” of the combined statement of changes in equity and the combined statement of cash flows.

As a consequence, the reporting packages for the reporting periods ending on September 30, 2018/ October 1, 2018 and the 1st half year ended March 31, 2019, were adjusted by management based on their current best estimate. Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Since January 2020, there is a progressive global spread of the COVID-19 pandemic resulting in various actions—including lockdowns—that have been taken by governments all over the world in order to contain and to control the virus. COVID-19 impacted the markets and facilities in multiple ways, depending on the local exposure to the virus and the measures taken by local governments: - Our segments Asia Pacific (AP), Americas (AMS) and Europe/Africa (EA), which comprise our elevator and escalator business, were affected to varying degrees. Nevertheless, the effect of the COVID-19 was felt in all regions, leading to complete lockdowns in some regions and milder restrictions in others. In Asia Pacific, temporary restrictions were mainly observed in China with recovery to almost normal operation in March 2020. India was also affected by government restrictions with lockdowns of facilities. In the Americas, some reductions observed in Brazil while production in the US remained mainly at normal levels, with only temporary restrictions on construction sites and service operations. In Europe/Africa, most impacted countries were Spain, France, Italy and Germany, with some site restrictions and temporary reductions or lockdowns in productions facilities. In most countries production capacities in our core factories have almost recovered to pre-pandemic levels. - The Access Solutions segment was affected in both business lines, Home Solutions and Airport Solutions. Activities for Home Solutions have been operated at a lower level with partial temporary shut downs of F-15 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Selected Notes to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) 02 COVID-19 (Continued)
Subsubsection Text: production facilities but are recovering constantly. The partial or complete shutdown of most airports has led to a decrease of New Installation and Service operations due to postponements and suspensions of some projects. The COVID-19 pandemic is considered as a triggering event for an impairment test of goodwill per March 31, 2020. Before March 31, 2020, all groups of cash-generating units of the Elevator Technology Business showed significant headroom. In addition, the key performance indicators of the operational planning of Elevator Technology were tested for validity against the background of the COVID-19 pandemic and, in effect, the recoverability of goodwill of the Elevator Technology Business was not classified as critical. The weighted average cost of capital discount rate (WACC) for all but one cash-generating units of the Elevator Technology Business decreased compared to September 30, 2019, mainly due to decreasing beta factors. The WACC is based on a risk-free interest rate of 0.1% (September 30, 2019: 0.1%) and a market risk premium of 7.5% (September 30, 2019: 6.75%). Furthermore, other intangible assets and property, plant and equipment were also tested for impairment per March 31, 2020 which did not result in any impairment losses for the Elevator Technology Business. Based on the uncertain progress of the COVID-19 pandemic, it cannot yet reasonably be predicted to what extent the pandemic will affect the future financial position and results of operations of the Elevator Technology Business. In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic the accumulated ADJ EBIT of the Elevator Technology Business is currently slightly below the budgeted expectations.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: In fiscal year ending September 30, 2020 the thyssenkrupp ET Group adopted the following standard, interpretation and amendments to already existing standards that, with the exemption of IFRS 16, do not have a material impact on the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: In January 2016, the IASB published the new accounting standard IFRS 16 Leases. The new standard replaces the previous classification of leases into operating and finance leases as a lessee and introduces a uniform accounting model for the lessee. Under the previous standard (IAS 17), lease obligations for operating leases were only to be disclosed in the notes. In accordance with IFRS 16, the rights and obligations resulting from leases must be recognized as a right-of-use of the leased asset and a corresponding lease liability in the lessee’s statement of financial position. This resulted in the following recognition and measurement principles: A contract constitutes a lease if the contract conveys the lessee - the right to control the use of an identified asset (the leased asset) - for a specific period - in exchange for a consideration. Since October 1, 2019, the thyssenkrupp ET Group as a lessee recognizes in general for all leases within the interim consolidated statement of financial position an asset for the right-of-use of the leased assets and a liability for the lease payment commitments at present value. These are primarily rentals of property and buildings, technical machinery and equipment as well as other equipment, factory and office equipment. The right-of-use assets reported under property, plant and equipment are recognized at cost less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses. Payments for non-lease components are not included in the determination of the lease liability. The lease liabilities reported under financial liabilities reflect the present value of the outstanding lease payments at the time the asset is made available for use. Lease payments are discounted at the interest rate implicit in the lease if it can be readily determined. Otherwise, they are discounted at the lessee’s incremental borrowing rate. The derivation of the interest rate is based on the assumption that an adequate amount of funds will be raised over an adequate period of time in the amount of an asset comparable to the right-of-use asset, taking into account the economic environment and comparable collateral. The lease liabilities include the following lease payments: - Fixed payments, less lease incentives to be paid by the lessor; F-16 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Selected Notes to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) 03 Recently adopted accounting standards (Continued)
Subsubsection Text: - variable lease payments that are based on an index or an interest rate; - expected amounts to be payable by the lessee under residual value guarantees; - the exercise price of a purchase option, if the exercise is reasonably certain and - payment of penalties for the termination of the lease, if the lease term reflects the lessee exercising an option to terminate the lease. Right-of-use assets are measured at cost, which are comprised as follows: - Lease liability; - lease payments made at or before the commencement date less any lease incentives received; - initial direct costs; and - dismantling obligations. Subsequent measurement of the right-of-use asset is performed at amortized cost. Right-of-use assets are depreciated on a straight-line basis over the lease term, unless the useful life of the underlying asset is shorter. If the lease agreement contains reasonably certain purchase options, the right of use is depreciated over the economic life of the underlying asset. In subsequent measurement, the lease liability is compounded, and the corresponding interest expense is recognized in the financial result. The lease payments made reduce the carrying amount of the lease liability. In accordance with the recognition exemptions, low-value leases of and short-term leases (less than twelve months) are recognized in the statement of profit or loss. The thyssenkrupp ET Group has identified certain asset classes (e.g. PCs, telephones, printers, copiers) which regularly contain leased assets of low value. Outside these asset classes, only leased assets with a value of up to USD/€5,000 are classified as low-value leased assets. Furthermore, the new regulations are not applied to leases of intangible assets. For contracts comprising a non-lease component as well as a lease component, each lease component must be accounted for separately from non-lease component as a lease. The lessee must allocate the contractually agreed-upon payment to the separate lease components based on the relative standalone selling price of the lease component and the aggregated standalone selling price of the non-lease components. In addition, intercompany leases will continue to be presented in the segment report according to IFRS 8 as operating leases in accordance with IAS 17. The term of the lease is determined based on the non-cancellable lease term. Especially real estate leases contain extension and termination options. Such contractual conditions offer the greatest possible operational flexibility to the thyssenkrupp ET Group. In determining the lease term, all facts and circumstances are considered that provide an economic incentive to exercise renewal options or not to exercise termination options. Lease term modifications from the exercise or non-exercise of such options are only considered in the lease term if they are reasonably certain and are based on an event that is within the control of the lessee. Use is made of the exemption option to apply IFRS 16 to all agreements that were previously identified as leases by applying IAS 17 and IFRIC 4. The thyssenkrupp ET Group has applied the modified retrospective approach in accordance with IFRS 16.C5(b). In accordance with this approach the comparative prior-year figures do not have to be adjusted and the first-time adoption effects are recognized in the retained earnings as of October 1, 2019. The thyssenkrupp ET Group recognized new assets and liabilities for its operating leases at the date of transition to IFRS 16. When applying the modified retrospective method, right-of-use assets were recognized at the initial recognition date at the carrying amounts of the lease liabilities adjusted for deferred lease payments. The lease liabilities were recognized at the present value of the lease payments outstanding at the date of first-time application, discounted at the lessee’s incremental borrowing rate at the date of first-time application. The thyssenkrupp ET Group made use of exemption options in the transition to IFRS 16 and treated leases with a remaining term of up to twelve months as short-term leases, left initial direct costs unaffected in the initial measurement of the right-of-use asset, and took current knowledge into account in determining the lease terms for agreements with extension and/or termination options. No impairment test in accordance with IAS 36 was carried out at the time of initial application. Instead, leases entered into immediately prior to October 1, 2019, F-17 ----- were assessed in accordance with IAS 37 “Provisions, Contingent Liabilities and Contingent Assets” to determine whether they were onerous. No onerous contracts were identified. The effects on the thyssenkrupp ET Group’s previous finance leases were insignificant. As of October 1, 2019, right-of-use assets in the amount of €345 million and lease liabilities in the amount of €349 million were recognized as part of the transition to IFRS 16. Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Based on the Executive Board’s decision as of February 27, 2020 to sell the entire Elevator Technology Business the new license agreement regarding the thyssenkrupp brand, entered into on September 30, 2019, was amended in March 2020 via an addendum agreement, since the governance model in the new license agreement was only suitable with an IPO. In substance, the terms and conditions of the addendum agreement lead to a limitation of the initially agreed indefinite useful life. The terms of the addendum agreement become effective subject to the condition precedent of all closing conditions of the transaction being fulfilled and will result in the repayment of the initially agreed fully paid up one-time fee in the amount of € 1,080 million reduced by a fixed amount of €99 million for the use of the brand starting October 1, 2019 until closing. In addition, a fixed amount of €74 million for the use of the brand for the period of no longer than 18 months after closing was agreed. Both, the amount receivable and the amount payable, are due immediately prior to closing. With the signing of the addendum agreement the intangible asset for the right of use of the thyssenkrupp brand is classified as held for sale in accordance with IFRS 5. Prior to the aforementioned classification as held for sale an impairment loss on the thyssenkrupp brand amounting to €99 million has been recognized.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: In the year ended September 30, 2019, the Elevator Technology Business acquired the elevator business of Nashville Machine Elevator Co., Inc. via asset deal effective May 31, 2019 and all shares of O´Keefe Elevator Company, Inc. effective July 1, 2019. The purchase price allocation of Nashville Machine Elevator Co. has not yet been finalized due to the pending identification of the acquired intangible assets. The purchase price allocation of the O’Keefe Elevator Company has also not yet been finalized due to remaining clarification of O’Keefe’s tax base. Compared to the presentation in the Combined Financial Statements for the fiscal year ended September 30, 2019, there have only been some minor changes. F-19 -----

Subsubsection Text: The changes in the various components of equity for the interim period ended March 31, 2020 are shown in the interim consolidated statements of changes in equity of the Company. As stated in Note 01, the thyssenkrupp ET Group was not a legal group for consolidated financial statements reporting purposes in accordance with IFRS 10 “Consolidated Financial Statements” until December 31, 2019. Therefore, the equity is carried over into the capital structure of the Company on December 31, 2019 (i.e. with finalization of the legal reorganization). The equity of the Company consists of the capital stock, the additional paid-in capital, the retained earnings and cumulative other comprehensive income. Subsection Title: Invested equity attributable to the thyssenkrupp Group
Subsubsection Text: The invested equity attributable to the thyssenkrupp Group was calculated by aggregating the invested equity of the Company, thyssenkrupp Elevator laO as well as of thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V., the equity of their direct and indirect subsidiaries and the invested equity of the Elevator Technology Business operating activities that were or are being conducted by direct or indirect subsidiaries of thyssenkrupp AG. The invested equity attributable to the thyssenkrupp Group was calculated by aggregating the invested equity of the Company, thyssenkrupp Elevator IaO as well as of thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V., the equity of their direct and indirect subsidiaries and the invested equity of the Elevator Technology Business operating activities that were or are being conducted by direct or indirect subsidiaries of thyssenkrupp AG.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Line item “Other transactions with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group” as presented in the interim consolidated statements of changes in equity
Subsubsection Text: During the period ended March 31, 2020, other transactions with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group include corporate cost allocations relating to central services provided by remaining thyssenkrupp Group in the amount of €8 million (March 31, 2019: €16 million), dividend distributions to the remaining thyssenkrupp Group of €(535) million (March 31, 2019: €(343) million), contributions and withdrawals from thyssenkrupp Group as a result of various transactions in the amount of €(3,219) million (March 31, 2019: €0 million), effects relating to profit and loss transfer agreements of €(7) million (March 31, 2019: €0 million), effects of combination and carve-out adjustments related to the allocation of Elevator Technology Business net assets in the amount of €35 million (March 31, 2019: €22 million), tax related adjustments of €96 million (March 31, 2019: €4 million), and other adjustments of €5 million (March 31, 2019: €3 million). The decrease in the line item “Other transactions with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group” in the amount of €(3,319) million is mainly impacted by the finalization of the legal reorganization of the thyssenkrupp ET Group as of December 31, 2019. The previously allocated assets and shares that had been contributed against equity in the Combined Financial Statements as of and for the fiscal years ended September 30, 2019, September 30, 2018 and September 30, 2017, are legally transferred to the thyssenkrupp ET Group in the interim period ended March 31, 2020. The consideration transferred (against purchase prices) for these share deals and asset deals resulted in a reduction of equity. Refer to Note 11 “Related Parties” for the transfers as part of the legal reorganization of the thyssenkrupp ET Group.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Line item “Allocation of invested equity according to legal structure on Dec. 31, 2019”
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2019, the legal reorganization was finalized and thus resulting in the necessity to present equity based on the capital structure of thyssenkrupp Elevator AG instead of reporting invested equity. The main effect shown in the line item “Allocation of invested equity according to legal structure on Dec. 31, 2019” is an allocation of previously reported invested equity to capital stock, additional paid-in capital and retained earnings. The amount of €4,522 million shown in additional paid in-capital and the amount of €500 million shown as capital stock are mainly derived from a contribution in kind as well as a capital increase as part of the legal reorganization. The capital increase amounts to €820 million and is shown in the additional paid-in-capital. The shares in thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V. in the amount of €4,202 million are contributed in kind into thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding AG and are shown in capital stock in the amount of €500 million and in additional paid-in-capital in the amount of €3,702 million.

Subsubsection Text: The restructuring provisions included in other provisions decreased by €15 million to €67 million compared with September 30, 2019. The additions in the amount of €14 million relate to the Europe/Africa and the Americas business units. In connection with the Elevator cartel, potentially injured parties have asserted claims for damages against thyssenkrupp AG and companies of the thyssenkrupp Group in and out of court. Since September 30, 2019 further claims have been quantified in the ongoing course of the legal proceedings, which has not led to a change in the risk assessment and recorded provisions. A majority of the proceedings have now been dealt with through settlement, withdrawal or dismissal of the claims. Legal cases are still pending in Austria, Belgium and the Netherlands. They are at different stages of proceedings. thyssenkrupp ET Group has recognized provisions for the portion of the pending claims which, in its opinion, will probably result in cash outflows.

Subsubsection Text: The terms of these guarantees depend on the type of guarantee and may range from three months to five years (e.g. performance guarantees). The basis for possible payments under the guarantees is the non-performance of the principal debtor under a contractual agreement, e.g. late delivery, delivery of non-conforming goods under a contract or non-performance with respect to the warranted quality. All guarantees are issued by instruction of a consolidated company of the thyssenkrupp ET Group upon request of the principal debtor obligated by the underlying contractual relationship and are subject to recourse provisions in case of default. Subsubsection Text: The carrying amounts of trade accounts receivable, other current financial assets as well as cash and cash equivalents equal their fair values. Equity and debt instruments are in general measured at fair value, which is based to the extent available on market prices as of the balance sheet date. When no quoted market prices in an active market are available, equity and debt instruments are measured by discounting future cash flows based on current market interest rates over the remaining term of the financial instruments. The fair value of foreign currency forward transactions is determined on the basis of the middle spot exchange rate applicable as of the interim balance sheet date, and taking account of forward premiums or discounts arising for the respective remaining contract term compared to the contracted forward exchange rate. Common methods for calculating option prices are used for foreign currency options. The fair value of an option is influenced not only by the remaining term of an option, but also by other factors, such as current amount and volatility of the underlying exchange or base rate. The carrying amounts of trade accounts payable and other current liabilities equal their fair values. The fair value of fixed rate liabilities equals the present value of expected cash flows. Discounting is based on interest rates applicable as of the balance sheet date. The carrying amounts of floating rate liabilities equal their fair values. Financial liabilities measured at amortized cost with a carrying amount of €4,640 million as of March 31, 2020 (September 30, 2019: €2,773 million, October 1, 2018: €1,575 million) have a fair value of €4,640 million (September 30, 2019: €2,773 million, October 1, 2018: €1,575 million) that was determined based on fair value measurement attributable to Level 2. As of March 31, 2020 the non-current financial debt included other loans of €3 million (September 30, 2019: €3 million). Financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value could be categorized in the following three level fair value hierarchy:

Subsubsection Text: The fair value hierarchy reflects the significance of the inputs used to determine fair values. Financial instruments with fair value measurement based on quoted prices in active markets are disclosed in level 1. In level 2 determination of fair values is based on observable inputs, e.g. foreign exchange rates. Level 3 comprises financial instruments for which the fair value measurement is based on unobservable inputs. In the reporting period there were no reclassifications between level 1, level 2 and level 3.

Subsection Title: Selected Notes to the Unaudited Interim Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) 11 Related Parties (Continued)
Subsubsection Text: The decrease in “thyssenkrupp Group financing receivables” from €2,225 million for the fiscal year ended September 30, 2019 to €2,221 million for October 1, 2018 results from the adoption of the new accounting standard IFRS 9 on October 1, 2018. The net financing position of thyssenkrupp ET Group (net of “thyssenkrupp Group financing receivables” and “thyssenkrupp Group financing liabilities, current”) decreased by €2,727 million to €(2,312) million compared to September 30, 2019. This decrease mainly impacted by the finalization of the legal reorganization of the thyssenkrupp ET Group as of December 31, 2019. The previously allocated assets and shares that had been contributed against equity in the Combined Financial Statements for the fiscal years ended September 30, 2019, September 30, 2018 and September 30, 2017, are legally transferred to thyssenkrupp ET Group in the interim period ended March 31, 2020. The payment of the purchase prices for these assets and shares has been financed by the cash pooling. Receivables or payables relating to payments from/due to the remaining thyssenkrupp Group under tax group arrangements are presented within the line items “Receivables – miscellaneous” and “Liabilities – miscellaneous”. The thyssenkrupp ET Group entered into agreements to purchase the leased multifunctional building in Neuhausen and the test tower in Rottweil conditional on the execution of the proposed IPO. As per the share purchase agreement (hereafter “SPA”) as of February 27, 2020, the fulfillment of the conditional IPO has lapsed, however, the parties to the SPA agreed in principle to execute the purchase of the properties in the same or a similar manner as intended under the proposed IPO. The amendments of the contracts have yet not been signed and will become effective before closing of the transaction. The assumed purchase prices amounting to a total of €74 million were paid upfront in September 2019. The purchase prices, that were formerly recognized as financial assets in accordance with IAS 32 “Financial Instruments: Presentation” and are presented in the cash flows from investing activities in accordance with IAS 7.16(e) “Statements of Cash Flows”, were effective March 1, 2020 netted against the respective lease liability. According to IFRS 16.46(a) the carrying amount of the right-of-use asset was decreased to reflect the lease modification. The gain was recognized in profit and loss. With the proposed amendments of the contracts the legal ownership of the test tower in Rottweil as well as the multifunctional building in Neuhausen will be transferred to the thyssenkrupp ET Group as part of the proposed closing. Furthermore the lease term of the leases of the thyssenkrupp ET Group headquarter located in Essen, thyssenkrupp Allee 1, was reassessed according to IFRS 16.20 in conjunction with B41 with the signing of the transaction on March 1, 2020 due to the sufficient certainty of a move of the headquarter location in the beginning of next calendar year. In total the lease modifications stated above resulted in an increase in the right-of-use assets of €11 million and a decrease in the lease liability of €66 million. The gain resulting from the modification of the leased multifunctional building in Neuhausen and the test tower in Rottweil recognized in profit and loss totaled to €4 million. - October 17, 2019, 90% of the shares in thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding France S.A.S., Puteaux Cedex, France were acquired for a purchase price of €359 million. Only such obligations from thyssenkrupp Elevator AG Executive Board members, that were active as of March 31, 2020, were transferred as part of the legal reorganization which amounts to €9,367 thousand (September 30, 2019: €11,134 thousand) for postemployment obligations and €3,807 thousand (September 30, 2019: €953 thousand) for obligations resulting from share-based payment. Subsubsection Text: Besides this, the thyssenkrupp ET Group maintained business relations with non-consolidated subsidiaries, associates and joint ventures of the remaining thyssenkrupp Group up to a minor extent.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: In addition to the contractual services specified above, the remaining thyssenkrupp Group provided services to the thyssenkrupp ET Group through thyssenkrupp AG, service companies and regional holding companies. These companies principally furnish central corporate services, such as tax and legal, IT services, corporate communications, personnel-related services, accounting, controlling, financial services and treasury. Until finalization of the legal reorganization such services have been reflected in form of corporate cost allocations which amount to €16 million until December 31, 2019 (March 31, 2019: €30 million). Starting January 1, 2020, the aforementioned services are provided as services under TSAs. As a result, no corporate cost allocations have been recognized for periods after January 1, 2020. For the 1st half year ended March 31, 2019, the allocation of the thyssenkrupp brand resulted in expenses of €71 million. As of September 30, 2019 the Elevator Technology Business purchased the right to use the thyssenkrupp brand for certain specified sectors relevant for the Elevator Technology Business for a purchase price of €1,080 million. Based on the Executive Board’s decision to sell the entire Elevator Technology Business the license agreement regarding the thyssenkrupp brand, entered into on September 30, 2019, was adjusted in March 2020 via an addendum agreement. The terms of the addendum agreement become effective subject to the condition precedent of all closing conditions of the transaction being fulfilled and will result in the repayment of the initially agreed fully paid-up one-time fee in the amount of €1,080 million, reduced by a fixed amount of €99 million for the use of the brand starting October 1, 2019 until closing. In addition, a fixed amount of €74 million for the use of the brand for the period no longer than 18 months after closing was agreed.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: During the reporting period, the thyssenkrupp ET Group was integrated into the cash pooling and cash management systems of the thyssenkrupp Group. Financial receivables and liabilities due from/to the thyssenkrupp Group are presented without netting in the Unaudited Consolidated Financial Statements. The interest expenses and interest income generated in connection with the financing activities with thyssenkrupp AG and the remaining thyssenkrupp Group companies in the 1st half year ended March 31, 2020 amounted to €28 million (2019: €13 million) and €14 million (2019: €30 million), respectively. During the reporting periods, the Elevator Technology Business was integrated into the cash pooling and cash management systems of the thyssenkrupp Group. Financial receivables and liabilities from/due to the thyssenkrupp Group are presented without netting in the combined financial statements. The interest expenses and interest income generated in connection with the financing activities with thyssenkrupp AG and the remaining thyssenkrupp Group companies in fiscal year ended September 30, 2019 amounted to €26 million (2018: €29 million; 2017: €45 million) and €57 million (2018: €55 million; 2017: €72 million), respectively.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The thyssenkrupp ET Group has entered into leasing transactions with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group. At the end of the 1st half year ended March 31, 2020, these consisted in particular of real estate and vehicle lease agreements with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group. F-25 ----- The Elevator Technology Business has entered into leasing transactions with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group. At the end of fiscal year 2018/2019, these consisted in particular of operating lease agreements and the finance lease of the test tower in Rottweil with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group with respect to real estate. The Elevator Technology Business entered into agreements to purchase the leased multifunctional building in Neuhausen and the test tower in Rottweil conditional on the execution of the proposed IPO. As per the share purchase agreement (hereafter “SPA”) as of February 27, 2020, the fulfillment of the conditional IPO has lapsed, however, the parties to the SPA agreed in principle to execute the purchase of the properties in the same or a similar manner as intended under the proposed IPO. The amendments of the contracts have yet not been signed and will become effective before closing of the transaction. The assumed purchase prices amounting to a total of €74 million were paid upfront in September 2019. Due to the uncertainty of the execution of the proposed IPO and the economic substance of the payment, the purchase prices were recognized as financial assets in accordance to IAS 32 “Financial Instruments: Presentation” and are presented in the cash flows from investing activities in accordance with IAS 7.16(e) “Statements of Cash Flows”. With the proposed amendments of the contracts the legal ownership of the test tower in Rottweil as well as the multifunctional building in Neuhausen would be transferred to the thyssenkrupp ET Group as part of the proposed closing.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The thyssenkrupp Group has provided €1,228 million guarantees/surety bonds in favour of the thyssenkrupp ET Group as of March 31, 2020 (September 30, 2019: €1,287 million; October 1, 2018: €1,285 million). Thereof €97 million corporate guarantees as of March 31, 2020 (September 30, 2019: €85 million; October 1, 2018: €101 million) and €1,131 million bank guarantees/surety bonds as of March 31, 2020 (September 30, 2019: €1,202 million; October 1, 2018: €1,184 million). The thyssenkrupp Group has provided €1,287 million guarantees/surety bonds in favour of the Elevator Technology Business as of September 30, 2019 (2018: €1,285 million; 2017: €1,195 million). Thereof €85 million corporate guarantees as of September 30, 2019 (2018: €101 million; 2017: €100 million) and €1,202 million bank guarantees/surety bonds as of September 30, 2019 (2018: €1,184 million; 2017: €1,095 million).

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Transfers as part of the legal reorganization of the thyssenkrupp ET Group
Subsubsection Text: As part of the legal reorganization, several corporate restructurings were carried out. Any subsequent legal transfers from thyssenkrupp AG to thyssenkrupp ET Group are recognized as an offset in equity that is for shares being transferred as well as for assets or liabilities transferred, as contributions in kind. The legal reorganization has been conducted via two legal intermediate holding entities, the thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V., Roermond, Netherlands and thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and Operations GmbH, Düsseldorf, Germany, which have both been transferred into the thyssenkrupp Elevator AG, forming a linked transaction on December 31, 2019. Whilst the transfer of the thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V. into thyssenkrupp Elevator AG has been conducted via a contribution in kind in exchange for new shares issued by thyssenkrupp Elevator AG to tk Nederland Holding B.V., the transfer of thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and Operations GmbH has been conducted as an acquisition of thyssenkrupp Elevator AG with a corresponding purchase price in the amount of €796 million. Prior to the transfer of thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V. and the of thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and Operations GmbH into thyssenkrupp Elevator AG both intermediate holding entities were legally formed, respectively restructured. The following companies and operations have been transferred into thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding “B.V.” in the interim period ended March 31, 2020: F-26 ----- As part of the legal reorganization, several corporate restructurings were carried out. The following significant transactions were completed in the year ended September 30, 2019. F-110 -----

Subsection Title: Further subsequent transfers not part of the legal reorganization of the thyssenkrupp ET Group
Subsubsection Text: February 11, 2020, the shares of thyssenkrupp Industrials Finance Germany GmbH, Essen, Germany were acquired for a purchase price of €25 thousand and as of February 18, 2020 the thyssenkrupp Industrials Finance Germany GmbH has been merged into thyssenkrupp Elevator AG.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The control and profit or loss transfer agreement (Beherrschungs- und Gewinnabführungsverträge) between the German thyssenkrupp ET Group companies and the remaining thyssenkrupp Group has been terminated as of December 31, 2019. The related impacts of the profit or loss transfer agreement, that were in place until December 31, 2019, are shown as contributions or withdrawals from reserves by the shareholders and are included in the line item “Other transactions with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group” of the interim consolidated statement of changes in equity and the line item “Payments received under profit and loss transfer agreements of the” interim consolidated statement of cash flows. In addition, profit or loss transfer agreements were in place with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group in the periods under consideration. For the purposes of the Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business, receivables and liabilities from/due to remaining thyssenkrupp Group in connection with control and profit or loss transfer agreements were presented as other financial assets and other financial liabilities, respectively. The related impacts of the profit or loss transfer agreements are shown as contributions or withdrawals from reserves by the shareholders and are included in the line item “Transactions with thyssenkrupp Group” of the combined statement of changes in equity and the combined statement of cash flows.

Subsection Title: Compensation of current Executive and Supervisory Board members
Subsubsection Text: The thyssenkrupp Elevator key management personnel compensation which has to be disclosed in accordance with IAS 24 comprises of the compensation of thyssenkrupp Elevator laO Executive Board members until December 31, 2019 and subsequently of thyssenkrupp Elevator AG Board Members starting as of January 1, 2020 and Supervisory Board members. In addition, the thyssenkrupp Elevator Technology Business was controlled by the ultimate parent, thyssenkrupp AG. Therefore, thyssenkrupp AG’s Management Board and Supervisory Board are deemed key management.
