Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Notes to the Combined Financial Statements 01 Basis of preparation •** **General information Background
Subsubsection Text: On May 21, 2019, the Supervisory Board of thyssenkrupp Aktiengesellschaft, Duisburg and Essen, Germany (hereafter “thyssenkrupp AG”) unanimously approved the Executive Board’s plans for a fundamental strategic realignment of the group. As part of this new strategy, the Executive Board proposed an initial public offering (hereafter “IPO”) of thyssenkrupp Elevator Technology Business (hereafter “Elevator Technology Business”) to the Supervisory Board. In addition to the IPO thyssenkrupp AG was also contemplating a full trade sale of the Elevator Technology Business to potential interested parties. On February 27, 2020, the Executive Board’s decision to sell its entire Elevator Technology Business to a consortium led by Advent, Cinven and RAG foundation was approved by the Supervisory Board of thyssenkrupp AG. The Elevator Technology Business—which designs and delivers passenger transportation solutions—has been separated from thyssenkrupp AG and its subsidiaries (hereafter “thyssenkrupp Group”). All companies making up the Elevator Technology Business have been transferred to thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V., Roermond, Netherlands, or thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and Operations AG, Düsseldorf, Germany, which was previously named thyssenkrupp Elevator AG until December 10, 2019 (hereafter “thyssenkrupp Elevator IaO2”[1]). In further steps, thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V. and its subsidiaries and thyssenkrupp Elevator laO and its subsidiaries were then transferred at December 6, 2019 and at December 31, 2019, respectively, under a new company named thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding GmbH, Essen, Germany (formerly thyssenkrupp Industrials GmbH, Essen, Germany, that was founded in June 2018 under the name thyssenkrupp Carbon2Chem Management GmbH, Duisburg, Germany). As of December 31, 2019, both companies are therefore 100%-subsidiaries of thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding GmbH, which is then the parent company of the thyssenkrupp Elevator Technology Group (hereafter “thyssenkrupp ET Group”). On January 16, 2020, name and legal form of thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding GmbH was changed to thyssenkrupp Elevator AG (hereafter “the Company”[2]). All legal entities and the Elevator Technology Business operating activities that comprise the thyssenkrupp ET Group have been transferred to thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V. or thyssenkrupp Elevator laO, or one of its direct or indirect subsidiaries as part of a restructuring under corporate law. Most of the German legal entities have been transferred into thyssenkrupp laO. Most of the foreign legal entities have been transferred into thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V. All legal entities not forming part of the thyssenkrupp ET Group have remained in the thyssenkrupp Group (hereafter “remaining thyssenkrupp Group”). Business operating activities attributable to the Elevator Technology Business that have not been conducted in Elevator Technology companies, have been transferred via asset deals into Elevator Technology Business legal entities. Operating activities attributable to the remaining thyssenkrupp Group that have been conducted in Elevator Technology companies have been transferred to the remaining thyssenkrupp Group companies. Due to the significant restructuring in the context of the legal reorganization, there is no historical financial information for the thyssenkrupp ET Group for the fiscal years ended September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017 that reflects the entire operating activities of the Elevator Technology Business. Prior to the legal reorganization the Elevator Technology Business did not exist as a separate group from October 1, 2016 to September 30, 2019, although it was under the common control of thyssenkrupp AG over that period. Therefore, combined financial statements were prepared for the fiscal years ended September 30, 2019, September 30, 2018 and September 30, 2017 (hereafter “Combined Financial Statements”). The Combined Financial Statements display a combined presentation on book value carry-over basis of IFRS group financial information of the Elevator Technology Business, as included in the historical thyssenkrupp AG consolidated financial statements for the respective periods. The Elevator Technology Business is defined as the future legal structure comprised of the Company, thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V., thyssenkrupp Elevator laO and their direct and indirect subsidiaries but also includes all Elevator Technology Business operating activities that historically were not yet 1 Until December 10, 2019, thyssenkrupp Elevator IaO refers to thyssenkrupp Elevator AG. Starting on December 10, 2019, thyssenkrupp Elevator IaO refers to thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and Operations AG. 2 Until January 16, 2020, the Company refers to thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding GmbH. Starting on January 16, 2020, the Company refers to thyssenkrupp Elevator AG. F-41 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Notes to the Combined Financial Statements (Continued) 01 Basis of preparation (Continued)
Subsubsection Text: part of these entities but, in the context of the legal reorganization, were transferred to the Company by December 31, 2019. The operating activities attributed to the thyssenkrupp ET Group that were previously conducted in the thyssenkrupp Group companies have been recorded at their historical amounts. This combination of entities under common control is hence not displayed by applying the acquisition method in accordance with IFRS 3, but by using the predecessor accounting method using book values as reported in the historical thyssenkrupp AG consolidated financial statements as of September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017, respectively. Further information on the scope and basis of preparation of the Combined Financial Statements is presented in Note 02 and Note 03. The Combined Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with the International Financial Reporting Standards, as endorsed by the EU (hereafter “IFRS”). The Combined Financial Statements comprise combined statements of financial position, combined statements of profit or loss, combined statements of comprehensive income, combined statements of cash flows, combined statements of changes in equity and notes to the Combined Financial Statements for the fiscal years ended September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017. The Combined Financial Statements are presented in euros, with all amounts rounded to the nearest million (million €) except when otherwise indicated; this may result in differences compared to the unrounded figures. The Combined Financial Statements were prepared on May 29, 2020 by the Executive Board of the Company. New IFRS accounting standards were applied in the Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business in fiscal years from October 1, 2016 to September 30, 2019 in accordance with the same respective dates of first-time adoption of thyssenkrupp AG. Specifically, for IFRS 15 “Revenue from Contracts with Customers”, thyssenkrupp AG adopted the standard in the fiscal year beginning on October 1, 2018, by applying the full retrospective approach to initial application. Due to the financial statements of that fiscal year for the thyssenkrupp Group only presenting one comparative period, the cumulative transition effects were included directly in retained earnings at the start of the comparative period on October 1, 2017. In contrast, for the Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business, due to the additional comparative period from October 1, 2016 to September 30, 2017 presented, according to the full retrospective approach, IFRS 15 has been applied starting as of October 1, 2016 for the Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business (i.e. the cumulative transition effects were included directly in invested equity attributable to the thyssenkrupp Group at the start of the comparative period on October 1, 2016). The separate financial statements or reporting packages of the combined companies or operations, respectively, were prepared as of the respective closing dates for the Combined Financial Statements. The periods for recognizing adjusting events in the Combined Financial Statements are identical to the respective periods of the IFRS consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG. in the scope of combination with effect from October 1, 2016, in accordance with the above and below principles. At the time of the actual respective individual transfers subsequent to September 30, 2019, the acquisition of such business operations may decrease equity of the Elevator Technology Business if the consideration transferred exceeds the book value of the business operations acquired. Businesses as defined in accordance with IFRS 3 “Business Combinations” in analogy for transactions under common control that have been transferred to the Elevator Technology Business during the legal reorganization were included with their respective assets and liabilities as well as income and expenses in the Combined Financial Statements for the whole of the reporting period, i.e. from October 1, 2016 to September 30, 2019. Businesses that were acquired from a third party during the reporting periods of the Combined Financial Statements were included from the date at which the thyssenkrupp Group gained control. Companies and operating activities that constitute a business and that were not controlled by Elevator Technology Business companies after the legal reorganization had been finalized, were excluded from the scope of combination for all periods. Assets and liabilities that do not constitute a business in accordance with IFRS 3 that were acquired or disposed of by entities that were part of the Elevator Technology Business during the reporting periods of the Combined Financial Statements were included in or excluded from these financial statements as of the date of the transaction. Leased assets which will be legally transferred from the thyssenkrupp Group to the thyssenkrupp ET Group after the closing of the transaction, remained treated as leased assets in the Combined Financial Statements (for more details refer to Note 22). Operating activities that represent business operations that have been transferred as part of the legal reorganization to an existing or newly formed Elevator Technology company but historically were part of a legal entity that has remained in the remaining thyssenkrupp Group, were included in the scope of combination for all periods presented. These transfers to existing or newly formed Elevator Technology companies have been part of a “linked transaction”, according to IFRS 10.B97, that was closed as of December 31, 2019. For these Elevator Technology Business operating activities, separate IFRS financial information were prepared and appropriately included in the Combined Financial Statements. For the purposes of the Combined Financial Statements, income, expenses, assets and liabilities were attributed and allocated to the relevant Elevator Technology Business operating activities. Assets and liabilities as well as income and expenses were attributed directly or, where this was not possible, indirectly with the help of appropriate allocation keys (for example on the basis of employee headcount or revenues), which were applied consistently during the periods under consideration. Legal transfers to/from the Company or its direct and indirect subsidiaries during the reporting periods or after September 30, 2019 but before or on December 31, 2019 involving shares of companies are referred to in the following as “share deals” and the legal entities concerned as “share deal companies”. Legal transfers to the Company or its direct and indirect subsidiaries during the reporting periods or after September 30, 2019 but before or on December 31, 2019, that entirely relate to assets and liabilities or obligations are referred to in the following as “asset deals” and the Elevator Technology Business operating activities concerned as “asset deal companies”. A full list of the companies and Elevator Technology Business operating activities included in the scope of combination of the Combined Financial Statements is provided in Note 03 of the notes to the Combined Financial Statements. were adjusted annually by the percentage of any changes in their equity corresponding to the Elevator Technology Business’s percentage interests in the respective companies. Intercompany balances and transactions within the Elevator Technology Business along with all gains and losses from transactions within the Elevator Technology Business were eliminated for purposes of the Combined Financial Statements. During the preparation of the Combined Financial Statements, deferred income tax effects on carve-out entries were recognized as set out in more detail below. one-time fee in the amount of €1,080 million reduced by a fixed amount of €99 million for the use of the brand starting October 1, 2019 until closing. In addition a fixed amount of €74 million for the use of the brand for the period of no longer than 18 months after closing was agreed. Both, the amount receivable and the amount payable, are due immediately prior to closing. With the signing of the addendum agreement the intangible asset for the right of use of the thyssenkrupp brand will be classified as held for sale in accordance with IFRS 5. The effects of the addendum display a non-adjusting event after the reporting period presented (also refer to Note 32). the Elevator Technology Business as included in the business area Elevator Technology within the thyssenkrupp Group, which is implemented on a regional and functional basis. This segment reporting structure is presented in the Combined Financial Statements for each of the reporting periods under consideration (for more details see Note 23). - a decrease in total invested equity of €(29) million as of September 30, 2019 (2018: €(11) million; 2017: €(8) million), - a decrease/increase in other provisions (current) of €(12) million as of September 30, 2019 (2018: €10 million; 2017: €9 million), - a decrease/increase in trade accounts payable of €(9) million as of September 30, 2019 (2018: €47 million; 2017: €37 million), - a decrease/increase in other non-financial liabilities €(2) million as of September 30, 2019 (2018: €12 million; 2017: €0 million), - an increase/decrease in contract liabilities €108 million as of September 30, 2019 (2018: €(41) million;2017: €(39) million) - an increase in cost of sales of €1 million in the year ended September 30, 2019 (2018: €15 million; 2017: €11 million) - an increase/decrease in income taxes of €17 million in the year ended September 30, 2019 (2018: €(11) million; 2017: €(3) million). Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Description of the Elevator Technology Business
Subsubsection Text: The employees of the Elevator Technology Business develop, manufacture, install, maintain and modernize: - Passenger and freight elevators; - Escalators and moving walks; - Passenger boarding bridges; - Stair and platform lifts. The systems of the Elevator Technology Business transport people in many of the world’s buildings—from major airports, train stations and shopping malls to large office towers and hotels. The Elevator Technology Business also provides tailored service solutions. The Elevator Technology Business has worldwide operations in a variety of legal entities as well as business operating activities and was included in the consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG, mainly in the reportable segment Elevator Technology.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: •** **Basis of preparation of the Combined Financial Statements Compliance with IFRS
Subsubsection Text: The following Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business were prepared in accordance with IFRS as well as the related interpretations of the IFRS Interpretation Committee (“IFRIC”) as they are to be applied in the EU at the end of the last reporting period presented. As the IFRS do not provide guidelines for the preparation of combined financial statements, IAS 8 “Accounting Policies, Changes in Accounting Estimates and Errors” has been used for the preparation of the Combined Financial Statements. IAS 8.12 requires the consideration of the most recent pronouncements of other standard-setting bodies, other financial reporting requirements and recognized industry practices. In the Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business presented below, the predecessor accounting approach has been applied in accordance with the recognized industry practices rules on business combinations under common control. The Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business reflect the Elevator Technology companies and the operating activities assigned to the Elevator Technology Business as historically included in the IFRS consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG. In general, the Elevator Technology Business applied the same accounting policies and measurement principles in preparing the Combined Financial Statements as were used in preparing the IFRS consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG (using the “extraction method”). This approach was adjusted with respect to transactions with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group companies and to ensure IFRS compliance. Transactions between the Elevator Technology Business and the remaining thyssenkrupp Group were recognized in accordance with IFRS and classified as related party transactions as defined in IAS 24 “Related Party Disclosures”. F-42 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Up to September 30, 2019, the Elevator Technology Business was comprised of the Company as well as Elevator Technology legal entities and business operating activities that were conducted in other direct and indirect subsidiaries of thyssenkrupp AG. The legal transfer of the legal entities and the Elevator Technology Business operating activities in the context of the reorganization under corporate law that comprise the thyssenkrupp ET Group was not completed by September 30, 2019. As a result, financial statements of the Elevator Technology Business as of and for the fiscal years ended September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017 have been prepared on a combined basis only. The scope of combination for the Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business for the fiscal years ended September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017 was determined on the principles of the legal reorganization approach. This approach is based on the fact that the economic activities that form the new entity were not managed as one division in the past, but the entities and operating activities included in the scope of combination are legally bound together within a reorganization process. During the reporting periods of the Combined Financial Statements, the assets and liabilities forming the reporting entity were under common control of thyssenkrupp AG. The Combined Financial Statements have been prepared on the basis of the extraction method from the historical consolidated financial statements of thyssenkrupp AG taking into account the target structure of the reorganization. The structure of the scope of combination of the Elevator Technology Business for these Combined Financial Statements is comprised of the following: - The Company, - Legal entities that were fully dedicated to the Elevator Technology Business by virtue of their operations and were part of the legal reorganization and were transferred to the Company by December 31, 2019, - Assets and liabilities as well as income and expenses of Elevator Technology Business operating activities that were part of the legal reorganization and were transferred to the Company by December 31, 2019, - Joint ventures and other investments that were part of the legal reorganization and were transferred to the Company by December 31, 2019. If the above components were already legally transferred in the Elevator Technology Business during the reported periods as of and for the years ended September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017, these individual transfers are already fully reflected within the equity for the respective period as of the dates of the respective individual transfers. Businesses or individual assets or liabilities that qualify as an Elevator Technology Business operation, that have transferred subsequently to September 30, 2019 to the Elevator Technology Business, are still included F-43 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Treatment of share deal companies in the Combined Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: Separate financial statements or reporting packages were drawn up for share deal companies and are included in the Combined Financial Statements. They also include liquidity and financial obligations as well as financial assets or liabilities from central cash pooling agreements with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group along with the respective interest income and expense. Any relevant income, expenses, assets and liabilities relating to business activities initially reported in these entities but not forming part of the Elevator Technology Business were excluded when preparing the separate financial statements or reporting packages for the Combined Financial Statements. F-44 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Notes to the Combined Financial Statements (Continued) 01 Basis of preparation (Continued) Treatment of asset deal companies in the Combined Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: For purposes of the Combined Financial Statements, the relevant income, expenses, assets and liabilities of asset deal companies were attributed to the Elevator Technology Business. Liquid assets, financial obligations and financial assets or liabilities from cash pooling agreements with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group were not attributed or allocated to the Elevator Technology Business because such assets or liabilities are not legally attributable to the Elevator Technology Business, nor do legal claims or obligations exist towards the remaining thyssenkrupp Group in these cases. Accordingly, no interest income or expense pertaining to such items was reflected in the combined statements of profit or loss. The Elevator Technology Business have obtained controlling, accounting, human resources, IT and infrastructure services from thyssenkrupp Group service companies, such as thyssenkrupp Regional Services Germany GmbH, Essen, Germany. In addition, holding companies such as thyssenkrupp AG have provided various central services including governance to the Elevator Technology Business. These services were historically reported within the business area Corporate in the thyssenkrupp Group and will either be transferred to the Elevator Technology Business as part of the legal reorganization or will be provided as a service under transitional service agreements subsequent to the legal reorganization. The respective income and costs for such services, that were historically recharged to the Elevator Technology Business, have been included in the combined statement of profit or loss at their historical amounts. Where income and costs for such services were historically not recharged but were essential to the operational business of the Elevator Technology Business were either directly attributed or, where this was not possible, allocated using appropriate allocation keys and are reflected in the Combined Financial Statements at their historical cost. Furthermore, assets or liabilities relating to administrative services, service companies or the central activities of the holding companies pertained to the Elevator Technology Business were attributed in the Combined Financial Statements based on the legal reorganization principle. Shared assets relating to such holding companies that did not legally transfer to the Elevator Technology Business were not included in the combined statements of financial position of the Elevator Technology Business. However, for such an appropriate usage charge was reflected in the Combined Financial Statements in the reporting periods. For shared assets relating to such holding companies that did legally transfer to the Elevator Technology Business, were included in the combined statements of financial position of the Elevator Technology Business. The usage by the remaining thyssenkrupp Group was accounted for by way of appropriate usage income charges to the remaining thyssenkrupp Group in the reporting periods.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Presentation of the Combined Financial Statements as well as combination and consolidation principles
Subsubsection Text: The transfers of businesses between the Elevator Technology Business and the remaining thyssenkrupp Group were qualified as transactions under common control. The Elevator Technology Business applied the predecessor accounting approach in accordance with IDW RS HFA 2 by carrying forward the historical carrying amounts recorded by the thyssenkrupp Group. All income, expenses, assets and liabilities that are attributable to the economic operations of the Elevator Technology Business and that are included in the legal reorganization process are reflected in the Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business. For periods within the overall reporting period from October 1, 2016 to September 30, 2019 there was no requirement to prepare consolidated financial statements, since the Elevator Technology Business did not constitute a legal group of entities in accordance with IFRS 10 “Consolidated Financial Statements”. As a result, the companies or operating activities were combined. The carrying amounts of the investments and the respective share of any parent company in the equity of its subsidiaries, which are both part of the Elevator Technology Business were treated in accordance with the relevant IFRS requirements. Profit or loss transfers with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group have been treated as contribution/withdrawal from/to the remaining thyssenkrupp Group. The Combined Financial Statements also include joint ventures accounted for using the equity method and other investments held at historical cost. The carrying amounts of companies accounted for using the equity method F-45 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Operating transactions of the Elevator Technology Business with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group are reported in the cash flows from operating activities. Financing transactions (in particular cash pooling) of the Elevator Technology Business with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group are presented in the cash flows from financing activities (for more details see Note 31). The advance payments made for the test tower in Rottweil, Germany, and the multifunctional building in Neuhausen, Germany, as well as the paid one-time fee for the thyssenkrupp brand are presented in the cash flows from investing activities (for more details see Note 22), whereas any related proceeds from loans are presented in the cash flows from financing activities. The transactions with the remaining thyssenkrupp Group also include cash inflows and outflows in connection with control and profit or loss transfer agreements between the Elevator Technology Business companies and remaining thyssenkrupp Group companies, capital contributions and transfers from reserves in connection with the reorganization under corporate law as well as tax receivables, tax liabilities and deferred taxes presented as contributions or withdrawals under the separate tax return approach (see the detailed explanation below). Services recharged by the holding companies were also presented within operating cash flow in the same way as tax charges and benefits under the separate tax return approach.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Historical goodwill arising on acquisitions within the thyssenkrupp Group was consistently allocated and reported in the Cash Generating Units that are expected to benefit from the synergies of the acquisition. The goodwill for the Combined Financial Statements was in turn assigned to the Elevator Technology Business on the basis of the extraction method, i.e. where it was historically allocated. Therefore, only goodwill directly related to the Elevator Technology Business is reflected in the Combined Financial Statements. Goodwill (excluding goodwill of equity method investments) has been allocated to Cash Generating Units (CGU) of all business units. The recoverable amount of each CGU is determined based on a value in use calculation using after-tax cash flow projections based on bottom-up prepared financial budgets approved by thyssenkrupp AG’s management covering a three-year period. The last budget year is generally used to determine the cash flows beyond the budget period and modified to calculate the perpetuity considering additional assumptions. A business specific, sustained growth rate is taken into account; as a rule this growth rate amounts between 1.35% and 1.5%. The weighted average cost of capital discount rate is based on a risk-free interest rate of 0.1% (2017/2018: 1.0%; 2016/2017: 1.25%) and a market risk premium of 6.75% (2017/2018: 6.5%; 2016/2017: 6.5%). Moreover for each CGU the beta, the cost of debt and the capital structure is derived individually from the relevant peer group. In addition CGU specific tax rates and country risk premiums are used. To discount cash flows after-tax discount rates are applied. Based on an iterative calculation the following pre-tax discount rates are derived from the after-tax discount rates:

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Combined Financial Statements include the pension obligations and plan assets directly attributable to the Elevator Technology Business. The obligations and plan assets have been valued on the basis of expert actuarial reports. In the case of Elevator Technology companies (share deal companies), both active employees and retirees have been included. In the case of operating activities to be transferred (asset deal companies), only active employees, which have been assigned to the Elevator Technology Business in the relevant periods have been included. The actual transfer of the employees and the associated actual transfer of their benefit entitlements may be subject to local requirements or the consent of the employees and may, therefore, differ from the obligations presented in the Combined Financial Statements. The transfer of the employees into Elevator Technology companies have been completed by December 31, 2019. The associated pension obligations have been determined on an individual basis. Only plan assets that have been part of the Elevator Technology Business until the completion of the legal reorganization have been included in the Combined Financial Statements. The actuarial valuation was based on thyssenkrupp Group parameters and where necessary adjusted for Elevator Technology Business specifics. Actuarial reports as of September 30, 2019, September 30, 2018, September 30, 2017 and October 1, 2016 under IAS 19 “Employee Benefits” were commissioned for material Elevator Technology Business operating activities.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Elevator Technology Business uses derivative financial instruments, including foreign currency forward contracts and foreign currency options to reduce its exposure to foreign currency risk. The Combined Financial Statements include all hedges directly attributable to the Elevator Technology Business. These derivatives are all entered into with counterparties within the thyssenkrupp Group. Of these derivatives, some are designated as hedging instruments for hedge accounting purposes. All hedge documentation for this has historically already been documented at a local level, i.e. where the hedged risk exists. As such, for the Combined Financial Statements, all hedge accounting previously recorded can be maintained. In the Combined Financial Statements any hedging relationships between the Elevator Technology Business and the remaining thyssenkrupp Group will be presented and accounted for as with related parties (for more details see Note 22).

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Employees of the Elevator Technology Business participated in share-based compensation programs of the thyssenkrupp Group. These are classified as cash-settled in line with the specific requirements for share-based payment transactions among group entities. The expenses and obligations arising from share-based compensation were historically recognized and reported in the financial statements of those companies which incurred the personnel expenses and also settled the obligations for their employees. For more details see Note 13. For the purposes of the Combined Financial Statements, this means that expenses were already correctly included in the reporting financial statements of share deal companies and no changes to the classification of the programs was necessary. For expenses and obligations related to employees that are part of the Elevator Technology Business but that were not part of a share deal company, however, the costs and obligations were included in the Combined Financial Statements with no changes to the classification so long as the contractual obligation to settle the shared-based payment liability has been transferred to an Elevator Technology Business company as part of the legal reorganization. F-47 ----- The Elevator Technology Business has participated in management incentive plans by the thyssenkrupp Group which grant stock rights to executive and senior employees that are exclusively settled in cash after the end of the respective performance period. The fair value of these rights is calculated on the date of grant and on each balance sheet date and recognized as an expense on a straight-line basis over the vesting period of three years with a corresponding increase in provisions. Furthermore a portion of the variable compensation was granted as share appreciation rights to the Executive Board members of thyssenkrupp Elevator laO inclusive of fiscal year 2014/2015. For both types of compensation, the provision is remeasured at each balance sheet date and at settlement date. Any changes in the fair value of the provision are recognized as part of income from operations. See also information provided in Note 13.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Notes to the Combined Financial Statements (Continued) 01 Basis of preparation (Continued) Capital structure
Subsubsection Text: The equity of the Elevator Technology Business consists of the invested equity attributable to the thyssenkrupp Group, other components of equity and the invested equity attributable to non-controlling interest. The Combined Financial Statements do not show share capital. Since the Elevator Technology Business has no share capital and reserves in its own right, any equity represents the parent’s net investment. Thus, the presentation of the equity of the Elevator Technology Business differs from the presentation of equity as prescribed in IAS 1 “Presentation of Financial Statements”. During the reporting periods under consideration of the Combined Financial Statements, the Elevator Technology Business was mainly financed by the remaining thyssenkrupp Group. The capital structure of the Elevator Technology Business at the time of the closing of the transaction will differ from the capital structure presented in the Combined Financial Statements.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: In accordance with the management approach required by IFRS 8 “Operating Segments”, the internal reporting of the Elevator Technology Business is based on the historical internal organizational and reporting structure of F-48 ----- In accordance with the so-called management approach, segment reporting of the Elevator Technology Business is based on the internal organizational and reporting structure. The data used to determine the internal key figures are derived from the Combined Financial Statements under consideration of the principles stated in the basis of preparation.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The thyssenkrupp Elevator Technology Business applied the following material accounting policies in the fiscal years ended September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017. The following policies should be read in conjunction with Note 01. F-51 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Notes to the Combined Financial Statements (Continued) 02 Summary of significant accounting policies (Continued) Consolidation principles in the Combined Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: The Combined Financial Statements include the Company, thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V., thyssenkrupp Elevator laO as well as Elevator Technology legal entities and the Elevator Technology Business operating activities that have been transferred to thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V. or thyssenkrupp Elevator laO, or one of the entities which are directly or indirectly controlled by thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V. or thyssenkrupp Elevator laO (subsidiaries) as part of a restructuring under corporate law. The ability to control a company in accordance with IFRS 10 results from: - holding power over an investee (normally achieved through a possession of more than half of the voting rights of a company); - being exposed to or having rights to variable returns from its involvement with the investee; and - the ability to use its power over the investee to affect the amount of the investor’s returns. Capital consolidation is performed by offsetting the carrying amounts of subsidiaries against their attributable equity. On acquisition, the identifiable assets, liabilities and contingent liabilities of a subsidiary are measured at their fair values at the date of acquisition. The interest of minority shareholders (non-controlling interest) is stated at the minority’s proportion of the fair values of the identifiable assets, liabilities and contingent liabilities recognized. All significant intercompany transactions and balances between Elevator Technology Business entities are eliminated on consolidation. Joint arrangements where two or more parties jointly control an activity either classify as joint operations or as joint ventures. Joint ventures are accounted for using the equity method of accounting. Where the Elevator Technology Business transacts with its joint operations or joint ventures, unrealized profits and losses are eliminated to the extent of the Elevator Technology Business’s interest. Subsidiaries and joint ventures which influence the Elevator Technology Business’s net assets, financial position and results of operations are only immaterial. Such entities are measured at fair value or in accordance with IAS 39 “Financial instruments: Recognition and Measurement” at amortized cost when the fair value of unlisted equity instruments cannot be reliably measured; they are presented under the “Other financial assets, non-current” line item. Goodwill arising on acquisition is recognized as an asset and is tested for impairment annually, or on such other occasions that events or changes in circumstances indicate that it might be impaired. Goodwill arising on the acquisition of a joint venture is included within the carrying amount of the joint venture or the associate, respectively. Goodwill arising on the acquisition of subsidiaries or joint operations is presented separately in the statement of financial position.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The functional and reporting currency of the Elevator Technology Business is the euro (€). Transactions denominated in foreign currencies are initially recorded at the rates of exchange prevailing on the dates of the transactions. Monetary assets and liabilities denominated in such currencies are retranslated at the rates prevailing on the balance sheet date. Profits or losses arising on exchange are included in the net profit or loss for the period. Financial statements of the foreign subsidiaries and financial information of Elevator Technology Business operations included in the Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business where the functional currency is other than the euro are translated using their functional currency which is generally the respective local currency. The translation is performed using the current rate method. Net exchange gains or losses resulting from the translation of foreign financial statements are accumulated and included in equity. Such translation differences are recognized as income or as expenses in the period in which the subsidiary is disposed of. Companies that manage their sales, purchases, and financing substantially not in their local currency use the currency of their primary economic environment as their functional currency. Financial statements prepared in local currency are translated into the functional currency using the temporal method. The resulting translation F-52 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Notes to the Combined Financial Statements (Continued) 02 Summary of significant accounting policies (Continued)
Subsubsection Text: differences are included in the combined statement of profit or loss as “Other income or expenses”. Thereafter, the functional currency financial statements are translated into the reporting currency using the current rate method. The exchange rates of those currencies significant to the Elevator Technology Business have developed as follows: Goodwill arising on acquisition is allocated to the Cash Generating Units that are expected to benefit from the synergies of the acquisition. Those groups of Cash Generating Units represent the lowest level within the Elevator Technology Business at which goodwill is monitored for internal management purposes. The recoverable amount of the Cash Generating Unit that carries a goodwill is tested for impairment annually as of September 30, or on such other occasions that events or changes in circumstances indicate that it might be impaired. For more details refer to Note 04. If the recoverable amount of an asset is estimated to be less than its carrying amount, the carrying amount of the asset is reduced to its recoverable amount. Impairment losses are recognized as an expense immediately. In case of impairment losses related to Cash Generating Units that carry a goodwill the carrying amount of any goodwill allocated to the Cash Generating Unit is reduced first. If the amount of impairment losses exceeds the carrying amount of goodwill, the difference is generally allocated proportionally to the remaining non-current assets of the Cash Generating Unit to reduce their carrying amounts accordingly. Where an impairment loss subsequently reverses, the carrying amount of the asset (Cash Generating Unit) is increased to the revised estimate of its recoverable amount. The revised amount cannot exceed the carrying amount that would have been determined had no impairment loss been recognized for the asset (Cash Generating Unit) in prior years. A reversal of an impairment loss is recognized as income immediately. However, impairment losses of goodwill may not be reversed. includes any transaction costs directly attributable to the acquisition of financial assets, which are not carried at fair value through profit or loss in future periods. The fair values recognized on the statement of financial position usually reflect the market prices of the financial assets. Business in the future to enable them to be used. The assessment of their future recoverability is based on forecast calculations of the respective Elevator entity or tax groups. Deferred tax liabilities are recognized on temporary differences taxable in the future. Deferred tax assets and deferred tax liabilities are offset if they relate to income taxes levied by the same taxation authority and the Elevator Technology Business has a legally enforceable right to set off current tax assets against current tax liabilities. Effects of changes in tax rates or tax law on deferred tax assets and liabilities are generally taken into account in the period in which the changes are enacted. Deferred and current taxes are recognized in the combined statements of profit or loss unless they relate to items recognized outside the combined statement of profit or loss in the combined statement of comprehensive income, in which case they, too, are recognized in other components of equity. recognized represents best estimate of the settlement amount of the present obligation as of the balance sheet date. Expected reimbursements of third parties are not offset but recorded as a separate asset if it is virtually certain that the reimbursements will be received. Where the effect of the time value of money is material, provisions are discounted using a market rate. A provision for warranties is recognized when the underlying products or services are sold. The provision is based on historical warranty data and a weighting of all possible outcomes against their associated probabilities. Provisions for restructuring costs are recognized when the Elevator Technology Business has a detailed formal plan for the restructuring and has notified the affected parties. A provision for onerous contracts is recognized when the expected benefits to be derived by the Elevator Technology Business from a contract are lower than the unavoidable cost of meeting its obligations under the contract. If the performance obligations fulfilled for the customer exceed the payments received or due from the customer, contract assets are recognized in the statement of financial position on a net basis insofar as the right to receive payment from the customer is still conditional. Unconditional rights to receive payment are recognized under trade accounts receivable and from this point payment automatically becomes due with the passage of time. If the payments received or due from the customer exceed the performance obligations fulfilled, contract liabilities are recognized in the statement of financial position on a net basis. _Recoverability of goodwill_ As stated in the accounting policy, the Elevator Technology Business tests annually and in addition if any indicators exist, whether goodwill has suffered an impairment loss. If there is an indication, the recoverable amount of the cash-generating unit has to be estimated which is the greater of the fair value less costs to sell and the value in use. The determination of the value in use involves making adjustments and estimates related to the projection and discounting of future cash flows (cf. Note 04). Although management believes the assumptions used to calculate recoverable amounts are appropriate, any unforeseen changes in these assumptions could result in impairment charges to goodwill which could adversely affect the future financial position and operating results. _Recoverability of assets_ At each balance sheet date, the Elevator Technology Business assesses whether there is any indication that the carrying amounts of its property, plant and equipment or intangible assets may be impaired. If any such indication exists, the recoverable amount of the asset is estimated. The recoverable amount is the greater of the fair value less costs to sell and the value in use. In assessing the value in use, discounted future cash flows from the related assets have to be determined. Estimating the discounted future cash flows involves significant assumptions, including particularly those regarding future sale prices and sale volumes, costs and discount rates (cf. Note 04 and 05). Although management believes that its estimates of the relevant expected useful lives, its assumptions concerning the economic environment and developments in the industries in which the Elevator Technology Business operates and its estimations of the discounted future cash flows are appropriate, changes in the assumptions or circumstances could require changes in the analysis. This could lead to additional impairment charges in the future or to reversal of impairments if the trends identified by management reverse or the assumptions or estimates prove incorrect. _Other provisions_ The recognition and measurement of other provisions are based on the estimation of the probability of a future outflow of resources as well as empirical values and the circumstances known at the reporting date. This means that the actual later outflow of resources may differ from the other provisions, cf. also the remarks under Note 15. _Revenue recognition on construction contracts_ Certain entities and operations of the Elevator Technology Business report some of their business transactions as construction contracts, in which revenue is recognized over time using the percentage-of-completion method. This method requires accurate estimates of the extent of progress towards completion. Depending on the methodology to determine contract progress, the significant estimates include total contract costs, remaining costs to completion, total contract revenues, contract risks and other judgments. The management of the operating companies continually reviews all estimates involved in such construction contracts and adjust them as necessary. The expected variable consideration amount is estimated at the inception of a contract with a customer. The estimate is made using either the probability-weighted expected value or the most likely amount. The estimation method giving the better forecast for the respective contract is always used. The variable consideration amount estimated at contract inception is reviewed at each reporting date and adjusted as necessary. In the case of contracts with customers which have multiple distinct performance obligations, the required allocation of the transaction price to the distinct performance obligations is carried out by reference to the relative standalone selling prices. The relative standalone selling prices used generally correspond to directly observable market prices at which the Elevator Technology company separately sells the performance obligations to other customers. If the standalone selling price is not directly observable, a best estimate of the standalone selling price is made. In these cases an adjusted market assessment approach, an expected cost plus a margin approach, or a residual approach is used. _Income taxes_ The recognition and measurement of current and deferred tax receivables and liabilities depend on management estimates of tax uncertainties and future business performance. This includes both the interpretation of existing F-60 ----- tax regulations and the testing of deferred tax assets for impairment. These estimates are adjusted when there is sufficient evidence of the need for such adjustment. _Employee benefits_ The Elevator Technology Business accounts for pension and other postretirement benefits in accordance with actuarial valuations. These valuations rely on statistical and other factors in order to anticipate future events. These factors include key actuarial assumptions including the discount rate, expected salary increases and mortality rates. These actuarial assumptions may differ materially from actual developments due to changing market and economic conditions and therefore result in a significant change in postretirement employee benefit obligations, of equity and the related future expense. (cf. Note 14 for further information). _Legal contingencies_ Elevator Technology companies are parties to litigations related to a number of matters as described in Note 20. The outcome of these matters may have a material effect on the financial position, results of operations or cash flows. Management regularly analyzes current information about these matters and provides provisions for probable contingent losses including the estimate of legal expense to resolve the matters. For the assessments internal and external lawyers are used. In making the decision regarding the need for loss provisions, management considers the degree of probability of an unfavorable outcome and the ability to make a sufficiently reliable estimate of the amount of loss. The filing of a suit or formal assertion of a claim against Elevator Technology companies or the disclosure of any such suit or assertions, does not automatically indicate that a provision of a loss may be appropriate. €417.7 million as of October 1, 2016, €410.3 million as of September 30, 2017 and €445.8 million as of September 30, 2018. As of October 1, 2016, aside from the reclassifications from current non-financial assets to contract assets and current non-financial liabilities to contract liabilities in the amount of €209.6 million and €1,274.5 million, respectively, no further material transition effects were identified. For the combined statements of financial position as of September 30, 2017 and September 30, 2018, the identification of such reclassification effects was determined not to be practical. Since the reporting entity has not previously prepared financial statements for the periods presented applying IAS 18 and since these special purpose Combined Financial Statements present the application of IFRS 15 for all periods presented, the Elevator Technology Business does not disclose an opening balance sheet as of October 1, 2016 and reconciliation effects on such balance sheet resulting from the adoption of IFRS 15. In July 2014 the IASB issued the final version of IFRS 9 “Financial Instruments”. The new standard includes revised requirements for the classification and measurement of financial assets, fundamental changes to the regulations on the impairment of financial assets, and revised rules on hedge accounting. The Elevator Technology Business adopts IFRS 9 in the fiscal year beginning on October 1, 2018. The option to apply the Standard prospectively was used and accordingly no adjusted comparative information was disclosed. Resultant transition effects are reported in invested equity attributable to the thyssenkrupp Group. The new hedge accounting rules are also applied prospectively. The transition effects at the date of adoption were recognized directly in equity and the comparative periods are presented in accordance with the previous rules of IAS 39 “Financial Instruments: Recognition and Measurement”. The effects of the transition on assets, liabilities and total equity are presented in the following two tables: The effects of the changed classification and measurement of financial assets at the adoption date were as follows: The effects of the adoption of the new impairment model in accordance with IFRS 9 are presented in the following table: Based on the contracts concluded at the balance sheet date, the Elevator Technology Business expects an increase in non-current assets and financial debt and an associated increase in the balance sheet total of approx. €0.4 billion. Related to the balance sheet total at September 30, 2019, the adoption of IFRS 16 would result in a reduction of the equity ratio of approx. 1 percentage point. In the combined statement of profit or loss, expense from operating leases was previously stated in the respective functional cost types. Future minimum lease payments and the expense from operating leases in fiscal year 2018/2019 are shown in Note 20. In fiscal year 2019/2020, EBIT is relieved immaterially and net financial income/(expense) is charged correspondingly. This results from eliminated operating lease expenses according to IAS 17 and from the initial recognition of depreciation of right-of-use assets from October 1, 2019 according to IFRS 16. The changed presentation of expense from operating leases will also result in a shift from cash flows from operating activities to cash flows from financing activities. This is because operating cash flows are no longer impacted by lease payments, only by interest payments whereas repayments are shown in cash flows from financing activities. In fiscal year 2019/2020 this will result in a higher double-digit million effect. The Elevator Technology Business will recognize right-of-use assets under property, plant and equipment and lease liabilities under financial debt on the statement of financial position. In addition to the standard presented above in detail, the IASB has issued further interpretations and amendments to standards and interpretations whose application is also not yet mandatory and which in part require EU endorsement before they can be applied. Management currently assumes that the application of these standards, interpretations and amendments will not have a material impact on the presentation of the Combined Financial Statements: - Amendments to IFRS 10 “Consolidated Financial Statements” and IAS 28 “Investments in Associates and Joint Ventures (2011)”: “Sale or Contribution of Assets between an Investor and its Associate or Joint Venture”, issued in September 2014, initial application deferred indefinitely - IFRIC 23: “Uncertainty over Income Tax Treatments”, issued in June 2017, initial application in fiscal year 2019/2020 - Amendments to IFRS 9 “Financial Instruments”, issued in October 2017, initial application in fiscal year 2019/2020 - Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Intangible assets with finite useful lives are capitalized at cost and amortized on a straight-line basis generally over a period of 3 to 15 years, depending on their estimated useful lives. Useful lives are examined on an annual basis and adjusted when applicable on a prospective basis. The amortization expense of intangible assets is primarily included in cost of sales in the combined statement of profit or loss. Intangible assets with indefinite useful lives are measured at cost and tested for impairment annually, or if there is an indication that their value has declined. Goodwill is stated at cost and tested for impairment annually or on such other occasions that events or changes in circumstances indicate that it might be impaired. Goodwill impairment losses are included in other expenses.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Fixtures and equipment are stated at cost less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses. Capitalized production costs for self-constructed assets include costs of material, direct labor and allocable material and manufacturing overhead. Borrowing costs directly attributable to the production of assets that necessarily take a substantial period of time to get ready for their intended use, are added to the cost of those assets, until such time as the assets are substantially ready for their intended use. Administrative costs are capitalized only if such costs are directly related to production. Maintenance and repair costs (day-to-day servicing) are expensed as incurred. The Elevator Technology Business recognizes in the carrying amount of an item of property, plant and equipment the cost of replacing parts and major inspection of such an item if it is probable that the future economic benefits embodied within the item will flow to the Elevator Technology Business and the cost of the item can be measured reliably. Where fixtures and equipment comprise of significant parts having different useful lives those parts are depreciated separately. Fixtures and equipment are depreciated over the customary useful life using the straight-line method. The following useful lives are used as a basis for calculating depreciation:

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: At each balance sheet date, the Elevator Technology Business reviews the carrying amounts of its intangible assets and property, plant and equipment to determine whether there is any indication that those assets have suffered an impairment loss. If any such indication exists, the recoverable amount of the asset is estimated in order to determine the extent of the impairment loss (if any). Where it is not possible to estimate the recoverable amount of an individual asset, the Elevator Technology Business estimates the recoverable amount of the Cash Generating Unit to which the asset belongs. F-53 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: On initial recognition leases are classified as either finance or operating. Lease transactions whereby the Elevator Technology Business is the lessee and bears substantially all the risks and rewards incidental to ownership of an asset are accounted for as a finance lease. Accordingly, the Elevator Technology Business capitalizes the leased asset at the lower of the fair value or the present value of the minimum lease payments and subsequently depreciates the leased asset over the shorter of the lease term and its useful life. In addition, the Elevator Technology Business records a corresponding lease obligation on the statement of financial position sheet which is subsequently settled and carried forward using the effective interest method. All other lease agreements entered into by the Elevator Technology Business, as a lessee, are accounted for as operating leases whereby the lease payments are expensed on a straight-line basis.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Inventories are stated at the lower of acquisition/manufacturing cost or net realizable value. In general, inventories are valued using the average cost method. Manufacturing cost includes costs of material, direct labor and allocable material and manufacturing overhead based on normal operating capacity.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The accounting policies for financial instruments presented below are in accordance with IAS 39 for the fiscal years ended September 30, 2018 and 2017, respectively and in accordance with IFRS 9 for the fiscal year ended September 30, 2019. For details regarding the changes of accounting policies for financial instruments due to the IFRS 9 regulations see the description in the section “Recently adopted accounting standards” of this Note. A financial instrument is any contract that at the same time gives rise to a financial asset of one entity and a financial liability or equity instrument of another entity. Financial instruments are recognized as soon as the Elevator Technology Business becomes a contracting party to the financial instrument. In cases where trade date and settlement date do not coincide, for non-derivative financial instruments the settlement date is used for initial recognition or derecognition, while for derivatives the trade date is used. Financial instruments stated as financial assets or financial liabilities are generally not offset; they are only offset when an unconditional legal right to set-off exists at that time and settlement on a net basis is intended.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: In particular, financial assets include trade accounts receivable, cash and cash equivalents, derivative financial assets, as well as equity instruments and bonds held. Financial assets are initially recognized at fair value. This F-54 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Classification and measurement of financial assets
Subsubsection Text: Trade accounts receivables are accounted for at amortized cost less valuation allowances. Receivables that do not bear interest or bear below market interest rates and have an expected term of more than one year are discounted with the discount subsequently amortized to interest income over the term of the receivable. Cash and cash equivalents include cash on hand and demand deposits as well as financial assets that are readily convertible to cash and which are only subject to an insignificant risk of change in value, they are measured at amortized cost.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Derivatives that are not part of an effective hedge accounting in accordance with IAS 39 must be assigned to this category when the fair value is positive as of measurement date. Gains or losses resulting from changes in fair value are recognized in profit or loss.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Available-for-sale financial assets are those non-derivative financial assets not assigned to any of the above categories. This category includes primarily equity and debt instruments which are in general measured at fair value. Gains or losses resulting from the measurement of available-for-sale financial assets are recognized directly in equity, with the exception of foreign currency conversion effects on monetary items as well as impairment losses on monetary and non-monetary items. On disposal of these financial assets, a cumulative gain or loss recognized directly in equity until then is recognized in profit or loss of the respective period. When the fair value of unlisted equity instruments cannot be reliably measured, they are measured at cost.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Financial assets measured at fair value through profit or loss
Subsubsection Text: The Elevator Technology Business does not use the option to categorize financial assets at fair value through profit or loss when initially recognized.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Impairments in the form of individual allowances for doubtful accounts adequately consider default risk. When there is objective evidence of default, the receivable concerned is derecognized. Receivables that are immaterial, and receivables of similar default risk, are grouped together and tested collectively for impairment based on past experience. At each balance sheet date, an assessment is made of whether there is any objective evidence that the carrying amounts of financial assets not carried at fair value through profit or loss are impaired. Objective evidence includes, for example, considerable financial difficulty of the debtor obligor, disappearance of an active market, and significant changes in the technological, market, economic or legal environment. A significant or prolonged decline in the fair value of an equity instrument is an objective evidence of impairment. The impairment loss on a financial asset carried at amortized cost is measured as the difference between the asset’s carrying amount and the present value of estimated future cash flows discounted at the financial asset’s original effective interest rate. An impairment loss is recognized in profit or loss. If in a subsequent period, the amount of the impairment loss decreases and the decrease can be related objectively to an event occurring after the impairment was recognized, the previously recognized impairment loss is reversed through profit or loss.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Financial liabilities are liabilities that must be settled in cash or other financial assets. Financial liabilities are initially carried at fair value. This includes any transaction costs directly attributable to the acquisition of financial liabilities, which are not carried at fair value through profit or loss in future periods. F-55 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Notes to the Combined Financial Statements (Continued) 02 Summary of significant accounting policies (Continued) Trade accounts payable and other non-derivative financial liabilities
Subsubsection Text: Trade accounts payable and other non-derivative financial liabilities are in general measured at amortized cost using the effective interest method. Transaction charges, including premiums payable on redemption or settlement, are periodically accrued using the effective interest method and increase the liabilities’ carrying amounts unless they have already been realized in the period in which they were incurred.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Financial liabilities carried at fair value through profit or loss
Subsubsection Text: The Elevator Technology Business does not use the option to categorize financial liabilities at fair value through profit or loss when initially recognized.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Derivatives that are not part of an effective hedge accounting in accordance with IAS 39 must be classified as “held for trading” and thus carried at fair value through profit or loss.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Derivative financial instruments, mainly foreign currency forward contracts, are used to reduce the currency risk. Such derivatives and so-called “embedded derivatives”, which are an integral part of certain contracts and must be accounted for separately, are measured initially and subsequently at fair value. If the fair value is positive, they are recognized as financial assets, otherwise as financial liabilities. If they do not qualify for hedge accounting, they are recognized at fair value in profit or loss, and gains or losses due to fluctuations in fair value are recognized immediately in profit or loss. Hedging relationships are mainly used to hedge foreign currency risks of firm commitments, future receivables and liabilities denominated in foreign currency. In the case of cash flow hedges, the fluctuations in fair value are divided into an effective and an ineffective portion. The effective portion of fluctuations in fair value is recognized initially directly in equity within cumulative other comprehensive income. Reclassification to profit or loss takes place when the hedged item affects profit or loss. The ineffective portion of fluctuations in fair value is recognized directly in profit or loss. The presentation of changes in the fair value of derivative financial instruments in the statement of profit or loss follows the presentation of the hedged items. For foreign currency forward contracts used to hedge sales risks, they are presented under net sales. For hedging instruments used to hedge procurement risks, they are presented under cost of sales, and for hedging instruments used to hedge financing risks they are presented under financial income/expense. More information about financial instruments is provided in Note 21. The Elevator Technology Business uses derivative financial instruments, including foreign currency forward contracts and foreign currency options. Derivative financial instruments are generally used to hedge existing or anticipated underlying transactions so as to reduce foreign currency risks. In some cases, the derivatives are designated as hedging instruments for hedge accounting purposes.
