Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Income taxes comprise taxes levied on taxable profit in the individual countries along with changes in deferred tax assets and liabilities that are recognized in combined profit or loss. For purposes of the Combined Financial Statements, income taxes were determined using the separate tax return approach on the assumption that the companies and operations of the Elevator Technology Business constitute separate tax payers. Legal entities and business operating activities are treated for purposes of the separate tax return approach as a tax group if such legal entities and business operations have historically been included in a tax group and as of December 31, 2019 have operated under a new tax group or are still included within the historical tax group. In such cases, the legal entity or business operating activities representing the head of the tax group is considered as the separate tax payer. Income taxes are reflected at the amounts likely to be payable under the statutory regulations in force, or already enacted in relation to future periods, at the end of the respective reporting year. In compliance with IAS 12 “Income Taxes”, deferred taxes are recognized on temporary differences arising between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities and their tax bases. Deferred taxes are also recognized for tax loss carryforwards and tax credits that are likely to be usable. Deferred tax assets relating to deductible temporary differences, tax credits and tax loss carryforwards are recognized where it is probable that sufficient taxable income will be available within the Elevator Technology F-56 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The equity line item “Other components of equity” includes changes in the equity of the Elevator Technology Business that were not recognized in the combined statement of profit or loss of the period, except those resulting from capital transactions with the owners. Other components of equity include foreign currency translation adjustments, unrealized gains and losses on fair value measurement of debt instruments and on derivative financial instruments in cash flow hedging as well as the share of the other comprehensive income of joint ventures accounted for using the equity method. Remeasurements of pensions and similar obligations are reported in invested equity attributable to the thyssenkrupp Group in the period that they are recognized as other comprehensive income.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Elevator Technology Business’s net obligation for defined benefit and other postretirement benefit plans have been calculated for each plan using the projected unit credit method as of the balance sheet date. A quarterly valuation of pensions is performed on the basis of updated interest rates and fair values of plan assets. As far as the fair value of plan assets related to pensions or similar obligations exceeds the corresponding obligation, the recognition of an asset in respect to such surplus is limited. As far as in connection with plan assets minimum funding requirements related to past service exist, an additional liability may need to be recognized in case the economic benefit of a surplus—already taking into account the contributions to be made in respect of the minimum funding requirements—is limited. The limit is determined by the present value of any future refunds from the plan or reductions in future contributions to the plan asset (asset ceiling). With the exception of net interest, all income and expenses related to defined benefit plans are recognized in income/(loss) from operations. Net interest included in net periodic pension cost is recognized in net financial income/(expense) in the Elevator Technology Business’s combined statement of profit or loss. The Elevator Technology Business’s obligations for contributions to defined contribution plans are recognized as expense in income/(loss) from operations as incurred. The effects of remeasurements of pensions and similar obligations are recognized in other comprehensive income and reported in invested equity attributable to the thyssenkrupp Group. They consist of actuarial gains and losses, the return on plan assets and changes in the effects of asset ceiling excluding amounts already included in net interest. Deferred taxes relating to remeasurements are also recognized in other comprehensive income. The Elevator Technology Business also maintains multi-employer plans. In principle, these multi-employer plans contain defined benefit plans as well as defined contribution plans. With respect to defined benefit multiemployer plans these are accounted for in the same way as any other defined benefit plan in case the required information is available. Otherwise these plans are accounted for as defined contribution plans. In particular in the USA and in the Netherlands, there exist multi-employer defined benefit plans that are accounted for as defined contribution plans due to the fact that the pension obligations and the plan assets cannot be assigned to the participating employers.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Provisions are recognized when the Elevator Technology Business has a present obligation as a result of a past event which will result in a probable outflow of economic benefits that can be reasonably estimated. The amount F-57 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Revenue from contracts with customers is recognized when the included distinct performance obligations, i.e. the distinct goods or services promised in the contract, are transferred to the customer. Transfer takes place when the customer obtains control of the promised goods or services. This is generally the case when the customer has the ability to direct the use of and obtain substantially all of the remaining benefits from the transferred goods or services. Revenue from contracts with customers corresponds to the transaction price. The transaction price includes variable consideration only to the extent it is highly probable that actual occurrence of the variable consideration will not result in a significant revenue reversal. Variable consideration can include for example volume discounts, delay penalties, early completion incentives, or credits in connection with bonus agreements. The transaction price is not adjusted for a financing component, mainly because the period between the transfer of goods and services and the date of payment by the customer is generally less than 12 months. Where a contract with a customer has multiple distinct performance obligations, the transaction price is allocated to the performance obligations by reference to their relative standalone selling prices. The standalone selling prices are determined on the basis of directly observable market prices or using recognized estimation methods. Revenue from the sale of goods and commodities is recognized at the point in time at which control is transferred to the customer. The time of transfer of control is determined partly on the basis of the delivery clauses agreed with the customer. Sales revenue from contracts with customers in the new installation and modernization business is recognized over time by the percentage-of-completion method. The percentage of completion is as a rule determined by the ratio of contract costs incurred up to the reporting date to the total estimated contract costs as of the reporting date. Contract losses are recognized as expense immediately and reported in the statement of financial position under other provisions. The recognition of revenue over time for the performance of services is generally carried out through linear allocation of the transaction price over the service performance period. Incremental costs of obtaining a contract with a customer are capitalized under non-current non-financial assets only if they relate to contracts with an original expected duration of more than 12 months. They are amortized by the straight-line method over the term of the contract. F-58 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Research costs are expensed as incurred. Development costs, whereby research findings are applied to a plan or design for the production of new or substantially improved products and processes, are capitalized if the product or process is technically and commercially feasible, it is intended to complete the intangible asset, there is a market for the output of the intangible asset, the attributable expenditure can be measured reliably, and the Elevator Technology Business has sufficient resources to complete development. Other development costs are expensed as incurred. Capitalized development costs of completed projects are stated at cost less accumulated amortization and impairment losses.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Certain line items on the combined statement of financial position and in the combined statement of profit or loss have been combined. These items are disclosed separately in the notes to the Combined Financial Statements. In general the Elevator Technology Business classifies assets and liabilities as current when they are expected to be realized or settled within twelve months after the balance sheet date. Elevator Technology companies that have operating cycles longer than twelve months classify assets and liabilities as current if they are expected to be realized within the company’s normal operating cycle.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Estimates and judgments in the application of accounting policies
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of the Elevator Technology Combined Financial Statements requires management to make judgements, estimates and assumptions that affect the application of accounting policies and reported amounts of assets and liabilities, income and expenses. All estimates and assumptions are made to the best of management’s knowledge and belief in order to fairly present the financial position and results of operations of the Elevator Technology Business; they are reviewed on an ongoing basis. Actual results may differ from these estimates. Accounting estimates and judgments made by management in the application of IFRS that have a significant effect on the Combined Financial Statements are in particular relevant for the following issues: _Business combinations_ As a result of acquisitions the Elevator Technology Business recognized goodwill in its statement of financial position. In a business combination, all identifiable assets, liabilities and contingent liabilities acquired are recorded at the date of acquisition at their respective fair value. One of the most significant estimates relates to the determination of the fair value of these assets and liabilities. Land, buildings and equipment are usually independently appraised while marketable securities are valued at market price. If any intangible assets are identified, depending on the type of intangible asset and the complexity of determining its fair value, the Elevator Technology Business either consults with an independent external valuation expert or develops the fair value internally, using an appropriate valuation technique which is generally based on a forecast of the total expected future net cash flows. These evaluations are linked closely to the assumptions made by management regarding the future performance of the assets concerned and any changes in the discount rate applied. F-59 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: In fiscal year 2018/2019 the Elevator Technology Business adopted the following standards, interpretations and amendments to already existing standards and interpretations that, with the exemption of IFRS 9 and IFRS 15, do not have a material impact on the Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business: In May 2014 the IASB issued the new standard IFRS 15 “Revenue from Contracts with Customers”. The purpose of the new standard on revenue recognition is to bring together the large number of existing guidelines contained in various standards and interpretations. At the same time it establishes uniform core principles to be applied to all industries and all types of revenue transactions. In April 2016 clarifications to IFRS 15 were issued relating mainly to the identification of separate performance obligations as well as the definition of principal and agent. The thyssenkrupp Group adopted IFRS 15 for the 2018/2019 fiscal year beginning on October 1, 2018 (IFRS 15 effective date). The full retrospective approach to initial application was applied, i.e. the cumulative transition effects were included directly in retained earnings at the start of the comparative period on October 1, 2017. For the Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business an additional comparative period from October 1, 2016 to September 30, 2017 is presented. According to the full retrospective approach, IFRS 15 was applied starting as of October 1, 2016 for the Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business (i.e. the cumulative transition effects were included directly in invested equity attributable to the thyssenkrupp Group at the start of the comparative period on October 1, 2016). With this the Elevator Technology Business is making use of the practical expedients provided in IFRS 15. In this connection at October 1, 2016 in particular contracts that begin and are completed within the same fiscal year or are completed at October 1, 2016 were not restated. The application of IFRS 15 results in contract assets, mainly relating to reclassifications of receivables from construction contracts to the contract assets required to be presented separately under IFRS 15. Further, the application of IFRS 15 results in contract liabilities mainly due to reclassifications from current non-financial liabilities, which relate to reclassifications of liabilities under construction contracts and to reclassifications of prepayments received. In addition, due prepayments not yet received in cash from customers are recognized as contract liabilities as explicitly required by IFRS 15. The IFRS 15 transition effects on the combined statements of financial position as of October 1, 2016, September 30, 2017 and September 30, 2018 were analyzed. The changed recognition of due prepayments not yet received in cash leads to an increase of trade accounts receivables and contract liabilities amounting to F-61 -----

Subsubsection Text: Effects of adoption of IFRS 9 on total invested equity . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** (15) The classification and measurement of financial assets under IFRS 9 is based on the financial asset’s cash flow characteristics and on the company’s business model for managing the financial assets. If a debt instrument is held with the objective of collecting contractual cash flows and if the cash flows are solely payments of principal and interest, the instrument is recognized at amortized cost. At the Elevator Technology Business this mainly concerns trade accounts receivable, contract assets, and cash and cash equivalents. If the cash flow conditions are met but the debt instrument is held both to collect contractual cash flows and to sell, the instrument is measured at fair value in equity (with reclassification). At the Elevator Technology Business this mainly concerns securities (debt instruments). For equity instruments not held for trading, the Elevator Technology Business has consistently exercised the option to recognize future changes in fair value in profit or loss. Derivatives that do not qualify for hedge accounting are also recognized at fair value in profit or loss. F-63 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: 1) Lar: Loans and receivables, Afs: Available-for-sale financial assets, Hft: Held for trading The adoption of IFRS 9 does not impact financial liabilities. Under the new impairment model (expected loss model) expected losses are reported and forward-looking information is used to a greater extent. The new impairment rules are applied to debt instruments, lease receivables, trade accounts receivable, and contract assets recognized at amortized cost or at fair value in equity. The expected credit loss is generally calculated by multiplying the three parameters probability of default, carrying value of the financial asset, and loss given default. The Elevator Technology Business applies the simplified impairment model under IFRS 9 and reports lifetime expected losses for all trade accounts receivable and contract assets. For all other financial assets twelve-month expected credit losses are reported. Owing to the short maturities, these generally correspond to lifetime expected losses at the Elevator Technology Business. The Elevator Technology Business has developed the following model to determine the expected credit loss, in particular to determine the expected default rates for trade accounts receivable. The probability of default is determined on the basis of historical default rates taking forward-looking information into account. Consideration is also given to the respective business model, customer groups, and economic environment of the region. Default is generally assumed after 360 days. The expected credit loss for other loans and receivables is determined on the basis of external credit information. As before, financial assets are fully or partially impaired on the basis of individual allowances if it is reasonable to assume that they can no longer be fully realized, e.g. because the due date has long passed, or owing to insolvency or similar proceedings. F-64 -----

Subsubsection Text: For hedge accounting the Elevator Technology Business exercised the option to apply the rules of IFRS 9 prospectively from October 1, 2018. All designated hedges existing at September 30, 2018 meet the hedge accounting requirements of IFRS 9 and will be continued. In some cases the hedging of components is possible. The option of initially reporting hedge costs (forward element and currency basis spread) in connection with designated foreign currency derivatives separately as costs of hedging in other comprehensive income is used prospectively in fiscal year 2018/2019. Reclassification to profit or loss takes place when the hedged item affects profit or loss. This will further reduce earnings volatility in the future. The Elevator Technology Business continues to use the spot-to-spot method to measure hedge effectiveness. At the transition date there were no impacts in the area of hedge accounting. Furthermore in fiscal year 2018/2019, the Elevator Technology Business adopted the following standards, interpretations and amendments to already existing standards that do not have a material impact on the Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business: - Amendments to IFRS 2 “Share-based Payment“: “Classification and Measurement of Share-based Payment Transactions“, issued in June 2016 - Annual Improvements to IFRSs 2014-2016 Cycle, issued in December 2016 - IFRIC 22: “Foreign Currency Transactions and Advance Consideration“, issued in December 2016

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Issued accounting standards that have not been adopted in fiscal year 2018/2019
Subsubsection Text: Adoption of the new standard IFRS 16 “Leases” issued in January 2016 is mandatory at the Elevator Technology Business from October 1, 2019. Under the previous lease standard IAS 17 payment obligations for operating leases are only to be disclosed in the Notes. In the future, the rights and obligations resulting from these leases must be recognized on the statement of financial position as right-of-use assets and lease liabilities upon transfer of control. The Elevator Technology Business will introduce the standard using the modified retrospective approach and apply IFRS 16 to all contracts previously identified as lease contracts under IAS 17 and IFRIC 4. When using the modified retrospective approach, prior-year comparative figures do not need to be restated, so the transition effects at the Elevator Technology Business will generally be stated as an adjustment to invested equity attributable to the thyssenkrupp Group at October 1, 2019. In addition the Elevator Technology Business will recognize the right-of-use assets in the amount of the associated lease liabilities at the date of initial application. As a result the adoption of IFRS 16 at the Elevator Technology Business will have no effect on total equity at October 1, 2019. The Elevator Technology Business will make use of the following practical expedients provided by IFRS 16: For short-term leases with a term of less than twelve months (and no option to buy) and for leases of low-value assets, no assets or liabilities will be recognized. This also applies to leases which at the date of initial application have a remaining term of less than one year. The Elevator Technology Business will not perform impairment testing and will instead assess the leases immediately before October 1, 2019 in accordance with IAS 37 “Provisions, contingent liabilities and contingent assets” to determine whether the leases are onerous contracts. F-65 -----

Subsubsection Text: Thereof: paid in cash and cash equivalents . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 9 21 In the year ended September 30, 2019, the Elevator Technology Business acquired the elevator business of Nashville Machine Elevator Co., Inc. via asset deal effective May 31, 2019 and all shares of O´Keefe Elevator Company, Inc. effective July 1, 2019. Both acquired businesses are exclusive distributors for thyssenkrupp Elevator and service providers with strong market positions in their respective local markets, Central Tennessee for Nashville Machine Elevator Co. and Nebraska and Iowa for O´Keefe Elevator Company, Inc. Both acquisitions aim at achieving direct access to these local markets supporting thyssenkrupp Elevator´s long-term trajectory of growth in the USA. The purchase price allocation of Nashville Machine Elevator Co. has not yet been finalized due to the pending identification of the acquired intangible assets. Based on the preliminary purchase price allocation, the acquisition of the business of Nashville Machine Elevator Co. affected the Combined Financial Statements of the Elevator Technology Business as presented below:

Subsubsection Text: The goodwill reflects the well-established and long standing customer relationships of the acquired business. The goodwill is fully tax deductible with straight-line amortization over fifteen years. Since the new acquired business joined the Elevator Technology Business effective as of May 31, 2019, it generated sales of €15 million and net income of €1 million which are included in the combined statement of profit or loss in the year ended September 30, 2019. If the acquisition had taken place on October 1, 2018, the company would have contributed sales of €45 million and income before taxes of €8 million to the combined statement of profit or loss. The purchase price allocation of the O’Keefe Elevator Company has also not yet been finalized due to remaining clarification of O’Keefe’s tax base. Subsubsection Text: As of September 30, 2019 the Elevator Technology Business acquired and recognized the thyssenkrupp brand as an intangible asset according to IAS 38 with an amount of €1,080 million. For the assessment of whether the useful life of the brand is finite or indefinite, following factors were mainly, but not exhaustive, considered: - the expected usage of the brand by the Elevator Technology Business and whether the brand could be managed efficiently by another management team; - typical product life cycles for this kind of brand and estimates of useful lives of similar assets that are used in a similar way; - the level of maintenance expenditure required to obtain the expected future economic benefits from the brand and the Elevator Technology Business’s ability and intention to reach such a level; - the period of control over the brand and legal or similar limits on the use of the brand. The brand is regarded as having an indefinite useful life, as based on an analysis of all of the relevant factors, there is no foreseeable limit to the period over which the asset is expected to generate net cash inflows for the Elevator Technology Business. Therefore the brand will not be amortized. Furthermore it will be tested for impairment in accordance with IAS 38.108 and IAS 36; for more details regarding the adjustment of the agreement in March 2020 and the related impact refer to the disclosures in Note 32.

Subsubsection Text: In fiscal years ended September 30, 2019, 2018 and 2017, employees of the Elevator Technology Business participated in the share-based compensation programs of the thyssenkrupp Group. For the purposes of the Combined Financial Statements, the expenses and obligations arising from share-based compensation were recognized in the financial statements of those Elevator Technology Business companies which incurred the expenses or obligations, respectively.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The long-term incentive plan (LTI) is a long-term oriented compensation component which issues stock rights to eligible participants. Plan participants are Executive Board members of thyssenkrupp AG and several other selected executive employees. As of September 30, 2019, 368,511 stock rights were issued in the 7th installment, 371,175 stock rights in the 8th installment and 535,858 stock rights in the 9th installment of the LTI (September 30, 2018: 442,936 stock rights in the 6th installment, 421,186 stock rights in the 7th installment and 411,997 stock rights in the 8th installment; September 30, 2017: 350,779 stock rights in the 5th installment, 461,073 stock rights in the 6th installment and 431,285 stock rights in the 7th installment) for the selected executive employees of the Elevator Technology Business. For installments of the LTI granted inclusive of fiscal year 2013/2014 (inclusive of the 4th installment), the number of stock rights issued based on individually fixed euro amounts will be adjusted at the end of each three-year tkVA performance period based on the average thyssenkrupp Value Added (tkVA) over this period, beginning October 1 of the year the stock rights were granted, compared to the average tkVA over the previous three fiscal year period. For the installments of the LTI granted beginning with fiscal year 2014/2015 (starting with the 5th installment) the number of stock rights issued will be adjusted at the end of the respective three-year tkVA performance period based on the average tkVA over this period compared with a tkVA target value set in advance. The amount of payment for an installment is calculated by multiplying the adjusted number of stock rights by the average price of thyssenkrupp’s stock in the first three months after the end of the tkVA performance period, with the result that the term of each installment extends over four fiscal years in total. To determine the fair value of the stock rights used to calculate the pro-rata liability as of the balance sheet date forward prices of the thyssenkrupp stock are calculated taking into account the existing caps. The forward calculation is carried out for predefined periods (averaging periods) taking into account the thyssenkrupp stock price and the euro interest rate curve as of the balance sheet date and the dividends assumed to be paid until the maturity of the stock rights. The following assumptions were used for the determination of the fair values as of September 30, 2017, 2018 and 2019, respectively:

Subsubsection Text: In the 2nd quarter of 2018/2019, the 6th installment of the LTI was settled with a payment of €17.69 per stock right and a payment of €5 million in total, respectively. In the 2nd quarter of 2017/2018, the 5th installment of the LTI was settled with a payment of €23.20 per stock right and a payment of €5 million in total, respectively. In the 2nd quarter of 2016/2017, the 4th installment of the LTI was settled with a payment of €21.92 per stock right and a payment of €16 million in total, respectively. Also in fiscal year 2018/2019 the 9th installment of the LTI was granted to the Executive Board of thyssenkrupp AG and additional executive employees. In total in fiscal year ended September 30, 2019 the Elevator Technology Business recorded an income of €10 million from the incentive plans due to the decline of the stock price and the average tkVA (2018: expense of €7 million; 2017: expense of €9 million). The liability arising from the LTI amounts to €5 million as of September 30, 2019 (2018: €20 million; 2017: €18 million). For fiscal years 2010/2011 until 2014/2015, for Executive Board members of thyssenkrupp Elevator IaO 20% of the performance bonus granted for the respective fiscal year was obligatorily converted into thyssenkrupp AG stock rights to be paid out after the expiration of three fiscal years based on the average thyssenkrupp share price in the 4th quarter of the 3rd fiscal year. In 2018/2019 the Elevator Technology Business recorded an expense of €0 million (2017/2018: €0 million; 2016/2017: €0.2 million) associated with this compensation component; due the termination of the program there is no obligation as of September 30, 2019 (2018: €0.5 million; 2017: €1.1 million). In the year ended September 30, 2019 a payment of €0.5 million occurred relating to the stock rights granted in 2014/2015 (2018: €0.6 million; 2017: €0.7 million). F-85 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The Elevator Technology Business maintains company pensions designed as defined benefit plans and defined contribution plans in various regions of the world. Those plans either are organized on an individual basis or via branch-wide solutions (“multi-employer plan”). Defined contribution plans are generally funded by compulsory, contractually or voluntary granted contributions paid into legally separated pension funds. The contributions are borne either by the employer or as a matching of employer and employees whereby the employer has no further obligation beyond the payment of contributions into the plan. All contributions are shown as personnel expense. Defined benefit plans are granted under consideration of country-specific Regulation (e.g. local legislation) or on voluntary basis. The plans are either funded via legally separated assets (“plan assets”) or directly funded by book reserves. The book reserve set out in the statement of financial position reflects the net value (obligations or asset) of defined benefit obligation and plan assets. The major exposure of defined benefit plans exists in Germany, Korea, France and Switzerland which covers 91% (2018: 91%; 2017: 91%) of the total defined benefit obligation respectively 89% (2018: 88%; 2017: 88%) of the plan assets of the Elevator Technology Business. For historical reasons a wide variety of voluntary defined benefit pension plans (DB plans) exist in Germany based on different risk profiles. As a rule such plans provide benefits in the event of disability and/or death or on reaching a specified age limit. The plans are mainly based on individual or collective arrangements. In the past the employer-funded pension plans in Germany generally offered annuity payments on defined benefits. These defined benefit plans (including final-salary pension plans, career-average pension plans, etc.) were established first in the far past but replaced at the turn of the millennium by contribution based pension DB plans with a risk-optimized form of payment (lump sum, installments, or annuity with limited indexation). Particularly for newly recruited professionals and managers, the “flexplan” was introduced at January 1, 2017 and replaced the last open “benefits plan” at thyssenkrupp. The “flexplan” is a contribution-based pension plan with a minimum guarantee interest of 1%. A key element to increase employees’ share in responsibility for their company retirement benefits is salary conversion, which is an option under all pension schemes currently open for new hires. Those plans additionally offer employer-funded matching contributions as an incentive. With regard to the funding of the company pension plans, particularly the “flexplan” is funded by a Contractual Trust Agreement (CTA) with a positive effect on the external funding level. The majority of Elevator Technology companies outside Germany also provide pension plans for their employees. These plans are in some cases based on statutory requirements or collective agreements (e.g. Korea, France or Switzerland), but in other cases they are provided by the companies of the Elevator Technology Business on a voluntary basis (e.g. Brazil). The range of benefits provided under the plans differs widely depending on local arrangements, extending from defined contribution plans to final-salary defined-benefit schemes with annuity payment. To safeguard the payments of benefits of DB plans, the pension plans outside Germany are funded to a much greater extent by externally separated assets. This is due in part to legal minimum funding standards, which require full external funding of the obligations or a financing under a capital funding system. For further information regarding the composition and investment strategy refer to the disclosures of the plan assets. F-86 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Notes to the Combined Financial Statements (Continued) 14 Accrued pension and similar obligations (Continued)
Subsubsection Text: The defined benefit plan in the USA was closed and frozen in the past right before the company entered into an annuity purchase with an insurance company taking the obligation to pay the benefits in the future directly to the retirees. In so far no obligations remain with the Elevator Technology company in the USA related to this defined benefit plan any more. As a replacement the company operates defined contribution plans in accordance with the “Internal Revenue Code 401(k)”. Beside such 401(k) plans, the Elevator Technology companies in the USA participate in a union-organized multiemployer plan (National Elevator Industry Pension Plan—“NEIPP”) for their unionized employees on the basis of a collective agreement. This plan is a defined benefit plan, but is accounted for as a defined contribution plan due to insufficient information about the allocation of assets. The risks from NEIPP differ from company-specific plans with regard to the jointly managed pension assets which can potentially also be used to cover obligations of other participating employers. When participating plan sponsors stop making ongoing contributions, the remaining plan sponsors collectively make up the unfunded deficit, with withdrawal from the plan regularly requiring the payment of a withdrawal contribution in order to limit the risk for the remaining plan sponsors. Material risks associated with the different types of pension plans include above all financial risks as well as risks in the areas of inflation and biometrics. Inflation risks which could lead to an increase in benefit obligations exist because some of the plans are based on (final) salary and in some cases annual pension modules are directly linked to current salaries (defined contribution plans). To this extent a rise in salaries above the salary/career trends assumed in the valuation of the obligation would also require a direct increase in the provisions (past service effect in the case of (final) salary pensions) or the future service cost (defined contribution plans). In addition, further charges could result from the need for a cost-of-living adjustment in excess of the assumed pension trend during the pension payment phase, which would lead to an immediate increase in the provisions. A significant number of the pension plans in Germany are required by law to provide a cost-of-living adjustment. A cost-of-living adjustment may also be required under (collective bargaining) agreements or agreed on a voluntary/discretionary basis. Biometric risks can result either from early benefit claims (risk of sudden changes to the statement of financial position after death or invalidity) or from underestimated life expectancies (longevity risk) and could likewise result in costs to the company due to unexpected increases in provisions and early cash outflows. Risks from changes to the discount rate are purely statement of financial position-related, i.e. the provisions are adjusted directly against equity without affecting income. Cash outflows are not affected. Under the pension plans in Germany, individual beneficiaries are in part counted more than once due to entitlements under different components of the pension systems. The breakdown of total of pension plans is as follows: In the year ended September 30, 2017, the settlements relate mainly to the replacement of a DB plan for the active workforce and simultaneous transition to a defined contribution plan as well as settlements of vested pension rights of former employees in the USA. established for each country as a function of their respective economic conditions. Discount rates are generally determined based on market yields of AA-rated corporate bonds of appropriate term and currency. As of September 30, 2019, the discount rate for pension obligations in Germany was 0.70% (2018: 1.70%; 2017: 1.90%). Expected contribution of the Elevator Technology Business in fiscal year 2019/2020 is €18 million (2018/2019: €9 million; 2017/2018: €7 million) related to its plan assets.

Subsubsection Text: The Elevator Technology Business also maintains domestic and foreign defined contribution plans. Amounts contributed by the Elevator Technology Business under such plans are based upon percentage of the employees’ salary or the amount of contributions made by the employees. The total cost of pension plans accounted for as defined contribution plans in the current fiscal year was €59 million (2018: €54 million; 2017: €54 million). In addition, contributions paid to public/state pension insurance institutions amounted to €162 million (2018: €186 million; 2017: €182 million). F-91 -----

Subsection Title: Notes to the Combined Financial Statements (Continued) 14 Accrued pension and similar obligations (Continued) Multi-employer plans
Subsubsection Text: In addition to the NEIPP, some companies in a few other countries also participate in multi-employer plans (e.g. Netherlands), although the NEIPP is by some distance the biggest plan of this kind. Unless otherwise indicated, the assessment of risk („zone status“) under Internal Revenue Code Section 432 and the Multi-Employer Pension Reform Act 2014 relates to the reporting dates June 30, 2017, June 30, 2018 and June 30, 2019, respectively. The NEIPP was not in critical or endangered status on either of these dates. The zone status is based on data provided by the NEIPP and certified by the plan actuary. The NEIPP is currently classified as “green zone” with a funding level of at least 80%. Due to the sufficient level of funding, there has been no need for either a financial improvement plan or a rehabilitation plan in recent years. The Elevator Technology Business is one of the four biggest sponsors of the NEIPP, paying more than 5% of total annual contributions to the NEIPP. For the year ended September 30, 2019, the Elevator Technology Business paid a contribution of €87 million to the plan (2018: €79 million; 2017: €80 million). The expected contributions for fiscal year ended September 30, 2020 are €82 million.

Subsubsection Text: are non-current. Provisions of €259 million (2018: €220 million; 2017: €223 million) have a remaining term of more than one year. Provisions for employee compensation and benefit costs primarily represent employment anniversary bonuses and obligations for the management incentive plans, while social plan and related costs pertaining to personnel related structural measures are reflected in the provision for restructuring activities. Pension related obligations for partial retirement agreements and early retirement programs, partly resulting from restructurings, are part of the provision for pensions and similar obligations. Product warranties and product defects represent the Elevator Technology Business’s responsibility for the proper functioning of the goods sold (product warranty) as well as the obligation that arise from the use of the products sold (product defect). Provisions for other contractual costs represent pending losses from uncompleted contracts. The provision for restructurings consists of provisions for employee termination benefits and exit costs which have been established by operating divisions for costs incurred in connection with activities which do not generate any future economic benefits for the Elevator Technology Business. Restructurings are being carried out in all business units. Other provisions include provisions for environmental obligations and other risks from individual items not allocable to other positions. Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Elevator cartel, potentially injured parties asserted claims for damages against thyssenkrupp AG and companies of the thyssenkrupp Group in and out of court. Some of the claims have not yet been quantified. The legal proceedings are pending in Germany, Belgium, Austria and the Netherlands and are at various stages; in some cases proceedings have already been mutually settled, claims have been withdrawn or were dismissed. The Elevator Technology Business has set aside provisions for those pending claims which, in its opinion, will probably lead to cash outflows. Provisions include retentions on insured claims of four users of the Elevator Technology Business products in the USA requesting individual damage payments for severe injuries and—in one case—fatality. Creditors of a former owner of an acquired business in Brazil claim reversal of the acquisition in order to access the acquired assets for satisfaction of claims against the former owner. A Chinese customer sues the Elevator Technology Business for delays in elevator installation and claims damage payments for increased construction cost. South Korean employees claim adjustment of calculations of ordinary wages.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Elevator cartel, potentially injured parties asserted claims for damages against thyssenkrupp AG and companies of the thyssenkrupp Group in and out of court. Provisions include retentions on insured claims of four users of the Elevator Technology Business products in the USA requesting individual damage payments for severe injuries and—in one case—fatality. The Elevator Technology Business faces a law suit relating to the architectural planning and execution of new headquarter building in the Middle East. Creditors of a former owner of an acquired business in Brazil claim reversal of the acquisition in order to access the acquired assets for satisfaction of claims against the former owner.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: In connection with the Elevator cartel, potentially injured parties asserted claims for damages against thyssenkrupp AG and companies of the thyssenkrupp Group in and out of court. Some of the claims have not yet been quantified. The legal proceedings are pending in Belgium, Austria and the Netherlands and are at various stages; in some cases proceedings have already been mutually settled, claims have been withdrawn or were dismissed. The Elevator Technology Business has set aside provisions for those pending claims which, in its opinion, will probably lead to cash outflows. Provisions include retentions on insured claims of two users of the Elevator Technology Business products in the USA requesting individual damage payments for severe injuries. F-93 ----- Creditors of a former owner of an acquired business in Brazil claim reversal of the acquisition in order to access the acquired assets for satisfaction of claims against the former owner. The Elevator Technology Business is in dispute with a French customer over liquidated damages relating to defective products and delays. In addition further legal and arbitration actions and official investigations and proceedings have been filed against Elevator Technology companies or may be initiated or filed in the future. Disputes in connection with the acquisition or disposal of companies or company units may lead to partial repayment of the purchase price or to the payment of damages or to tax charges. Furthermore, damage claims may be payable to contractual partners, customers, consortium partners and subcontractors under performance contracts. Predicting the progress and results of lawsuits involves considerable difficulties and uncertainties. This means that lawsuits, official investigations and proceedings as well as claims not disclosed separately could also individually or together with other legal disputes, official investigations and proceedings as well as claims have a negative and also potentially major future impact on the Elevator Technology Business’s net assets, financial position and results of operations of the Elevator Technology Business. However, at present the Elevator Technology Business does not expect pending lawsuits, official investigations and proceedings as well as claims not explained separately in this section to have a major negative impact on the Elevator Technology Business’s net assets, financial position and results of operations.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The carrying amounts of trade accounts receivable measured at amortized cost, other current receivables as well as cash and cash equivalents equal their fair values due to the short terms. For trade accounts receivable measured at fair value, the fair value equals the carrying amount less impairment losses recognized in other comprehensive income. Equity and debt instruments are in general measured at fair value, which is based to the extent available on market prices as of the balance sheet date. When no quoted market prices in an active market are available, equity and debt instruments are measured by discounting future cash flows based on current market interest rates over the remaining term of the financial instruments. The fair value of foreign currency forward transactions is determined on the basis of the middle spot exchange rate applicable as of the balance sheet date, and taking account of forward premiums or discounts arising for the respective remaining contract term compared to the contracted forward exchange rate. Common methods for calculating option prices are used for foreign currency options. The fair value of an option is influenced not only by the remaining term of an option, but also by other factors, such as current amount and volatility of the underlying exchange or base rate. The carrying amounts of trade accounts receivable and other current liabilities equal their fair values due to the short remaining terms. The fair value of fixed rate long-term financial liabilities equals the present value of F-100 -----

Subsubsection Text: expected cash flows. Discounting is based on interest rates applicable as of the balance sheet date. The carrying amounts of floating rate liabilities approximately equal their fair values. Financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value could be categorized in the following three level fair value hierarchy: Gains and losses arising from changes in fair value of foreign currency derivatives that do not comply with the hedge accounting requirements under IAS 39 are included in the “derivatives that do not qualifying for hedge accounting” category. The category “financial liabilities measured at amortized cost” mainly comprises of interest expenses on financial liabilities as well as gains and losses on foreign currency liabilities. Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The fair value hierarchy reflects the significance of the inputs used to determine fair values. Financial instruments with fair value measurement based on quoted prices in active markets are disclosed in level 1. In level 2 determination of fair values is based on observable inputs, e.g. foreign exchange rates. Level 3 comprises financial instruments for which the fair value measurement is based on unobservable inputs using recognized valuation models. In the reporting year there were no reclassifications between level 1 and level 2. Financial liabilities measured at amortized cost with a carrying amount of €2,773 million (2018: €1,575 million; 2017: €1,733 million) have a fair value of €2,773 million (2018: €1,575 million; 2017: €1,732 million) that was determined based on fair value measurement attributable to level 2.

Subsection Title: Netting of financial assets and financial liabilities
Subsubsection Text: In general, master netting arrangements exist only for derivative financial instruments in the Elevator Technology Business that however totally or partially do not meet the offsetting criteria under IAS 32. In these cases a right of offsetting is enforceable only on termination of the contract on the grounds of a major breach of contract or insolvency of one of the contractual parties. The gross amounts for these derivatives are therefore presented separately in the statement of financial position. Potential offsetting exists in the amount of €2 million (2018: €2 million; 2017: €2 million). Subsubsection Text: If a hedging relationship does not meet the requirements for hedge accounting in accordance with the conditions under IFRS 9 (previous years: IAS 39) or hedge accounting is economically not reasonable, the derivative financial instrument is recognized as a derivative that does not qualify for hedge accounting. The resulting impact on profit or loss is shown in the table on net gains and losses from financial instruments by measurement categories. This item also includes embedded derivatives. They exist in the Elevator Technology Business in the way that regular supply and service transactions with suppliers and customers abroad are not concluded in the functional currency (local currency) of either contracting parties.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Being a global business, the Elevator Technology Business is exposed to financial risks in the form of credit risks (default risk), liquidity risks and market risks (foreign currency and interest rate risks) during the course of ordinary activities. The aim of risk management is to limit the risks arising from operating activities and associated financing requirements by applying selected derivate and non-derivative hedging instruments. Within the framework of risk management, financial risks and credit risks must be avoided as far as possible, compensated by a risk portfolio, passed on to third parties or limited (principle of risk aversion).

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk (default risk) is the risk of the Elevator Technology Business incurring financial losses due to the non-fulfillment or partial fulfillment of existing debt obligations. Credit risk management is governed by corporate guidelines. Companies and business operating activities of the Elevator Technology Business are required to implement credit risk management in accordance with these guidelines. In order to minimize default risks (credit risks) from the use of financial instruments, such transactions are only concluded with counterparties that meet our internal minimum requirements of the Elevator Technology Business. Predominantly, the Elevator Technology Business concludes its financial instruments currently and in the future with thyssenkrupp AG. Therefore, thyssenkrupp AG represents the main counterparty subject to credit risk. The Elevator Technology Business generally secures default risks with suitable advance and progress payments. Only in seldom cases, in case that a credit risk analysis provides a higher default risk, letters of credit and payment guarantees from banks, insurance companies and management companies are requested. In order to minimize default risks from operating activities, the corporate guidelines provide for the assessment of default risk based on the risk profile of the business partner using suitable internal and, where available, external information, such as ratings and credit reports, and the estimation of a financial risk exposure of the respective business transaction from the Elevator Technology Business perspective. The Elevator Technology Business takes a credit decision for each business transaction with each business partner using the aforementioned approach. Taking into account the individual characteristics of its customer structures and business models, the Elevator Technology Business lays down clear process rules for determining which measures are to be taken in the event of payment default in order to mitigate the maximum default risk as far as possible. Transactions whose value exceeds specified materiality thresholds, especially in the area of major sales contracts, also require prior approval at the different management levels inside the Elevator Technology Business. Among other things, the amount and hedging of default risks are assessed.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity risk is the risk that the Elevator Technology Business is unable to meet its existing or future obligations due to insufficient availability of cash or cash equivalents. F-106 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: Market risk is the risk that fair values or future cash flows of non-derivative or derivative financial instruments will fluctuate due to changes in risk factors. Among market risks relevant to the Elevator Technology Business are foreign currency and interest rate risks. Associated with these risks are fluctuations in income, equity and cash flow. The following analyses and amounts determined by means of sensitivity analyses represent hypothetical, futureoriented data that can differ from actual outcomes because of unforeseeable developments in financial markets. Moreover, non-financial or non-quantifiable risks, such as business risks, are not considered here. F-107 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Notes to the Combined Financial Statements (Continued) 21 Financial instruments (Continued) Foreign currency risk exposure—Foreign currency hedging is used to fix prices on the basis of hedging rates as
Subsubsection Text: protection against any unfavorable exchange rate fluctuations in the future. Hedging periods are generally based on the maturities of underlying transactions. Foreign currency derivative contracts usually have maturities of twelve months or less, but can also be up to six years in single exceptional cases. The US dollar is the only relevant risk variable for sensitivity analyses under IFRS 7, as the vast majority of foreign currency cash flows occurs in US dollars. As hedging transactions are generally used to hedge underlying transactions, opposite effects in underlying and hedging transactions are almost entirely offset over the total period. Thus, the currency risk exposure described here results from hedging relationships with off-balance sheet underlying transactions, i.e. hedges of firm commitments and forecasted sales. Based on our analysis, the US dollar exposure as of September 30, 2019 was as follows: If the euro had been 10% stronger against the US dollar as of September 30, 2019, the hedge reserve in equity and fair value of hedging transactions would have been €0 million (2018: €1 million; 2017: €2 million) higher and earnings resulting from the measurement as of the balance sheet date €2 million (2018: €2 million; 2017: €2 million) higher. If the euro had been 10% weaker against the US dollar as of September 30, 2019, the hedge reserve in equity and fair value of hedging transactions would have been €0 million (2018: €1 million; 2017: €3 million) lower and earnings resulting from the measurement as of the balance sheet date €3 million (2018: €2 million; 2017: €4 million) lower.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Interest rate risk—Interest rate instruments can result in cash flow risks, opportunity effects, as well as interest
Subsubsection Text: rate risks affecting the statement of financial position and earnings. Refinancing and variable-rate financial instruments are subject to cash flow risk which expresses the uncertainty of future interest payments. Cash flow risk is measured by means of cash flow sensitivity. Opportunity effects arise from non-derivatives, as these are measured at amortized cost rather than fair value, in contrast to interest derivatives. This difference, the so-called opportunity effect, affects neither the statement of financial position nor the statement of profit or loss. Opportunity effects and interest rate risks affecting the statement of financial position and earnings are determined by calculating fair value sensitivity analyses and changes. As of September 30, 2019, a +100 /(20) basis point parallel shift in yield curves is assumed for all currencies in interest analyses. The parallel downward shift is limited to (20) basis points to account for continued low interest rates with in part negative interest rates. Negative interest rates are included in the current analysis. The analysis results in the opportunities (positive values) and risks (negative values) shown in the following table:

The counterpart of these transactions is mainly the ultimate holding company thyssenkrupp AG. The transactions resulted in the recognition of receivables and liabilities between the Elevator Technology Business and the companies of the remaining thyssenkrupp Group, especially thyssenkrupp AG. Receivables or payables relating to payments from/due to the remaining thyssenkrupp Group under tax group arrangements are presented within the line items Receivables—miscellaneous and Liabilities—miscellaneous.

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Notes to the Combined Financial Statements (Continued) 22 Related parties (Continued) Other services
Subsubsection Text: In addition to the contractual services specified above, the remaining thyssenkrupp Group provided services to the Elevator Technology Business through thyssenkrupp AG, service companies, and regional holding companies. These companies principally furnish central corporate services, such as tax and legal, IT services, corporate communications, personnel-related services, accounting, controlling, financial services and treasury. The cost of such services provided by the remaining thyssenkrupp Group to the Elevator Technology Business totaled €66 million in the fiscal year ended September 30, 2019 (2018: €71 million; 2017: €98 million). Furthermore the allocation of the thyssenkrupp brand resulted in expenses of €142 million in the fiscal year ended September 30, 2019 (2018: €139 million; 2017: €114 million). Effective September 30, 2019 the Elevator Technology Business purchased the right to use the thyssenkrupp brand for certain classified sectors relevant for the Elevator Technology Business for a purchase price of €1,080 million.

Subsubsection Text: The Elevator Technology Business offers global urban passenger transportation systems throughout the entire lifecycle. The business units are in line with the internal organizational and reporting structure and represent the segments in accordance with IFRS 8.

Subsubsection Text: The business unit comprises the manufacturing, new installation, modernization and maintenance of elevators, escalators and walkways for countries in Europe and Africa.

Subsubsection Text: The business unit comprises the manufacturing, new installation, modernization and maintenance of elevators, escalators and walkways for countries in the Middle East, Asia, Australia and New Zealand. These three reportable segments mainly comprise the elevator and escalator business (excluding mobility home solutions).

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: The business unit manages globally customized mobility home solutions, i.e., the manufacturing, installation and maintenance of stairlifts, home elevators and platform lifts as well as Passenger Boarding Bridges primarily for the access to airplanes. Additionally Corporate Elevator provides certain functions and services to the operating businesses of the Elevator Technology Business, e.g., Financing, R&D, Providing IP, Recruiting, etc.

Subsubsection Text: intercompany interest income. The allocations of thyssenkrupp AG include corporate costs and non-operational effects that were historically recorded on parent company level and previously not allocated or charged to the Elevator Technology Business. The accounting principles for the segments are the same as those described for the Elevator Technology Business in the summary of significant accounting principles. Elevator Technology Business’s key earnings performance indicator is adjusted EBIT (Earnings Before Interest and Taxes). Adjusted EBIT is calculated according to economic criteria and is independent from IFRS rules. It provides information on the profitability of a unit and contains all elements of the income statement relating to operating performance. This also includes items of financial income/expense that can be characterized as operational, including income and expense from investments where there is a long-term intention to hold the assets. It is adjusted for special items, i.e. excluding disposal losses/gains from M&A, restructuring expenses, impairment losses/impairment reversals and other non-operating expenses and income. It is more suitable for comparing operating performance over several periods. Operating net working capital is the key indicator for measuring liquidity and solvency in operating activities. It is primarily comprised of inventories, trade accounts receivable, trade accounts payable and net advance payments. Total assets in accordance with the combined statement of financial position can be reconciled to operating net working capital as follows:

Subsection Title: Notes to the Combined Financial Statements (Continued) 32 Subsequent events (Continued) Legal restructuring of the thyssenkrupp ET Group
Subsubsection Text: In the course of the legal restructuring, all companies that were not yet controlled by the Company, but by the thyssenkrupp Group in the reporting period for the Combined Financial Statements and are assigned to the Elevator Technology Business due to their business activities, have been legally transferred from the thyssenkrupp Group to the thyssenkrupp ET Group. In the context of the legal reorganization, the following companies and operations have been transferred and are now direct or indirect subsidiaries of the Company: - October 10, 2019, thyssenkrupp Airport Systems Co. (Zhongshan) Ltd., Zhongshan/Guangdong, China - October 10, 2019, thyssenkrupp Escalator Co. (China) Ltd., Zhongshan/Guangdong, China - October 17, 2019, thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding France S.A.S., Puteaux Cedex, France - October 18, 2019, thyssenkrupp Access Corp., Kansas City/Missouri, USA - October 18, 2019, thyssenkrupp Airport Systems Inc., Fort Worth/Texas, USA - October 18, 2019, thyssenkrupp Elevator Americas Corp., Wilmington/Delaware, USA - October 18, 2019, thyssenkrupp Real Estate North America LLC., Chicago, Illinois, USA; this company was renamed to thyssenkrupp Elevator Real Estate USA LLC, Chicago, Illinois, USA on December 16, 2019 - October 24, 2019, thyssenkrupp Elevator (Singapore) Pte.Ltd., Singapore, Singapore - October 25, 2019, Marohn thyssenkrupp Elevator Co. Ltd., Changshu City, Jiangsu Province, China - October 31, 2019, thyssenkrupp Elevators (Shanghai) Co. Ltd., Shanghai, China - October 31, 2019, thyssenkrupp Access China Ltd., Shanghai, China - November 13, 2019, Hytrac Lifts Ltd., Coalville, Great Britain - November 13, 2019, SDV Escalators Ltd. (UK), Skipton, North Yorkshire, Great Britain - November 13, 2019, thyssenkrupp Access Ltd., Stockton-on-Tees, Great Britain - November 14, 2019, Grupo thyssenkrupp S.L., Madrid, Spain; this company was renamed to thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding Ibérica S.L.U., Madrid, Spain on December 5, 2019 - November 14, 2019, thyssenkrupp Elevator Eastern Europe GmbH, Vienna, Austria - November 15, 2019, thyssenkrupp Canada Inc., Calgary/Alberta, Canada; this company was renamed to thyssenkrupp Elevator Canada Holding Inc., Calgary/Alberta, Canada on December 16, 2019 - November 15, 2019, Lift & Engineering Services Ltd., West Midlands, Great Britain - November 15, 2019, thyssenkrupp Aufzüge Ltd., Nottingham, Great Britain - November 19, 2019, thyssenkrupp Elevadores, S.A., Guaiba, Brazil - November 26, 2019, thyssenkrupp Elevator Italia S.p.A., Milan, Italy - December 03, 2019 thyssenkrupp Elevator USA Holding, Inc., Chicago, Illinois, USA - December 06, 2019, thyssenkrupp Elevator International Holding B.V., Roermond, Netherlands - December 31, 2019 thyssenkrupp Elevator Innovation and Operations AG, Düsseldorf, Germany The companies and operations included in the scope of combination are listed under reference Note 03 “Combined companies and equity interests”. Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Notes to the Combined Financial Statements (Continued) 32 Subsequent events (Continued) Other relevant events
Subsubsection Text: - In connection with the elevator cartel, potentially injured parties have asserted claims for damages against thyssenkrupp AG and companies of the thyssenkrupp Group in and out of court. Since September 30, 2019 further claims have been quantified in the ongoing course of the legal proceedings, which has not led to a change in the risk assessment and recorded provisions. A majority of the proceedings have now been dealt with through settlement, withdrawal or dismissal of the claims. Legal cases are still pending in Austria, Belgium and the Netherlands. They are at different stages of proceedings. thyssenkrupp has recognized provisions for the portion of the pending claims which thyssenkrupp believes will probably result in cash outflows. - The Company received €820 million from thyssenkrupp Nederland Holding B.V. as capital contribution on December 18, 2019. - As of January 16, 2020, the thyssenkrupp Elevator Holding GmbH changed its legal form into a German stock corporation and has been renamed to thyssenkrupp Elevator AG. The control and profit or loss transfer agreements (Beherrschungs- und Gewinnabführungsverträge) between the thyssenkrupp ET Group and thyssenkrupp AG as well as other thyssenkrupp Group companies have been terminated on December 31, 2019. - As of February 11, 2020, thyssenkrupp Industrials Finance Germany GmbH, Essen, Germany has been transferred to the thyssenkrupp ET Group and as of February 18, 2020 has been merged into the Company. - In 2011 the state of Delaware initiated an audit of certain entities within the scope of combination to determine their compliance with the Delaware Escheats laws, also known as abandoned and unclaimed property laws. A provision in connection with this matter was recognized for certain legal entities within the scope of combination. As a result of the current negotiations with the state of Delaware the related provision was reduced by a double digit € million amount after balance sheet date. This revaluation of the provision displays a non-adjusting event after the reporting period presented. - Since January 2020, there is a progressive global spread of the COVID-19 pandemic resulting in various actions – including lockdowns – that have been taken by governments all over the world in order to contain and to control the virus. COVID-19 impacted the markets and facilities in multiple ways, depending on the local exposure to the virus and the measures taken by local governments: The elevator and escalator business (segments Europe/Africa, Americas and Asia/Pacific) was affected to varying degrees. Nevertheless, the effect of the COVID-19 was felt in all regions, leading to complete lockdowns in some regions and milder restrictions in others. Although production came to a temporary standstill in some countries, most of the production facilities are currently operating and in the process of recovering. In most countries production capacities in our core factories have almost recovered to pre-pandemic levels. The Access Solutions business (segment Access Solutions) was affected in both business lines, Home Solutions and Airport Solutions. Activities for Home Solutions have been operated at a lower level with partial temporary shut downs of production facilities but are recovering constantly. The partial or complete shutdown of most airports has led to a decrease of New Installation and Service operations due to postponements and suspensions of some projects. The COVID-19 pandemic is considered as a triggering event for an impairment test of goodwill per March 31, 2020. Therefore, the operational planning of Elevator Technology was tested for validity against the background of the COVID-19 pandemic and, in effect, the recoverability of goodwill of the Elevator Technology Business was not classified as critical. Furthermore, other intangible assets and property, plant and equipment were also tested for impairment per March 31, 2020 which did not result in any impairment losses for the Elevator Technology Business. Based on the uncertain progress of the COVID-19 pandemic, it cannot yet reasonably be predicted to what extent the pandemic will affect the future financial position and results of operations of the Elevator Technology Business. In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic the accumulated ADJ EBIT of the Elevator Technology Business is currently slightly below the budgeted expectations. F-125 -----

Section Title: WHERE YOU CAN FIND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Notes to the Combined Financial Statements (Continued) 32 Subsequent events (Continued)
Subsubsection Text: - Based on the Executive Board’s decision as of February 27, 2020 to sell the entire Elevator Technology Business the new license agreement regarding the thyssenkrupp brand, entered into on September 30, 2019, was amended in March 2020 via an addendum agreement, since the governance model in the new license agreement was only suitable with an IPO. In substance, the terms and conditions of the addendum agreement lead to a limitation of the initially agreed indefinite useful life. The terms of the addendum agreement become effective subject to the condition precedent of all closing conditions of the transaction being fulfilled and will result in the repayment of the initially agreed fully paid up one-time fee in the amount of €1,080 million reduced by a fixed amount of €99 million for the use of the brand starting October 1, 2019 until closing. In addition a fixed amount of €74 million for the use of the brand for the period of no longer than 18 months after closing was agreed. Both, the amount receivable and the amount payable, are due immediately prior to closing. With the signing of the addendum agreement the intangible asset for the right of use of the thyssenkrupp brand will be classified as held for sale in accordance with IFRS 5. - On February 27, 2020, the Executive Board’s decision to sell its entire Elevator Technology Business to a consortium of Advent, Cinven and the RAG foundation was approved by the Supervisory Board of thyssenkrupp AG. The purchase price (assuming closing of the transaction at June 30, 2020) is €17.2 billion. The purchase agreement has been signed in February 2020. The closing of the transaction is subject to merger control approvals, although thyssenkrupp continues to expect no concerns from the responsible authorities. Even under the circumstances of the COVID-19 pandemic, the closing of the transaction is expected by the end of the current fiscal year. Thyssenkrupp AG will reinvest part of the purchase price (€1.25 billion) in a stake in the Elevator Technology Business. - During the 1st half ended March 31, 2020, the Elevator Technology Business reported restructuring costs amounting to €14 million in the business units Europe/Africa and Americas. Essen, May 29, 2020 thyssenkrupp Elevator AG The Executive Board Peter Walker Ercan Keles Dr. Detlef Hunsdiek F-126 -----
